webTitle: A human reminder to the monster

fields.headline: A human reminder to the monster
fields.standfirst: Leader: Death of a superstar
fields.trailText: The memory of Sir Stanley Matthews will hopefully serve to put the lives of those who make up the modern game into context.
fields.body:
Archivists and librarians across the country will be frantically collating every blurred picture and fuzzy newsreel to preserve the memory of Sir Stanley Matthews.

Let's hope so, to ensure that those young men who represented England the other night can have a permanent method of putting their own footballing lives into context.

Matthews lived in an austere black-and-white world when television was a metropolitan plaything of the wealthy. He performed on a stage without probing cameras, flash guns and microphones and when freedom of expression on the field of play was encouraged. He was a product of Pathe and prudence; how would he have coped with Sky and stress?

And how would he have managed carrying the expectations of shareholders, TV rights-holders and sponsors on his shoulders, dealing with an environment where winning is more important than wing play and also trying to second-guess a schizophrenic media?

There are no excuses for the petulance of the Beckhams and the stupidity of the Gazzas, but we expect young men with more money than sense to be all things to all men: demi-gods who must win the World Cup and deliver a good return on City investment. All that Matthews was asked to do was dribble the ball and supply a telling cross.

Some of Britain's most powerful businessmen are on tenterhooks awaiting the Premier League's tender document for the new TV deal in three or four weeks. Despite the editorials that the modern game is frantic and lacking in skill compared with Matthews' day, Sky, BBC, NTL, ONdigital, ITV and even British Telecom are in a sweat over how the deal from the end of next season will be sliced. Estimates for the entire cake range from £1bn to £2bn.

The Premier League, which received about £730m over five years last time, wants a deal in place by early autumn and there are strong hints that because of European Commission pressure the new arrangement will see an unbundling of rights.

It could mean Sky losing exclusivity, and BBC's coveted highlights package on Saturday evenings may be challenged. It could mean about a dozen different ways of watching Premiership football and we might even see BT outbidding the lot and acting as a broker. The squabbling and the infighting promises to be intense and very unpleasant.

We don't really know who runs football, the Premier League or the Football Association, Martin Edwards or Rupert Murdoch, and we're unsure if any of them is strong enough to control the monster.

The bigger the TV deal, the greater, surely, the pressure on players. And it also follows that football will come under even more microscopic scrutiny.

The more cameras and microphones crammed into a stadium, the more opportunity for a few drunks to made idiots of themselves, such as those who tried to ruin Sir Stan's minute's silence the other night.The time has come for us to adopt a more suitable way of paying our respect. But if a period of silent remembrance is now inappropriate, why not adopt the Italian way of spontaneous and prolonged applause? Or a suitable hymn?

There will be a minute's silence before all tomorrow's football matches. My guess is that those with TV cameras present will degenerate into a toe-curling embarrassment.

Sir Stanley Matthews led a full and fruitful life. He enriched our lives beyond the pitch. I hope those newsreels are safely stored so that when the game becomes larger than life itself we can put it all into perspective again with glimpses of his darting runs and his gentle words.

webTitle: Pakistan set off on perilous pursuit of Boycott

fields.headline: Pakistan set off on perilous pursuit of Boycott
fields.trailText: Pakistan, wilfully toying with the most combustible combination in world cricket, have approached Geoffrey Boycott to be their new coach.
fields.body:
Pakistan, wilfully toying with the most combustible combination in world cricket, have approached Geoffrey Boycott to be their new coach. If it ever comes to pass, the mixture will be so explosive that the United Nations will have to go into emergency session.

There are many good reasons why English cricket's greatest controversialist will not throw in his lot with the most querulous Test team in the world. Not least because they left him a message and asked him to ring them back.

But Boycott, taking a few days off in South Africa after his England commentary duties for TalkSport, is not dismissing the approach out of hand. "In Zimbabwe I got a message to ring certain numbers," he confirmed yesterday. "I haven't spoken to anyone. I'm waiting to see what happens."

Boycott will savour being in demand. He was allowed only a brief, and disputatious, hold on the England captaincy in the 70s and his coaching duties have been limited to privately arranged tutorials with the likes of Graham Gooch and Michael Atherton. The fact that England are due to tour Pakistan next winter, for the first time in 13 years, will not escape such a meticulous mind.

Boycott's survival qualities, for which he was renowned as an opening batsman, have become equally apparent in real life. Only 15 months after the Sun dubbed him "Boycott the Brute" and sacked him as a columnist after he was found guilty of assaulting a former lover, other areas of News International have assisted his rehabilitation.

TalkSport has encouraged his provocative commentary style and he is poised to make a return on Sky Television this summer. That may depend on the outcome of his appeal against the assault conviction in a French court in early May.

Pakistan would at least remind Boycott of his bleakest days with Yorkshire. They were beaten 3-0 in the Test series in Australia, lost the final of the tri-nation tournament in the same country, and an experimental young side has just been routed 3-0 in a home one-day series by Sri Lanka.

That has led the Pakistan board, in the guise of their operations manager Yawar Saeed, to seek out a foreign coach before the Sharjah Cup next month. "We have decided to talk to Geoffrey Boycott in the next few days," he said. Barry Richards, the former South Africa batsman, is another target.

fields.headline: Solano aggravated and fined
fields.trailText: Nolberto Solano returned to training at Newcastle United yesterday to discover that the club had fined him the maximum two weeks' wages.
fields.body:
Nolberto Solano returned to training at Newcastle United yesterday to discover that the club had fined him the maximum two weeks' wages.

The Peruvian, who was allowed to link up with his national squad for the Gold Cup earlier this month but with express instructions not to play, appeared for 86 minutes against Haiti and aggravated a thigh injury. "We have disciplined him," said Bobby Robson, Newcastle's manager. "He will not be fit for Saturday's game."

London's recalcitrants seem to have got lucky, however, though Nigeria's manager Joe Bonfrere described Chelsea's Celestine Babayaro and Arsenal's Nwankwo Kanu as "unprofessional" for returning from African Nations Cup duty 10 days late.

"What they did was not good for Nigeria," Bonfrere added. "They should be punished. The clubs may now have reason not to release them anytime we seek their release."

Colin Hendry's proposed move from Rangers to Coventry was put on hold until today after the Highfield Road club called off a press conference due to "travel problems".

The 34-year-old Scotland defender, a £4m arrival from Blackburn last season, was part of the Ibrox side who won the treble but after a series of injuries fell out of favour with the manager Dick Advocaat.

Dan Petrescu, 32, has signed a two-year extension to his Chelsea contract. "There was interest from other clubs but I told them I wasn't interested as I wanted to finish my career at Stamford Bridge," said the Romanian wing-back.

Benfica's Jorge Cadete yesterday completed a medical at Bradford, who are hoping to complete his loan signing later today. The Charlton goalkeeper Sasa Ilic has joined West Ham on a month's loan.

webTitle: Call of the ward may leave Elliott out in the cold

fields.headline: Call of the ward may leave Elliott out in the cold
fields.standfirst: Leicester's captain faces dilemma as wife prepares for fourth child
fields.trailText: Daniel Taylor meets Leicester captain Matt Elliott who has had more reasons than most to find himself reduced to a bundle of nerves this week as his wife prepares for the birth of their fourth child.
fields.body:
If the build-up to a big match is a time for frayed nerves and gnawed fingernails, Matt Elliott has had more reasons than most to find himself reduced to a bundle of nerves this week.

On Sunday there is every chance the Leicester City captain will hold aloft his first major trophy. But even if Dave Challinor's long throws do not prevent that, the danger is that mother nature will.

Like every good punchline, it is all about the delivery. Elliott's wife Cathy is pregnant with their fourth child and, with impeccable timing, the baby is due the same day that the captain should be leading out Leicester City against Tranmere Rovers in the Worthington Cup final.

It is a dilemma that has left Elliott not knowing whether to laugh or cry. And it is not beyond the realms of possibility that his only involvement at Wembley will be to send a good-luck message before dashing to a maternity ward.

"I don't know what will happen if I get a late call, that's an awkward one. There's a no-man's-land from 8pm on Saturday to 10am on Sunday when I would be in a quandary about what to do," he says. "I've not really spoken to the gaffer but he knows the situation.

"Ideally she would have had it already and at one stage she was talking about being induced but she decided against that, so now it's a case of playing it by ear and seeing what happens.

"I've been sitting here for the last 10 days thinking it could be any time now. You can't be on tenterhooks all the time but the closer it gets to the due date the likelihood increases."

Provided he is not brow-mopping beside a hospital bed, Elliott will be assigned to combat Challinor's world-record throw-ins rather than the emergency attacking role which has brought him unexpected success during Leicester's recent injury problems. Despite the prospect of a cricked neck, the 31-year-old is glad to leave goalscoring duties to Emile Heskey and Tony Cottee.

"There are a lot of centre-forwards who go into defence and say it's a piece of cake, but you don't hear too many people saying it the other way around," he says. "It's a totally different game, all the stuff about bending your runs and all that bollocks, it totally loses me. I just try to make a nuisance of myself.

"But it's better for the side if I'm in defence. If I'm up front it just shows we have problems in the squad."

Although he is too diplomatic to say as much, victory would also be one in the eye for the detractors whose sneering derision would have neutrals wondering whether the midlands club had changed their name to Leicester-nil.

Chelsea's chairman Ken Bates and the Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger can count themselves honorary members of the Leicester-baiting union, and Aston Villa's manager John Gregory applied for membership by expressing the sardonic wish that "they would actually cross the halfway line" for the second leg of their semi-final. It was a comment he was later to regret as Elliott headed the solitary goal that saw the Leicester squad booking their fittings for Wembley suits.

"If anything the criticism has just brought us closer together. We never intended to play boring unattractive football but we were down to the bare bones at times so there are no apologies," says Elliott.

"It started when we got a 0-0 draw at Arsenal and, OK, we didn't offer much attacking-wise, but then again [our goalkeeper] Tim Flowers didn't have much to do either.

"Then we were criticised against Villa but I thought we did it perfectly, an away draw and a win at home. If Juventus or AC Milan had done that in Europe it would have been hailed as world-class. We were called boring.

"We had a chat among ourselves and decided that if we beat Villa we would make the most of it. Frankie [Sinclair] had the idea of celebrating by pretending to fall asleep and then Neil Lennon came in with tiptoeing across the halfway line. In the end we combined the two. It may have been a bit childish, but why not?"

webTitle: Sir Stan Flowers before his feet

fields.headline: Sir Stan Flowers before his feet
fields.trailText: A hush fell over much of the Potteries at noon yesterday as Stoke-on-Trent paid tribute to its favourite son, Sir Stanley Matthews, who died on Wednesday.
fields.body:
A hush fell over much of the Potteries at noon yesterday as Stoke-on-Trent paid tribute to its favourite son, Sir Stanley Matthews, who died on Wednesday.

Workers at the Wedgwood and Royal Doulton factories downed tools as a mark of respect and local radio stations joined in the silent tribute. A minute's silence will also be observed before each of this weekend's Premiership and Football League matches and at Sunday's Worthington Cup final.

Hundreds of people gathered and placed flowers at the winger's statue in Hanley, his birthplace. Stoke City are likely to commission another statue in his honour close to the club's new Britannia stadium, where the main entrance road to the ground is already named Stanley Matthews Way. England's football authorities also plan to discuss how best to provide a permanent memorial.

The Stoke club are planning one of the biggest funerals in football history to honour Matthews, who was 85; more than 100,000 people are expected to attend. Football's first knight began and ended his career with Stoke, who yesterday promised to give him a send-off to remember.

Matthews' family have asked the club to handle the arrangements and the chief executive Jez Moxey confirmed: "It is clear this will be the biggest funeral Stoke-on-Trent will ever have seen. I know Sir Stan wouldn't have wanted too much fuss but we cannot ignore the fact that so many people will want to pay their respects and honour him."

Tributes were also paid by the prime minister and the Queen, who yesterday sent a private message of sympathy, Buckingham Palace said.

Tony Blair, who attended Matthews' 80th birthday party, commented: "He was always a model sportsman who played the game as it should be played, never booked or sent off once."

webTitle: Wembley plan may go down the tube

fields.headline: Wembley plan may go down the tube
fields.trailText: Wembley officials have been warned that planning permission for the new stadium may be rejected unless they commit money to improving infrastructure such as roads and railway stations.
fields.body:
Wembley officials have been warned that planning permission for the new stadium may be rejected unless they commit money to improving infrastructure such as roads and railway stations to ease the congestion that has blighted the venue on match days.

Officials from Brent council and representatives of Wembley National Stadium Limited, the Football Association subsidiary set up to oversee redevelopment of the stadium, are locked in disagreement over an issue which could jeopardise England's bid to stage the 2006 World Cup.

Brent council is to meet in five weeks to discuss Wembley's planning application. If it is rejected, another two years might elapse before the matter could be settled through an appeals procedure. Fifa, the world governing body, is to decide on the 2006 venue in five months and is unlikely to be impressed if Wembley is still locked in a planning dispute.

Brent planning officials have completed their technical assessment of Wembley's application and insist that, as things stand, they will advise councillors to reject it.

"Wembley stadium has to realise it has a contribution to make, but we don't want them to pay for everything," said Paul Daisley, the leader of Brent council. "I can't see my officers giving a positive endorsement of the planning application until these issues of infrastructure are addressed. We are determined to make sure that we have a safe and improved environment around Wembley."

The main sticking point concerns the possible redevelopment of two railway stations, an underground station and two roads leading to Wembley.

WNSL officials insist that although they are willing to make a contribution to certain areas that might be affected by construction of the £375m stadium, it is not their role to redevelop stations and roads and that they do not have the money Brent is asking for.

According to some estimates, the local authority is demanding about £30m towards redevelopment of infrastructure, with the total cost estimated at up to £150m.

A WNSL spokesman said: "It is not our job to redevelop stations and prettify Brent. We are here to build a football stadium. Our lottery grant has been spent and everything else is debt-financed. We would not get any more revenue from more attractive rail and underground stations."

Organisations responsible for the stations insist they will not redevelop them unless WNSL makes a significant contribution, because the stations are at their busiest when Wembley stadium is in use.

Wembley stadium is serviced by Wembley Stadium, Wembley Park and Wembley Central stations. All are shabby, poorly equipped and unable to deal with large crowds. An estimated 45,000 fans use Wembley Park for matches.

The WNSL spokesman said: "We know we are building a jewel in a rubbish heap but it is up to the council and London Underground to tackle that problem."

Getting away from the stadium has also been a frustrating experience, with many enduring long waits before being allowed on to platforms. fields.bodyText: Wembley officials have been warned that planning permission for the new stadium may be rejected unless they commit money to improving infrastructure such as roads and railway stations to ease the congestion that has blighted the venue on match days. Officials from Brent council and representatives of Wembley National Stadium Limited, the Football Association subsidiary set up to oversee redevelopment of the stadium, are locked in disagreement over an issue which could jeopardise England's bid to stage the 2006 World Cup. Brent council is to meet in five weeks to discuss Wembley's planning application. If it is rejected, another two years might elapse before the matter could be settled through an appeals procedure. Fifa, the world governing body, is to decide on the 2006 venue in five months and is unlikely to be impressed if Wembley is still locked in a planning dispute. Brent planning officials have completed their technical assessment of Wembley's application and insist that, as things stand, they will advise councillors to reject it. "Wembley stadium has to realise it has a contribution to make, but we don't want them to pay for everything," said Paul Daisley, the leader of Brent council. "I can't see my officers giving a positive endorsement of the planning application until these issues of infrastructure are addressed. We are determined to make sure that we have a safe and improved environment around Wembley." The main sticking point concerns the possible redevelopment of two railway stations, an underground station and two roads leading to Wembley. WNSL officials insist that although they are willing to make a contribution to certain areas that might be affected by construction of the £375m stadium, it is not their role to redevelop stations and roads and that they do not have the money Brent is asking for. According to some estimates, the local authority is demanding about £30m towards redevelopment of infrastructure, with the total cost estimated at up to £150m. A WNSL spokesman said: "It is not our job to redevelop stations and prettify Brent. We are here to build a football stadium. Our lottery grant has been spent and everything else is debt-financed. We would not get any more revenue from more attractive rail and underground stations." Organisations responsible for the stations insist they will not redevelop them unless WNSL makes a significant contribution, because the stations are at their busiest when Wembley stadium is in use. Wembley stadium is serviced by Wembley Stadium, Wembley Park and Wembley Central stations. All are shabby, poorly equipped and unable to deal with large crowds. An estimated 45,000 fans use Wembley Park for matches. The WNSL spokesman said: "We know we are building a jewel in a rubbish heap but it is up to the council and London Underground to tackle that problem." Getting away from the stadium has also been a frustrating experience, with many enduring long waits before being allowed on to platforms. The new stadium will have an increased capacity of 90,000, fewer parking spaces (3,000 as opposed to 6,000), and fans will be encouraged to use public transport. At the moment, two roads leading to Wembley are closed before matches so that both lanes can be used for football fans arriving for matches.

fields.headline: South African stories
fields.standfirst: In this piece taken from the current print edition of the                                               London Review of Books, appearing online exclusively at                                               Books Unlimited, RW Johnson offers tales from the new South Africa
fields.trailText: RW Johnson's tales of everyday life in interesting times
fields.body:
The reality of rape

The voice on the phone was terrified and tearful. 'I'm in such trouble, such trouble.' It took me quite a while to get Josephine to say what had happened. She is the 18-year-old daughter of my domestic servant here in Johannesburg. Josephine, like her two sisters, is a boarder at a school near Pietersburg, 350 kilometres away. In the school holidays the three girls come and stay with their mother, Doris, who lives in a cottage in my garden - I had waved them off back to school only a few weeks before, Josephine, the eldest, shepherding her smaller sisters.

Josephine had left her school to visit cousins in the area over the weekend and, late on the Sunday, had got a taxi back to the school. The driver had dropped his other two passengers and then driven Josephine to his house in a nearby township where he had overpowered and raped her. He had then locked her in a back room, told her that he would keep her there for his pleasure for a month, and then kill her. After that he had gone off to a shebeen, saying he might bring back some of his friends later that night to 'have some fun' with her too.

Josephine had managed to attract the attention of two small boys in the street and they had helped her escape. She had been back at school for a day but all she could do was cry, she said. I told her I would send her mother to fetch her right away. Doris was almost hysterical when she heard the news but I bundled her into a taxi and told her to hurry.

I rang my friend Brian who runs an epidemiological unit mainly concerned with HIV/Aids. It'll cost you, he said, but if she can get AZT and 3TC in the first 12 hours you can cut the Aids risk by 80 per cent. Brian has twice had to apply such emergency treatment to nurses working in his unit after they pricked themselves with needles used to draw blood from the HIV positive prostitutes who are the central figures in his unit's attempt to control the scourge. I explained that it was already more than 24 hours since Josephine had been raped and that 36 hours would probably have elapsed before she arrived. It might still be worth a try, he said, but the antibodies in her blood would be replicating at a terrifying rate by now.

When Josephine arrived I rushed her to a top specialist - a calm Englishman who'd been out here for 18 years. 'I can't do without the drama, the dynamism of being here,' he explained almost apologetically when I asked what a man of his eminence was doing in a crowded, chaotic hospital. He was a keen Chelsea supporter and in between carrying out the tests on Josephine he and I chatted about the great days of Charlie Cooke, David Webb and Peter Osgood.

He told me it was already too late to try AZT and 3TC on Josephine but he was cautiously hopeful. 'To get Aids there has to be mixing of blood, which means there has to be a break in the skin or an open sore due to some other sexually transmitted disease. Chances are that the taxi-driver is a sexually reckless fellow and has at least one of these STDs, so Josephine's chances of syphilis and gonorrhoea are high but I can deal with that,' he explained. 'The key question is whether he was so rough while he was raping her that he broke her skin. It's because rape is so traumatic that it so often results in Aids transmission. Especially gang rape, of course, which is almost bound to do it.' That Josephine escaped before the collective 'fun' began had, I now realised, been crucial.

After examining Josephine, the specialist told me he could find no break in the skin but he wouldn't have the results of the tests for another six weeks. 'In any case,' he pointed out, 'at least 20 per cent of all black 18-year-old girls are HIV positive already and that figure is rising rapidly towards 30 per cent. She could have been HIV positive before the attack.' I told him I didn't think so: I have lectured Josephine endlessly on the perils of Aids since she was 15, and she is a religious girl. Josephine stayed with us for a week but, despite my efforts, would not talk to the rape counsellor I sent her to.

Jo had told the police about the rape. She had given them the driver's name and address, and there was even a corroborating witness who knew about other rapes he'd carried out. Josephine remained nervous: the man had told her that he'd kill her if the case ever came to the attention of the police. I phoned several times but they never seemed to know anything about it and there was a lot of fruitless hunting around for a case number. The taxi driver was seen walking around as if nothing had happened. Clearly nothing would be done. Jo recovered bit by bit. Then, at last, test results came through: HIV negative, praise the Lord. With many misgivings she returned to school.

A few days later I looked at my phone bill and realised something was wrong. It was enormously high and I didn't recognise some of the numbers at all. I left the print-out in the kitchen and next morning Doris's manner told me everything I needed to know. We all make mistakes, she said with a grin. We learn only from our mistakes. The really big mistake, I said, is that you've been stealing from me. Over half this phone bill is yours and you've been coming into the house specially to make calls, many of them very long distance and for half an hour at a time.

I told you the alarm code of the house and you've been coming in when I was away and on days when you weren't working in the house. You have systematically lied to me and cheated me. At a time when I was doing everything I could, paying for Josephine's schooling, lending you money, spending money on the Aids doctor, the lot. How long has this been going on? It's just this month, she said, crying now. Sometimes I get lonely in the house and want to chat to my friends so I call them.

I go and check. It's actually been going on for many months, the amount creeping up all the time. Doris obviously thought I never checked a bill and for a long time she was right. I call her in furiously. I could sack you for this, I say. I told you when I first employed you, I have to trust someone who works in my house, that's the only rule. You'll never be happy again with me now, she wept, you'd better sack me.

In the end I say: look, the deal is this. I won't sack you and you can stay if you want. But the reason I do this is for your daughters, especially Jo. You should beat me, Doris says. You can beat me all afternoon, I will deserve it. I don't want to beat you, I tell her. It's not about beating, it's about trust. It takes time to rebuild trust. I change the alarm code, keep it secret, make her pay for the last month's calls. It's all very difficult and sullen for a while.

Jo rings again, an incoherent, frantic message on the answering-machine. As so often with phone calls from Africans made from cafés or friends' houses, there were loud background voices, slamming doors and much general clatter, but I half-imagined that I heard the phrase 'raped again'. That couldn't be right. Then Doris comes tearing in, eyes wild, getting ready to scream.

It was right. In South Africa, the rape capital of the world, the odds were in favour of its being right. They reckon that only in 1 in 20 rapes gets reported but even so 131 are reported every day, one every 11 minutes. If you believe the 1-in-20 thing then it's one every 33 seconds. It's quite possible: many African men still believe (and will even tell you) that it is their right to have their way with any woman they want, whenever they want.

So we had to go through the whole ghastly thing over again. Jo came down to Jo'burg, this time so traumatised that she couldn't speak about it to her mother or me for several days. There'd been this man - the husband/boyfriend of a teacher from another school who stayed near where Jo lived. He was a big strong man and he 'was 'painted silver around his waist'. He'd begun to tell Jo he loved her; she was alarmed, and told his wife. In the end the man had come to her and told her she already owed him her life, not just because she'd caused so much trouble between him and his wife, but because he'd had to protect her from his wife's wrath.

Anyway, whatever the bullshit, he'd raped her. We told the police, though without much hope. More than 1,300 policemen have been killed in South Africa since 1994; the court system isn't working; criminal justice is a mess; and rape an epidemic. The officers who called dutifully took notes but you got the feeling that one more rape victim wasn't too big a deal.

This time I phoned the Aids doctor but didn't go myself. Maybe because it all seemed a bit more routine. In any case, Jo and her mum went without me. It turned out that the test would be far quicker this time, thanks to whatever tests were still relevant from the first occasion. Within five days the doctor phoned me: 'Well,' he said. 'I have the test results. Jo is HIV negative.'

I nearly died twice over before he got to the negative. I phoned Doris immediately. She virtually swooned away. I saw Jo, she rushed to me, clung to me with big hugs, told me that I was the only man she knew who wasn't a bastard. I tried to work on that. Look, there are a lot of nice men out there, don't let this thing spoil your life. Only white men are nice, she said. Or some of them. Not all that many, I said.

I was walking on the slopes of Table Mountain that weekend when the call came through on my cell phone: there'd been another attempt to rape Jo. A neighbour phoned. An intruder had unscrewed the handle of the cottage door and let himself in. Doris and her boyfriend Ernest had been asleep in the double bed and Jo had been stretched out on a mat in the passage. First thing she'd known the man was pulling off her pants and trying to lie on top of her. She screamed, Doris woke up and pressed the remote-control button which brings armed men running. They were there within a minute but the man was gone. Jo had no sight of him, just a torchlight in her face.

Back in Jo'burg, I sat Jo down. I've installed all manner of extra security, I pointed out: locks here, bolts there, gates padlocked. And whoever it was never realised that your mother had a remote control for the alarm and could bring armed men running like that. No one's going to try it again. You'll be safe. But are you telling me the truth? Was this the man who raped you in Pietersburg following you down here? No, she said. So did she have a jilted boyfriend somewhere in the background? No.

The point is this, I said. No one's ever tried to break into my house: it has a big notice on it saying Instant Armed Response. But people who do want to break in do so because they want to steal, and because they want to steal they try to break into the main house, not the servants' quarters. But this guy broke in to rape you. The odds against this are millions to one and the odds against it happening just after you've been raped up in Pietersburg are billions to one. So what on earth is going on? I don't know, she said, I only saw the torch in my face. I asked her mother. I don't know, she said, I can't understand it, something's wrong, I agree with you. But she had no more light to shed.

Jo was so scared of being on her own now that she went everywhere with her mother. She couldn't bear to be in the cottage on her own, a fact I cursed, for I had wanted, above all, for her to feel that this one place, at least, was safe for her. I decided she'd better come and work in my office. It was a perfect solution. Connie, my assistant, made a big fuss of her, introduced her to computers, showed her how to e-mail and fax, how to pull things off the Internet. Jo, a country girl with poor English who'd never seen a modern office, was thrilled, couldn't wait each day to go to work - and gradually she became useful, a real help.

She didn't want to go back to school - she was scared the rapists would kill her. It was impossible to have much confidence in the police. In the end she and her mother came up with a solution: they wanted to get the help of Mapogo a Mathamaga ('the colours of the leopard'), the giant vigilante organisation which centres on Pietersburg.

Founded by a black businessman, John Magolego, Mapogo now has 35,000 paid up members, 10,000 of them white - it's a booming business. It moves into an area, rounds up criminal suspects, beats the hell out of them, drags them behind vans on rocky roads or dangles them over crocodile-infested rivers and gets the 'truth' out of them. It doesn't bother with courts, evidence or the police and it claims remarkable success. Once it moves into an area the crime rate falls to zero. Jo and her mum had heard all about Mapogo. So now they wanted me to phone John Magolego.

I don't approve of vigilantes, I said. I know the police and the courts are hopeless but once you start with vigilantes where does it stop? Some of the people they beat up - and kill - are quite innocent. What if the taxi driver who raped Jo is himself a Mapogo member? Doris just looked straight through this. Jo must be safe, she said. Here is the number, please phone him. The assumption being that any black man will always take more notice if it's a white man who calls.

John Magolego, it turned out, was a very calm, pleasant-sounding and well-spoken man. But this is terrible, he said. Raped twice? Of course we will deal with this. She has the names? Good. She must contact my man in Pietersburg and join Mapogo. He gave me the numbers and explained that the Mapogo office was next to a bakery in a township and one of the bakery staff had to run and summon the Mapogo officer to the phone. The first few times he wasn't there so I rang Magolego again. 'That is not very good,' he said carefully. 'But we have been having a big rally - many thousands came to celebrate our anniversary. I saw our officer there. He must have stayed over. By tomorrow he will be back and I can promise he will deal with your problem.'

Which was just what happened. It will cost you money, the man said in English, and then broke into Afrikaans. After a while I handed the phone over to Doris. She spoke for a while in Sepedi and then put the phone down. You must borrow me 730 rands (£73) she said: 165 rands to join, 50 rands monthly subscription, 15 rands for the Mapogo sticker with the two leopard heads and a 500-rand fine for not having joined Mapogo before. I'm not paying for any of that, I said, you'll have to borrow from your friends.

My daughter must be safe, she said. Good God, I want her to be safe too, I said, but I don't approve of vigilantes. Magolego is a big man, she said, he can make her safe. Well don't ask me for money, I said. This could well be tantamount to taking out a contract on these two guys. Do you want them to live? Doris asked. Not especially, I said. But you're a Christian, Doris, you go to church every morning. God does not want them to live, she said.

Doris disappeared for a while over the weekend. On Monday she said, you must borrow me five hundred rands: I borrow the money for Mapogo from my friends in Alexandra but now I must pay them back. She knew I knew that her friends there lived in shacks. The whole thing was simple and circular, a nonsense to cater for white foolishness. She was full of protestations of gratitude as I counted the money out but the truth was that I had been pulled more and more into her world and she was calling the shots.

We're waiting to hear from Jo but I realise that I am quite fatalistic about whatever Mapogo does. I don't really feel differently from Doris about those two guys. If they are removed from the scene many more girls will be safe, and if they just get the shit beaten out of them they're lucky. More troubling is the possibility that there's a whole lot going on here that I'm not being told - the usual white dilemma, the fear of being made a fool of.

The talk I'd given Jo about trust and telling the truth was pretty much the same one I'd given Doris. And Doris had deceived me about the phone all the time I was helping her. For all I knew Jo was still holding out on me about the intruder. Probably Doris's story about borrowing R730 in Alexandra was nonsense too; probably what I'd given her had been paid directly to Mapogo. There was no way of knowing for sure.

Technology

In my office in Johannesburg we always seem to have a lot of computer trouble. To sort it out I had inherited from my predecessor a computer troubleshooter called Villiers Strydom, a tall, slim, mustachioed Afrikaner. Villiers, who appeared to live by mobile phone (it was never switched off and you never got him any other way), was famous with the secretaries for promising to come to fix the latest glitch and not quite managing to get there.

The resulting aggravation would produce earnest discussions as to whether we shouldn't dispense with his services and find someone else. But we never did. Villiers did seem very good at his work; and he always arrived in the end, even if not when promised, and he was cheap. He was nice, too: soft, gentle, good-humoured and nothing like the stereotypical bull-of-the-pampas Afrikaner rugger bugger that his name led you to expect. In fact, Villiers greatly disliked that sort of person: he was a passionate citizen of the new South Africa - not just non-racist but strongly anti-racist, anti-sexist and the rest of it.

When he talked of the things he so passionately disliked in traditional Afrikanerdom - the straitlacedness, the crude bully-boy racism, the Calvinist parochialism - he could get quite upset, and at those times he seemed quite frail: tears would well in his eyes, his voice would tremble and you would notice again how slender his tall, thirty-something frame was.

What turned Villiers on was hi-tech gizmos, the new, the laid-back. Like not a few of his peers, he was a natural Californian born of Boers. He was also, we soon realised, gay. After a while he introduced a young friend, Arthur, who came around with him and learnt his trade, devotedly watching Villiers as he fixed our errant Windows, e-mail and printers.

One day Villiers let us down even more badly than usual and I was getting ready to fire him when I ran into my predecessor. You can't do that, he said. Villiers really likes all the people in your office. He says they're the nicest people he's ever worked with, he's always going on about it, it would break his heart. Besides, he's HIV positive. He's being very brave about it, going to a gym, keeping super-fit. He told me all that one day when he was working after hours. He was tired and because of that got rather tearful and it sort of came out. He says he knows the normal HIV-Aids cycle is only six years long but he's determined to extend his life by achieving and maintaining perfect health. But you can't let him know you know.

Not long after that we had another breakdown. 'My fucking machine has got cyber-Aids,' Helen, one of our secretaries, said in exasperation. After that I had to take her into the secret, too, so that she didn't say something similar in front of Villiers. Soon everyone in the office knew, but no one said a word. All it meant was that Villiers got a lot more sympathetic mothering, which seemed to bemuse and delight him.

Another day he came in to install some new programs, looking dreadful. His brother had been shot dead over the weekend, he said, and the whole family was in uproar, his mother in hysterics and everyone leaning on him for support as the remaining man in the family. He wept openly over the Windows 98 and Word 97 and seemed about to snap.

Next week it was even worse. The bloody police, he said, have got this crazy idea that my sister-in-law shot him. It was bad enough for her already, having her husband mown down, but now they're accusing her, pushing her around, forcing her to make statements. Now she, too, is in hysterics.

Things went on in this way for a week or so until Villiers looked as if he was going to burst. He fled to lie on a beach with Arthur somewhere up the north coast of KwaZulu-Natal. I spoke to him there on his mobile phone. He was chortling with the sheer pleasure of getting away. When he was back I asked him about his sister-in-law. Oh, that's sort of settled down, he said. The police have left her alone so she's calmer now. We're all calmer now. Anyway, I reckon maybe she did shoot him. My brother was a difficult guy, she might have had her reasons. He winked.

Not long after that, Villiers was upgrading my colleague Susan's machine when she saw his T-shirt was bulging at the back. What's that, she asked. Villiers pulled out a giant gun, the sort of Magnum you see in the movies. He was really serious about it all, taking shooting classes, learning how to be fast on the draw, the lot. In Dirty Harry, Villiers said, Clint Eastwood says this is the most powerful handgun in the world so I reckon, OK, they got my brother but they're sure as hell not getting me.

But we thought your sister-in-law did it, we said. Maybe she did, he said. Quite possibly. But anyway they're not getting me. I always keep it loaded. No use having it otherwise, but don't worry, there's a safety catch. This seemed fair enough and we all got used to Villiers moving about the office all rodded up.

Then we got a note saying that Villiers's one-man show was now to be called Monet Systems. I just like the name, sort of French, was all he would say. A little while later he announced that he was changing his name to Lanchester Monet. English or French? we asked. Sort of both, he said. I just don't like being an Afrikaner so I've decided to stop being one. After a while we got his new business card: Lanchester Jean-Paul Monet. You're getting more French, we said, but you can't speak French. I'm working on it, he said: the key lifestyle decision is the name change. You have to call me 'Lanchester' now.

What with work, Arthur, the gym, the shooting classes and French lessons Lanchester was now frantically busy. We saw him less and less. Our computers were held together with rubber bands, literally. The fax machine would only work if you had it jammed against the wall in a certain position and the printers wouldn't work unless you unplugged and replugged them at each go. Finally, we called in someone else. Every now and again we get an e-mail from Villiers/Lanchester, but we just say the computers are working OK.

fields.bodyText: The reality of rape The voice on the phone was terrified and tearful. 'I'm in such trouble, such trouble.' It took me quite a while to get Josephine to say what had happened. She is the 18-year-old daughter of my domestic servant here in Johannesburg. Josephine, like her two sisters, is a boarder at a school near Pietersburg, 350 kilometres away. In the school holidays the three girls come and stay with their mother, Doris, who lives in a cottage in my garden - I had waved them off back to school only a few weeks before, Josephine, the eldest, shepherding her smaller sisters. Josephine had left her school to visit cousins in the area over the weekend and, late on the Sunday, had got a taxi back to the school. The driver had dropped his other two passengers and then driven Josephine to his house in a nearby township where he had overpowered and raped her. He had then locked her in a back room, told her that he would keep her there for his pleasure for a month, and then kill her. After that he had gone off to a shebeen, saying he might bring back some of his friends later that night to 'have some fun' with her too. Josephine had managed to attract the attention of two small boys in the street and they had helped her escape. She had been back at school for a day but all she could do was cry, she said. I told her I would send her mother to fetch her right away. Doris was almost hysterical when she heard the news but I bundled her into a taxi and told her to hurry. I rang my friend Brian who runs an epidemiological unit mainly concerned with HIV/Aids. It'll cost you, he said, but if she can get AZT and 3TC in the first 12 hours you can cut the Aids risk by 80 per cent. Brian has twice had to apply such emergency treatment to nurses working in his unit after they pricked themselves with needles used to draw blood from the HIV positive prostitutes who are the central figures in his unit's attempt to control the scourge. I explained that it was already more than 24 hours since Josephine had been raped and that 36 hours would probably have elapsed before she arrived. It might still be worth a try, he said, but the antibodies in her blood would be replicating at a terrifying rate by now. When Josephine arrived I rushed her to a top specialist - a calm Englishman who'd been out here for 18 years. 'I can't do without the drama, the dynamism of being here,' he explained almost apologetically when I asked what a man of his eminence was doing in a crowded, chaotic hospital. He was a keen Chelsea supporter and in between carrying out the tests on Josephine he and I chatted about the great days of Charlie Cooke, David Webb and Peter Osgood. He told me it was already too late to try AZT and 3TC on Josephine but he was cautiously hopeful. 'To get Aids there has to be mixing of blood, which means there has to be a break in the skin or an open sore due to some other sexually transmitted disease. Chances are that the taxi-driver is a sexually reckless fellow and has at least one of these STDs, so Josephine's chances of syphilis and gonorrhoea are high but I can deal with that,' he explained. 'The key question is whether he was so rough while he was raping her that he broke her skin. It's because rape is so traumatic that it so often results in Aids transmission. Especially gang rape, of course, which is almost bound to do it.' That Josephine escaped before the collective 'fun' began had, I now realised, been crucial. After examining Josephine, the specialist told me he could find no break in the skin but he wouldn't have the results of the tests for another six weeks. 'In any case,' he pointed out, 'at least 20 per cent of all black 18-year-old girls are HIV positive already and that figure is rising rapidly towards 30 per cent. She could have been HIV positive before the attack.' I told him I didn't think so: I have lectured Josephine endlessly on the perils of Aids since she was 15, and she is a religious girl. Josephine stayed with us for a week but, despite my efforts, would not talk to the rape counsellor I sent her to. Jo had told the police about the rape. She had given them the driver's name and address, and there was even a corroborating witness who knew about other rapes he'd carried out. Josephine remained nervous: the man had told her that he'd kill her if the case ever came to the attention of the police. I phoned several times but they never seemed to know anything about it and there was a lot of fruitless hunting around for a case number. The taxi driver was seen walking around as if nothing had happened. Clearly nothing would be done. Jo recovered bit by bit. Then, at last, test results came through: HIV negative, praise the Lord. With many misgivings she returned to school. A few days later I looked at my phone bill and realised something was wrong. It was enormously high and I didn't recognise some of the numbers at all. I left the print-out in the kitchen and next morning Doris's manner told me everything I needed to know. We all make mistakes, she said with a grin. We learn only from our mistakes. The really big mistake, I said, is that you've been stealing from me. Over half this phone bill is yours and you've been coming into the house specially to make calls, many of them very long distance and for half an hour at a time. I told you the alarm code of the house and you've been coming in when I was away and on days when you weren't working in the house. You have systematically lied to me and cheated me. At a time when I was doing everything I could, paying for Josephine's schooling, lending you money, spending money on the Aids doctor, the lot. How long has this been going on? It's just this month, she said, crying now. Sometimes I get lonely in the house and want to chat to my friends so I call them. I go and check. It's actually been going on for many months, the amount creeping up all the time. Doris obviously thought I never checked a bill and for a long time she was right. I call her in furiously. I could sack you for this, I say. I told you when I first employed you, I have to trust someone who works in my house, that's the only rule. You'll never be happy again with me now, she wept, you'd better sack me. In the end I say: look, the deal is this. I won't sack you and you can stay if you want. But the reason I do this is for your daughters, especially Jo. You should beat me, Doris says. You can beat me all afternoon, I will deserve it. I don't want to beat you, I tell her. It's not about beating, it's about trust. It takes time to rebuild trust. I change the alarm code, keep it secret, make her pay for the last month's calls. It's all very difficult and sullen for a while. Jo rings again, an incoherent, frantic message on the answering-machine. As so often with phone calls from Africans made from cafés or friends' houses, there were loud background voices, slamming doors and much general clatter, but I half-imagined that I heard the phrase 'raped again'. That couldn't be right. Then Doris comes tearing in, eyes wild, getting ready to scream. It was right. In South Africa, the rape capital of the world, the odds were in favour of its being right. They reckon that only in 1 in 20 rapes gets reported but even so 131 are reported every day, one every 11 minutes. If you believe the 1-in-20 thing then it's one every 33 seconds. It's quite possible: many African men still believe (and will even tell you) that it is their right to have their way with any woman they want, whenever they want. So we had to go through the whole ghastly thing over again. Jo came down to Jo'burg, this time so traumatised that she couldn't speak about it to her mother or me for several days. There'd been this man - the husband/boyfriend of a teacher from another school who stayed near where Jo lived. He was a big strong man and he 'was 'painted silver around his waist'. He'd begun to tell Jo he loved her; she was alarmed, and told his wife. In the end the man had come to her and told her she already owed him her life, not just because she'd caused so much trouble between him and his wife, but because he'd had to protect her from his wife's wrath. Anyway, whatever the bullshit, he'd raped her. We told the police, though without much hope. More than 1,300 policemen have been killed in South Africa since 1994; the court system isn't working; criminal justice is a mess; and rape an epidemic. The officers who called dutifully took notes but you got the feeling that one more rape victim wasn't too big a deal. This time I phoned the Aids doctor but didn't go myself. Maybe because it all seemed a bit more routine. In any case, Jo and her mum went without me. It turned out that the test would be far quicker this time, thanks to whatever tests were still relevant from the first occasion. Within five days the doctor phoned me: 'Well,' he said. 'I have the test results. Jo is HIV negative.' I nearly died twice over before he got to the negative. I phoned Doris immediately. She virtually swooned away. I saw Jo, she rushed to me, clung to me with big hugs, told me that I was the only man she knew who wasn't a bastard. I tried to work on that. Look, there are a lot of nice men out there, don't let this thing spoil your life. Only white men are nice, she said. Or some of them. Not all that many, I said. I was walking on the slopes of Table Mountain that weekend when the call came through on my cell phone: there'd been another attempt to rape Jo. A neighbour phoned. An intruder had unscrewed the handle of the cottage door and let himself in. Doris and her boyfriend Ernest had been asleep in the double bed and Jo had been stretched out on a mat in the passage. First thing she'd known the man was pulling off her pants and trying to lie on top of her. She screamed, Doris woke up and pressed the remote-control button which brings armed men running. They were there within a minute but the man was gone. Jo had no sight of him, just a torchlight in her face. Back in Jo'burg, I sat Jo down. I've installed all manner of extra security, I pointed out: locks here, bolts there, gates padlocked. And whoever it was never realised that your mother had a remote control for the alarm and could bring armed men running like that. No one's going to try it again. You'll be safe. But are you telling me the truth? Was this the man who raped you in Pietersburg following you down here? No, she said. So did she have a jilted boyfriend somewhere in the background? No. The point is this, I said. No one's ever tried to break into my house: it has a big notice on it saying Instant Armed Response. But people who do want to break in do so because they want to steal, and because they want to steal they try to break into the main house, not the servants' quarters. But this guy broke in to rape you. The odds against this are millions to one and the odds against it happening just after you've been raped up in Pietersburg are billions to one. So what on earth is going on? I don't know, she said, I only saw the torch in my face. I asked her mother. I don't know, she said, I can't understand it, something's wrong, I agree with you. But she had no more light to shed. Jo was so scared of being on her own now that she went everywhere with her mother. She couldn't bear to be in the cottage on her own, a fact I cursed, for I had wanted, above all, for her to feel that this one place, at least, was safe for her. I decided she'd better come and work in my office. It was a perfect solution. Connie, my assistant, made a big fuss of her, introduced her to computers, showed her how to e-mail and fax, how to pull things off the Internet. Jo, a country girl with poor English who'd never seen a modern office, was thrilled, couldn't wait each day to go to work - and gradually she became useful, a real help. She didn't want to go back to school - she was scared the rapists would kill her. It was impossible to have much confidence in the police. In the end she and her mother came up with a solution: they wanted to get the help of Mapogo a Mathamaga ('the colours of the leopard'), the giant vigilante organisation which centres on Pietersburg. Founded by a black businessman, John Magolego, Mapogo now has 35,000 paid up members, 10,000 of them white - it's a booming business. It moves into an area, rounds up criminal suspects, beats the hell out of them, drags them behind vans on rocky roads or dangles them over crocodile-infested rivers and gets the 'truth' out of them. It doesn't bother with courts, evidence or the police and it claims remarkable success. Once it moves into an area the crime rate falls to zero. Jo and her mum had heard all about Mapogo. So now they wanted me to phone John Magolego. I don't approve of vigilantes, I said. I know the police and the courts are hopeless but once you start with vigilantes where does it stop? Some of the people they beat up - and kill - are quite innocent. What if the taxi driver who raped Jo is himself a Mapogo member? Doris just looked straight through this. Jo must be safe, she said. Here is the number, please phone him. The assumption being that any black man will always take more notice if it's a white man who calls. John Magolego, it turned out, was a very calm, pleasant-sounding and well-spoken man. But this is terrible, he said. Raped twice? Of course we will deal with this. She has the names? Good. She must contact my man in Pietersburg and join Mapogo. He gave me the numbers and explained that the Mapogo office was next to a bakery in a township and one of the bakery staff had to run and summon the Mapogo officer to the phone. The first few times he wasn't there so I rang Magolego again. 'That is not very good,' he said carefully. 'But we have been having a big rally - many thousands came to celebrate our anniversary. I saw our officer there. He must have stayed over. By tomorrow he will be back and I can promise he will deal with your problem.' Which was just what happened. It will cost you money, the man said in English, and then broke into Afrikaans. After a while I handed the phone over to Doris. She spoke for a while in Sepedi and then put the phone down. You must borrow me 730 rands (£73) she said: 165 rands to join, 50 rands monthly subscription, 15 rands for the Mapogo sticker with the two leopard heads and a 500-rand fine for not having joined Mapogo before. I'm not paying for any of that, I said, you'll have to borrow from your friends. My daughter must be safe, she said. Good God, I want her to be safe too, I said, but I don't approve of vigilantes. Magolego is a big man, she said, he can make her safe. Well don't ask me for money, I said. This could well be tantamount to taking out a contract on these two guys. Do you want them to live? Doris asked. Not especially, I said. But you're a Christian, Doris, you go to church every morning. God does not want them to live, she said. Doris disappeared for a while over the weekend. On Monday she said, you must borrow me five hundred rands: I borrow the money for Mapogo from my friends in Alexandra but now I must pay them back. She knew I knew that her friends there lived in shacks. The whole thing was simple and circular, a nonsense to cater for white foolishness. She was full of protestations of gratitude as I counted the money out but the truth was that I had been pulled more and more into her world and she was calling the shots. We're waiting to hear from Jo but I realise that I am quite fatalistic about whatever Mapogo does. I don't really feel differently from Doris about those two guys. If they are removed from the scene many more girls will be safe, and if they just get the shit beaten out of them they're lucky. More troubling is the possibility that there's a whole lot going on here that I'm not being told - the usual white dilemma, the fear of being made a fool of. The talk I'd given Jo about trust and telling the truth was pretty much the same one I'd given Doris. And Doris had deceived me about the phone all the time I was helping her. For all I knew Jo was still holding out on me about the intruder. Probably Doris's story about borrowing R730 in Alexandra was nonsense too; probably what I'd given her had been paid directly to Mapogo. There was no way of knowing for sure. Technology In my office in Johannesburg we always seem to have a lot of computer trouble. To sort it out I had inherited from my predecessor a computer troubleshooter called Villiers Strydom, a tall, slim, mustachioed Afrikaner. Villiers, who appeared to live by mobile phone (it was never switched off and you never got him any other way), was famous with the secretaries for promising to come to fix the latest glitch and not quite managing to get there. The resulting aggravation would produce earnest discussions as to whether we shouldn't dispense with his services and find someone else. But we never did. Villiers did seem very good at his work; and he always arrived in the end, even if not when promised, and he was cheap. He was nice, too: soft, gentle, good-humoured and nothing like the stereotypical bull-of-the-pampas Afrikaner rugger bugger that his name led you to expect. In fact, Villiers greatly disliked that sort of person: he was a passionate citizen of the new South Africa - not just non-racist but strongly anti-racist, anti-sexist and the rest of it. When he talked of the things he so passionately disliked in traditional Afrikanerdom - the straitlacedness, the crude bully-boy racism, the Calvinist parochialism - he could get quite upset, and at those times he seemed quite frail: tears would well in his eyes, his voice would tremble and you would notice again how slender his tall, thirty-something frame was. What turned Villiers on was hi-tech gizmos, the new, the laid-back. Like not a few of his peers, he was a natural Californian born of Boers. He was also, we soon realised, gay. After a while he introduced a young friend, Arthur, who came around with him and learnt his trade, devotedly watching Villiers as he fixed our errant Windows, e-mail and printers. One day Villiers let us down even more badly than usual and I was getting ready to fire him when I ran into my predecessor. You can't do that, he said. Villiers really likes all the people in your office. He says they're the nicest people he's ever worked with, he's always going on about it, it would break his heart. Besides, he's HIV positive. He's being very brave about it, going to a gym, keeping super-fit. He told me all that one day when he was working after hours. He was tired and because of that got rather tearful and it sort of came out. He says he knows the normal HIV-Aids cycle is only six years long but he's determined to extend his life by achieving and maintaining perfect health. But you can't let him know you know. Not long after that we had another breakdown. 'My fucking machine has got cyber-Aids,' Helen, one of our secretaries, said in exasperation. After that I had to take her into the secret, too, so that she didn't say something similar in front of Villiers. Soon everyone in the office knew, but no one said a word. All it meant was that Villiers got a lot more sympathetic mothering, which seemed to bemuse and delight him. Another day he came in to install some new programs, looking dreadful. His brother had been shot dead over the weekend, he said, and the whole family was in uproar, his mother in hysterics and everyone leaning on him for support as the remaining man in the family. He wept openly over the Windows 98 and Word 97 and seemed about to snap. Next week it was even worse. The bloody police, he said, have got this crazy idea that my sister-in-law shot him. It was bad enough for her already, having her husband mown down, but now they're accusing her, pushing her around, forcing her to make statements. Now she, too, is in hysterics. Things went on in this way for a week or so until Villiers looked as if he was going to burst. He fled to lie on a beach with Arthur somewhere up the north coast of KwaZulu-Natal. I spoke to him there on his mobile phone. He was chortling with the sheer pleasure of getting away. When he was back I asked him about his sister-in-law. Oh, that's sort of settled down, he said. The police have left her alone so she's calmer now. We're all calmer now. Anyway, I reckon maybe she did shoot him. My brother was a difficult guy, she might have had her reasons. He winked. Not long after that, Villiers was upgrading my colleague Susan's machine when she saw his T-shirt was bulging at the back. What's that, she asked. Villiers pulled out a giant gun, the sort of Magnum you see in the movies. He was really serious about it all, taking shooting classes, learning how to be fast on the draw, the lot. In Dirty Harry, Villiers said, Clint Eastwood says this is the most powerful handgun in the world so I reckon, OK, they got my brother but they're sure as hell not getting me. But we thought your sister-in-law did it, we said. Maybe she did, he said. Quite possibly. But anyway they're not getting me. I always keep it loaded. No use having it otherwise, but don't worry, there's a safety catch. This seemed fair enough and we all got used to Villiers moving about the office all rodded up. Then we got a note saying that Villiers's one-man show was now to be called Monet Systems. I just like the name, sort of French, was all he would say. A little while later he announced that he was changing his name to Lanchester Monet. English or French? we asked. Sort of both, he said. I just don't like being an Afrikaner so I've decided to stop being one. After a while we got his new business card: Lanchester Jean-Paul Monet. You're getting more French, we said, but you can't speak French. I'm working on it, he said: the key lifestyle decision is the name change. You have to call me 'Lanchester' now. What with work, Arthur, the gym, the shooting classes and French lessons Lanchester was now frantically busy. We saw him less and less. Our computers were held together with rubber bands, literally. The fax machine would only work if you had it jammed against the wall in a certain position and the printers wouldn't work unless you unplugged and replugged them at each go. Finally, we called in someone else. Every now and again we get an e-mail from Villiers/Lanchester, but we just say the computers are working OK. Read on: a road accident, a boy called Hitler and a blessing in interesting times

fields.headline: Double exposure
fields.standfirst: Drug busts and duck muck, fireballs and fish hauls
fields.trailText: Drug busts and duck muck, fireballs and fish hauls
fields.body:
E-fitted up
Congratulations to Scotland's Donald Tumilowicz, runaway winner of this week's Most Unlucky Drugs Courier in Britain Award. Mr Tumilowcz, 26, had agreed to transport £19,000 worth of heroin from his home in West Lothian to a drop-off at a bar in Aberdeen. He had duly arrived at the bar, and ensconced himself in a corner to await his rendezvous. What he failed to notice, however, was that he had sat down directly beneath a police e-fit poster of a man wanted in connection with a series of flashing incidents in a local park. That in itself didn't necessarily constitute a problem. What did was that by a vicious twist of fate Mr Tumilowicz happened to be the spitting image of the computer-generated picture above him. Whilst he innocently sipped his pint of heavy, suspicious staff, convinced he was the so-called Torry Tickler, contacted the police, who arrived at the bar and began questioning him. Even then he might have got away with it, for it soon became evident that he hadn't been anywhere near Aberdeen at the times of the alleged incidents. Unfortunately, however, his insistence that he wasn't carrying any drugs when police officers hadn't asked him if he was aroused suspicion, and he was duly searched, revealing a bag of what Mr Tumilowicz claimed were "sweeties", but closer examination proved to be 58.58mg of heroin with a street-value of £19,000. He was subsequently sentenced to three and a half years in prison. "These things always seem to happen in Aberdeen," commented one local. "The other day someone tried to rugby-tackle me because they thought I was Saddam Hussein."
Aberdeen And District Independent

Fife fireballs
More excitement further south in Scotland, where Fife Constabulary was inundated with phone calls this week after sightings of a UFO passing over St Andrews. Switchboards were jammed with calls from concerned locals, who reported seeing a large flaming object hurtling through the sky over the town. "It was like a huge fiery ball," recalled one eyewitness. "Which was amazing because only three days before I'd won the karaoke competion at our local pub with a rendition of Great Balls of Fire." Theories as to what the object was have ranged from an alien visitation to the testing of a top-secret missile to the second coming of Jesus Christ. Experts, however, believe that it was probably a large meteor passing through the night sky some 80 miles above the earth. "It was rather beautiful," said one man. "It's just a shame it didn't land on the Scottish parliament."
The Fife Herald

Swinging haddock
It's not been a good week for fish. In Ipswich a mystery creature has been savaging fish in Christchuch pond in the middle of the town. So far some 200 have been killed, with more victims appearing every day. Rumours that the damage is being caused by asylum seekers have been dismissed by animal experts, who believe it's actually the work of a rogue mink, either an escaped pet, or one released from a fur farm by animal rights activists. In Derbyshire, meanwhile, a drunken prank involving a giant haddock ended up with three teenagers having to foot a bill for almost £3,000. The haddock in question was an ornamental bronze one, the crowning glory of a council-built fountain in the centre of Alfreton's high street. The three miscreants, who cannot be named for legal reasons, had, after a night's heavy drinking, climbed onto the fountain and wrenched the haddock free, severely damaging pipes in the process. There is some confusion as to precisely what happened next, with some eye-witnesses claiming the three made off in a taxi, others insisting they made a tour of the town's chip shops asking for their prize to be battered and fried. What is certain is that one of the three woke the next morning with two policemen in his bedroom and a large fish cradled in his arms. They were fined £2,700 and given a one-year conditional discharge. "I think they've learnt their lesson," said one lawyer. "They'll never touch another haddock in their lives."
Suffolk Evening Star & Derby Evening Telegraph

Sea scents
Morecambe, the Dubrovnik of Lancashire, has been overwhelmed of late by the most appalling stench. The smell was first noticed along the town's seafront, where people out walking on the promenade were assailed by an odour described variously as "nauseating", "repellent" and "like a mixture of bad eggs and rotting pig carcasses". "We'd taken my mother-in-law out in her wheelchair," explained one man. "She's getting on a bit now, and when the smell hit us we presumed she'd, you know, let one off, like old people do. I said 'Christ, mum, you want to watch what you're eating!' but she didn't seem to know what I was talking about." Numerous other such misunderstandings took place before the odour was finally traced to the town's flower beds, which council gardeners had apparently been spreading with a new type of fertiliser made of duck manure. "When someone told me duck droppings were one of nature's finest fertilisers, I thought 'What a load of crap!'" said one local gardener. "And then, of course, I realised it was."
Morecambe Online

Letter of the week
"I'm tired. Very, very tired. Of what? Of listening to an endless diatribe of complete and utter crap! I am an 'older' person who has taken as much bullshit as anyone can take. I want the police to get off their blue serge arses and be a force again. I want local authorities to kick bad tenants out of accommodation they don't deserve (and if they haven't got the balls to manage their tenants, they should sell the properties to an organisation that can).
Do you know what life is like in this city? As people lose faith in the force that used to be the most respected in the world, they no longer feel safe enough to report crime because the police won't/can't protect them. So the evil little shits that are destroying our city have it all their own way. Why is it that a small minority of lazy, thieving, arrogant little bastards can ride roughshod over the majority? Because the majority are so bloody idle! DO SOMETHING! Demand ZERO TOLERANCE NOW!!!
Let Avon and Somerset Police, the yellow line and tax disc specialists, respond. And if that superb body of well-paid tax collectors is looking in, I have a heartfelt message for you: You're all bloody well useless. Get the yobboes and filth off our streets now!
Jo Publik Western Daily Press

The smell was first noticed along the town's seafront, where people out walking on the promenade were assailed by an odour described variously as "nauseating", "repellent" and "like a mixture of bad eggs and rotting pig carcasses". "We'd taken my mother-in-law out in her wheelchair," explained one man. "She's getting on a bit now, and when the smell hit us we presumed she'd, you know, let one off, like old people do. "When someone told me duck droppings were one of nature's finest fertilisers, I thought 'What a load of crap!'" said one local gardener. "And then, of course, I realised it was." I am an 'older' person who has taken as much bullshit as anyone can take. I want the police to get off their blue serge arses and be a force again. I want local authorities to kick bad tenants out of accommodation they don't deserve (and if they haven't got the balls to manage their tenants, they should sell the properties to an organisation that can). Do you know what life is like in this city? As people lose faith in the force that used to be the most respected in the world, they no longer feel safe enough to report crime because the police won't/can't protect them. So the evil little shits that are destroying our city have it all their own way. Why is it that a small minority of lazy, thieving, arrogant little bastards can ride roughshod over the majority? Because the majority are so bloody idle! DO SOMETHING! Demand ZERO TOLERANCE NOW!!! Let Avon and Somerset Police, the yellow line and tax disc specialists, respond. And if that superb body of well-paid tax collectors is looking in, I have a heartfelt message for you: You're all bloody well useless. Get the yobboes and filth off our streets now! Jo Publik Western Daily Press

fields.headline: Most wanted: Bottega Veneta
fields.trailText: File this under Buy Now, Feel Smug Later. Your friends might not be overly impressed by a BV monogram, or by the Vicenza-based company's signature woven leather, just yet. But after the Bottega Veneta show was the surprise hit of fashion week in New York, the smart money is on the label to be the Next Big Thing. Harvey Nichols, the only British stockist, is currently revamping the Bottega Veneta concession (it reopens next Wednesday), but you will still have to make do with the accessories until autumn, when the harlequin leather-and-tweed skirts and ribbon leather blouson jackets, currently available only in Italy and the US, might make it to these shores.

webTitle: Universities hit by research brain drain

fields.headline: Universities hit by research brain drain
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Britain's research capabability is being undermined by a brain drain of the brightest and best graduates away from an academic career, university vice chancellors warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain's research capabability is being undermined by a brain drain of the brightest and best graduates away from an academic career, university vice chancellors warned yesterday.

They published research showing serious difficulties in recruiting high calibre professors and senior academics for departments including engineering, computer science, law, business, maths and chemistry.

In the "key areas of the knowledge driven economy", universities were struggling to attract the talented staff needed to retain a world lead in research and development, said the report by the research group Industrial Relations Services.

Universities were being forced to appoint academics without the necessary qualifications or experience, it said. Diana Warwick, the committe of vice chancellors and principals chief executive, called for an urgent injection of government funds to close the gap between academic salaries and those in the private sector.

She was supported by research from the Association of University Teachers showing that a third of academic staff were over 50 and preparing for retirement. The next generation of researchers were choosing better paid jobs in the private sector and abroad.

"While experience is valuable, too few of our best young people are attracted to academic careers. And they are right. It is now a poor career. The universities, as a result are in a precarious state ... The crisis in teacher education is coming. The clock is ticking," said David Triesman, the union's general secretary.

According to the AUT's analysis of staff in the older universities, there were more lecturers over 50 than under 35. The union pointed to poor academic pay as the key factor. Pay for junior lecturers, starting at under £15,000, was outstripped by private sector firms.
