fields.headline: South African stories
fields.standfirst: RW Johnson's tales from the new South Africa, continued
fields.trailText: RW Johnson's tales from the new South Africa, continued
fields.body:
Victims

We were driving in a two-car convoy through the Transkei when the thing you're always being warned about happened. In my rear-view mirror I saw a little girl dash out in front of Carol's white Nissan. The impact of the bumper lifted her briefly into the air before she landed, rolled over and scurried away down the hillside fringed with huts.

We stopped - a bad move. There are endless stories of white motorists driving through the Transkei, hitting a child and, when they stop, being set on and sometimes killed by angry mobs. One is always warned not to stop in such an event, the assumption being that the non-existent traffic sense of Transkei peasant children makes such accidents reliably frequent.

But we stopped. What else can you do when you've hit a child? Leaving Carol, my 80-year-old mother and my daughter relatively secure in the cars, my son Richard and I plunged down the hill, going from hut to hut asking for the little girl. Directed ever further down we soon found ourselves accompanied - 'surrounded' does more justice to the tenseness of the situation - by a crowd of young men with knobkerries. At length we found the girl.

She was eight but looked younger, and was being looked after by an old man who had bandaged her knee. She seemed to be basically all right, but extremely fearful as if waiting to be scolded. When I pressed all the money I had on me into her hand she was evidently amazed. I told the old man that she probably needed to lie down. He nodded and took the child inside. As we headed back uphill our escort of young men melted away.

Back at the top two burly Xhosa women had somehow ensconced themselves in the car alongside Carol and my mother, one claiming to be the child's mother, while the other - who was clearly in charge - was introduced as her friend. The mother, showing no sign of wanting to be with her daughter, had despatched a youth to bring her up while she stuck close to the car. Within a minute the little girl was produced. Carol suggested that we take all three of them to the nearest hospital at Mount Frere in case there was an internal injury of some kind. Once we were in the car the mother's friend suggested I give her a lift some two hundred miles in another direction while the mother herself began talking of the taxi fare back home. I said I couldn't help with the lift but would of course pay the taxi fare.

Mount Frere hospital lay in a back street thronged with tribesmen and traders. The town itself is as bone-poor as the rest of the Transkei and there'd been a lot of gang violence in the area in previous months, including several good-sized massacres. Carol and Richard said they'd go into the hospital but that I had better stay and guard my mother and daughter. As she left, Carol beckoned me over and to my surprise pulled a tiny revolver out of her shorts. I shouldn't need this in the hospital, she said, but you might need it out here. It's loaded. If there's trouble just keep the trigger pressed and it will keep on firing.

I hid the gun down my shorts and pulled my shirt over it to try to disguise the fact that I was armed. My mother and daughter certainly never suspected that I had a gun. An hour later there was still no sign of Carol, the women or the girl and dusk was approaching. We had miles to go on terrible roads on which animals and people were liable to wander heedless of approaching cars. If we didn't leave soon the drive would be impossible. I went inside the hospital to investigate. There were no doctors, no nurses, no one even at reception. The place was filthy, the toilets solid with shit and flies buzzed busily everywhere. It was difficult to imagine that conditions could have been worse than this under any preceding regime.

The little girl was stretched out on a bare table staring unseeing at the ceiling - in a trance or in shock. Carol and Richard had tried to persuade the two women attendants present that she needed attention or at least a blanket but had got nowhere: looking around I could see no evidence that the hospital had blankets and sheets. In the end we just left our phone numbers and addresses and gave something like twenty times the taxi fare to the girl's mother and her friend - though we were still unsure as to whether this really was the girl's mother.

The following day we went to a police station in KwaZulu-Natal to report the incident. The constable we dealt with clearly had a hangover and expressed incredulity that we thought it worth doing. In the end I took the report form from him and filled it in myself. He filed it with the air of a man throwing away waste paper. The regional administrative centre of the Eastern Cape Government in Kokstad professes itself unable to make contact with the Eastern Cape capital of Bisho, so what chance was there that a report filed in KwaZulu-Natal would somehow get through to the authorities in the Eastern Cape?

Moreover, the area where the accident had happened had recently seen a great deal of cattle-rustling as well as political violence: minor road accidents were an irrelevant distraction. Later we phoned the hospital and were told that a doctor had seen the girl and discharged her. The main consequence of the accident was that a couple of hundred extra rands had been injected into the Transkei economy, a sort of tariff which might have been exacted over an incident of any kind. Friends shook their heads: that was the Fourth World, they said; welcome back to the Third. We were treated as if we were the victims of the accident, though it didn't feel like that. The two women, one of whom may have been the girl's mother, had successfully put themselves forward as victims and got the lion's share of the money. The money I had given to the real victim, the little girl, was doubtless confiscated by an adult. Throughout the whole drama she never spoke a word.

A boy called Hitler

Not long ago I was trying to locate my friend Michael, and phoned his daughter, Annie, who lives at Hillcrest, in the hills outside Durban. It's always just a bit tricky ringing her up, because you never know which of her husbands you might get. The first one was Dave, but a few years after she married him she met Jim. She explained to Dave that she wanted to live with Jim and have babies with him, which Dave said was OK, but he looked sad and said it would make him lonely, so Annie said: 'Well you could stay on if you like.' He did and is very sweet with the kids.

Anyway, this time I got neither husband, but a strange male voice which said no, Michael wasn't there, or if he was, he was asleep. Who is that, by the way? I asked. Hitler, the voice said. I was a bit puzzled and rang Michael's great friend, David Cohen. I know, he said, that happened to me too. But I didn't press it. If you're Jewish you don't want to quarrel with someone called Hitler.

Hitler, it turned out, was a little Xhosa boy. Africans quite often name children after qualities they like - Beauty, Perfect, Fairness, Golden Miles or Happiness. I've even known a Psychology Ndlovu and an Electricity Bengu. But sometimes they use names of people they think are just generally famous (eg Nelson). Hitler's mother, a peasant woman in the Transkei, had heard that Hitler was a pretty famous man.

When her Hitler was eight she had her sixth child and told Hitler that there was just no money or food for him. If you stay here in the Transkei you'll starve, so you'd better go to Durban, she said. It's a huge city. In a place like that there is always bound to be more money and things that come loose so you can take them. Just keep walking north. It'll take you several weeks, but you'll be OK if you keep the sea on your right.

Hitler's marathon walk must have been quite something: it would have been testing for a 28-year-old, let alone a boy of eight. How he managed to find food as he walked, I don't know. But one day he reached the big city and became a street child on the Durban beachfront. Unfortunately, there were already many hundreds of other street children there, begging, stealing, mugging and fighting. Once white tramps had slept there but they've mostly gone now, either stabbed or chased away by the kids.

The competition is rough and after a while Hitler decided to migrate out of town. He found a shopfront in Hillcrest, where he slept under cardboard and begged for his breakfast. During the day he attended a little village school, then came back and begged for his supper in the evening. He'd been doing this for a year and was 10 years old when Annie, doing her Saturday supermarket shop, bumped into him and said he'd better come home with her.

Annie's idea was that Hitler would make a good friend for her own eight-year-old, Ben, and could go to school with him. Everyone told her that street children are ruined by the trauma they've already been through, that they are often on drugs or glue, that they all steal and will probably go on to rape and murder, too. The weight of evidence is heavily on the side of such advice, but Hitler did indeed become Ben's great friend, was utterly delighted to have found a place where you got TLC and square meals, and realised that his mother had been right to kick him out: this was much better than starving in the Transkei. At school he was a bit behind but tried hard.

One thing he tried hard at was running, and he soon revealed a great talent, winning just about every event at the school sports day. At which point he was, inevitably, asked if he was any good at rugby. (By this stage he'd had enough ribbing to understand that there was something wrong with his name, and he announced that he would be Timothy from now on.) But no, he'd no idea how to play rugby. He soon did though: was quickly in the school team and before long in the provincial side, which means that he could one day be a prospect for the Springbok team itself.

Lately he had found himself on a rugby tour in the Eastern Cape, which gave him a chance to drop off to see his mother back home in the Transkei. She had done the right thing, he reported: life in Durban was something else, which caused her to wonder whether she shouldn't kick another few chickens out of the nest. The last I heard, Timothy, as well as the rugby and keeping Annie and her husbands happy with his homework, had taken up marathon running, at which he was looking distinctly promising.

Grace

During the 1994 election I went out to a township with a friend who is an extremely literal-minded and evangelical Christian. The township, he explained, was torn between the ANC and Inkatha and their two leaders, Teaspoon Mkhize and Spitfire Dhlamini. At one point in the day I found myself interviewing an ANC warlord while a drugged teenager sat at the door, watching us menacingly, a Kalashnikov across his lap.

At day's end I sat down to dinner with my friend and his wife and he said grace. 'Lord,' he said, eyes tight shut, holding each of us by the hand, 'what about that young boy with the AK-47, what of your plans for him? I think about him especially.' When he said grace again at the end of the meal, he simply said: 'Lord, thank you for sending us such a wonderfully interesting country to live in.'

fields.headline: Scient joins the European crowd
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Bob Howe, chief executive of Nasdaq-listed Scient, is the latest American export to set up shop in London talking of the "exciting opportunities" for e-business in Europe.
fields.body:
Bob Howe, chief executive of Nasdaq-listed Scient, is the latest American export to set up shop in London talking of the "exciting opportunities" for e-business in Europe.

His excitement is not surprising, given the fact that the internet services market in Europe is expected to grow by 46% to $28bn (£17.5bn) in 2004, according to research by International Data Corp.

But it is already a crowded market for management consultancies like Scient, all trying to stake a claim on that same rapid growth.

In fact Scient - which opened its London office two months ago - is a latecomer to the European market. Established competitors include Razorfish, with clients such as Nokia and Electrolux, and the multinational consultancies such as KPMG and Andersen.

However, Howe says Scient's entry into the European market was earlier than they had anticipated, and that it had only been undertaken because of increasing demand from potential clients. Scient's clients in the US include Johnson & Johnson, Nasdaq and Chase.

"We are about transforming and positioning businesses to win in the electronic environment," said Howe.

"With the opening up of the European market, companies have great opportunities for gaining penetration, and then there is wireless communications, which we believe is the next wave of the future."

Howe claims Scient's ability to draw in big firms relates to its strong management team, which boasts several former IBM executives including himself. He set up IBM Consulting in 1991, where he worked with Scient's chief operating officer, Steve Mucchetti.

A crucial element of Scient's rapid success - it was only founded two years ago and is now capitalised at $6bn - is its strategy of not letting any single client constitute more than 10% of revenues, which keeps its risk spread.

"We have about 85 clients to date and have launched 16 new electronic businesses. On a quarter-to-quarter basis, we could say two-thirds of those business give us recurring revenues. But we do not let any of those companies become more than 10% of revenues, even though some of them could."

Scient is already working for three British companies "in the retailing and financial services sector" on developing e-business models. But the firm will not say who they are.

Its London office has 50 staff, and expects that number to grow fivefold within a year, a large chunk of Scient's 874 global workforce.

Howe said he is looking at more offices in France, Germany, Italy and the Netherlands. Expansion into those markets could be made organically or through acquisition and joint ventures. Scient has not entered into any mergers or made acquisitions to date but has about $200m to invest.

The company wants Europe to balance its revenues, biased towards the US. Howe expects Scient's revenues from North America to fall to about 45% as the company beings winning further business across Europe and in Asia. fields.headline: Justify My Love, Secret and Holiday
fields.trailText: LOOK AT THIS. LOOK AT IT. JUST LOOK AT IT, WILL YOU?!?!?
fields.body:
LOOK AT THIS. LOOK AT IT. JUST LOOK AT IT, WILL YOU?!?!?

Turn a Fiver into £10,000 with George Best! Kamikaze Football is the new online Premiership footy game. Register now at www.kamikazefootball.com.

SOON BE GONE DON

Don Hutchison, the only Scottish international the Fiver has ever heard saying things like 'howay', 'why aye man' and 'that Jimmy Nail is a talented bonny lad, bonny lad', has stunned Everton by refusing to sign the contract that's been put in front of him. He now looks certain to leave the club he "wanted to sign for life" for.

By all accounts, Geordie Don wanted £20,000 a week, a figure which would have put him on a par with the top earners at Goodison. But Bill Kenwright's new regime wouldn't go a penny above £15,000 (£15,000.01? On your way, la!), an offer Hutch slammed as "a disgrace". "A lot of fans are thinking I'm asking for the earth but that's rubbish," explained the Tyneside Scot. "I was just looking for parity with some of the other players."

Hutchison's agent Rachel Anderson went on: "It was so far removed from an acceptable offer that he just said 'well I might as well wait'. He did accept that he would wait until January and sign for a European club or to the end of next season and sign for an English club. But I don't think that will be the case now because the club will want to capitalise on his value."

So a quick sale looks likely, and both Tottenham and Newcastle are hanging around waiting to pounce. Sunderland are also interested, but the Fiver thinks Peter Reid is wasting his time - no self-respecting Scotsman would turn out for the arch-rival Mackems, would they?

FOLLOW THIS

The annual Leicester Challenge (sponsored by Worthington) will be live at Football Unlimited on Sunday from 3pm.

A DOG OF A DAY

Hot, sweaty and with an unsightly rash developing, the Fiver is in the throes of Cup fever, as the annual Leicester Challenge (sponsored by Worthington) reaches its thrilling climax. And who better to demonstrate the virtues of the English game to a watching world than the cream of Merseyside, Tranmere Rovers?

Down at the Tranmere training camp, all is veiled in a cloud of secrecy. But behind John Aldridge's iron curtain of moustachioed security guards, Dave Challinor, the man credited with the longest throw in the world (have you heard?), is dying to explain the trick football is talking about. After the Cruyff turn and the Carlos free kick, the game is now rapt by the Tranmere toss.

"I don't consider myself a freak," whispers Challinor, modestly. "Grip is important," he confides. "I feel it's the speed that I release the ball behind my head," he continues, indiscreetly. "Frankly, my throws are hard," he carries on, for all the world to hear. "Hard to defend against because defenders struggle to get a clean header with any power on the ball" - stop Dave, you're giving the game away! - "because it is dropping out of the air and has travelled so far." - la la la la, the Fiver has its fingers in its ears.

Let's hope manager Aldridge has bunged up his lugs as well, because Dave can expect little mercy should his carefree babble be picked up by his employers. The cold-hearted club have already ruthlessly axed their mascot Rover, an old fat bulldog, in favour of a brand new fit one, also called Rover. A spokesman said: "He's a huge improvement on the last one, who had really outlived his day." Bookies are offering 15-8 on the reject mutt being chucked out of the team coach onto the hard shoulder of the M62 this evening, and 4-1 on Challinor bouncing along after him.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I'm hurting. I'm hurting a lot." - Bryan Robson, either talking about Middlesbrough's Premiership plight or recording backing vocals on Alanis Morrisette's new album.

THE PLAYER, THE MANAGER, THEIR FANS AND THEIR LOVERS

Welcome to our weekly selection of the choicest, ripest, plumpest Premiership cuts. We'd love to keep up our boycott of Manchester United games but... well, we're tired and we can't be bothered to fight any more.

Arsenal v Southampton

"Hello, Kanu! Had fun on your holiday, did you? Enjoyed missing that penalty? I hope you did, because it's cost you two week's wages, you skiving swine! Grr! Now get in that team!" Is that what Arsene Wenger said upon the itinerant striker's return? Probably not, although Kanu is likely to replace the suspended Thierry Henry in a team with no other injury problems. Marian Pahars may be back for the Saints, for whom Glenn Hoddle is in a 100% record situation. Matt Le Tissier unfit!!!

Middlesbrough v Leeds

It's a fascinating match between a team which isn't quite going to get relegated and a team which isn't quite going to win the league. Whether Paul Ince is going to contribute to this edge-of-the-seat stuff is a moot point, though - getting some sort of physician to poke around his groin before the match should settle the argument. Meanwhile, it's up and down for David O'Leary O'Leeds: little Michael Bridges is back, but Gary Kelly, Matthew Jones and Eirik Bakke are in awful trouble with the FA, so Danny Mills, David Hopkin and Alfie Haaland fill in.

Wimbledon v Man Utd

Wow. Look at this. Roy Keane and Paul Scholes are suspended. Dwight Yorke is unavailable. David Beckham, Ryan Giggs and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer are doubtful. And there's talk that Jordi Cruyff might play. If ever Wimbledon had a chance to beat the champions it's now. That's the Fiver off down the bookies to put a pony on Fergie's men, then.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Chelsea defender Frank Leboeuf may sign for Lyon in the summer, according to Opta Soccer.

Internazionale have put together a £35m package to land David Beckham. Manchester United will receive a £22m transfer fee while the player would be paid £13m.

Derby are interested in Feyenoord's Argentinian centre half Patricio Graff.

Sheffield Wednesday want Howard Wilkinson as their manager. The 56-year-old England technical director, manager of the Owls in the 1980s, has turned down two approaches so far.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Sam Hammam has sold his 20% share in Wimbledon, finally severing ties with a club he has been involved with since non-league days. Hammam sold an 80% stake in the Dons in 1997 to Norwegian businessmen Kjell Inge Rokke and Bjorn Rune Gjelsten, but has recently been virtually frozen out from the day-to-day running of the club. Hammam said: "It has been an honour for me to have known and been partners with Kjell and Bjorn. Yes always an honour and, until recently, a pleasure."

Tottenham are hoping to complete the signing of Reading's England Under-16 goalkeeper Shaun Allaway in deal which could eventually be worth £2m. Allaway, 17, will cost an initial £300,000. The arrival of Allaway may speed up the departure of Espen Baardsen.

Gary Kelly has signed a new five-year contract with Leeds.

Elgin City, who join the Scottish Football League next season, have appointed Inverness CT assistant boss Alex Caldwell as their new manager.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: Friday Night's All Wright (10.30pm)

Watch Ian fudge links, deliver remarkably poor gags and ask questions which are so badly phrased they can only be answered monosyllabically. Thank God it's only on once a week.

Friday Night's All Wright (11.30pm)

Aaaaaaiiiiiiiiiiiieeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeee!!!

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (5pm)

It sounds like animation from eastern Europe but it isn't.

Sky Sports 2: Worthington Cup Final Preview (8pm, 12.30am, 4.30am)

We know not what this is. Perhaps it's got something to do with the annual Leicester Challenge (sponsored by Worthington).

Hold The Back Page (9.30pm, 12.30am SS1, 4am SS1)

Four journalists in a room. They realise there is no free beer. They row.

fields.headline: Nothing ventured, nothing gained
fields.standfirst: Richard Branson on the best - and worst - decisions he ever made.
fields.trailText: Richard Branson on the best - and worst - decisions he ever made.
fields.body:
"The best decision I ever took was to spend nearly £3 million on launching Virgin Atlantic in 1984.

Almost everyone, including most of the Virgin Directors at the time, thought the idea of a new high quality, value-for-money airline under the Virgin brand was doomed.

16 years later we have 30 planes carrying millions of people more cheaply than ever before all over the world and a business worth £1.2 billion.

The worst decision I ever took was to start a London listings magazine called 'Event' in the early 1980s.

Time Out had gone on strike so our team thought we couldn't lose, but we did not count on the ex-Time Out team starting their own magazine called 'City Limits'. Six months later at a cost of nearly £1 million we closed it.

Still, nothing ventured, nothing gained - I have no regrets about it because all of us learn most from mistakes!"

fields.headline: The Insider
fields.standfirst: She goes to the parties so you don't have to
fields.trailText: The ability of members of the fashion press and buying industries to brave any weather in duster coat and slingbacks is a sight to behold, especially now that the slight comfort of a pashmina would be a severe fashion crime. If the Girl Guides ever need team leaders prepared to brave freezing temperatures for which they are woefully underdressed, without unsightly shivering or mascara-smudging tearfulness, they could do a lot worse than start recruiting at Milan fashion week. However, Trussardi's catwalk show, inexplicably staged on a rooftop on a chilly February evening, might just have been a goosebump too far. Luckily, Trussardi had the foresight to team up with Remy Martin for their aftershow party. Waiters winced as fashionistas knocked back (in one) medicinal glasses of vintage cognac (in most cases, the drink was older than the drinker). Once defrosting had occurred, however, it was back to business as usual - champagne.

The ability of members of the fashion press and buying industries to brave any weather in duster coat and slingbacks is a sight to behold, especially now that the slight comfort of a pashmina would be a severe fashion crime. If the Girl Guides ever need team leaders prepared to brave freezing temperatures for which they are woefully underdressed, without unsightly shivering or mascara-smudging tearfulness, they could do a lot worse than start recruiting at Milan fashion week. However, Trussardi's catwalk show, inexplicably staged on a rooftop on a chilly February evening, might just have been a goosebump too far. Luckily, Trussardi had the foresight to team up with Remy Martin for their aftershow party. Waiters winced as fashionistas knocked back (in one) medicinal glasses of vintage cognac (in most cases, the drink was older than the drinker). Once defrosting had occurred, however, it was back to business as usual - champagne.

Corso Como 10 is Milan's premier shoe-shopping, risotto-eating, martini-sipping, people-watching venue - an A-list mall set in a romantic, crumbling maze of leafy courtyards, whitewashed rooms and spiral staircases, so picture-perfect that you half expect credits to roll and title music to start up. It was the ideal location for American heavyweight fashion magazine W to choose for its exhibition, W: The Show, a collection of the best of the photographs published in the magazine over the past decade. The opening night cocktail party pulled in an impressive global fashion crowd, including Gucci's Tom Ford, Anna Wintour of American Vogue and British designers Clements Ribeiro, but for once the wallflowers were the main attraction: a breathtaking display of work by photographers including Bruce Weber, Mario Sorrenti, Mario Testino, Paulo Roversi, Craig McDean, David Sims and Juergen Teller.

The glitz-free artistic tenor of Milan parties continued with Tina Brown's in the Galleria d'Art Moderne. This "informal dinner" was another evening in honour of an American magazine - this time, Talk - aimed perhaps at plentiful Milanese advertising budgets. Brown mingled with designers Dolce & Gabbana and Anna Molinari, and models including Trish Goff and Gisele turned up to add a little gorgeousness, in case the Patrick Demarchelier photographs on show weren't eye-candy enough. But the most exciting thing? Food. Not canapés: proper, grown-up food, where you still have some left after the first nibble. Bliss.

fields.headline: Most everywhere:  coloured tights
fields.trailText: Coloured tights are eminently frivolous. You can't wear them unless you're an art student, a fashionista, or have absolutely no interest in getting promoted. In the workplace, they get funny looks. Men are confused by them. They like legs, but not orange ones. Especially when they're teamed with a pair of sky-blue slingback mules. But since Gucci put bright pink tights on the catwalk for spring/summer, coloured tights have been creeping into our consciousness as a brighter alternative to dull old Naturals and Nudes. Prada do lipstick red ones, Versace do emerald green ones, but king of the coloured tights is Wolford, offering every possible permutation from acid yellow to navy blue. For a cheaper version, try the high street's Pamela Mann, who does a neon pink pair for a fiver.
fields.body:
Coloured tights are eminently frivolous. You can't wear them unless you're an art student, a fashionista, or have absolutely no interest in getting promoted. In the workplace, they get funny looks. Men are confused by them. They like legs, but not orange ones. Especially when they're teamed with a pair of sky-blue slingback mules. But since Gucci put bright pink tights on the catwalk for spring/summer, coloured tights have been creeping into our consciousness as a brighter alternative to dull old Naturals and Nudes. Prada do lipstick red ones, Versace do emerald green ones, but king of the coloured tights is Wolford, offering every possible permutation from acid yellow to navy blue. For a cheaper version, try the high street's Pamela Mann, who does a neon pink pair for a fiver.

Coloured tights can be a quick way to give a dull outfit pizazz (very 80s word but that's the decade that inspired this trend). Our advice is: start off slowly. Try a pair in brown or olive green, then work up to burgundy, which is only a shade away from plum or purple. Soon you will have moved on to lilac (very modish), pink and maybe even red. Then the fun really starts. Red tights look bitchin' with burgundy shoes. Lilac legs rock with orange stilettos. The exact colour combinations are up to you. And if you really can't bear to be parted from your beloved black 40 deniers, fear not. They're having a fashion moment, too.

Coloured tights can be a quick way to give a dull outfit pizazz (very 80s word but that's the decade that inspired this trend). Our advice is: start off slowly. Try a pair in brown or olive green, then work up to burgundy, which is only a shade away from plum or purple. Soon you will have moved on to lilac (very modish), pink and maybe even red. Then the fun really starts. Red tights look bitchin' with burgundy shoes. Lilac legs rock with orange stilettos. The exact colour combinations are up to you. And if you really can't bear to be parted from your beloved black 40 deniers, fear not. They're having a fashion moment, too.

fields.headline: The Italian job
fields.standfirst: If you can make it there, you'll make it anywhere: Richard Benson finds out how British fashion graduates fare in the tough world of tailoring that is Milan
fields.trailText: Joanna Yulan Jong has had the kind of career British fashion students who come to Milan dream of. After working for a number of companies as a designer, she decided to launch her own label's spring/ summer 2000 collection at London Fashion Week last autumn; orders are healthy, the buzz strong and fashion trade bible Women's Wear Daily is tipping her alongside Patty Shelabarger and former Prada menswear designer Neil Barrett as one of this year's Milan-based up-and-comers.

Joanna Yulan Jong has had the kind of career British fashion students who come to Milan dream of. After working for a number of companies as a designer, she decided to launch her own label's spring/ summer 2000 collection at London Fashion Week last autumn; orders are healthy, the buzz strong and fashion trade bible Women's Wear Daily is tipping her alongside Patty Shelabarger and former Prada menswear designer Neil Barrett as one of this year's Milan-based up-and-comers.

Jong's career path has been conventional but fast-track. After graduating in fashion design at the Royal College of Art, she came to Italy in 1992 and built a reputation with her work for major design groups. In 1996, Giorgio Armani personally recruited her as design director for his Le Collezione womenswear line. Having established her international credentials - and an impressive contacts book - she left Armani last year to work on Yulan and maintains her income by working as a freelance consultant to big design houses. Her Yulan collection for spring/summer 2000 is notable for its high standards of craftsmanship. The tailoring and design are based on folding, wrapping and layering, but it is the colour that has drawn the attention of the cognoscenti. Each of the 30 pieces is dyed precisely the same shade of red which, Jong says, is a feat generally regarded as difficult-to-impossible, given the use of different fabrics and textures.

Jong is the kind of designer Milan needs in order to maintain its unique tradition of fostering creativity and business nous in tandem. Of the four fashion capitals, this is the one to which graduates have come if they want to pursue directional, creative design and learn to make it sell. London is innovative but so lacking in infrastructure and business support that young designers have to set up their own, small labels, which then suffer from naive management; New York is too corporate and market-led to allow much experiment; Paris is class-bound and hierarchical, which makes it hard for the young to get a foothold. Milan, by contrast, likes to recruit our talent ("If you're good and a little bit crazy-British, you can get very well rewarded in Italy," explains one London designer working here) and though it works people hard, Milan usually trains them well.

However, that tradition may be under threat and future graduates could find it hard to follow a career path like Jong's. In the bar of the Principe de Savoia hotel, the international fashion community's preferred Milanese drinking venue, the talk is of economic conditions squeezing out the middle-sized fashion production companies; of northern family-based fashion businesses closing because of new developments in their markets; and, of course, of designers suffering as a result.

The problem is the growth of the big fashion conglomerates. Over the past five years, Prada, Gucci Group and the French LVMH have been buying up companies and bringing hard-headed, expansionist policies to the European fashion industry. In Italy, smaller, artisan concerns are finding their prices undercut and their margins undermined by the conglomerates' economies of scale; those looking to cut costs are hampered by Italian employment laws that render it prohibitively expensive to make staff redundant.

"They [the conglomerates] have created a monopoly and there's nothing we can do," says Leonardo Baratella, head of LEBA, an independent production company based in Vicenza, near Milan. "I have always run this company in a flexible way and tried to keep ahead of things, yet I'm now forced to close down."

Smaller companies suffer as price margins are cut: "But they cannot afford to close down because to sack a whole factory floor of staff would cost hundreds of millions of lire. If they can't close, they end up with no alternative but to accept decreased prices which pushes them further into difficulties. In the end, they will sell at the first chance to a big company at a reduced price.

"The other day," he sighs, "a machine representative came to show me some new machines. He had seen four companies that day; each had asked if they could sell him their machines, instead of buying them from him."

Of course, the big companies will argue that they are only bringing modern, globally-oriented business techniques to an old-fashioned market. Some observers would say the smaller companies have let themselves down, with their innate conservatism in business and design. What seems indisputable is that, for the next few years at least, it will become harder for young designers to break through with their own collections. One British woman, who prefers not to be named, tells how last year she left a senior post at one of the biggest Milan houses to design her own collection. After showing it in Paris, she had good reviews and sold it into shops around Europe, but it was never manufactured because her Italian production company could not afford the initial outlay and the fabric supplier could no longer accept deferred payment. She has gone back to consulting for established labels.

Mark Strong, a St Martins graduate who's been designing for a company based near Milan for just over a year, is pessimistic. "It has always been hard for British graduates coming here," he says. "They work you really hard and you usually end up stuck in grotty company flats in small factory towns miles from Milan. A lot of people think that if they make it, they can start their own label, but that seems to be getting harder and just working for the companies is horrible because they're panicking. They are still doing business like they were in the 80s and early 90s, and they know they're getting out of date, but they don't know how to compete. They know they need to take more risks with their design but they can't afford a drop in their old customers while they build up a new base."

This need for newness with guaranteed public appeal means that for those who can break through, the potential interest and rewards are high - Jong is currently considering offers from several powerful backers who want to launch her internationally. For the less fortunate or gifted however, the future is less bright; right now, it's business as unusual in Milano.

fields.headline: Bright on!
fields.standfirst: Bravo!  Bella! Fashion editor  Laura Craik  reports from the Milan shows  The trends
fields.trailText: There is no mystery attached to why the Italians sell such a lot of clothes. Women want to look thinner. Taller. More powerful. Comfy in the daytime and sexy in the evening. And that's what Milan does.
fields.body:
Growing old is neither easy nor graceful. It is particularly angst-ridden if you're in the fashion business, where youthful beauty is prized over everything. At the shows, you see the Milan grans, powdered and buffed and dressed in their £5,000 outfits, and you wonder what possible relevance a wisp of see-through chiffon blouse or a sequined miniskirt can have to their lives. True, they can appreciate these things on an aesthetic level, but how can you get excited about clothes you can't wear? You can't. That's why there is such an outcry when hotpants are revived, or yellow, or sheer. Only a model can look good in those, nary a real woman. And so fashion editors (who are real women, honest) dismiss these trends in their journals and avidly wait for black to come back again. Which, of course, it always does.

There is no mystery attached to why the Italians sell such a lot of clothes. Women want to look thinner. Taller. More powerful. Comfy in the daytime and sexy in the evening. And that's what Milan does. That's why, however creative and wonderful London might be, it will never, ever have the clout of Milan because there is only a limited market for flesh-coloured leather corsets and chair covers that turn into dresses.

It was a vibrant season, literally. Not only was colour everywhere but pattern, too. Geometric prints zigzagged their way down the catwalk so loudly that donning pretentious black shades was a sensible idea. Clothes that give you a headache? Not instantly desirable, but wait.

Let's start with the most influential designers, since Milan is all about pecking order. Gucci staged a strong show. Faded optic print minidresses with plunging necklines sparkled in bronze and gold Lurex, while burnished gold leather coats were fastened with jewel-encrusted belts. Was this the 60s or the 70s? A mixture, with a dash of Easy Rider chic thrown in. You've worn the biker jacket, but for autumn Mr Ford presents the biker coat, in black leather or soft brown herringbone. It will sell and sell, as will his elegant jewelled slingbacks.

That was the "Look at me" end of the spectrum. There were also narrow hipster trousers, high-collared jackets with fluted edges and wet black jersey dresses that made for easy elegance.

Why must fashion move so fast? It barely has one good idea before tossing it aside for the next. Of course, this keeps the tills ker-chinging. Miuccia Prada would have done better to stick with the "sincere chic" look she pioneered last season, but instead she went back to the 40s with floral-printed chiffon tea dresses and cashmere coats topped with fox fur collars tied askew. These looked lovely, as did the ribbon Prada used as belts on daffodil yellow coats and velvet dresses. Harder to wear were trapeze-line cropped jackets in thick crushed velvet, calf-length pleated bowling skirts and stiff herringbone dresses with diagonal purple stripes. Shoes and bags - the things everyone will buy - were strong as usual. Two-tone mules with a slight wedge and herringbone/leather weekend bags will sell out before they hit the shops.

Versus had an excellent season. Here was Gisele in a tight turquoise Lycra dress, all big backcombed hair and bright red lips. This was the 80s, but with no New Romantic ruffles, just clean colours (red, yellow, purple, green) and happy patterns. Jersey dresses with keyhole backs, tight sweaters with computer-generated prints and plunging lace dresses were all worn with bright tights and red stilettos. Extra points go to Donatella for practising what she preaches: she took her bows dressed in an acid orange shirt and purple trousers.

For his Emporio line, Giorgio Armani was in sombre mood. Daywear was olive green and black, with ruched, slashed, embroidered velvet. Everything was narrow: tapered trousers, nipped-in jackets, flat patent brogues. If colour frightens you, this is where to head. The Giorgio Armani collection was somewhat brighter, with jaw-dropping eveningwear including tight lace bodies cascading into huge skirts of beaded tulle.

Dolce & Gabbana took us to a tent festooned with rugs and cushions, for a show rich in textures and vibrant colours. Strongest was the duo's outerwear: patchwork fur coats, diamanté-studded purple shearling jackets and belted trenches were all worn with jaunty velvet berets. The label also pushed three-quarter pantaloons as a new trouser shape, worn with chiffon scarves and stripy Lurex tops.

Two labels whose time has come are Maxmara and Missoni. Both do what they do regardless of trends: now fashion has caught up. Maxmara is a deeply 80s label, but office 80s, not clubby 80s. Loose belted cardigans, slouchy moleskin trousers and herringbone coats with leather trim looked effortless for day, while eveningwear was given a 40s feel by teaming chiffon blouses and drop-waisted beaded skirts with strings of pearls. Tank tops and waistcoats came in cherry red, navy and beige.

Missoni's zigzag stripes are their trademark: this season, they were bolder than ever, in the sexiest collection the label has ever shown. Those stripes arrowed over wide-legged Lurex jumpsuits, satin hotpants and plunge-necked blouses in yellow, turquoise and brown. Dogtooth blouson jackets with vented backs were worn with tulip-shaped skirts and fantastic gold-leaf tights.

Antonio Berardi's collection was so much better than last season's, 90% wow and chock-full of ideas. In gorgeous colours such as grape, navy and eau de nil, Berardi showed a raft of dresses - knife-pleated chiffon printed with giant flowers, pearlised snakeskin tubes and stripy calf-length velvet columns with deep V-necks. There was a 20s feel to the collection: the models all had marcel waves and many wore long strings of pearls.

Lawrence Steele could easily do Gucci, should Tom Ford find it all a bit too much. Gold leather coats with mink hoods, tight cashmere jumpers brushed with gold leaf and strappy gold mules were mixed with cream, black and burgundy in a polished collection whose every fabric was super-luxe. Soft black leather jackets and angora sweater dresses again referred to the 80s, as did black pencil skirts with white piping. Give this man more outlets in Britain! Then we'll all be glamorous (and skint).

Other labels looking strong are Blumarine (mink-trimmed cardies won't go down well in Britain, but beaded skirts and cashmere jerseys will), Narciso Rodriguez (slim 40s suits and knitted sequin dresses) and Allessandro Dell'Acqua (graphic jersey dresses and chiffon separates).

There was plenty in Milan to get excited about, if you like bright colour and loud patterns. Sadly, British women don't. But maybe next season's glorious offerings will change our minds. Or at least coax us into buying a purple handbag. Or some red shoes. Just maybe.

The trends:

Grape

Big brooches

Pencil skirts

Fur trims

Gold

Piping

Herringbone

Bold stripes

Bottle green

Lurex

Bigger bags

Floppy hats

Chiffon

Sci-fi prints

Trenchcoats

Plunging necks

Ribbon

Velvet

80s/40s/20s

webTitle: Mozambique takes stock as storm brews

fields.headline: Mozambique takes stock as storm brews
fields.trailText: Mozambique counted the cost yesterday of the ruinous floods that have dashed hopes of an early economic recovery. And experts say another cyclone is brewing in the Indian Ocean.
fields.body:
Mozambique counted the cost yesterday of the ruinous floods that have dashed hopes of an early economic recovery. And experts say another cyclone is brewing in the Indian Ocean.

The US sent experts to assess the damage and Portugal pledged $2m (£1.2m) in aid to its former colony, which braced for epidemics of water-borne diseases.

In Palmeira, north of the capital Maputo, local residents queued to unload maize from helicopters arriving every 10 minutes from the capital. While residents of Xinazane, across a swollen river from Palmeira, waded through waist-deep water to collect food or to carry their ill to the town's small, poorly-equipped hospital.

One woman said she had waited days after a bridge was swept away for the river to drop far enough to allow her to cross with her two-year-old daughter, who has malaria.

Mozambican officials said at least 150 people had died, more than 200,000 had been left homeless and 800,000 were at risk.

UN officials in Maputo said they had had no official reports of cholera deaths, but South African radio reported that between 15 and 18 people were dying of the disease every day in Beira, the country's largest second city. And residents in Palmeira said a child died of malaria, the second major flood-driven threat facing Mozambique's 15m people.

Relief agencies were reported to have delivered 964 tonnes of maize to the region, far short of what will be needed in one of Africa's poorest countries.


Reuters

fields.headline: Guyana
fields.trailText: 1. No, not Ghana in Africa, but the Republic of Guyana - the only English-speaking country in South America, where, this weekend, Prince Charles will be doing a spot of light royal touring.
fields.body:
1. No, not Ghana in Africa, but the Republic of Guyana - the only English-speaking country in South America, where, this weekend, Prince Charles will be doing a spot of light royal touring.

2. About the size of the UK, Guyana is on the Atlantic coast of South America, next to Venezuela. It's home to the Kaieteur falls - the world's highest single-step waterfall.

3. It's formerly part of the British Empire and many famous Brits have Guyanese roots, including: Frank Dobson's deputy Trevor Phillips; the Commission for Racial Equality's Sir Herman Ouseley; Middlesex cricketer Mark Ramprakash; and Michael Caine's wife Shakira.

4. More Guyanese live abroad than in Guyana, many communicating online.

5. But it's perhaps better known for the Reverend Jim Jones, whose 913 followers (including 270 children) committed suicide in 1978.

6. It's one of the most ethnically mixed countries in the Caribbean.

7. It's still one of the world's poorest countries with the knock-on effects of crime and drugs. Today, Charles will be visiting victims of domestic violence.

8. He may even take in local papers such as the Stabroek News or the Guyana Chronicle.

9. If he has time, he could do a little "pork-knocking" (panning for gold to you and me).

10. But then, Guyana is the home of the lost city of Eldorado.

It's formerly part of the British Empire and many famous Brits have Guyanese roots, including: Frank Dobson's deputy Trevor Phillips; the Commission for Racial Equality's Sir Herman Ouseley; Middlesex cricketer Mark Ramprakash; and Michael Caine's wife Shakira. 4. More Guyanese live abroad than in Guyana, many communicating online. 5. But it's perhaps better known for the Reverend Jim Jones, whose 913 followers (including 270 children) committed suicide in 1978. 6. It's one of the most ethnically mixed countries in the Caribbean. 7. It's still one of the world's poorest countries with the knock-on effects of crime and drugs. Today, Charles will be visiting victims of domestic violence. 8. He may even take in local papers such as the Stabroek News or the Guyana Chronicle. 9. If he has time, he could do a little "pork-knocking" (panning for gold to you and me). 10. But then, Guyana is the home of the lost city of Eldorado.

webTitle: Patter of tiny feet for Kate Winslet

fields.headline: Patter of tiny feet for Kate Winslet
fields.trailText: The Hollywood Reporter has announced that Kate Winslet is expecting her first child with husband Jim Threapleton
fields.body:
The Hollywood Reporter has announced that Kate Winslet is expecting her first child with husband Jim Threapleton. The actress, who got married last year to the assistant director, is said to be "thrilled".

Winslet recently turned down the role of Bridget Jones in a big-budget version of Helen Fielding's novel, The Diary of Bridget Jones (the part has now gone to the American actress Renee Zellweger), but is keen to fit in one more role before the baby is born in late September. She is in talks to star in Enigma, a thriller based on Robert Harris's best-selling novel about the race to break German code during the second world war.

Michael Apted, who recently helmed the nineteenth Bond film, The World is Not Enough, will direct the film which boasts a script written by Tom Stoppard. Dougray Scott and Saffron Burrows will also star in the film, which is scheduled to begin shooting in London this spring.

Winslet, who just wrapped the Marquis de Sade tale Quills, still has another literary period piece in development, Emile Zola's Therese Raquin. But this project is likely to be put on the backburner until Winslet is back from maternity leave.

webTitle: 'There is life in the 100-year-old dog yet'

fields.headline: 'There is life in the 100-year-old dog yet'
fields.standfirst:
Guardian political editor Michael White looks at a century of Labour, from Hardie to Blair

Blair fourth in best leader poll
fields.trailText: Guardian political editor Michael White (left) looks at a century of Labour, from Hardie to Blair.
fields.body:
Like most anniversary dates this one is open to quibbles. There had been plenty of revolutionary socialist parties formed in late Victorian England and trade unionists elected to parliament in alliance with the Liberals. At Bradford in 1893 an Independent Labour Party, the famous ILP, had been formed, five years after Keir Hardie's Scottish Labour Party.

But the modest gathering at the Memorial Hall in Farringdon Street, not far from the Guardian's London home, on February 27 1900 was the one that would matter in terms of continuity and achievement. By forming the Labour Representation Commitee, with the ''tepid'' support of the TUC, the mixture of trade unionists, middle class Fabians and assorted leftwing socialists created a parliamentary platform for Labour's coalition that would see it elbow aside the historic Liberal Party and form the first Labour government 24 years later.

That divergence is now a matter of controversy since Tony Blair (though few of his senior colleagues) has repeatedly argued that the Lib-Lab split delivered the bulk of 20th British government into Conservative hands. Centre-left progressives, he believes, should edge towards cooperation and coalition to keep the Tories out in the 21st.

What reinforces Blair's concern (and his obsession with re-election) is grim awareness that the progressive landslides of 1906, 1945 - Labour's annus mirabillis - and 1966 all melted away within 5 years, though many of their achievements in public education, welfare, health and housing (above all, Nye Bevan's NHS) endure.

In 1900 two LRC MPs were elected, Hardie in Merthyr Tydfil, and Richard Bell, a railway worker in Derby. By 1906 the number of Labour MPs had risen to 29, largely thanks to the notorious (and Thatcherish) Taff Vale judgement which put union funds at risk from strike damages. With Labour support the new Liberal government reversed it, though the issue rumbled on. It still does.

Radical though it was on social reform, Lords reform and tax, the New Liberalism failed to address falling wages. The result, famously recorded in George Dangerfield's Strange Death of Liberal England, was rising militancy, strikes and syndicalist thinking. Along with militant feminism and Ireland, it was all very New Labour.

The situation was close to revolutionary. Then World War I broke out in August 1914 and most socialist parties across Europe went patriotic. Strictly speaking the Labour Party, as it was now called, was not yet socialist and its most charismatic leader, James Ramsay MacDonald, opposed the war. Arthur Henderson, Hardie's successor, joined the war coalition.

The Fabian intellectual Beatrice Webb had already written in her diary ''Ramsay MacDonald is no longer a socialist,'' reflecting a nose for betrayal that would characterise Labour history. Only this week, the writer Hanif Kureishi, told the Guardian that New Labour deserves credit for improving race relations - ''much as one hates to admit it.''

MacDonald's split with his party over the global financial crisis of 1929-31 ensured that he remains public enemy No 1 in Labour's pantheon of betrayal. When Neil Kinnock succeeded Michael Foot as Labour leader in 1983 one Trot magazine dubbed him ''The New MacDonald'' in huge type - on his first day.

For most of its history Labour was dogged by the Communist Party of Great Britain, politically weak but industrially strong. But small Trotskyite groups linger on, sometimes in open hostility, entryist in the 80s (until Kinnock turned the tide), today rallying optimistically to ''help'' Ken Livingstone become London mayor on May 4.

The old Labour adage was that it owed ''more to Methodism than to Marx.'' But the party's constitution became quasi-socialist in 1918. The war had made the state powerful and prestigious, as wars do, and Clause IV's pledge ''to secure for the workers by hand or by brain the fruits of their industry...on the basis of the common ownership of the means of production'' was intended to impress the middle class - and help squeeze the Liberals.

In 1918 Labour duly got 2 million votes and 60 MPs. By 1924 there were 191. MacDonald's first 10 month minority government sought desperately to prove itself competent and respectable - shades of the 90s again - yet ended in the fiasco over the forged Zinoviev Letter. It was published by M16 courtesy of the Daily Mail, ''the Forgers Gazette'' as Michael Foot still calls the Tory tabloid which also hounded him.

Modestly reformist the 1924 and 1929 governments hardly frightened the propertied classes. Even the TUC general strike of 1926 lasted barely a week, with the parliamentary leadership keen to see it end. '' Who are the leaders of the Labour Party in England,'' asked a French intellectual in 1931. ''Not intellectuals, but trade unionists...hard working, rather timid, very conservative negotiators, they are born parliamentarians.''

Reduced from 289 to just 46 seats in the national government election of 1931 - Labour's worst moment - the 30s were Auden's ''low dishonest decade'' for a party which embraced pacifism more readily than the radical economics of Keynes and such diverse disciples as Oswald (ex-Labour) Mosley, Nye Bevan, Lloyd George, even Harold Macmillan.

But if the 30s were bad the 40s were to be Labour's finest hour. Its benches, not the Tories, cheered Churchill when he first appeared in the Commons as prime minister in 1940. Its leaders, Bevin, Morrison ( Peter Mandelson's grandpa) Greenwood and their deceptively mild stop-gap leader (1935-55), Clem Attlee, sustained the coalition in war.

In peace Labour ejected Churchill and (''we are the masters now'') finally got the chance to liquidate the empire, create the post-war order ( Nato, the UN, the cold war) and implement domestic reform. Clause IV had its moment as even the hated mine-owners saw their pits nationalised. In 1951 Labour won record votes, but lost power for 13 years.

The prosperous 50s were also damaging and divisive, Gaitskell's proto-modernisers versus the Bevanites. Harold Wilson skillfully reunited them around an inclusive moderniser's slogan - ''the white heat of technology'' - in 1964. He mocked the Tories out of power with the help of a new magazine, Private Eye. But Wilson's over- nimble footwork gave opportunism a bad name.

Far from becoming ''the natural party of government'' (Wilson's boast) Labour was now in trouble. With old industries crumbling the unions funked reform on Barbara Castle's terms in 1969, thwarted Ted Heath's version - in another cycle of revived industrial militancy in 1974 - only to be hammered by Margaret Thatcher after 1979.

She launched the most sustained assault on all Labour had painstakingly built since 1900. Not every citidel fell, the NHS was cherished in Bath as well as Barnsley. But the old industries crumbled still faster while the new ones - more often services not manufacturing - did not inspire the kind of collectivist solidarity around the factory, the Labour club and the Daily Mirror which had sustained the party.

Higher education for everyone, largely a Labour legacy, enticed what would one day be called the ''aspirational'' and upwardly mobile'' to the suburbs, leaving behind what Blairism now dubs the socially-excluded. '' They have rottweillers, wear shell suits and read the Sun,'' one Old Labour MP observed bitterly. Attlee's grandchildren became Thatcher's kids.

If Wilson's 1964-70 governments had fluffed the big economic issues (we still bask in its social reforms, which Mrs Thatcher attacked, but did not repeal), Jim Callaghan's was under-appreciated. His deputy, the literary Michael Foot liked nautical metaphor. Sailor Jim sailed through a typhoon of global financial disorder, strikes and layoffs, hyper-inflation, war and terrorism, from 1976-79 - with no Commons majority at all.

But it was ''Maggie'' who inherited the North Sea oil boom and those assertive young voters (''deference is dead''), while Labour engaged in yet another bitter internal war. It was fought between the realists-cum-modernisers, Foot, Kinnock, Smith, Blair and Brown ( Peter Mandelson usually in the background), and the socialist core which had rallied to the mesmerising sound of Tony Benn, Labour's golden boy turned radical prophet.

His family had followed the 20th century path: from Liberal to Labour to socialist - but not back again, though son, Hilary, got elected in 1999 as ''a Benn, but not a Bennite.'' The modernisers had won, the voters had rewarded them with that record 179-seat majority.

As Tony Blair heads towards his third anniversary with a 50:29:15% lead in this week's polls, it looks all-but-certain that he will get that elusive second working majority at Westminster. Yet it would be a rash, not to say complacent, New Labour apparatchik who believes that the the globalised world, managerial and pragmatic, which Blair inherited and seeks to harness will last for ever.

If nothing else, Labour's turbulent history shows how the pendulum swings back in circumstances none too hard to forsee. World depression, war, environmental crisis any of them could shift the political fulcrum away from laid-back individualism and consumer power towards collectivism, ideology renewed egalitarianism. Eco-militancy is already thriving.

If that happens plenty of people inside Labour's ranks will be quick to say ''told you so'' and seize the hour, as Ken Livingstone may be tempted to attempt to seize it this week. ''Fairness and efficiency'' is Blair's equivalent of Wilson's white heat. But, as always, Labour pride in its achievements is mixed with Labour disappointment at its failures.

The party may be disciplined and quiet, but it is not dead. There is life in the 100-year-old dog yet. Who knows who it will bite next - or whether it will consult a focus group before doing so.

fields.headline: Houses selling in record time
fields.trailText: Houses are selling in record time, with properties changing hands on average in only nine weeks, according a survey released today. Some properties in the south-east can change hands in less than a week.
fields.body:
Houses are selling in record time, with properties changing hands on average in only nine weeks, according a survey released today. Some properties in the south-east can change hands in less than a week.

The Bradford & Bingley report highlights Ipswich and West Sussex as the fastest-selling areas, followed by Newcastle upon Tyne and parts of Manchester. It takes much longer to find a buyer in the north and Scotland - between 10 and 12 weeks - than in the east.

Such is the housing shortage in the south-east that on average 13 buyers register a bid for every property. They pay an average of £103,580, almost double the £52,330 paid on average in the north, and vendors achieve 97% of their original asking price.

The managing director of Bradford & Bingley, David Woodcock, described the strength of competition as "intense". "In terms of interest rates, the competition in the mortgage market is intense, mitigating the impact of the recent rises. I would say that the market could absorb at least one further interest rate rise without any noticeable effects." The Bank of England increased the base interest rate to 6% this month.

fields.headline: Explosives found after barracks blast
fields.trailText:
Three gas cylinders packed with home-made explosives were found inside a
Northern Ireland army base today, hours after a small explosion shattered
several windows at the barracks.
fields.body:
Three gas cylinders packed with home-made explosives were found inside a Northern Ireland army base today, hours after a small explosion shattered several windows at the barracks.

The explosives were made safe by an army bomb disposal expert, close to the perimeter fence of Shackleton Barracks at Ballykelly, Co Londonderry.

No-one was injured in the explosion, but Ulster Unionist MP Ken Maginnis said it underlined the need for disarmament.

"There have now been a series of disturbing incidents, clearly intended to intimidate government," said the party's security spokesman.

"All of these incidents vindicate those who want to achieve an end to violence, the threat of violence and an early start to decommissioning."

There was no warning for the attack and no immediate claim of responsibility. However, suspicion may fall on the dissident republican Continuity IRA, the only republican group not to declare a ceasefire, who were responsible for the bombing which caused extensive to a hotel in Irvinestown, Co Fermanagh nearly three weeks ago.

It was the first attack on an army base since the dissident republican campaign of 1997 and 1998 which ended with the bombing of Omagh, Co Tyrone, and the deaths of 29 people and injury of hundreds more.

An investigation will be mounted into how the explosives were smuggled into the base on a disused airfield, which is currently home to battalions of the Royal Welch Fusiliers and Royal Irish Regiment.

Democratic Unionist Party assembly member Gregory Campbell condemned the attack and said it showed it would be wrong to scale down security precautions.

Mr Campbell said: "I think it would be a mistake in the times in which we live if the government or if the GOC or chief constable were to scale down unnecessarily routine security arrangements which mean that attacks like this can take place.

"Last night's events show they can and do take place, so it is foolish to routinely run down security arrangements.

"Security must be maintained and improved where there is a risk to human life."

fields.headline: Russia investigates alleged Chechnya atrocities
fields.trailText:
Moscow today opened an investigation into a reported atrocities against Chechens by Russian troops, after TV footage showed
Russian soldiers piling bodies into a mass grave, some of them
apparently bound and some mutilated.
fields.body:
Moscow today opened an investigation into a reported atrocities against Chechens by Russian troops, after TV footage showed Russian soldiers piling bodies into a mass grave, some of them apparently bound and some mutilated.

Russia's NTV commercial television station showed film which it said had been shot by a German reporter for the Germany N24 television channel of Russian soldiers dumping dead Chechen men into a mass grave. The film showed that many of the bodies had been bound, although NTV quoted the German reporter as saying they had been wrapped in barbed wire. One of the men had had his ear cut off. A lorry was also shown dragging a body behind it.

Sergei Yastrzhembsky, the chief presidential spokesman on Chechnya, called the footage "a very serious document that demands thorough study, first of all regarding the circumstances of the Chechens' death."

However, other Russian officials dismissed the footage as "propaganda" and "a falsification". Interior ministry spokesman Oleg Aksyonov was reported by Interfax news agency as saying: "The authors of the TV report carried out a political order... Elementary logic suggests that if a crime were committed, video recording was unlikely to be permitted." He said that the tape actually showed the burial of rebels killed in combat.

Russia's human rights commissioner, Oleg Mironov, called the tape "another propaganda trick by the rebels... In the present situation, when the operations of Russian troops in Chechnya are under unremitting control, hardly anyone would risk committing the unlawful acts shown on the tape," Interfax quoted him as saying.

Russia had come under intense international pressure to investigate the video. Foreign secretary Robin Cook, just back from a trip to Moscow, said he had telephoned his Russian counterpart Igor Ivanov "to ask him directly for an investigation of these allegations". He said he had repeatedly raised with Moscow British concerns about Russia's actions in the Chechen war.

Javier Solana, the head of EU foreign policy, said: "I am very concerned about the reports, accompanied by shocking images, of apparent human rights abuses in Chechnya.

"I urge Russia to cooperate fully with such an investigation and bring to justice any person implicated in these apparent crimes."

Mr Ivanov has accused the west of using the media to wage an information war against Moscow, though the reports of atrocities have come mainly from human rights organisations. Human Rights Watch, a respected organisation in the US, this week accused Russian soldiers of going on a killing spree on February 5 in Aldi, a district of southern Grozny, murdering at least 62 civilians.

The organisation also said that refugees returning to the devastated Chechen capital are still finding the corpses of relatives killed by Russian troops. "It is becoming increasingly clear that these are not isolated incidents," said Holly Cartner, executive director of Human Rights Watch. "We are uncovering a pattern of summary executions throughout Grozny."

In the Aldi incident, Human Rights Watch said a large group of Russian soldiers, possibly more than 100, had gone to the district and systematically murdered civilians in their homes and on the streets. Soldiers were said to have looted and burned many houses and demanded money from civilians, sometimes promising to spare their lives if they agreed to pay. Several witnesses interviewed by Human Rights Watch also alleged that Russian soldiers had raped at least two women.

Russian troops have effectively sealed off Grozny from the outside world, and very few civilians have managed to leave the city to tell about alleged abuses.

Sergei Yastrzhembsky, the chief presidential spokesman on Chechnya, called the footage "a very serious document that demands thorough study, first of all regarding the circumstances of the Chechens' death." However, other Russian officials dismissed the footage as "propaganda" and "a falsification". Interior ministry spokesman Oleg Aksyonov was reported by Interfax news agency as saying: "The authors of the TV report carried out a political order... Elementary logic suggests that if a crime were committed, video recording was unlikely to be permitted." He said that the tape actually showed the burial of rebels killed in combat. Russia's human rights commissioner, Oleg Mironov, called the tape "another propaganda trick by the rebels... In the present situation, when the operations of Russian troops in Chechnya are under unremitting control, hardly anyone would risk committing the unlawful acts shown on the tape," Interfax quoted him as saying. Russia had come under intense international pressure to investigate the video. Foreign secretary Robin Cook, just back from a trip to Moscow, said he had telephoned his Russian counterpart Igor Ivanov "to ask him directly for an investigation of these allegations". He said he had repeatedly raised with Moscow British concerns about Russia's actions in the Chechen war. Javier Solana, the head of EU foreign policy, said: "I am very concerned about the reports, accompanied by shocking images, of apparent human rights abuses in Chechnya. "I urge Russia to cooperate fully with such an investigation and bring to justice any person implicated in these apparent crimes." Mr Ivanov has accused the west of using the media to wage an information war against Moscow, though the reports of atrocities have come mainly from human rights organisations. Human Rights Watch, a respected organisation in the US, this week accused Russian soldiers of going on a killing spree on February 5 in Aldi, a district of southern Grozny, murdering at least 62 civilians. The organisation also said that refugees returning to the devastated Chechen capital are still finding the corpses of relatives killed by Russian troops. "It is becoming increasingly clear that these are not isolated incidents," said Holly Cartner, executive director of Human Rights Watch. "We are uncovering a pattern of summary executions throughout Grozny." In the Aldi incident, Human Rights Watch said a large group of Russian soldiers, possibly more than 100, had gone to the district and systematically murdered civilians in their homes and on the streets. Soldiers were said to have looted and burned many houses and demanded money from civilians, sometimes promising to spare their lives if they agreed to pay. Several witnesses interviewed by Human Rights Watch also alleged that Russian soldiers had raped at least two women. Russian troops have effectively sealed off Grozny from the outside world, and very few civilians have managed to leave the city to tell about alleged abuses.

fields.headline: Mission impossible in Kosovo
fields.standfirst:
Derek Brown explains why sending more troops to Kosovo won't help resolve the situation there
Plus: MoD modifications
fields.trailText: 1pm: Derek Brown explains why sending more troops to Kosovo won't help resolve the situation there
fields.body:
Nato ambassadors in Brussels are pondering a request from military commanders for 2,000 more troops to be sent to Kosovo. They would be better employed trying to work out what the soldiers already there are doing.

The international force in Kosovo numbers more than 30,000. They are trying to prevent a final solution to the evil ethnic rivalry between Serbs and Albanians. In purely military terms, they are doing a splendid job in severely trying circumstances. But their mission is doomed.

Nato's political leadership says it wants to build a peaceful multiethnic Kosovo; a worthy aim which Nato itself has made impossible. Last year, the air campaign against Yugoslavia created exactly the excuse that the Serbian paramilitaries needed to terrorise half the Albanian majority into fleeing the province.

When Nato finally mustered the political courage to send in ground forces, the refugees flooded back - and immediately started driving out the Serbs.

There are now around 20-25,000 Serbs left in Kosovo; about a tenth of the pre-Nato population. The last remaining concentration of Serbs is cooped up in the ghetto of northern Mitrovice, close to the Serbian border. Absurdly, Nato now wants to resettle Albanians in their former homes in north Mitrovice.

They can do so only at the point of a gun, for the Serbs - no doubt with the aid and encouragement of the Milosevic regime in Belgrade - are determined to hang on to their last foothold in Kosovo, and perhaps make it the basis for partitioning the province.

Nato leaders say they will never countenance ethnic cleansing or partition. But they were unable to prevent the first, and must soon be obliged to contemplate the second. For Kosovo has already been comprehensively, irretrievably divided by Milosevic's ruthlessness, by Nato's powerlessness and above all by mutual communal hatred.

In that context, the lines on the map are irrelevant. But in another sense, Mitrovice is much more than just a last Serb redoubt. The town lies at the heart of a mining industry which is Kosovo's only significant economic resource. The giant Trepca conglomerate is based there. Though it is now barely functioning, it used to be Yugoslavia's biggest export earner, selling an annual £60m of minerals and other products.

All in all, then, Kosovo is a continuing political, diplomatic, economic, military and social disaster. Pity the poor devils who are likely to be sent there in the next few days, to join mission impossible.

Related documentary
Kosovo: special report

MoD modifications

The revelation that the standard issue British forces' rifle does not work terribly well in extreme conditions could not be more embarrassing for the ministry of defence.

Earlier this week, there were reports that after a £1bn refit the latest version of the Tornado bomber can't drop "smart" bombs. Then there was the one about Royal Navy vessels being confined to port for lack of fuel. And another, about military radios malfunctioning in Kosovo.

Defence secretary Geoff Hoon is indignant. "Our forces don't have lousy kit. Our forces actually have some of the very best kit in the world. Inevitably, when you are dealing with £23bn a year, there are problems."

Odd that. Most of us would imagine that a budget of £23bn would iron out problems rather than create them.

Useful link
Ministry of defence

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: Judi Dench to co-present Oscars, Harry Potter script does the rounds, Norman Jewison "in shock", Clint Eastwood to be honoured, and Catherine Zeta Jones and Richard Gere on the casting couch
fields.body:
 Judi Dench is to make her debut at this year's Oscar ceremony. The actress, who won Best Supporting Actress last year for her 10-minute portrayal of Elizabeth I in Shakespeare in Love, will co-present the annual back-slapping with Billy Crystal on March 26.

 Warner Bros president, the excitingly named Lorenzo Di Bonaventura, has, according to a rumour on Dark Horizons, sent the Harry Potter script to a select group of directors. The group is: Barry Levinson, Wolfgang Peterson, Jonathan Demme, Chris Columbus, Brad Silberling, Peter Weir, Terry Gilliam, Sam Mendes, and Tom Shadyac. The job came up for grabs on Tuesday when Steven Spielberg bowed out of the race.

 Norman Jewison has said that he is in a "state of shock" that his film, The Hurricane - based on the true story of middle-weight boxer, Rubin Carter, wrongly imprisoned for 19 years on a racist murder rap - has not been nominated for an Oscar. The veteran director, who in his career has garnered 45 Oscar nominations, believes that it was the release date that prevented the film, starring Denzel Washington in the title role, from being nominated. "We came out so late that there wasn't time for all the Academy members to see the movie. And a lot of Academy members live in England and they didn't even get a tape. We came out on 29 December so who got a chance to see it?"

 Read more about what Norman Jewison and Denzel Washington have to say about the making of The Hurricane in our exclusive NFT interview.

 Veteran actor turned director, Clint Eastwood, is to be honoured with a lifetime achievement award from the Venice Film Festival. Festival organisers say he will receive the award on August 30, the opening day of the 11-day festival.

 Star Wars director George Lucas has professed a love of the documentary and said he wants to make a film in that genre. In a recent discussion with students at UC Berkeley posted on the Star Wars site, the director said that he originally intended to become "a documentary cameraman, and then make sort of avantgarde films on the side". But his dreams were thwarted by the fact that back in the 70s there was no market for them. Now, because of the advent of cable Lucas sees an opportunity to go back to his first interest: "anthropological films, historical documentaries, historical dramas, cinema verité and the (traditional) documentaries."

 >Catherine Zeta Jones is to star with her fiancé Michael Douglas in a film called Smoke and Mirrors, bought by Initial Entertainment Group as a vehicle for the couple. Douglas is lined up to play nineteenth century French magician, Jean-Robert Houdin, who was sent to Algeria with his assistant, Collette (Catherine Zeta Jones), to expose a religious sorcerer said to be behind an anti-colonial plot. The action-adventure film, based on a true story, could start shooting before the end of the year.

 Richard Gere is in talks to star in Julia Pastrana, a drama based on the true story of a physically deformed circus performer who falls in love with the man who exhibits her. Helmed by Taylor Hackford, who directed Gere in An Officer and a Gentleman, the film is likely go into production towards the end of the year.
