fields.headline: Sell-off linked to rail tragedy
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The fragmentation of the rail industry since privatisation and a breakdown of the safety system were cited last night as the underlying causes of the Southall rail crash in September 1997.
fields.body:
The fragmentation of the rail industry since privatisation and a breakdown of the safety system were cited last night as the underlying causes of the Southall rail crash in September 1997.

Strongly worded statements by Professor John Uff, chairman of the Southall rail inquiry, and Bill Callaghan, chairman of the health and safety commission, yesterday brought new pressures to bear on the government to reverse the rail sell-off.

Prof Uff highlighted the industry's post-privatisation fragmentation in his report and strongly criticised Railtrack for replacing one set of rules "with a hotchpotch of different rules".

He said that the accident, in which seven people died when a Great Western Trains passenger express hit a freight train, occurred in "circumstances which were exacerbated by privatisation".

In a determined attempt to forestall more criticism, Mr Callaghan said that he had summoned all those involved in the Southall crash to an action meeting.

"Let them be in no doubt that those who use and work on the railway will not tolerate any delay," he declared.

"The system broke down as a result of the fragmentation of the industry. There is a need to look at human behaviour as much as equipment in effective safety systems."

Prof Uff's conclusions particularly expose the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, on the issue of privatisation of the rail network. However, Mr Prescott welcomed the "very thorough report", saying that many of the issues raised had already been addressed by measures since the crash.

Although the train driver, Larry Harrison - who went through two yellow lights and a third, red, light before applying the brakes - is primarily held responsible for the accident, Prof Uff's report is mainly concerned with the failure of safety systems.

The automatic train protection (ATP) was not functioning on Mr Harrison's train, and the in-cab automatic warning system (AWS) broke down the day before and had not been repaired.

Prof Uff said yesterday that Railtrack should put into place clear rules to stop any train running that did not have an operative AWS. "The train should be taken out of service immediately," he said.

But Railtrack admitted later that it was consulting rail companies on a variation to Prof Uff's recommendation. Rather than immediately stopping any passenger train that proves to have ineffective safety equipment, Railtrack argues that so long as the cab is double manned and its speed does not exceed 70mph, it is safe to allow it to proceed to a convenient stopping point.

Rod Muttram, Railtrack's safety director, said the company had pledged to seek continuous safety improvements "to ensure that safety remains the number one priority of the industry". Railtrack would also have to look at AWS in the light of the report's recommendations, he added.

Relatives of the Southall victims welcomed the report but blamed the rail companies for the failure of safety regimes. They also blamed Mr Prescott for allowing Railtrack to keep control of safety in a separate subsidiary company.

Mr Prescott said he had already taken steps to build on the sort of problems highlighted by Prof Uff. The health and safety executive would be directly responsible for deciding whether train companies were operating safely.

He expected GWT to be among the first of the rail companies to be subjected to a new regime of annual audits. AWS would be replaced in two years by an improved safety system costing £250m, and within 10 years ATP would be installed throughout the network at a cost of £2bn.

Prof Uff also criticised the inexperience of some of those running the industry.

Within hours of his remarks an outspoken statement from Go-Ahead, the transport company operating the Thames Trains service involved in the Paddington rail crash last October, claimed that the Paddington crash would not harm its bids to take over further rail franchises.

Martin Ballinger, Go-Ahead's managing director, said: "From our own indications, we reckon that at the time of the accident, our safety procedures were as good as the vast majority of the industry, and better than an awful lot.

"I don't think our personal reputation is at stake, and we can hold our head up high and say we operated safely within the safety standards."

fields.headline: Buying weapons for Britain's army
fields.trailText:
Is there a problem with Britain's weapons?
All 300,000 rifles used by Britain's armed forces are expected to be recalled for modifications costing millions of pounds because they tend to jam in extreme temperatures. It's the latest embarrassment for the ministry of defence (MoD). Earlier this week, it emerged that the Tornado GR4, the latest version of Britain's warplane, had trouble dropping precision-guided, or smart, bombs during the Kosovo conflict because a new laser-guided targeting system was delivered not in full working order.
fields.body:
Is there a problem with Britain's weapons?
All 300,000 rifles used by Britain's armed forces are expected to be recalled for modifications costing millions of pounds because they tend to jam in extreme temperatures. It's the latest embarrassment for the ministry of defence (MoD). Earlier this week, it emerged that the Tornado GR4, the latest version of Britain's warplane, had trouble dropping precision-guided, or smart, bombs during the Kosovo conflict because a new laser-guided targeting system was delivered not in full working order.

Who purchases military equipment?
The buying is done by the defence procurement agency (DPA), part of the ministry of defence (MoD). The DPA buys over £5bn of new equipment and spares for the armed forces annually, which makes it is the single biggest purchaser of manufactured goods in the UK. At any one time, its 5,500 staff are managing more than 13,000 contracts, ranging from the purchase of submarines to small parts for a field radio.

What is the history of the DPA?
Based at Abbey Wood, north Bristol, the DPA was created on 1 April 1999, replacing the MoD procurement executive, which could be traced back to its roots in the admiralty, war office and air ministry. The Labour government created the DPA in an attempt to streamline a complicated process as part of its smart procurement initiative, which is designed to procure equipment for the armed forces 'faster, cheaper and better'.

How does the purchasing process work?
The DPA says competition is fundamental to achieving value for money so competitive bidding is used wherever possible. MoD does not simply accept the cheapest bid, but that which provides the best overall value for money, taking account of all the relevant factors. The entire life of a piece of equipment is considered, because support costs over its lifetime can far exceed the cost of acquiring it. But politics also enter the equation; governments sometimes will opt for buying domestic instead of a cheaper foreign system for reasons of national pride and security. During the Thatcher years, there was an almighty split within the Conservative government on whether to buy helicopters made by Westland (British) or Sikorski (American).

So why are cost overruns endemic in weapons procurement?
Buying a weapon is like getting an estimate on a new building; the final cost invariably seems to be more than the initial estimate. Cost overruns in the US defence procurement are legion and legendary - remember the Pentagon was once charged $800 for a toilet seat. The problem could get worse as European governments encourage weapons makers to merge to benefit from economies of scale. In the US, there is now only a handful of giant defence corporations like Lockheed Martin and Boeing. With fewer companies to supply arms, governments could have less bargaining power.

What is the situation in Britain?
In 1998, the national audit office, the government's financial watchdog released a highly critical report on defence procurement. It found 25 major defence projects running over budget and over deadline, including the Eurofighter project. The report by auditor general Sir John Bourn said the projects, which cost a total of around £36bn, were three years late. The NAO estimated that the final cost will be billions of pounds more than expected. Sir John said overall delays, including projects like Eurofighter, the Merlin helicopter and Challenger tank, had become worse over time. Only three of the 25 projects were expected to enter service at the dates originally planned, compared to five in the 1996 report. The government hopes to do better with its smart procurement initiative.

What will be the future of procurement?
This is going to get even more complicated as Britain has set up a joint armaments procurement agency with, France, Germany and Italy. OCCAR (Organisation Conjoint de Co-operation en matiere d'armement) will establish a centre of practical expertise, developing procedures based on best practice and learning lessons from the past.

fields.headline: Driver went through warning signals
fields.standfirst:
Great Western Trains heavily criticised for 'serious and reprehensible failures' of communication

Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The official inquiry report into the Southall train crash yesterday blamed the "unexplained inattention" of the driver as the primary reason for the accident in September 1997 when seven passengers were killed.
fields.body:
The official inquiry report into the Southall train crash yesterday blamed the "unexplained inattention" of the driver as the primary reason for the accident in September 1997 when seven passengers were killed.

Larry Harrison drove his Great Western train at 60-80 mph through two warning signals before crashing. The report by John Uff, chairman of the Southall inquiry, said Mr Harrison had been unable to respond to the two signals before being unable to stop in time at a third signal which was at red.

He had left the driving seat when he realised a collision was imminent and there was nothing more he could do, going through a bulkhead door into a narrow passage to the left of the engine facing the direction of travel.

A freight train passed in front of the GWT train as it was approaching Paddington. As Mr Harrison failed to brake the express piled into the freight train. Hundreds were injured.

Mr Harrison emerged with cuts and bruises and severely shaken and shocked, the official report into the crash said.

The report contained a transcript of Mr Harrison's conversation with a signalman after the crash.

The signalman asks: "Are you okay?"

He replies: "I'm okay, yeah. I was just putting my stuff away in the bag. The A, the A, the, the AWS has been isolated (put out of operation) because some, some brake problem, I believe, so, I had no AWS so, I put my stuff away in the bag and the next thing I knew, I was coming up against red, up, such coming through, through..."

Signalman: "Through Southall station?"

Mr Harrison: "Through Southall, yeah."

The report said Mr Harrison was outwardly a "competent, skilled and highly experienced driver, yet on one crucial occasion, his inattention led to disaster."

Professor Uff said Mr Harrison, who denied that he been bending down to pack his bag just before the crash, was "a man capable of a somewhat cavalier disregard of convention". He was also "capable of irregular behaviour which might lead to the disregarding of safety rules".

But Professor Uff admitted it was not possible from the evidence to conclude that Mr Harrison was misusing the controls.

The report placed the immediate responsibility for the Southall crash on Mr Harrison, but it was also highly critical of Great Western Trains and the post-crash investigation. The in-cab automatic warning system (AWS) was out of order due to a fault. If it had been working, it could have prevented signals being passed at danger.

The report spoke of "serious and reprehensible failures" of communication within GWT which led to the Swansea to London express making its journey without AWS working. Specifications for AWS testing were "ambiguous and obscure" and the "fault lay in the system operated by GWT".

James Turnock, the driver using the train before Mr Harrison, had reported the AWS problem to an operations supervisor at Paddington and by telephone to GWT control at Swindon. He did not, as the rules require, report to a signalman and Railtrack was unaware of the failure.

Another cause of the accident was the failure of Railtrack to put in place clear rules to prevent normal running of a high speed train which had an inoperative AWS.

The report also criticised GWT's policy of driver train ing, and the introduction of the sophisticated automatic train protection system which can prevent trains going through danger signals.

ATP was switched off in Mr Harrison's train as he had not received a refresher course on its use. "It is regrettable that a new positive safety culture was developed by GWT only after the Southall crash," said the report.

Tensions between British transport police and Railtrack staff led to errors. Too many experts were called in and their roles quickly became confused. Important evidence was overlooked and destroyed.

Professor Uff said: "Unregulated and competing interests succeeded in duplicating and confusing both the investigation and inquiry process. It is unacceptable that a technical accident investigation should be directed or controlled by the transport police."

The report expressed concern that the Southall public inquiry was delayed for two years because of criminal proceedings in which both Mr Harrison and GWT were cleared of manslaughter. GWT was fined £1.5m after admitting an offence under the health and safety at work act.

Professor Uff said it was axiomatic that the post-accident rail inquiry should not be held up by the possibility of criminal proceedings.

Mr Harrison said last night: "I would like to say once again to the bereaved families and passengers who were injured, how sorry I am for what happened. I made a mistake, a human error, which had terrible consequences."

He added: "If I knew then what I know now, I would never have taken the train out."

Strategies for consideration

 Automatic warning system (AWS) to be regarded as vital to the continued running of a train.

 Airline-style safety briefings for train passengers.

 Automatic train protection (ATP) should be maintained on Great Western lines.

 Extension to the present coverage of ATP on Great Western should be considered.

 New authorities to oversee projects including AWS and ATP should be set up.

 Technical investigation of serious rail accidents should generally be controlled by the railway inspectorate.

 Driver training should include driving in abnormal conditions, including driving without AWS working.

fields.headline: Bad blood
fields.standfirst: First they spurn our beef. Now the French have banned blood donations from people who have visited Britain What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: First they spurn our beef. Now the French have banned blood donations from people who have visited Britain.
fields.body:
How does it feel to be an international pariah? Offer British blood to save the life of a Canadian, American or New Zealander and you will be politely turned down. To make matters worse, any of the citizens of these three countries who visited Britain for a six-month period between 1980 and the end of 1996 are also banned from giving blood.

The reason is that Britain's national dish is tainted. Visitors from the former colonies are certain to have wanted to sample the delights of roast beef and yorkshire pudding. As a result, so the blood-donor agencies of these countries have decided, their citizens might be infected with the "British disease" of new variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, the human equivalent of mad cow disease. These visitors may already have unwittingly sentenced themselves to an early death from this terrible disease by visiting Britain and they do not want them to pass it on to fellow citizens back home in their pints of blood. Now the French, who claim their would not eat our beef anyway, are anxious to rub salt in the wounds by banning any of their citizens, who have so much as set foot in Britain in the same period, from giving blood.

A visitor from outer space might be forgiven for avoiding Britain as a place of pestilence.

Let's examine the evidence for our quarantine as unclean inhabitants of an offshore island. So far there have been 52 victims of the human variant of this disease (known as nvCJD). It is a crippling and always fatal disease that rots the brain and reduces people to cabbages. The tragedy is that it strikes mostly at teenagers and young adults; middle-aged parents face watching their children die slowly and painfully.

The problem is that the scientists do not know where it will all end. They believe that the incubation period is so long that eventually 400,000 of us may die of it - although this is an absolute upper estimate it is a terrifying possibility. Who will live and who will die no one knows, the only certainty is that anyone who ate beef in the 15 years or so after the early 80s might get the disease.

It has taken a long time for the awfulness of this all this to sink in. From the first it was clear that the scandal had wrecked an export industry. It has also made Britain a byword for disgraceful farming practices, cutting corners to make a fast buck by turning cows into cannibals.

It was some time before we realised that this in turn made our blood contaminated - or at least potentially so. In 1998 the UK expert advisory committee said there was a theoretical chance that transmission could come from infected blood. This would be through the white blood cells. As a result all white blood cells were removed from all donated blood in the UK. As a further precaution all plasma used for the manufacture of blood products, like the factor VIII, used as a clotting agent by haemophiliacs, is imported from abroad.

The shame of all this was compounded last year when our former colonies began to single out their own citizens who had visited the mother country as potentially unclean too - and now the old enemy, the French, have joined in.

The department of health in London is taking a balanced view. There was no evidence that nvCJD had ever been transmitted in human blood. The two cases of nvCJD in France has almost certainly come from French people eating cattle exported from Britain which were already carrying the disease.

The action of the four countries in banning British blood is understandable. After all there is the terrible memory of the tainted blood scandal of the 80s when 1,200 haemophiliacs were infected with HIV from imported human plasma products and 600 died. Three thousand got hepatitis C. In France this is currently an emotive issue, because a former prime minister and two other ministers were tried last year for failing to prevent the use of Aids-infected blood by the French health service in the 80s. The current crop of politicians does not want to risk the same with CJD-contaminated blood.

The problem for the French is that up to 22% of their blood donors have visited Britain in the last 15 years and they are already critically short of supplies in the hospital service. The risk of losing lives because of shortage of blood in hospitals is greater than the chance of getting nvCJD. But the stigma of Britons being classed as unclean remains.

The long running CJD inquiry is still to report and the evidence of the appalling behaviour of the ministry of agriculture in trying to cover it all up still haunts us. Richard Packer, permanent secretary at MAFF, has just taken early retirement. It may be coincidence but at the same time new, unproven, suggestions have emerged that cattle brain may have been used as a substitute for egg white in mayonnaise, and Mr Packer was accused of turning a blind eye to the scandal at late as 1995 - ignoring the fact that six years after high-risk bovine offal was banned from sale some of it was still reaching the food chain.

How long will it be before we can again be proud of having British blood coursing through our veins?

fields.headline: The best mimic scene
fields.standfirst: The Talented Mr Ripley
fields.trailText: The 1950s. Dickie Greenleaf (Jude Law) returns to his Italian villa to find his girlfriend Marge (Gwyneth Paltrow) having dinner with the mysterious Tom Ripley (Matt Damon). Having listened to Tom's apologies for showing up unannounced, Dickie turns to him, an inquisitive look on his face.
fields.body:
The 1950s. Dickie Greenleaf (Jude Law) returns to his Italian villa to find his girlfriend Marge (Gwyneth Paltrow) having dinner with the mysterious Tom Ripley (Matt Damon). Having listened to Tom's apologies for showing up unannounced, Dickie turns to him, an inquisitive look on his face.

"Can you mix a martini?"

Tom looks nonplussed.

"Sure", Tom replies hesitantly.

Dickie sighs loudly in disbelief, as Marge laughs and says:

"I'll make it."

She exits, at which point Dickie turns once more to Tom.

"Everyone should have one talent", he says. "What's yours?"

"Forging signatures. Telling lies. Impersonating practically anybody."

"That's three. Nobody should have more than one talent."

He looks Tom up and down.

"OK. Do an impression."

"Now?"

Dickie nods. Tom begins speaking in an uncanny approximation of Dickie's father's voice.

"My son's only talent is for cashing his allowance."

Dickie's jaw hangs open.

"That is too much! You made the hairs on my neck stand up."

He continues for a while, until Marge returns with the martinis.

"Marge," Dickie exclaims, "this is scary. You've got to hear this - meet my father."

See also: Down Among The Z Men, The Hard Way, Total Recall, Superman II, Mimic

Don't see also: Sommersby

Pointless trivia: While studying at Harvard, Matt Damon dated a medical student called Skylar Satenstein, whose name was then borrowed by Gus Van Sant for the character of Damon's girlfriend in Good Will Hunting; Satenstein is now married to Lars Ulrich, drummer of Metallica.

fields.headline: Stop these long tours
fields.trailText: The end of a Test series or tour is usually a moment of emptiness for the fan. It feels like only yesterday that the series began, and you know that tomorrow there will be a hole in your life where Ceefax page 341 or the desktop scoreboard used to be.
fields.body:
The end of a Test series or tour is usually a moment of emptiness for the fan. It feels like only yesterday that the series began, and you know that tomorrow there will be a hole in your life where Ceefax page 341 or the desktop scoreboard used to be.

Yesterday, as England's cricketers finally headed home, there was only relief. And it wasn't just the realisation that we won't have to listen to the Sky commentators any more. This tour was far too long.

For the management and the six players who were in both the Test and the one-day squad, it has been a four-month epic. Three of those players, Nasser Hussain, Darren Gough and Andy Caddick, have had far too much to do. Hussain's form, unnoticed by an adoring press corps, went to pieces by the end Ð he batted three times in Zimbabwe, and made six runs. And Gough was himself only in the one-day games. Caddick alone sustained his form throughout, and he is an oddity, the one player of today with the appetite of an Alec Bedser.

The other three players didn't have nearly enough to do. Alan Mullally missed more than half the Test series through injury. Gavin Hamilton went from first choice to utter outcast in the space of four days at the Wanderers, and Chris Read was neither seen nor heard until the one-dayers. There were mutterings about his attitude. If you had been sent on a business trip by your employer, and given nothing to do for three months but serve drinks, it is just possible that your attitude wouldn't have been perfect either.

Long tours are a glaring anachronism, a relic of the days when it took five weeks to get to anywhere else that played cricket. They survive simply because the game is so set in its ways. Make that the English game. The only long tours left that do not involve England are West Indies to South Africa (which has only happened once, and was such a disaster that it is unlikely to be repeated) and West Indies to Australia. But then the West Indies board is usually short of money, and no more famous for forward-thinking than our own dear ECB.

Long tours are soul-destroying and can be highly damaging to families. The leading cricket writers now go on about half of each England tour, reducing it to manageable proportions Ð eight weeks away, with wives or girlfriends flying out in the middle. David Gower, who has two small daughters, has become a global commuter, making four separate trips to Africa this winter. The players, of course, are even more likely than the media-men to have young families. Darren Gough hasn't seen his second son, Brennan, for four months. That's a sixth of Brennan's life so far. It's wretched for both of them, not to mention Mrs Gough.

Most cricketers are not exactly New Men, but then the system doesn't allow them to be. Jonty Rhodes is missing South Africa's tour of India at the moment on paternity leave, the first recorded example of such a thing in cricket. It should be the first of many.

England clearly should not have gone to Zimbabwe Ð they had just faced them in South Africa, and are about to meet again in England. Nor should they have played five Tests against South Africa. Four is quite enough. The administrators have a bias against four-Test series: England tend to play them only after hosting the World Cup, so we can expect the next one in about 2019. But as last summer's tussle with New Zealand showed, four Tests is almost as good as five for the spectator, and better from every other point of view.

The ECB have missed a trick as they step up to hosting seven Tests a summer. Their plan is to have one team for five Tests, another for two. It should have been four and three. Pakistan are coming for two Tests in 2001, as a support act for the Ashes, which is an insult to them and their many British fans. It leaves two five-Test slots vacant, in 2002 and 2003: one will doubtless go to South Africa, whose support here is passionate but small and itinerant Ð during the World Cup, it seemed to consist entirely of backpacking barpersons. It's almost as if Lord's is trying to right what it sees as the wrong of South Africa's long exclusion. Can someone tell it that that was actually a good thing?

The coming winters are more promising. Next year England go to Pakistan (after a 13-year gap) and Sri Lanka, for three Tests each. Those should be separate tours with a break at home in the middle, and players should be allowed to miss one or the other, as Graham Gooch did 13 years ago. The same goes for India and New Zealand the following winter. We don't need fewer tours Ð in fact when the Wisden World Championship becomes official, we will need slightly more. But we do need shorter ones.

Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com and Wisden Cricket Monthly

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.trailText:
Cheapskate... where to eat out for under £15

Caravan Serai , 50 Paddington Street, London W1. Tel: 0171-224 0954
fields.body:
Cheapskate... where to eat out for under £15

Caravan Serai , 50 Paddington Street, London W1. Tel: 0171-224 0954

London's first Afghan restaurant, established in 1975. Folk thought highly of it then. Devotees think highly of it now. It's nice to know that some things remain constant while all around is change, if not decay. There are generous helpings of ashak (leek stuffed with lamb and lentils), maushawa (yoghurt, chickpea and meatball soup) and mash pilaw (rice and lentils). The cooking has a flavour of India, Turkey and North Africa, and there is ample evidence of those countries' love of carpets, as well as Afghanistan's own, as interior decoration. Easy to eat for less than £15, lunch at £6.95 is a bargain.

Quick bites... where to eat out in under 15 minutes

De Gustibus, 53 Blandford Street, London W1. Tel: 0171-486 6608

Bakery, cafe, deli, all things to all people. Well, perhaps not quite. It's tiny, for a start, cheery, cluttered and cosy. Seats maybe 12. But then there's the queue out into the street come breakfast and lunch, and all for the bread and fillings or the short list of hot dishes. Nothing costs less than £1.25 or more than £4.25. The tortino - double-filled focaccia with mozzarella, vegetables and olives - is a megastar among sandwiches. Less a sandwich than a lunch in the hand. Other sarnies, savoury dishes and puddings are made with the same mad-cap enthusiasm. Chatty service. Fine coffee.

On the menu: seakale

What is it? Crambe maritima, a hardy perennial that grows wild on our shingle beaches. A long-lost vegetable, much loved by Victorians.

Loved for what? Its delicate young shoots which, when blanched under a forcing pot, are ivory white with delicate pink and yellow leaf curls at the top.

webTitle: Hollywood mogul Geffen savaged in new biography

fields.headline: Hollywood mogul Geffen savaged in new biography
fields.trailText: David Geffen, co-founder of DreamWorks, manipulated his way to becoming one of the most influential figures in showbusiness, according to a controversial new biography of Hollywood's richest man
fields.body:
David Geffen, co-founder of DreamWorks, manipulated his way to becoming one of the most influential figures in showbusiness, according to a controversial new biography of Hollywood's richest man.

The book, David Geffen: a Biography of New Hollywood, by Tom King, is said to have caused a panic not seen in America's entertainment capital since the revelations of the prostitute Heidi Fleiss.

King paints a portrait of a man driven to get to the top at almost any cost. "It became clear that Geffen would do or say almost anything to wangle introductions, build relationships and win clients," the book says.

Geffen, who launched the careers of the Eagles and Jackson Browne and whose Geffen record company launched the grunge band Nirvana, is estimated by Forbes magazine to be worth $2.7bn. He became a household name when he teamed up with Steven Spielberg and Jeffrey Katzenburg to form the DreamWorks studio in 1994.

A reporter with the Wall Street Journal, King was given unique access to Geffen's life, including interviews with many famous friends. Now the movie and music mogul is reported to be angry with the book as it includes a wealth of detail about Geffen's flamboyant sex life.

While trying to impress his new lover, Cher, Geffen managed to anger Phil Spector so much that the producer pulled a gun on him in his New York studio, the book claims. He is also said to have boasted to the film-makers Stephen Woolley and Neil Jordan about the male prostitute he had been having sex with on the night of the assassination of John Lennon, whom Geffen had signed to his record label.

King catalogues how Geffen tried to impress one young beau, Todd Mulzet, by getting him invited to the Oval Office on the night of Bill Clinton's surprise 48th birthday party. Geffen proceeded to give Mr Clinton a 45-minute lecture on spinning the press, and afterwards declared to Mulzet: "I did that for you. Imagine. Me, giving the president advice!"

One of the more persistent rumours surrounding the book's publication, however, has been scotched: there was no secret wedding between Geffen and Keanu Reeves.

webTitle: New curbs on right to jury trial

fields.headline: New curbs on right to jury trial
fields.standfirst: Straw's redrafted proposal would deny choice of crown court to a further 2,000 defendants a year
fields.trailText: A change by Jack Straw, the home secretary, to curb criticism of his courts shake-up legislation will lead to up to 2,000 a year more defendants being denied the right to choose a jury trial, it was confirmed last night.
fields.body:
A change by Jack Straw, the home secretary, to curb criticism of his courts shake-up legislation will lead to up to 2,000 a year more defendants being denied the right to choose a jury trial, it was confirmed last night.

Mr Straw announced the change when he unveiled his second bill to limit the right of defendants to choose a crown court trial in front of a jury.

A cross-party coalition in the House of Lords inflicted a crushing defeat on his first bill to introduce the change last month and 59 Labour MPs have already indicated that they object to the measure and want the whole question referred to an official government inquiry into the criminal justice system. It reports this summer.

The government has threatened to invoke the parliament act and overrule the Lords if they try to reject it again after it has gone through the Commons. The second reading of the new bill is likely to be within three weeks.

The home secretary's new mode of trial (number two) bill drops a requirement for magistrates to take account of the effect of a conviction on the reputation or livelihood of a defendant. Magistrates will also have to give reasons if they refuse to allow a case to be heard in the crown court.

The bill will take away from about 18,000 defendants the right to choose whether their case is heard in front of a jury in the crown court or in the magistrates court.

Most serious offences are automatically tried in front of a jury and most minor offences are heard by magistrates but there is a group of "middle-ranking" crimes, such as theft and burglary - most of which involve questions of personal honesty - in which defendants currently have a choice.

Mr Straw's critics had claimed that the "reputation and livelihood" test would lead to a two-tier system of justice whereby a middle-class bank manager with no previous convictions would automatically qualify for the more expensive jury trial while the homeless and unemployed would be restricted to the magistrates court.

The home secretary announced that he had dropped the test from the new bill and that instead magistrates will have to take into account the nature of the case, the circumstances of the offence and whether the punishment they have the power to impose is adequate to match the offence. The change means that he has decided to remove the injustice by denying the middle classes the right to choose jury trial as well.

The home office said the new bill would mean 14,000 fewer cases tried by the crown court each year which will save around £128m. This figure includes 2,000 more cases - as a result of the "concession" - than in the original estimate given for the bill that was killed by the House of Lords.

John Wadham, director of the civil rights group Liberty, said last night: "This bill is no better than the last. To avoid being seen to be creating a two-tier system of justice, the government have equalised downwards.

"The right to jury trial must not be eroded merely to save money."

Ann Widdecombe, shadow home secretary, accused Mr Straw of gross arrogance. "It is only five minutes since the Lords threw out this deeply flawed bill and here is the home secretary deciding to railroad it through the Commons," she said.

webTitle: La Vie Sur Terre opens African Film Festival

fields.headline: La Vie Sur Terre opens African Film Festival
fields.trailText: The award-winning La Vie Sur Terre (Life on Earth) is one of the highlights of the largest-ever African Film Festival opening in Britain today
fields.body:
The award-winning La Vie Sur Terre (Life on Earth), a film about a man who returns to his Mali village to visit his father on the eve of the millennium, is one of the highlights of the largest-ever African Film Festival opening in Britain today.

With funding from the European Commission, the Ford Foundation and the UK Government's Visiting Arts agency, Africa at the Pictures begins its journey around the country at the ICA by showcasing a selection of prize-winning films that display the diversity of African film-making.

The tour, organised by academic Keith Shiri, includes some of the best films from the first twenty years of the biennial Fespaco (Pan-African Film and Television) Festival, which is held in Ouagadougou, the capital of Burkina Faso in West Africa.

Films from Africa, particularly the Francophone countries, started to catch the attention of the European world in the late 1960s, but it was not until 1990 that the NFT held its first programme of African films. The organisers hope this yearÕs showcase will mean that a greater number of people are exposed to the continentÕs growing industry.

fields.headline: Lara quits as Windies captain
fields.trailText: Brian Lara was reported today to have quit as West Indies captain. BBC TV quoted a statement from Lara saying he had decided to step down after "moderate success and devastating failures."
fields.body:
Brian Lara was reported today to have quit as West Indies captain. BBC TV quoted a statement from Lara saying he had decided to step down after "moderate success and devastating failures."

Lara was first appointed captain in the 1996-97 season when Courtney Walsh was injured. He took over on a permanent basis for the home series against England in 1997-98. A successor has yet to be named for the upcoming series with Zimbabwe, with the first Test on March 16.

Lara said: "There is a need for me to withdraw from my present leadership position." Lara still holds the world record for the highest Test and first-class scores but a run of disastrous results under his captaincy made his position untenable.

The most recent blow was losing all five one-day internationals in New Zealand after a 2-0 Test-series defeat. After one of the one-day defeats Lara was said to be close to tears when he talked about "trying to salvage a legacy."

There had also been massive disappointment on the 1998-99 tour of South Africa. It began with a row between the players and the West Indies cricket board over pay and conditions, and ended in a humiliating 5-0 defeat in the Test series.

A home series with Australia last year finished 2-2 with Lara's supreme batting saving the day, but the trip to New Zealand looks to have been the final straw.

fields.headline: Greene's love poems fetch £20,700
fields.trailText: Greene's love poems fetch £20,700
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  Arts and Heritage Correspondent
fields.body:
A tiny booklet of poems, an agonisingly personal relic of the passionate, adulterous relationship which inspired Graham Greene's novel and the film The End of the Affair, was sold to a private collector yesterday for £20,700.

Collectors and dealers, spurred by the publicity for the film, vied for the poems, which Sotheby's expected to fetch no more than £10,000 to £15,000.

After Two Years was privately published in 1949 by Greene and his mistress, Catherine Walston. It was the sole publication of "the Rosaio Press" - the name taken from Greene's villa on the island of Anacapri, where the lovers spent passionate months together, causing anguish to their respective spouses.

The poems were published two years into the affair. One explains the title: "I have only two years to give/But they are yours." In fact the affair lasted 13 years, and it was described by Sotheby's books expert, Peter Selley, as "the love of his life".

The book sold yesterday is one of a handful surviv ing from the only edition of 25.

It was copy number three: number one was for Walston, number two for Greene himself. The third was a somewhat startling gift, inscribed by Greene to her sister, Bonte Duran: "For Bontie with great love from two of us, Graham." Whether she read the poems or heard him recite them is not recorded.

The numbered copies were intended for friends. It is believed most of the edition was destroyed.

The sale in London saw mainly private collectors competing with dealers to snap up all 70 Graham Greene lots, mostly at prices far above estimates. A first edition of the novel The End of the Affair, inscribed by Greene but slightly damaged, sold for £1,265, against a top estimate of £600.

Graham Greene met the American-born beauty at a party in 1946. He was already married and so was she, to the English socialist millionaire Harry Walston, who condoned her affairs but insisted she remain with him and their children.

Greene made no secret of the affair: his wife Vivien survives him, and spoke recently of her shock at coming home to find her husband and his lover waiting on the doorstep. She cooked them dinner and made them up a bed in the spare room.

Another lot was a first edition of A Gun For Sale, inscribed "For DG with very great love, Graham". DG was Dorothy Glover, a book illustrator, whose affair with Greene began when they shared a shelter in the blitz, when both were air raid wardens.

He described her to his wife as "one of the great loves of my life", but broke off the affair after meeting Walston.

The annual Sotheby's English literature and history sale contained many other rarities, including Ian Fleming's Goldeneye passport - used when the creator of James Bond was liaising with the American secret service on Operation Goldeneye.

That was a plan for naval intelligence to communicate through Gibraltar if Spain joined the war on Germany's side. The top estimate was £3,000.

After fierce competition between James Bond collectors and specialist dealers, it was sold to a private collector in the UK for £15,525.

One saw the whores recite

The thirty-two positions

Peter invented for the

body's delight.

But the thirty-third is

Between me and you.

(from After Two Years)

fields.headline: So long, Good Friday
fields.standfirst: Sheila Johnston on the scrapping of plans to reissue a classic thriller
fields.trailText: Sheila Johnston on the scrapping of plans to reissue a classic thriller
fields.body:
"You know, I was thinking," says the director John Mackenzie, with his characteristic sense of understatement, "The Long Good Friday... it has had a rather chequered history." Most people today won't recall the jinx which hovered over his movie, and which this week popped up again to dog its planned re-release.

The Long Good Friday has established itself as a benchmark for the London gangster movie. Both Mackenzie and Bob Hoskins have been enthusiastically supporting the film's imminent re-release. A few days ago, however, a cryptic press release announced that, "due to unforeseen circumstances", the movie, which was originally to be screened around the country, will now play for just seven days at the National Film Theatre in London.

This decision sees history repeating itself: 20 years ago, The Long Good Friday almost never saw the light of day. Commissioned by Lord Grade's company, Black Lion Films, it alarmed them on account of its violence and the prominent role played by the IRA. Hoskins's Cockney accent gave further cause for concern and, at one point, absurdly, his voice was redubbed by an actor from Wolverhampton. "Bob was about to sue them," Mackenzie recalls.

Eventually the film was rescued by Hand Made, the company formed by ex-Beatle George Harrison and his American manager, Denis O'Brien, which had already done a similar salvage operation when Monty Python's Life of Brian faced the axe. HandMade bought the rights to The Long Good Friday for £700,000 from a relieved Grade.

HandMade's film library was acquired last year by Equator, a film sales company hoping to move into production. It had initiated the current re-release of The Long Good Friday. So why suddenly withdraw it? Steve Turney, Equator's sales director, says that they had hoped to generate publicity for a planned sequel and that writer Barrie Keefe was hard at work on a new script. Alas, Turney said, things were not proceeding as planned: "With the success of Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels, everything made sense on paper. But things just don't happen as fast as we hope."

This news was greeted with some astonishment and not a little annoyance by Mackenzie. "That's ridiculous. I don't see how a sequel can be ready. It's only a pipe-dream at the moment. It'll be bloody years." Later he rings back to add that he had spoken to Keefe's agent who "was even more amazed than I was".

Hoskins, Keefe and Mackenzie had already tried many times to write a sequel, but had never come up with a concept. "There have been quite a few scripts, not bad ones, but they just weren't right," Hoskins says. "I even tried to write one."

Most people today won't recall the jinx which hovered over his movie, and which this week popped up again to dog its planned re-release. The Long Good Friday has established itself as a benchmark for the London gangster movie. Both Mackenzie and Bob Hoskins have been enthusiastically supporting the film's imminent re-release. A few days ago, however, a cryptic press release announced that, "due to unforeseen circumstances", the movie, which was originally to be screened around the country, will now play for just seven days at the National Film Theatre in London. This decision sees history repeating itself: 20 years ago, The Long Good Friday almost never saw the light of day. Commissioned by Lord Grade's company, Black Lion Films, it alarmed them on account of its violence and the prominent role played by the IRA. fields.headline: Home truths
fields.standfirst: The Dardenne brothers tell Jonathan Romney how the down-at-heel Belgian steel town they grew up in inspired their film Rosetta
fields.trailText: The Dardenne brothers tell Jonathan Romney how the down-at-heel Belgian steel town they grew up in inspired their film Rosetta
fields.body:
Seraing is a down-at-heel steel town that is effectively a suburb of Liège, in eastern Belgium. It has an unemployment rate of about 25%, and most of its smelting furnaces and rolling mills have closed down, although two chimneys on the banks of the Meuse still belch out sulphurous yellow fumes.

In the lower town, at the foot of a hill, conveyor belts and ramps hang over canyons of disused factory walls, and a drab red-light district glows with more of a chemical purple and blue. It's the last place on earth you'd expect to inspire great cinema; even Jean-Pierre and Luc Dardenne, who grew up and continue to work here, admit: "It's rather gloomy - not a fun place."

Yet against all odds, Seraing has inspired the Dardenne brothers for more than 20 years as film-makers, and most recently produced a world-class feature, the surprise outsider at Cannes last year. Their film Rosetta hit Cannes like an unaccustomed bombshell of real cinema. Its kinetic, morally tough, no-frills realism won not only the Palme d'Or, but a shared best actress prize for Emilie Dequenne, aged 17 when she won the award in May last year, as a taciturn girl living on a campsite with an alcoholic mother, and doggedly battling through a succession of no-hope jobs.

It seems the ultimate Cannes fairy tale, and with a new brotherly duo for the press to file alongside the Coens, Tavianis, Farrellys, Wachowskis et al. But the Dardennes are no fresh-faced debutants. They are in their mid- to late 40s and have been making films since the 70s, although the world only heard of them four years ago when their feature La Promesse (The Promise) got them on the festival circuit for the first time.

But it's no accident they have been Belgium's best-kept secret: they're none too anxious to sell themselves. Jean-Pierre, the older brother, says of the post-Cannes press attention, "I find it all a bit pornographic. I don't like talking that much, explaining why I do this, why I do that - it goes against my nature." Both confess they tend to be afflicted by doubt and find it emotionally difficult to get films made.

The brothers have an office in a stately, austere building by the river in central Liège. It's home to two companies, their feature outlet, Les Films du Fleuve, and Dérives, their video workshop, which produces half a dozen documentaries a year by other film-makers. Until recently, Jean-Pierre ran an audio-visual workshop at Liège university, while Luc still teaches screenwriting in Brussels, where he lives. It's a tight family set-up: Jean-Pierre's wife is also their set photographer.

The general assumption with siblings in film - especially if they're this reclusive - is that they must be desperately weird, but the Dardennes seem as normal as you can get. Luc is chattier, Jean-Pierre more solemn, and they're a little spiky with each other. When I arrive, Luc, the more dapper of the pair, is grumbling about a doctor's appointment he thinks he might miss, and there's a testy altercation over one of my questions. "No, what he's saying..." Luc begins to explain. "No, I understand what he's saying," mutters the burlier Jean-Pierre, who has a slight look of Ronnie Biggs. But they muster up sandwiches and coffee, and are genial as can be.

When they began making films, their work was strictly a local concern. Although neither brother ever belonged to a political party, they started making videos as a form of direct action. "We didn't think of ourselves as film-makers," Luc says. "We went to local housing estates, strikes, factories, trying to do political work, making interventions as film-makers. We thought: people don't know each other, no one knows who's living next to them, so we'll make portraits of people and show them on Sundays in a garage or a cafe. People would see them and think, 'Oh look, there's old what's-his-name.' We tried to form bonds between people."

In a sense, they're still making community portraits. Rosetta and its predecessor, La Promesse - about a teenage boy whose slum landlord father ruthlessly exploits illegal immigrants - have the hardened edge of reality about them. The term "gritty" has never been more apposite, but the Dardennes insist they aim for realism, not naturalism. "Naturalism," Jean-Pierre explains, "is something picturesque, like a historical TV mini-series - it's when you pile on the details. We call our cinema 'realism' because it's inspired by the everyday world we live in."

"Our realism," says Luc, "is stripped down to the bone. We try and take away as much as we can and keep what's really significant." Everything comes directly from Seraing, Luc says. "When we're writing, we immediately see the streets, the houses, the people - even if they don't exist any more, because much of the town has disappeared. It's a sort of womb for us - we like to dive back into it when we're working on a character."

They're not in a hurry to turn their attention to the outside world. "It might seem weird, but we're not great travellers," Jean-Pierre admits. Luc adds, "We need a place where we can sweat it out - a sort of sauna. If we were anywhere else, we'd have to recreate that sort of closed space for ourselves." But, Jean-Pierre speculates, "it could be the Seraing in our heads doesn't actually have that much to do with the real one. We grew up here so the place inhabits us, in a way."

The brothers are no spoilt bourgeois scions moonlighting with tales of the hard-scrabble life. Sons of a factory draughtsman, they've struggled throughout their career. Originally working for theatre and film director Armand Gatti, they were inspired by him to do their own work; and to raise money for their first equipment, both worked as labourers on a nuclear plant. For years, they were absolute outsiders: when I ask how they were seen by other Belgian directors, they reply, "We weren't."

Later, when their second fiction feature was a flop, they ran up enormous debts, which took years to pay off. Even a Palme d'Or, they emphasise, hardly means they're raking it in, especially since they're slow workers and it may be a long time before they complete their next film. Cannes success has, however, made a difference in other ways: received by both public and media as a national triumph, Rosetta also inspired the passing of a bill, known as the "Plan Rosetta", that aims to protect the interests of young, low-paid workers.

In the 80s, the brothers clocked up several documentaries, on topics ranging from the Walloon resistance movement to Polish emigration. But their start in fiction was difficult. They started tentatively by adapting a play, Falsch, in 1986. The follow-up, Je Pense à Vous, six years later, about a steelworker who loses his job, was a disaster - and not only commercially.

They were out of their depth, they admit. "We're always stressed when we shoot, and that can be good, but on that film, it was negative stress. We were afraid of our own fear." They still sound shell-shocked talking about it. They didn't know their own minds, and ended up being dominated by their director of photography. "We learned that what happens on set is a power struggle," says Jean-Pierre. "If they know you're afraid, you're screwed."

Left with nothing to lose, they realised they needed to be in charge on La Promesse. "Deciding that we'd be responsible for the work every day, from eight in the morning to six at night, it got us moving on our own track." Putting together a team they were comfortable with, they returned to the way they'd started out, with Jean-Pierre supervising photography and editing and Luc overseeing the sound.

The brothers like the viewer to be part of the collaborative process. Theirs is not a realism that lays down the law and shows you how the world is: you have to find your own way in it. Hence the telegraphic, sketchy nature of their narratives, which let us work out for ourselves who these characters are and where they've been. "We're interested in telling stories that happen in the present, and the backstory is something the viewer constructs. If you put it there on the screen, the present becomes nothing more than the consequence of the past. But because certain things stay in the shadows, you feel things are happening in the present - you have to have shadow to have light."

The Dardennes' latter features are exciting, athletic films in which space feels like an obstacle course to be negotiated at some peril - the treacherous building sites of La Promesse, the mud-steeped, inhospitable trailer park where Rosetta lives. The films' ragged feel makes it seem as if they fell into shape by accident, but the brothers are sticklers for working out timing and positioning. On Rosetta, they even devised a system of poking the actors with rods to nudge them into place. You clearly need to be in shape to make a film like Rosetta, set in inclement weather with key scenes by a filthy lake.

The brothers crack up laughing, thinking of technicians coming a cropper during fast manoeuvres: "There were a few casualties." Most notable is the final scene, a marathon five-minute single take, in which Emilie Dequenne struggles with a hefty gas canister, herself apparently at physical breaking point. "We did let out five kilos of gas - it weighed 13 kilos rather than 18."

Dequenne was selected for more than her ability to heave canisters. Her performance, exuding traumatically repressed fury, absolutely merits the Cannes award. An unknown who had done some local theatre and taken elocution lessons, Dequenne was chosen from 300 applicants.

The brothers were amused by her letter - "wildly pretentious", they say, still smiling at her chutzpah - but immediately knew they had their Rosetta when she acted out a chunk of the script. The performance is all the more astounding in that Dequenne clearly isn't the film's stubbornly uncommunicative feral child, but - when I briefly met her last year - an articulate and rather glamorous young woman who clearly has her showbiz future sorted out. She's now living in Paris and due to appear in her first costume drama.

After the interview, Luc returns to Brussels, while Jean-Pierre takes me to Seraing to show me one of their key locations - a shabby, grey bus depot where Rosetta works at a waffle van. There's not much to see - just a boarded-up pizza restaurant tucked away beneath a crumbling network of brutalist flyovers, all looking even smaller and dingier than it does on screen.

Further into Seraing, Jean-Pierre points out a row of shops. Rosetta walked up the street, he explains, and Igor, hero of La Promesse, walked down it: they were just shot from different angles. A portly character in a mouldy-looking fur cap emerges from a nearby house. Jean-Pierre waits till he's gone, then explains that he was the original model for the slum landlord in La Promesse.

Seraing wouldn't seem to be the most fertile terrain for a filmic fictional world, yet the Dardennes seem to have teased their entire imaginative universe out of it. There are, as they say, a million stories in the naked city - and cities don't come any more naked than this.

fields.headline: Hate and war
fields.standfirst: In his first British interview in 20 years, Oscar-winning film-maker Peter Watkins talks to Peter Lennon about the banning of The War Game, the corruption of television, and his new drama set during the Paris Commune
fields.trailText: In his first British interview in 20 years, Oscar-winning film-maker Peter Watkins talks to Peter Lennon about the banning of The War Game, the corruption of television, and his new drama set during the Paris Commune
fields.body:
At 10am, no more than a few score of us gathered in a modest cinema, grandly named Le Méliès in Montreuil, one of those chill eastern suburbs of Paris where workers have won the right to live in cheerless concrete batteries and socialise in malls where environmental wretchedness is the architectural endowment.

Actors, crew and some visitors were going to sit for five hours 45 minutes (bring your own sandwiches) to see a film called La Commune, in which 220 people from this and other workers' areas of Paris re-enact an experience of their forebears: the socialist Commune uprising of 1871, a nadir in French history.

In the wake of the disastrous Franco-Prussian war, following three months of fierce defiance, of heady aspirations for justice and democracy, months of solidarity and pitiful bungling, government troops assailed the barricades and in one "semaine sanglante" slaughtered, street by street, more than 30,000 of their fellow countrymen and women, and children over 14. It was worse than anything in the Terror of 1793, so persistently chronicled by historians. Even today, the French education curriculum skates evasively over this event.

The energy, conviction and skill with which the players of La Commune perform is startling; few had any previous acting experience. So genuine is the force of their passion that at moments you feel they might be about to erupt and carry the revolt live into the auditorium.

The director is Peter Watkins, outlawed genius, accomplishing again what he achieved decades ago in Culloden and The War Game: giving a demonstration of what can be achieved when programme makers are willing to use the public as creative participants, rather than passive viewers. The only director you can compare with Watkins's working methods is Peter Brook, also exiled by negligence and resentment. In both cases, the contribution from actors is creatively nurtured, but there is never any doubt that the outcome has been forged in an individual furnace. The project was backed by funds from a number of sources, notably Sept Arte and the French Centre du Cinema.

La Commune, while pillorying oppression (the Parisian working-class were under martial law for the following five years), also contains direct criticism of media manipulation. The events are "covered" by national television as if it existed at the time: once again a fastidious newscaster tells the public what is deemed desirable for it to know and in moments of crisis turns to the obligatory pundit for a supposedly civilised analysis. (Watkins put ads in the conservative Le Figaro to find people willing to give the "royalist" view of La Commune - and came up with, as splendid royalist stalwart, historian François Foucart.)

Neither does Watkins overlook left-wing oppression within the Commune; his radio reporters behind the barricade get into a dispute in reporting the banning of one of the insurgent newspapers which became too critical of the movement. Ironically the paper banned was... La Commune.

Media manipulation and the abuse of television power are issues which have preoccupied Watkins since the banning of The War Game by the BBC in 1965. (It was eventually shown in 1985, to Watkins's indignation, marking the 40th anniversary of the Hiroshima bomb.) For 30 years, he has lectured from Australia to the US to Scandinavia on this theme. Outlawed is the appropriate word to describe the status of one of Britain's most talented film-makers, working in exile now for over 40 years.

Watkins's crime was that he not only fell foul of the BBC but, he felt at the time, the defence establishment. We now know that, from 1954, subsequent Tory and Labour administrations were in agreement that the government would "retain control of the manner in which the effect of nuclear weapons were made known to the public". The BBC declared its duty not to frighten the old or very young - thereby committing itself (ironically during its most liberal period under Hugh Carleton Greene), to arms race censorship.

Watkins's mistake was to be inflexibly principled; he carried his fight against the BBC - for whom he made the film - around the world and became regarded as unemployable by any television institution. After being deprived of its TV showing, The War Game was released as a feature film instead in the 60s. But in those years the image of Watkins as a paranoid drifter, hopelessly incapable of mature collaboration, was created and perpetuated by the the media. He moved to Scandinavia and now lives in Lithuania with his second wife.

But how is it that a supposedly constitutionally disobliging film-maker can persuade 220 foreigners to work their guts out for months, rehearsing and performing in absurdly cramped conditions? La Commune was shot in the cramped Armand Gatti workshop at Montreuil, site of film pioneer Georges Méliès's original studio.

And how did this supposedly rebarbative creature manage so successfully in the past with a Norwegian cast and crew (as he did for Edvard Munch in the mid-1970s). Nowadays, silence (used wonderfully in Munch) is despised; contemplativeness outlawed. The result is that museums have become one of the rare places where you can see truly responsible or artistic work - the Musée d'Orsay in Paris is La Commune's final destination.

Patrick Murphy, a British academic who is co-authoring with John Cook a biography of Watkins to be published next year by Manchester University Press, frequently watched Watkins at work on La Commune. "They all work in complete unity with him," Murphy said. "Cast and crew are for him and he is for them.

"He has a remarkable ability to communicate with the cast. He deals on a very personal level; he knows every one of them, has respect for them and this comes back through them to him. He is able to raise their awareness of the actors to a remarkably intense degree. Watkins's casts do not act in the normal sense of the word - they become. It is a remarkable experience to see him at work. This explains how he got those performances from the people in Culloden and The War Game."

So where is the problem for television? Is it that ordinary people have respect for integrity, however uncomfortably inflexible, and that institutions - particularly TV, in recent years corrupting itself at vertiginous speed - simply cannot afford it?

The BBC washed its hands of The War Game and, in a move which would rid it of responsibility but allow it to maintain that there was no real "ban", gave the film to the BFI. But when The War Game was nominated for an Oscar (winning the best feature length documentary award of 1967, although it only looked like a documentary), the BBC did something which would have made even Pilate blush.

Nine years after the banning, revenge still dripped from every corporate word.

At one point he made it clear that, even aged 65, exile was still painful for him.

Despite two years of work, the Swedish Film Institute pulled the plug on his almost-complete Strindberg. When the BFI gave it a single showing some years ago, they refused to introduce him to the audience. Contrary to its usual practice, the Halliwell guide makes no mention of the Oscar for The War Game in the 70s and 80s editions of either the Television or Film Companions. It's enough to make you paranoid.

Watkins admits that he is "a product of the British educational system" - educated at Brecon, a small public school in Wales, although his family is English. "But, thank God, I had no university education. Instead I went to drama school."

There is an extraordinary consistency in his development. While doing military service ("I did not intend to point my rifle at a human being") at Canterbury, he made his first film, Forgotten Faces, a 20-minute model of what was to come. He recreated the Budapest uprising in the back streets of Canterbury, with locals and a couple of Hungarians. It won him the top Amateur Ciné Camera Award ("A very nice object depicting a hand-cranked camera.") This got him a job as PA and then programme-maker at the BBC.

A few years later he was defiantly going around the world showing The War Game in schools, colleges, public meetings.

"But you did not have copyright," I said, "How did you get a print?"

"I don't play the game entirely by the rules of the BBC establishment," he said. "What could the BBC do - send in the police in Australia or America? They were too embarrassed to deal with me physically."

There is a glimpse here of why television companies find him intimidating.

But Watkins insists that the BBC "must not be made an Aunt Sally". CBS, NBC, all the big television institutions are equally at fault, as is "so-called community television".

"The discussion about my position must be in a broader context," he said. "Not just about somebody who produced a film on nuclear weapons which was squashed. Basically I am someone who has been working for 30 years to help shift the power balance between public and TV. The crisis is so severe in television."

"On the basis of what?"

"Everything."

"Financial? Political?..."

"Go on," he said, his smile getting tighter. "Any word you care to use."

"Cultural?"

"Creative?" he suggested. "Moral?"

"I have no doubt," Watkins continued, "that had TV taken an alternative direction during the 1960s and 1970s and worked in a more open way, global society today would be vastly more humane and just."

His thesis, which few honest citizens can quarrel with, is that there has been an "accumulation of global media power with no accountability that is not only not being challenged but is not even being debated".

"Dennis Potter is dead," he concludes. "The people who were once able to work critically within the media have been marginalised."

fields.headline: Low budget, high fidelity
fields.standfirst: Forget mega-buck Hollywood movies, says Mike Figgis. For great cinema, go see a clutch of new, inventive, low-budget films
fields.trailText: Forget mega-buck Hollywood movies, says Mike Figgis. For great cinema, go see a clutch of new, inventive, low-budget films
fields.body:
Show Me Love is a really terrific film from Sweden which has outgrossed all the US competition, including Titanic, in Scandinavia. Like Festen (shot entirely on a domestic digital video camera) it is part of a refreshing re-emergence of Scandinavia. It is not a Dogme film, though. It was shot on Super 16mm with a small budget and lots of inexperienced teenage actors and it really crackles with life and energy. As such it falls into a genre of Swedish youth movies. The plot is very simple and not particularly original except that here two teenage girls are in love with each other rather than the conventional boy and girl stuff.

Both this film and Festen are better than any other film I have seen in recent years. They are certainly better than anything in the Oscars this year and last year. On every level of film excellence - writing, acting, directing, cinematography and editing - they were superior to those big overblown films with their overblown vistas and production values and over-sentimentalised morals. I urge everyone who likes good film-making to go and see this film. Like I said, it's just my opinion that this is a good film, but I am a film-maker fascinated by the emergence of small films such as The Blair Witch Project and the Dogme films and my own efforts over the last six years.

I prefer small films and rarely get excited by big, expensive films. I feel shut out of big films, as if I am not being asked to participate in the event. It would be true to say that I feel the same about big theatre and big music. There comes a point where you know you are being manipulated by tricks rather than connecting with emotions and ideas and truths. It is much harder to tell the truth to a lot of people than a few. Glenn Gould retreated into the recording studio rather than play the big concert halls. It is a bald fact that bigger means more expensive to produce - as soon as you cross that line, you have to make compromises.

It is very difficult to sell foreign-language films in America and Britain. Audiences are not used to making that much effort because they have become accustomed to the idea that a film is there to entertain them and that their role is essentially passive. What a sad state of affairs that is. Film is something that can be so involving.

I was in LA when Show Me Love was released. I do not know a single person who went to see the film despite some good reviews and I think it got stuck in the gay film circuit. I hope the same thing does not happen in Britain. I wonder how many prints have been struck. I wonder how much they will spend on advertising.

My last released film, The Loss of Sexual Innocence, has two prints for the entire UK, no poster and managed to hang on in two cinemas in London for a couple of weeks before setting off on a tour of the rest of the UK. Reviews were either terrible or very good. The film took 17 years to make it to the screen and involved complex deals with foreign distributors to get its relatively small budget together.

The same was true of my next film, Miss Julie. Neither film has any British money behind it. A healthy revolution is taking place and I'm pleased to have been a small part of it. I've been urging the use of 16mm for some years now and have just shot a feature on video, so I am aware of the problems that exist within the industry. The biggest challenge now is not shooting the film for a small budget, but getting it seen, getting distribution.

The problem is the studio system. And it isn't possible to talk about these new, interesting, smaller films without acknowledging this context that all films still have to function within. There is no conspiracy, nothing as smart as that. It's just that the studio system is a vast pyramid that has executives at the top and beneath them thousands of film people who deal with the plethora of junk that comes with a studio film.

Vast rental houses provide equipment to make the films. Very expensive stuff: cranes and Steadicams and gadgets by the thousand. Every year they make this equipment even more complex. And if you make a studio film, you should be using this stuff. In the film business, which is male-dominated, there is a macho attitude about equipment. Many times I have heard directors talk about the fact that they like to make commercials because they get to use all the new equipment. Consequently the style of film-making came to be influenced by the style of commercials. Many British directors have made their mark this way.

After Leaving Las Vegas came out, I heard on the grapevine that the camera rental companies were pissed off because new film-makers wanted to try Super 16 cameras and they had invested in 35mm. People make such a good living in this business that the idea of shooting a low-budget film because you want to is heresy.

But the biggest problem with studio films is that they are not good enough any more. And the reason they are not good enough is because they cannot trust the individual vision of the film-maker. There is simply too much money at stake. An interesting date is the day Fatal Attraction was tested in front of an invited audience. As a result of that test the ending was re-shot and the film was a huge hit. This proved... whatever the studio wanted it to prove. The theory now is that any film can be fixed by spending money on it. And very few execs will have the courage to back a film that is not right in the middle of the taste-buds of an average audience. It is far simpler to say no than to say yes to an idea.

I will not labour the point here but it is impossible to talk about the emergence of the new, smaller, cheaper cinema without putting it into the context of the studio system. All the fat and waste of the studios is dragging down the art of story-telling for obvious reasons. It is quite natural, therefore that groups of film-makers with good ideas might want to do it a different way, a way that gives them some freedom and control. But the real revolution has to be a reappraisal of the way in which films are distributed. British cinema is saturated by the American product and it is very difficult to hold a cinema for more than a couple of weeks with a small film. It would be interesting to know how the Swedes managed to do so well with Show Me Love.

There is much interest in the Dogme movement. Most actors and younger directors have been influenced by it and everyone talks of wanting to do it Dogme style. This will inevitably produce a lot of bad films, but that is OK. But Dogme is also in danger of becoming a semi-religious cult. There is nothing like a set of rules to get everyone excited.

My impression is that Lars von Trier and his mates did it as a bit of a serious joke, never thinking that it would take hold of the aspiring film-makers' imagination in the way that it has. My sense is that they wanted to make films with a strong individualism. There is nothing new in any of this. The French new wave, British 60s cinema, Cassavetes and Pennebaker, Ken Loach have consistently produced fine cinema. But they were considered to be on the fringe and when a small film had a success it was never seen as an indication of public taste changing, merely as a one-off. The problem always came back to distribution, or lack of it.

Add to this the way films are reviewed. With the exception of this publication and perhaps one or two others, a film such as Festen or Show Me Love will not get much notice. Even a really bad review of an American studio film will get a main photo and first place on the film review page.

Why is this? It's surely not a conspiracy, but the fact is that we get most of our information about new films from newspapers and magazines, which must compete in a free market, and most of the time they opt for a generic product. Film and sport stars and supermodels all rate the same. All that is about to change. The days of critics as we know them are numbered. The internet will offer a better choice - yet another aspect of the digital revolution that very few of us saw coming: their job function is no longer secure.

The advent of the digital video camera is going to have such a far-reaching effect on the film business. I've been in LA for the last month and I am very aware of how nervous the studio people are. Job security is a huge issue. The idea that all those big machines and trucks and equipment may suddenly be out of date is deeply worrying to many of them. There is much talk about loss of quality, and the erosion of standards, and how film is such a complex and deeply complicated business that it can't be entrusted to any old Tom, Dick or Harry.

But the truth is that it is no longer that difficult to make a film. One cheap camera and a laptop will get you there. This will open the doors to so many great artists who would certainly have been denied the opportunity five years ago. Film has been such an elite occupation for so long, it is going to be very difficult for some of the old guard to deal with this influx of lower-caste geniuses. But it is far too important a medium to allow it to continue in this tired fashion. Film-making belongs to the people and it is high time they took it back from the bankers.

 Show Me Love is released on March 3.

 Mike Figgis is finishing Timecode 2000.

Film and sport stars and supermodels all rate the same. All that is about to change. The days of critics as we know them are numbered.
