fields.headline: Chillin' with Cube
fields.standfirst: Self-styled Nigga Ya Love To Hate Ice Cube stars in the upcoming Three Kings, and has written and produced his own film, Next Friday. Danny Leigh talks to him about making it in the mainstream
fields.trailText: Self-styled Nigga Ya Love To Hate Ice Cube stars in the upcoming Three Kings, and has written and produced his own film, Next Friday. Danny Leigh talks to him about making it in the mainstream
fields.body:
En route to Ice Cube's hotel, I had his 1992 album The Predator on my Walkman. It made a strange accompaniment to the stroll down Park Lane. Then again, Ice Cube records weren't made for trips to the Dorchester. They were made for Compton, Inglewood, Long Beach and South Central. And, much to the chagrin of countless suburban (read white) US parents, for well-appointed teenage bedrooms from Maine to the Pacific.

Because Ice Cube records were made by the self-styled Nigga Ya Love To Hate, founder member of seminal gangsta rappers Niggaz Wit' Attitude, whose solo career later chronicled a decade of crisis for urban (read black) America; a decade of Rodney King, LA riots, gangs, crack and OJ Simpson. But they were also made by the affable 30-year-old film star and entrepreneur sitting opposite me, sipping Evian in a PR suite while a make-up artist hovers outside ("just a little powder, man"). With two movies and an NWA reunion on the way, Ice Cube has business to discuss.

In fact, he's barely shaken hands before he's on to his role in Three Kings, indie luminary David O Russell's inspired account of a gaggle of US troops causing havoc amid the detritus of the Gulf War. Stretching out in his seat, he admits his involvement owed less to his enthusiasm for Russell's previous films, Spanking the Monkey and Flirting With Disaster (neither of which he's seen), than for sharing agents with co-star George Clooney. "And even then," he explains, "I wasn't sure about it. Wasn't sure at all. Because it's offbeat, it's not your typical... movie. But once David O Russell explained what he wanted to make then, yeah, I was cool with it."

It's hardly surprising: the stylish absurdity of Three Kings provides him with easily his best screen vehicle since his debut, John Singleton's mordant 1989 gang drama, Boyz N The Hood (although, to be honest, the likes of Anaconda don't offer much competition). The only irony comes from his playing a grunt. After all, when George Bush was dropping smart bombs on Baghdad, Ice Cube was Amerikkka's Most Wanted; the title of his first solo album proved prophetic when his name subsequently appeared on a far-right death list.

He beams serenely at the memory. "You know, it's funny, 'cause if you asked me back in '91 would I ever be in a movie as a soldier, a US soldier, I'd have said get the hell out of here. Hell no! But that's what I like about the film - we showed there were a lot of people on both sides who really didn't want to be there."

Indeed, other than its freewheeling comic swagger, Three Kings' most startling aspect is its willingness to point the finger at both Saddam and the White House. Presumably that cold-eyed pragmatism appealed to him? "Oh yeah," he responds. "Of course. I love any time you can enlighten people to mistakes, that's how I started my career. It definitely turned me on. Plus I like the interaction of the soldiers and the Shi'ite Muslims."

As he's raised the subject, I ask whether - having converted in the early 90s - he's still Muslim himself. "Yeah. Oh yeah." And still involved with the Nation of Islam, the militant faction he once called "the best place for any young black male"? This time he hesitates. "Ah, when you say involved with the Nation, it's tricky. I never was in the Nation of Islam... I mean, what I call myself is a natural Muslim, 'cause it's just me and God. You know, going to the mosque, the ritual and the tradition, it's just not in me to do. So I don't do it."

Although he's entirely gracious about it, something in his manner suggests now isn't the time to go into the small print of his relationship with Islam. Instead, we turn to his status as an ascendant multimedia potentate. Describing his movie career as "opportunistic", he happily admits the film gigs are part of a bigger game plan. For example, having seen his 1998 directorial debut - the ambitious if confused The Players Club - perform disappointingly, a follow-up depends on "getting my name a little bigger through acting, so next time I direct, it'll come out a little stronger".

Then there's Cubevision, the film production company recently established to accessorise his existing music set-up, Street Knowledge. "Cubevision is there to develop the shit that other people are shaky on," he muses. "Raw shit, ideas from the street. When people see the Cubevision logo, they should know it's something good, something worth checking out."

What it also does, of course, is grant him autonomy from the studios. Prior to The Players Club, three of his pitches were unceremoniously bounced around Hollywood's executive suites before disappearing over the horizon. He nods enthusiastically.

"And now I would never rely on the studio system. Because their system is too goddamn fickle. Executives get fired, executives get hired, and you don't even know if your guy is gonna be there when the movie's done. Or is another cat gonna come in and say 'What? I don't want this'? Man, I went through that, and I vowed I'd never do it again. That's why I'm intent on bringing my own shit into the movie house."

Which leads on to Next Friday (the sequel, unsurprisingly, to 1995's Friday), his other imminent release, in which he takes on the triple-header role of producer, screenwriter and star. It's interesting for three reasons. The first lies in the film's temperament: a relentlessly crass but wholly congenial comedy - wherein the leading man returns as uber-homie Craig, now ensconced in the SoCal suburbs - whose prevailing themes (family is good, bullies get their comeuppance) could have come straight out of the Eisenhower 1950s.

It may be enveloped in a haze of blunt smoke, but that's about its only connection with the casually atavistic world of Boyz N The Hood. "Well," he shrugs, "that's the many faces of Ice Cube. I mean, people know me as one way, hardcore, a bad motherfucker, and that's cool. But the fans wanted this and you got to give the fans what they want. Or you're just playing into the hands of the doubters."

The second interesting feature of the film, meanwhile, is its status as the "surprise" box office hit of 2000 thus far: a surprise because precious few movies become America's biggest draw with as little media hubbub as Next Friday. What attention it did receive largely focused on an opening weekend shooting at the Rolling Hills Plaza, Torrance, California.

Understandably, Ice Cube, or O'Shea Jackson as he once was, allows himself a sly smile at the thought of the entertainment machine's wrongfooting by his film. "Right, 'cause they thought it was just a lightweight black comedy. And I knew that, both from the outside and from inside the studio. They thought, Oh, here's this nice little black movie, we'll give him a few screens and see what it do. And to come out like it did and make $19m first weekend, I mean that ain't no fuckin' joke, man. So now the business know all about my nice little black movie."

And the third interesting thing about Next Friday? Well, that's on the soundtrack: a classic slab of bellicose West Coast hip-hop, it's called Chin Check and it marks the return of NWA, the hugely influential group Ice Cube quit in 1989 over an exponentially bitter business dispute; without him, NWA stumbled to a halt two years and one shoddy album later.

Now, however, a summer stadium tour and more recording await, with the peerlessly nasal Snoop Doggy Dogg drafted in to replace the late Eazy E. Rumours of Eminem's involvement prove exaggerated, which sadly ends the idea of a white kid from Detroit becoming a Nigga Wit' Attitude.

Strangely, when I mention the song, he's almost apologetic, declaring it to have been recorded in a hurry and, moreover, "just an appetiser". Then the self-assurance re-enters his voice: " 'Cause everyone knows that the album's gonna be the big record."

It will, both because of the nostalgia invoked by the memory of their brutally anthemic debut, Straight Outta Compton, and their post-split legacy (chiefly the solo work of Cube and fellow member Dr Dre, inspiration for rap's pre-eminent late 90s G-Funk sound). When he refers to his group as"hip-hop royalty", it doesn't come across as merely the hyperbole of a man with something to sell.

But why, when none of the interested parties can need the money, get back together now? "We were tired of talking about it," comes the response. "For years, every time we'd see each other we'd be like 'You know what we should do? You know what we should do? We should do an NWA record.' So finally it gets to the point where it's like, 'OK, meet me at the studio on Wednesday.' "

It all sounds so simple. Yet he must be aware there's a lot of baggage involved: the shadow cast by Eazy's Aids-related death, their involvement with deeply unsavoury music mogul (and current resident of the federal California Men's Colony) Suge Knight, the spat over money still vexatious enough for Cube to declare "fuck [former manager] Jerry Heller" on Chin Check...

"Aw no, that doesn't bother me," he replies. "History is history, there's no point trying to get away from that. So, yeah, we got baggage, but all we can do now is put together an album that's greater than anybody's expectations. Because when it's done, it's got to be the best record out there."

Which is a bold ambition for a group whose infamous teenage pronouncement that "life ain't nothing but bitches and money" seems somewhat at odds with the current reality of its members' lives as confirmed family men. To wit, the one time Cube gets genuinely excited during this interview is when he talks about flying home for his daughter's sixth birthday party. "Yeah," he concedes, "our lifestyles have slowed down, we got money and families. But the group is like a razor blade, you know what I'm saying? It's bigger than our personal lives. And you gotta keep it sharp. You can't let it get dulled up."

He makes a point of maintaining eye contact as he says this. Despite the movies, despite the kids' birthday parties, and despite the make-up artist, you sense it might be a while yet before he decides to become the Nigga Ya Love To Love.

"It's like sports," he remarks. "The rookies get the attention, and it's the veterans who come through and win the championships, when the rookie's at home watching on TV."

He leans back in his chair, timing the punchline. "And I play for the championships."

 Three Kings opens on March 3. Next Friday is released on March 10.

fields.headline: Video reviews
fields.standfirst: Cookie's Fortune | Gregory's Two Girls | Wild Wild West
fields.trailText: Cookie's Fortune | Gregory's Two Girls | Wild Wild West
fields.body:
Cookie's Fortune
Rental
Alliance Atlantis Cert 15
***

Robert Altman has always preferred the scenic route to the motorway and Cookie's Fortune is in no hurry to get to the plot. It prefers to meander around the small southern town of Holly Springs, Mississippi, often in the company of Charles S Dutton, probably the least-known of a typically starry cast - but arguably the key figure here, a comfortable middle-aged fan of fishing and Wild Turkey, and a much-loved local character.

Altman takes ages setting up the fact that here is a town where nothing much has happened for years - until the eccentric Cookie commits suicide in a bid to be reunited with her late husband. Bossy niece Glenn Close decides to make the suicide look like murder and an eccentric chain of events occurs in which everybody, in the fullness of time, pretty much gets their just deserts, but only at a very southern pace.

Clint Eastwood tried this sort of thing with Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil and made Savannah just seem tedious; but Altman's little town is a nice place to visit, especially if you're all blockbustered out. You have to slow down like you do for a country holiday. In the director's diverse career this is fairly minor; it's no Short Cuts or The Player. But its good nature is appealing and, amazingly, it did make the US top 10. The ensemble acting is, as you'd expect, exemplary and it's good to see stroke victim Patricia Neal, in her first role for many years, handling the title role with zest.

Gregory's Two Girls
Rental and DVD £19.99
Film Four Cert 15
***

Not really a sequel to Gregory's Girl, but true to the 1980 film's whimsically amusing spirit and its ditheringly ineffective lead character: a schoolboy turned into an unlikely schoolteacher in the intervening two decades, and played by the still gawky John Gordon Sinclair.

The two girls in question are schoolgirl Frances (Carly McKinnon) and girlfriend Bel (Maria Doyle Kennedy). Little has changed in the not-so-new town of Cumbernauld, or director Bill Forsyth's world view. The women are again far more capable and forceful characters. Another familiar Forsyth theme is Scotland v the might of America (he's been to Hollywood and back since Gregory's Girl). Here, Gregory's initial antipathy to the dumbed-down US in the person of his sister's boyfriend, who declares Scotland "an old, safe, dead country", turns into admiration as his knowledge of Gregory's hero, Noam Chomsky, is revealed. The plot pits his woolly idealism against the reality of political activism.

Wild Wild West
Rental and DVD £19.99
Warner Cert 12
***

So what went wrong?, people ask of this disastrous end to the charmed run of director Barry Sonnenfeld and star Will Smith, who previously combined for Men in Black, one of the 90s' most perfect combinations of Hollywood flash and quirky, independent-style wit.

Almost everything is the answer but, most fundamentally, this is a film set in 1869, filmed in 1999 and with a script that sounds like 1965, when the US TV series which was never shown here was launched. In other words, it is dully and relentlessly sexist in a way that could only possibly work with an Austin Powers smirk or lashings of irony.

Smith's sprightly rap played over the closing credits has more wit than anything its four credited screenwriters could come up with, and casting Smith as a government agent 130 years ago makes nonsense of history too. It's meant as a frisky romp, but Smith and Kevin Kline never provide a hint of the Smith & Jones empathy from Men in Black. Then there's arch- villain Kenneth Branagh's accent, probably the worst British Texan attempt since Michael Caine's fondly-remembered turn in Hurry Sundown.

The only MiB alumnus to escape unscathed is production designer Bo Welch, whose 80ft metal tarantula deserves a far better movie to stomp through. Wild Wild West is as silly as a sack of spoonbills.

fields.headline: Open Your Eyes
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: This is a workmanlike film, with similarities to Bunuel and Georges Franju's Eyes Without a Face. But it never quite comes to life...
fields.body:
Directed and co-written by the young Spanish director Alejandro Amenabar, Open Your Eyes is a weird psychological thriller about Cesar (Eduardo Noriega), a spoilt young rich guy who is disfigured after a horrendous car crash, and is then eerily unable to distinguish between dreams and reality. Made in 1997, the film is getting a belated UK release, perhaps to capitalise on the presence of Penelope Cruz, who in this film has some semi-nude sex scenes of the sort she is unlikely to agree to again, now that she is an international star.

This is a workmanlike film, with similarities to Bunuel and Georges Franju's Eyes Without a Face. But it never quite comes to life, and its far-from-unexpected dénouement reveals a resemblance to a certain American blockbuster widely available on DVD, but which - to be fair - it pre-dates by at least a year.

fields.headline: The Green Mile
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: If you can stand this three-hour-plus stretch of saccharine gibberish and patronising racial politics, you've got a stronger stomach than me
fields.body:
The execution of black men in the American south: what an obvious subject for a sentimental slice of feelgood drama starring Tom Hanks! This is the substance of The Green Mile, adapted from Stephen King's novel and directed by Frank Darabont, who brought us The Shawshank Redemption. His subject need not evoke the unlovely realities associated with, say, Ricky Ray Rector, the mentally disabled black man whose 1992 execution in Arkansas was enthusiastically endorsed by Governor Bill Clinton. This is because the story takes place in the picturesque olden days of 1935: heritage death penalty.

Tom Hanks plays Paul Edgecomb, possibly the most liberal death-row prison guard in the history of the universe, never mind the 30s. That bulbous, funny-shaped lower lip of his is permanently throbbing with sensitivity, though scruples about the death penalty itself play no part in his quivering humanity.

Our Tom gently presides over an ethnic rainbow of prisoners lining up for the electric chair: one white francophone, one Native American, one horrible white-trash hick, and one black man called John Coffey, who is physically enormous (naturally) a gentle giant (of course) and possessed of luminous Christ-like healing powers (oh, behave). Tom lets John Coffey put his hand on his nether regions to cure his urinary infection! And the saintly prison governor allows John unaccompanied into his wife's boudoir - did I mention this is set in 1935? - to cure her brain tumour!

If you can stand this three-hour-plus stretch of saccharine gibberish and patronising racial politics, you've got a stronger stomach than me.

fields.headline: The Talented Mr Ripley
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A dismayingly unthrilling thriller and bafflingly unconvincing character study
fields.body:
The world of The Talented Mr Ripley is full of a certain type of rich young person who is "only comfortable around people who have money and despise it". The author of this gorgeous deadpan irony is Meredith Logue (Cate Blanchett), a highly-strung young heiress first sighted on a first-class Cunard passage to Italy.

It is from observing her that Tom Ripley (Matt Damon), a clever, insecure young social climber, begins to learn the self-deprecatory tics and evasions necessary for impersonating someone really rich. A humble piano-tuner and men's washroom attendant, Ripley is mistaken for an echt Princeton man by a wealthy magnate and is charged by him with a mission to go out to Italy to find his tearaway son Dickie Greenleaf (Jude Law) and bring him back to America.

Ripley is delighted to oblige; his sinister, shallow knack of charm-deployment and acquaintance-scraping allows him to befriend Dickie and Dickie's girlfriend, Marge (Gwyneth Paltrow). Eventually, Ripley's fervent identification with the exquisite Dickie attains a level of pathological creepiness comparable to Michael Redgrave and his ventriloquist dummy in Dead of Night, and his infatuation with their sumptuous lifestyle leads to an erotic obsession and murder.

Anthony Minghella's movie, based on Patricia Highsmith's thriller - itself a sort of bebop version of Henry James's The Ambassadors - is handsomely furnished and designed, its locations and set-dressings a creamy love letter to the dolce vita of 1950s Italy. There is only one big error: on the beach, Matt Damon is shown sporting a crisp set of abs, decades before these were invented. (It is part of what I have elsewhere identified as the Six-Pack Fallacy, whereby any remotely presentable male lead must always have the Pack, but is not shown doing the thousands of daily ab-crunches needed for its upkeep.)

Here, homoerotic attraction is mixed with chippy social envy, and Minghella's film efficiently bottles the consequent gamey aroma and holds it under our noses. Jude Law gives a very stylish and charismatic performance as the exquisite Dickie, all cruelty and caprice. He easily outclasses the nerdy, bucktoothed Matt Damon - the picture suffers a very noticeable voltage-drop when Law is off-screen. The women are very underwritten. Paltrow is peaky and pallid; Blanchett does her very considerable best with Meredith, though yet again I wonder if anyone is ever going to give her a role to equal Elizabeth.

Philip Seymour Hoffman blows them all away with a scene-stealing black-comic turn as Dickie's awful preppie buddy Freddy Miles - the only one to sense that something is not right with Ripley - making boorish conversation in one of the richest basso profundo voices around.

All these attractive features in Minghella's movie, however, simply go to make up a house of cards which is brought crashing down halfway through by the central plot implausibility of Ripley's getting away with passing himself off as Dickie. Would Meredith really not know what Dickie looks like, never have seen a photo?

Granted, the mass media were not as ubiquitous in the 50s as now - but a fabulously rich young American playboy's doings in Italy would have set the paparazzi bulbs a-popping and his name linked with crime would get the gossip mags working overtime. This mistaken-identity device would be all right in something like an early Shakespearian comedy, but not the modern world, and the final hour of this film is a long and tedious tangle of over-wrought plot compensations.

The Talented Mr Ripley begins as an ingenious exposition of the great truth about charming people having something to hide: namely, their utter reliance on others. It ends up as a dismayingly unthrilling thriller and bafflingly unconvincing character study. Ripley says he'd rather be a fake somebody than a real nobody - but a fake nobody is all we're offered...

fields.headline: Streets ahead of the competition
fields.standfirst: Rosetta, an uncompromising, passionate tale of poverty, is nothing short of a classic, says Peter Bradshaw
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: This is a film with a rigorous transforming gaze, a strange and passionate urgency... It is a film whose grace and lyricism has earned it, simply, the status of classic: something of real greatness
fields.body:
Nothing indicts this year's Oscar list more than the omission of Rosetta from the list of nominees for best foreign film. For the stupidity and ignorance of this oversight, the constituent members of the "Academy" deserve to have their ears nailed to the bumpers of their hired limos. Because this film, a deserving winner of the Palme d'Or at Cannes, is a stunning and remarkable achievement.

Written and directed by Luc and Jean-Pierre Dardennes, using mostly one hand-held camera, and without a musical score, Rosetta is broadly in the tradition of Bresson's Mouchette and Fellini's Nights of Cabiria: an uncompromising depiction of real poverty and the terrible gravitational pull of ennui and despair that this exerts. It is also a luminous and compassionate account of a young woman struggling to climb out of the swamp of want: by turns furious, frustrated, and strangely impassive.

Emilie Dequenne is the 18-year-old non-professional that the Dardennes brothers discovered to carry the burden of this film, and what an astounding discovery she is: we have 90 minutes in which she is rarely out of shot, and often in the most searching close-up, the camera recording every flinch, every grimace, and - in one very moving moment - her single, radiantly beautiful smile. It is one of the most extraordinary, unselfconscious performances in the cinema at present, and Dequenne makes most "acting", with its tinpot cliches of gesture and hand-me-down inanities, look very paltry indeed.

Rosetta lives with her slatternly, alcoholic mother on a Belgian caravan site and burns with nothing more than a desire for what the bourgeoisie take for granted: a regular job, a regular life. She gets by on a sort of tinker existence, selling second-hand clothes that her mother mends in rare moments of sobriety. But even the dire blue-collar jobs she wants are in short supply; the scent of her angry desperation repels nervous managers and she always returns to the arena of her domestic shame. This is the terrible trailer-park where her mute mother, catatonic with drink and self-loathing, exemplifies the dizzying abyss of futility over which Rosetta now finds herself teetering.

This picture focuses with cold, resolute clarity on what poverty means. It finds its locations in both the town and in a kind of degraded pastoral: Rosetta is expelled from the grisly Edens of shop and factory work and has to scrape an existence poaching on a riverbank accessed through a torn fence: trapping fish in broken bottles.

The material detail of all this is conveyed with compelling neutrality, and with a subtlety that rewards repeat viewings. It was only when I watched it for a second time that I noticed that Rosetta appears to have had her mother customise the apron she wears as a saleswoman on a waffle stand: the word "Rosetta" is tinily embroidered. How she loves that terrible job. Discharging its obligations looks like a living death, but to Rosetta it is a badge of human dignity, of existence, worth doing anything for, including a terrible act of betrayal against Riquet (Fabrizio Rongione), a boy who is clearly in love with her.

The Dardennes' camera is always there, jogging alongside Rosetta as she grimly walks everywhere, rarely or never able to afford the bus. It peeps warily around corners, the way Rosetta does; it is breathlessly at her side, like an anxious child or nervy younger sibling, concerned at all times to keep Rosetta's face in plain view. It may whip-pan round, nervously to confront whatever deceitful man is standing in Rosetta's way, but always swings compulsively back to Rosetta's face like a compass needle.

Often she and it are on the run. Rosetta is always running: running like a devastated child from employers who are taking her job away, running to catch her truant mother, running away from Riquet. And the camera scrambles after her, seeming to join in with the desperate and demeaning grapple that invariably ensues. There is an element of absurdity here, almost farce, but the effect is one of pathos, rather than black comedy: Rosetta is still struggling and has not collapsed into despair.

There is a clarity and severity in this film that takes it beyond an Anglo-Saxon realm of social realism or miserabilism: this is a film with a rigorous transforming gaze, a strange and passionate urgency. Every time I watch it, it becomes more moving, more commanding, more exceptional. It is a film whose grace and lyricism has earned it, simply, the status of classic: something of real greatness.

fields.headline: Bruce blooms
fields.trailText: The Presidents' Day long weekend is Hollywood's equinox, a short period in which you become totally disoriented by what's suddenly on the nation's screens. The future and the recent past seem simultaneously to jostle for our attention.
fields.body:
The Presidents' Day long weekend is Hollywood's equinox, a short period in which you become totally disoriented by what's suddenly on the nation's screens. The future and the recent past seem simultaneously to jostle for our attention.

Last weekend was the last chance for all the stale old Christmas and New Year movies before they were retired to make room for the first wave of spring contenders. This week it's the turn of several mid-budget tragicomedies, "dramedies" and other ill-conceived generic hybrids no less abominable in conception than they were execrable in execution.

In the same week, one opens the LA Times and finds the suddenly double-thick issues smeared with dozens of full-page ads for all the movies that have been nominated for Academy awards. In the case of the movies that garnered the most nominations, the ads are accompanied by national re-release campaigns to cash in on the intensive Oscar coverage.

This is one of the reasons there were no big-budget studio releases this weekend, no Godzillas, no ID4s. No one wants to risk a big release when attention is elsewhere. For bombast and brainlessness we must wait until Memorial Day in May.

Among the newcomers, we were favoured with a tie at the top between Hanging Up, the latest date-movie from the profoundly tiresome Ephron sisters, Nora and Delia, and the latest Bruce Willis movie, a hit-man comedy called The Whole Nine Yards, co-starring Matthew Perry.

This, believe it or not, is the third Willis movie since The Sixth Sense was released in the summer. First came Alan Rudolph's Breakfast of Champions, which did zero business, although it only got made because of Willis's involvement - proof of his occasionally excellent taste. The next, simpering family drama The Story of Us, was adequate proof that, on his bad days, Willis has the tastebuds of a meths connoisseur.

The Ephron sisters have yet to overcome their pathological urge to cast the irksomely ditzy, rinky-dink Meg Ryan in everything they write or direct. We've had Sleepless in Seattle and You've Got Mail, both of which were several leagues the other side of nauseating, and now we have Hanging Up, the story of three sisters - Ryan, Diane Keaton, Lisa Kudrow - and their randy old single dad, played by Walter Matthau, apparently on day-release from Grumpier Old Men or The Odd Couple 2.

Men who took their dates to see Scream 3 a fortnight ago paid for it this week as they were dragged screaming to endure Hanging Up, which I'm pleased to see earned a 21-toilet-flush salute of rancid reviews.

The Whole Nine Yards was better received by the critics. It plays to Willis's strengths, his geniality and tough-guy image, and leaves the clowning and the pratfalls to second-billed Matthew Perry. Perry is playing Chandler Bing yet again, with only the merest variations, but it's a good turn wherever he does it, so no one complained.

Natasha Henstridge fans (and yes, I mean you, the spotty youths in rows four and five holding your Game Boys under your desks) will be pleased to note her cameo as Willis's estranged wife, and disappointed to learn that she remains fully clad throughout the movie. I can hear them wailing now, "But full-frontal nudity's the whole point of Natasha Henstridge! Waaah!"

Elsewhere there was the kiddie comedy Snow Day at number three, competing for the under-nines market alongside Disney's The Tigger Movie. The big movies of last week saw disastrous drop-offs in attendance. Scream 3, which was number one for two weeks, fell to number six, and Leonardo DiCaprio's anaemic comeback The Beach washed up at number seven.

"It's a dark movie," claimed Fox's distribution chieftain Tom Sherak by way of explanation. No, Tom. Clean, Shaven is a dark movie. Henry: Portrait of a Serial Killer is a dark movie. The Beach is a dork movie, a lightweight movie, and it got the kicking it deserved.

Which left the Oscar race re-issues to fill out the bottom of the chart. The Green Mile and The Cider House Rules tied at number 10, and American Beauty rose from number 59 to number nine. This is good news for a rather good movie, but is less surprising when you learn that last week it was in only seven cinemas, and this week it's in 1,287.

I confess a total lack of interest in the whole Oscar process. It occupies the first three months of the year in LA, a dark spell that resembles the depressing period after the clocks go back in the autumn. The papers are clogged with the many award ceremonies that precede the Oscars: the Golden Globes, the New York Critics Association, its LA equivalent, followed by all the different guilds within the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, directors, writers, actors, and so on.

Then the hacks weigh in to handicap the race, we get endless boring behind-the-ceremony features, and the usual nonsense about dresses, hairdos and what big rock Shazza's gonna wear. A long time ago Oscar night was a good excuse for an at-home knees-up, 20 drunks in a suburban living-room all screaming at the TV as Dances With Wolves beats GoodFellas for best picture. Not any more, though.

I gave up on it after Forrest Gump cleaned up, at just about the time I lost interest in presidential politics. Actually, the politicians are suddenly managing to make things much more interesting in their race. I wouldn't dream of voting for a Goldwater Republican (or any other kind) like John McCain, but anyone who can make jokes about Alzheimer's disease ("You can hide your own Easter eggs!") and still expect an endorsement from Nancy Reagan, earns my admiration for sheer effrontery and a guffaw-prompting lack of tact. Of which sadly, there was precious little on our movie screens this week. Maybe next Friday...

fields.headline: Emilie Dequenne
fields.trailText: Emilie Dequenne
fields.body:
First film?

I think it was Manon des Sources. All I remember is that I was really afraid of Daniel Auteuil when he was hanging from the tree.

Favourite film?

I've seen In the Name of the Father 30 times. I saw it when I was 14, and I think that when you're a teenager, it sticks in your memory. It hit me in my stomach and I wanted to scream.

Most erotic movie moment?

L'Amant with Jane March. I like the moment when the boy comes into the room and they make love on the ground because they can't wait. It's very beautiful.

What's the most annoying habit in a cinema?

When people don't turn off their mobile phones.

Favourite snatch of dialogue?

I like it in Wayne's World when the guy in the car is very ill and his friend says, "If you want to be sick, be sick in here," and he points to this tiny bag that he's holding.

Which actor would you most like to be?

fields.headline: Army set to recall 300,000 'unreliable' rifles
fields.trailText:
The ministry of defence faces new embarrassment over reports that Britain is considering the recall of all 300,000 standard rifles
used by its troops because they tend to jam in extreme weather. Necessary modifications are expected to cost tens of millions of pounds.
fields.body:
The ministry of defence faces new embarrassment over reports that Britain is considering the recall of all 300,000 standard rifles used by its troops because they tend to jam in extreme weather. Necessary modifications are expected to cost tens of millions of pounds.

A defence official said the ministry was studying a report by German arms maker Heckler & Koch, which has carried out tests on the SA80 rifle and made modifications. The ministry said it would issue its own report soon on possible improvements to the rifle, which has been in service since the late 1980s.

"We haven't recalled any rifles yet and the SA80 remains a very effective weapon. It is being used in Kosovo and Bosnia where the temperature drops to -20C," the official said. "There are reliability problems only in extreme climates, but improvements are being planned as a matter of urgency. Any modifications would be carried out in an organised way; not all SA80s would be recalled in one go."

Soldiers deployed in Kosovo said this week that their SA80 rifles were "fragile" and prone to jamming if not kept meticulously clean. Troops have complained about the rifle for eight years. Ministers have yet to give final approval for modifications, but MoD officials accept that every rife would have to be altered. The modifications will mean changes to the magazine, the bolt and gas systems that eject the cartridges when the rifle is fired.

The likelihood of a expensive overhaul of all 300,000 standard rifles in the armed forces is just the latest embarrassment for the ministry of defence. Earlier this year there were claims that the Royal Navy was forced to keep some ships in dock because a shortage of fuel.

This week it emerged that the £1bn Tornado GR4 had encountered early difficulties dropping precision-guided bombs during the Kosovo conflict. The upgraded jets could not be used because a new laser-guided targeting system was delivered without the state of the art mechanism in full working order. Older Tornado GR-1s and Harrier jets were used instead. The Kosovo operation also underlined the inadequate state of the Clansman radio.

MPs found last year that the MoD's handling of major defence projects was "weak in almost every aspect" after 25 large-scale purchases overran by more than £3bn and were delivered on average 37 months late. These included the Eurofighter, the four-nation project to produce one of the most advanced military jets in the world, which has overrun by at least £1.36bn and will enter service in 2002 - three years behind.

fields.headline: Charles charms Caribbean hosts
fields.trailText:
Prince Charles has been keen to stress his commitment
to the Commonwealth during his Caribbean tour over the
past week, but he was given a sharp reminder of
Britain's colonial failings when he was welcomed to
south America's only English-speaking state.
fields.body:
Prince Charles has been keen to stress his commitment to the Commonwealth during his Caribbean tour over the past week, but he was given a sharp reminder of Britain's colonial failings when he was welcomed to south America's only English-speaking state.

Hamilton Green, the mayor of the Guyanan capital Georgetown, bestowed the freedom of the city upon the prince. Referring to his own family's slave heritage, he said: "Who could have imagined that the descendants of an African slave could, with sincerity and warmth, welcome a member of the royal family to a territory which we now claim to control?""

The comments, made at ceremony yesterday, were an important marker for the prince, who has achieved recognition during his visit to the former colonies as a champion of the black and Asian cause in Britain. Earlier, in Tobago, the opposition leader in the island's assembly praised him for his work through his Youth Business Trust. "With the assistance of your charity, many people - particularly young black people - would not have recorded the same level of success that is evident among the ethnic population of Britain," Deborah Moore-Miggins said.

Prince Charles was keen to stress that he was taking a practical lead on race relations issues, pointing out to the audience at Georgetown city hall the Guyanan background of his own deputy press secretary, Colleen Harris. (The prince did not, however, say how many people from ethnic minorities are employed in the rest of his household. And Ms Harris was not, as the prince suggested, born here - she is a Londoner.)

Nonetheless, the prince has been feted as a man who is at ease with the Caribbean communities. He has tried his hand at the steel drums, enthused about the preparations for the world-famous Trinidad carnival - although he drew the line at limbo dancing when invited to dive below a fiery limbo pole at the residence of the prime minister of Trinidad and Tobago.

"I feel very much at home here, because we have so many of your countrymen living and working in Britain. I come across them on many different occasions, in Brixton and in Hackney," he told council members at the Tobago assembly. It may have been a clumsy way of putting it, but the intention was clear.

Before he arrived, the only impression that most Caribbeans had of the prince was that of a cold and uncaring man who had allowed his marriage to a naive but beautiful princess to wither away. Now that he is here, the local newspapers are full of pictures and stories about his meet-the-people manner. "They are just stunned," one local reporter said in Trinidad. "This is not what they expected at all."

As the Queen's determination to carry the monarchical torch well into the 21st century has become clearer, it appears that this man is determined to find more ways of answering the question which follows him everywhere: "What is the point of the Prince of Wales?"

fields.headline: Dobson turns on Blair 'prats'
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Frank Dobson last night made his most determined attempt to throw off his image as the creature of the Labour machine in London's mayoral race, backtracking on his support for Tony Blair's plans for partial privatisation of the tube and declaring that the government would have a "fight on their hands" if it opposed him.
fields.body:
Frank Dobson last night made his most determined attempt to throw off his image as the creature of the Labour machine in London's mayoral race, backtracking on his support for Tony Blair's plans for partial privatisation of the tube and declaring that the government would have a "fight on their hands" if it opposed him.

Using the first public debate between the three main parties' mayoral candidates - organised by the Guardian - and facing Ken Livingstone, who was sitting 15 yards away in the audience, the former health secretary attacked the Labour leadership as "prats" and said the decision to use an electoral college to pick the party's candidate had been "stupid".

Warning that he did "not trust the officials at the department of transport to get these things right", Mr Dobson - who earlier this week derided Mr Livingstone's public-sector bond alternative as "pie in the sky" - announced that he planned to appoint an independent panel to look at the financing of each scheme on its merits.

His new line, revealed at the Guardian debate in Church House, Westminster, came only a day after Mr Livingstone said the mayoral election would become a "referendum on London's right to govern itself" unless Labour dropped its scheme to part-privatise the tube.

But last night, the former Greater London council leader - who said he was at the meeting as part of his effort to "listen to Londoners" before making up his mind on his next move - appeared unimpressed by Mr Dobson's shift in his direction.

"The question is: will we have partial privatisation of the tube or not?" Mr Livingstone's spokesman said after the meeting. "A public-private partnership for the tube was overwhelmingly rejected by the party membership. Labour needs a candidate who has a clear policy on the tube. It's not going to be possible to get through the election without a policy."

But the Brent East MP, who was given a standing ovation by a large part of the 500-strong audience as he arrived, came under attack from Susan Kramer, the Liberal Democrat mayoral candidate, for failing to vote against the government's plans for London Underground in parliament.

Ms Kramer, who also backs a bond-financed modernisation public-sector scheme, taunted Mr Livingstone to declare his expected independent candidacy: "I just wish anybody who wants to get into this race will get into it." The Tory candidate, Steve Norris, called Labour's selection an "utterly shameful gerrymandered and corrupt process".

Meanwhile, trade union leaders last night issued a cautiously worded statement aimed at putting pressure on Mr Livingstone not to stand as an independent and calling for "unity around the official Labour candidate".

After a meeting of the trade union Labour liaison committee, an umbrella group for Labour-affiliated unions, its chairman, Bill Morris, urged Mr Livingstone not to leave the party and to meet Labour's general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, and himself to discuss his concerns.

The statement comes after a decision by the London regional council of the Rail Maritime and Transport union on Wednesday to call on Mr Livingstone to stand as an independent. Yesterday, the Communication Workers' Union executive voted down a motion pressing Mr Livingstone to accept the outcome of Labour's selection and back Mr Dobson.

A Labour spokesman said Mr Morris's statement was "potentially an important development" in moves to end the stand-off between the party leadership and Mr Livingstone, who has also been approached directly by Ms McDonagh asking for a meeting.

But the party's Millbank headquarters rejected any suggestion that Mr Dobson's change of tune on the underground represented a u-turn on policy or that the party leadership might be prepared to shift its own ground on the controversy.

"Basically, Frank can say what he likes about the tube modernisation," a senior spokesman said last night. "But the policy is the policy and it doesn't matter whether it's Frank or Ken, that's the situation. Frank's going to be his own man. But it's not like we're going to change our manifesto and plump for bonds. We want the candidate's personal stamp on the manifesto but at the same time that can't be in contradiction to the policy as it stands."

fields.headline: Verdi: Falstaff
fields.trailText: In our series on building a classical library, Andrew Clements selects the definitive recording of Verdi's Falstaff.
fields.body:
In anything approaching a decent performance, Falstaff delivers one of the most satisfying experiences the operatic repertoire can offer. Verdi's last opera, premiered in 1893, when he was just eight months short of his 80th birthday, is a summation of everything that he had accumulated in a lifetime in the theatre, woven together into a seamless fabric with a deftness, wit and abundance of musical invention that seem almost miraculous.

Verdi always maintained that Falstaff was a study in character; he called it a "commedia lirica", and Boito's exemplary libretto, based upon The Merry Wives of Windsor but also incorporating material from Henry IV parts I and II, is an exploration of human nature, using Shakespeare's ageing fat knight as its focus.

Yet for such a peerless masterpiece, Falstaff has received surprisingly few complete recordings. Perhaps for half a century record companies have been awed by the towering presence in the catalogue of Arturo Toscanini's version (RCA), taken from a radio broadcast in 1950. It provides a model not only of how to get every morsel of the text across, but of how, in the right hands, the score just uncoils with total naturalness, as if the music was being invented at the moment of its performance.

The cast is uneven, but Giuseppe Valdengo is a model of what a Falstaff should be, beautifully sung and subtly shaded, without a trace of coarseness. The mono recording is dated now; even the most assiduous remastering can't disguise its dryness, and some of the colour in Verdi's score is bleached out; Toscanini demands to be heard, but for an all-round recommendation a better sound is needed.

In fact, the finest all-round version now available was made only six years after Toscanini's legendary account. There have been other contenders since, but none quite comes off. Leonard Bernstein's, with Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau in the title role (Sony Classical), is certainly refined but misses some of the essential earthiness of the humour; Carlo Maria Giulini's (Deutsche Grammophon) is too earnest by half; Georg Solti's (Decca) rattles along and contains some marvellous moments, but sometimes seems forced.

Herbert von Karajan recorded the opera twice. His second version, from 1980 (Philips), is marred by the archness with which Giuseppe Tadei attempts to characterise the title role, but the first, made in London in 1956 with the Philharmonia Orchestra, is simply glorious. Every detail of the orchestral writing sparkles, every rhythm is irrepressible. The cast is led by Tito Gobbi, who encompasses every facet of Falstaff's larger-than-life personality, Rolando Panerai is an imposing Ford, and the merry wives themselves are led by Elisabeth Schwarzkopf's Alice. Wonderfully guided by Karajan, the performance becomes the glorious, life-affirming celebration it should be.

Key recording: Karajan (EMI 5 67162 2, two CDs)

webTitle: Bush rejects reprieve for woman on death row

fields.headline: Bush rejects reprieve for woman on death row
fields.trailText: A 62-year-old woman was executed by injection after governor George W. Bush rejected her claim that she killed  her fifth husband in self-defense and deserved a reprieve.
fields.body:
A 62-year-old woman was executed by injection after governor George W. Bush rejected her claim that she killed her fifth husband in self-defense and deserved a reprieve.

On Thursday, Betty Lou Beets became the fourth woman to be executed in the United States since the Supreme Court in 1976 allowed the death penalty to resume. She was also the second woman executed in Texas since the Civil War ended in 1865.

She gave no final statement as she lay strapped to the death chamber gurney. She made no eye contact with the victim's family, but smiled at relatives on her side.

Death penalty opponents had urged Bush to grant Beets a 30-day delay, arguing it would be consistent with his description of himself as a "compassionate conservative" in his U.S. presidential campaign. The delay was Bush's only option, since the state parole board did not recommend that her sentence be commuted to life in prison. During Bush's five and a half years as governor, 120 convicted killers have been executed in Texas. He has spared one condemned inmate.

"After careful review of the evidence of the case, I concur with the jury that Betty Lou Beets is guilty of this murder," Bush said in a written statement after returning to Texas from California, where he was campaigning for the Republican nomination. "I'm confident that the courts, both state and federal, have thoroughly reviewed all the issues raised by the defendant."

Beets and her lawyers insisted the former bartender-waitress, convicted of fatally shooting fifth husband Jimmy Don Beets nearly 17 years ago and burying his body under a flower garden, was the victim of years of domestic abuse and should be allowed to live.

On Thursday the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in New Orleans, Louisiana rejected an appeal that accused the state of not following its own rules in reviewing Beets' case. The arguments were dismissed on Wednesday by a federal judge in Austin as a delay tactic. Beets' lawyers also took the matter to the U.S. Supreme Court, which rejected it without comment. According to the governor's office, Bush had received 2,108 phone calls and letters opposing Beets' execution by Thursday afternoon, and 57 calls and letters favoring it.

Before Beets, the last woman executed in Texas was Karla Faye Tucker, on Feb. 3, 1998. Tucker hacked two people to death with a pickaxe, but said she had a religious conversion in prison and appealed for mercy. Bush was criticized for mocking Tucker in a magazine interview last year.

Beets was the ninth convicted killer and the second in as many days to be executed in Texas, the nation's most active death penalty state. Although Beets insisted she was innocent, a jury convicted her of killing Jimmy Don Beets, a Dallas Fire Department captain, to collect his life insurance and pension. Her claims of domestic abuse surfaced only recently and were not a factor in her 1985 trial, although one of her daughters, Faye Lane, in a tearful plea for her mother's life, said this week her mother was acting in self-defense after years of abuse.

Betty Lou Beets also was convicted of shooting and wounding her second husband, Bill Lane, and was charged but never tried in the 1981 shooting death of her fourth husband, Doyle Barker. Both had been shot in the back of the head and stuffed into blue sleeping bags.

Beets was the ninth convicted killer and the second in as many days to be executed in Texas, the nation's most active death penalty state. Although Beets insisted she was innocent, a jury convicted her of killing Jimmy Don Beets, a Dallas Fire Department captain, to collect his life insurance and pension. Her claims of domestic abuse surfaced only recently and were not a factor in her 1985 trial, although one of her daughters, Faye Lane, in a tearful plea for her mother's life, said this week her mother was acting in self-defense after years of abuse. Betty Lou Beets also was convicted of shooting and wounding her second husband, Bill Lane, and was charged but never tried in the 1981 shooting death of her fourth husband, Doyle Barker. Both had been shot in the back of the head and stuffed into blue sleeping bags.

fields.headline: Holiday cot death risk
fields.trailText: Cot deaths are more common at weekends and holidays, according to statistics published yesterday.
fields.body:
Cot deaths are more common at weekends and holidays, according to statistics published yesterday.

Disruption to routine and changes to where the baby sleeps could be partly to blame, it is thought.

The study by the office for national statistics found that between 1993 and 1998, 1,431 babies died from sudden infant death syndrome during the week and 705 at the weekend or on a public holiday.

Experts had assumed that there was an equal chance of death whatever the day, but found that 50 more babies than expected died on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

The trend was not seen in other deaths among infants aged between 28 days and one and there is uncertainty over why there was an increased risk of cot death on weekends.

The report's author, Nirupa Dattani, said: "It could be attributed to a number of factors, including changing parental routines, changes in the environment."

Cot deaths fell by a third between 1993 and 1998, while the overall infant mortality rate decreased by a tenth.

The reduction in cot deaths was mainly due to better guidance about how babies should sleep to avoid the risk of the syndrome. In 1998 there were 280 cot deaths in England and Wales, compared with 453 in 1993.

The report found that low birth weight babies, twins and triplets, and children born outside marriage are at increased risk of cot death.

More than 60% of cot deaths occurred in babies where the parents were not married, according to the ONS.

There are also regional variations in the rate of cot deaths, the study revealed. The north west consistently had the highest rate while north Thames boasted the lowest.

Cot death rates by region for 1998 were as follows (rate is deaths per 1,000 live births): North west: 0.55; Northern and Yorkshire: 0.51; Trent: 0.41; West Midlands: 0.35; Anglia and Oxford: 0.41; North Thames: 0.39; North Thames: 0.29; South and West: 0.65; Wales: 0.42.

Joyce Epstein, secretary general of the Foundation for the Study of Infant Deaths, said: "We need to know much more about the babies that are dying. Important details about their deaths are not being collected and analysed nationally, so vital information is being lost that could save lives."

fields.headline: MoD prepares to recall rifles
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence is preparing to recall more than 200,000 rifles following persistent complaints by British soldiers that they are unreliable.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence is preparing to recall more than 200,000 rifles following persistent complaints by British soldiers that they are unreliable.

The SA80 - the standard weapon used by all three branches of the armed forces - have been criticised by soldiers since the 1991 Gulf war when they were found to be prone to jamming.

A military spokesman insisted last night that the rifle was an effective weapon which had not caused any problems in the Balkans.

fields.headline: No interests
fields.trailText: Lord Levy writes: Contrary to your report (Labour backer named as PM's Middle East envoy, February 23), I do not have "substantial business interests in Israel". Indeed, I have no business interests in Israel.
fields.body:
Contrary to your report (Labour backer named as PM's Middle East envoy, February 23), I do not have "substantial business interests in Israel". Indeed, I have no business interests in Israel. You also quote Frances Maude demanding to know whether I have used my trips to raise funds for the Labour party. The Labour party does not accept funds from overseas donors and I have done no fundraising for the Labour party on any of my trips abroad. It has also been suggested in other quarters that I have given funds to the election campaign of Ehud Barak as prime minister of Israel. I would like to make it clear that I have given no funds in any way to the Barak campaign for prime minister.

Lord Levy
House of Lords

fields.headline: We'll down tools for Ken
fields.trailText: Presumably the freepost compromise proposal for the London mayoral elections whereby all candidates' statements will be delivered together (Lords force mayoral climbdown, February 23) will include an advisory letter from Tony Blair - just as with the ballot paper and statements sent to London Labour party members. That monstrous anti-democratic act alone is enough to justify Ken Livingstone going independent, whatever he may have said before.
fields.body:
Presumably the freepost compromise proposal for the London mayoral elections whereby all candidates' statements will be delivered together (Lords force mayoral climbdown, February 23) will include an advisory letter from Tony Blair - just as with the ballot paper and statements sent to London Labour party members. That monstrous anti-democratic act alone is enough to justify Ken Livingstone going independent, whatever he may have said before.

I have been an active Labour member for 18 years and, like many others, have contributed large amounts of time and money to New Labour. I have resigned my post as a constituency campaigns organiser because the party has been stolen from the members. I will not lift a finger for Dobson or Millbank's GLA political hirelings.

Those who impose candidates against the wishes of members will have to do their own campaigning.

Piers Corbyn
London
reclaimtheparty@hotmail.com

 Ian McCartney (Comment, February 23) is outrageously disingenuous. Of course Tony Benn didn't resign in 1981 and run as an independent - he was standing for deputy leader of the Labour party. And no, the electoral college used "to choose" the London mayor is not the same as used to select Tony Blair, because in the latter case all affiliated organisations were obliged to ballot their members and, as far as I'm aware, the PLP was allowed a secret ballot. This time only Campaign Group MPs dared defy the party machine; they are considered beyond the pale. The electoral college shows we have reached the point where either our elected representatives are unrepresentative of members' views or they're too scared or too ambitious to stand up for them. Either way, it's a disastrous state of affairs and can only end in tears.

Jenny Rathbone
London

 It was unwise of Ian McCartney to call in aid Denis Healey's victory as deputy leader in 1981. Unlike Frank Dobson, Denis Healey was not only the actual, but also the moral victor. He won the support of every single constituency party which balloted its members and, with one exception, every trade union. His actual majority would have been enormous, rather than wafer thin, if the largest union, the TGWU, had voted in accordance with the wishes of its members.

Richard Heller (Political adviser to Denis Healey 1981-83)
London

 So Ken wrote a letter promising not to stand against Frank. This has now been published by people who promised to abolish private prisons, protect rights to trial by jury, ban fox-hunting with hounds, remove safety functions from Railtrack and do away with selection for schools. But the greatest broken promise of all was for one member one vote.

C Smith
Bridgend

 Has Paul Richards (Letters, February 23) considered the possibility that the people "who thought themselves bigger than the Labour party" are not the likes of Ken Livingstone, but those responsible for contriving an electoral system whereby the votes of 74,000 members of the party are outweighed by 22,000 votes for the preferred candidate. He might be less complacent about the allegedly certain fate of those who leave Labour had he considered that Dick Taverne and Ramsay MacDonald both won the elections immediately subsequent to their departure, as did SO Davies (Merthyr Tydfil 1970) and James Maxton (Glasgow Bridgeton 1935).

Huw Richards
London
richards@dircon.co.uk

fields.headline: Site value
fields.trailText: The disastrous construction work carried out on Kathleen Saigol's property is an extreme example of what can and does, with monotonous regularity, go wrong in projects of this type (£700,000 award over building works bungle, February 24).
fields.body:
The disastrous construction work carried out on Kathleen Saigol's property is an extreme example of what can and does, with monotonous regularity, go wrong in projects of this type (£700,000 award over building works bungle, February 24). The key is independent inspection, on site at the various stages of the project. The employment of a fully qualified and experienced clerk of works to provide advice to the client represents far less than the cost of a day in court, and one more step in eradicating the cowboys who continue to blight the construction industry.

Don McGeorge
Institute of Clerks of Works

fields.headline: More than hot air
fields.trailText: John Vidal's analysis of emissions trading is unnecessarily pessimistic (Emission trading sparks criticism, February 22). Trading could be one innovative and highly effective response to the need to reduce our emissions of carbon dioxide.
fields.body:
John Vidal's analysis of emissions trading is unnecessarily pessimistic (Emission trading sparks criticism, February 22). Trading could be one innovative and highly effective response to the need to reduce our emissions of carbon dioxide. The inter-governmental panel on climate change has calculated that a global reduction in carbon dioxide emissions of about 60% is needed just to stabilise our climate.

Crucial to the success of any trading regime is an effective overall cap in the level of emissions. There is already evidence around the world of successful trading systems which are achieving reduced emissions at a lower cost to business. In the US, a trading scheme to reduce emissions of sulphur dioxide and tackle acid rain has helped reduce controlled sulphur dioxide emissions by 23% below allowable emission levels, while the flexibility offered by trading is estimated to have reduced the cost to business by between a third and a half.

On February 9, I introduced a 10 minute rule bill on the floor of the House of Commons to establish an emissions trading system here in Britain.

A domestic trading scheme is essential to help British business, environmentalists, the City and policy-makers to assess the benefits and the potential for participation in the coming international emissions trading system. It could help Britain to lead the design of the international system, and argue a case to be the location of the brokerage system that would conduct international trading.

My bill would establish an emissions trading authority with a board made up of representatives from British environmental groups, business, the City and academics. The authority would monitor and oversee the trading of emission deliver a verification process and impose penalties for non-compliance.

Gareth R Thomas MP

fields.headline: Learning at Sir Stan's feet
fields.trailText: A sad moment, but I did recall with a smile an old story which in some ways summarised Stanley Matthews's skills (Obituary, February 24).
fields.body:
A sad moment, but I did recall with a smile that old story which in some ways summarised Stanley Matthews's skills (Obituary, February 24). Stan, Tommy Lawton and Tom Finney are up front for England. Finney is having to play on the left wing. Stan puts over his perfect centre and Tommy heads it in easily. On the trot back to half way line, Tommy Lawton raises his hands and gives gentle applause to Stan. A little while later Tom Finney puts over a centre and Tommy Lawton obliges again. As the players head off at half-time, Tom Finney runs up to Lawton and says, "How come, Tommy, when Stan put that centre over and you scored you clapped him, but when I did the same - nothing!"

"Ah well!" explained Lawton. "You see when Stan puts those centres over, he always does it with the laces away from my forehead." For today's addicts, footballs in those days... oh, well.

Cliff Coxon
Paignton, Devon

 Stanley Matthews was neither booked nor sent off once throughout his whole long career in the game. And, writing on England's match against Argentina in which Dennis Wise received a yellow card for a late tackle (Dennis leaves menace behind, Sport, February 24) you described Wise as giving a "controlled, impressive display". In view of Wise's appalling disciplinary record, what would he have to do to earn your disapprobation: start the third world war?

Dr RF Carter
London
Richard.carter@bigfoot.com

fields.headline: Failures and successes of adoption
fields.trailText: Many of us hardened adopters would not agree with Meg Henderson on every point (When love is not enough, February 23). We were pioneers in an area where there was absolutely no support after the papers were signed.
fields.body:
Many of us hardened adopters would not agree with Meg Henderson on every point (When love is not enough, February 23). We were pioneers in an area where there was absolutely no support after the papers were signed. For those of us who struggled - usually completely alone, isolated from church, school, neighbourhood and medical good practice with our wayward adopted children - there are still many avenues to pursue beyond institutional care.

In California a massive system of support has developed from those first hard-to-place adoptions in the 1960s. It just hasn't reached these shores yet. Fostering and institutionalisation are the marks of a dark-age society. None of it is necessary. This steady diet of hysterical abuse stories and no funding is getting tedious. It is like all political/financial matters, a matter of spin and prevarication.

Name and address supplied

 We (my husband and myself) have not quite suffered the trauma that Meg Henderson has, but we adopted two children and now we have not heard anything of them for quite a number of years.

I do not feel that Tony Blair understands about adoption. Is this another wheeze for a type of privatisation so that child care homes can be reduced? If so, some more couples will be in for some heartache.

Muriel Wright
Nottingham

 There are some success stories in adoption. I was adopted at the age of 10 months by a couple that today would not have been allowed to adopt. My adoptive mother was 44 and my father 40 at the time. I was given a safe and secure childhood in idyllic surroundings and, because of my adoptive parents' support, I was able to overcome failure at school to eventually go on to university and a good career. My adoptive mother died three years ago; my adoptive father, now aged 90, lives with myself, my wife of 30 years and our children.

For whatever reasons, I came from a damaged background, I certainly had problems, but I am equally sure that life in a children's home, where I would have been thrown out at 16, would not have given me the support to make my life a success.

Dave Hayzen-Smith
Burton on Trent
hayzen@btinternet.com

webTitle: Reed's late grab for safety of the net

fields.headline: Reed's late grab for safety of the net
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Anglo-Dutch publishing group Reed Elsevier yesterday outlined plans to invest £750m to move its business on to the internet but failed to prevent a 10% slump in its share price.
fields.body:
Anglo-Dutch publishing group Reed Elsevier yesterday outlined plans to invest £750m to move its business on to the internet but failed to prevent a 10% slump in its share price.

Crispin Davis, who became chief executive of Reed in September, said the cash sum which outstrips recent announcements from Reuters, Pearson and BSkyB was to make up for years of under-investment.

It will be partly funded by a wide ranging cost control programme announced in December. Reed gave further details of the programme yesterday including the loss of 1,500 jobs, largely in the US.

The announcement was made as Reed reported what it conceded was a disappointing performance last year that saw pre-tax profits falling by 9% to £710m on turnover of £3.4bn. The company added a warning that the online investment would result in next year's profits being "somewhat below" those of 1999.

Mr Davis forecast some 25% of revenues would be generated by the internet by 2002 - a target of around £1bn and up from last years £120m. "The internet is quite clearly the driver for growth and I think we have very good assets to build on - a market leading position, very strong brands, excellent content and global reach," he said.

Cash will be spent building online versions of Reed's business, science and legal publications which will initially be offered in parallel to the paper versions but with the aim of replacing most of its operations with the internet. Examples include ScienceDirect Internet which includes 10 years of scientific journal archives online.

By 2002, 60% of science revenues are expected to come from online operations, 40% of legal revenues and 10% of business-to-business revenues.

Reed Elsevier said it would weed out non-core businesses, including OAG Worldwide and Springhouse. Disposals so far earmarked accounted for £200m of revenue in 1999 and are expected to have a small negative impact on earnings in the short term.

There was some sign from the City however that investors are beginning to suffer internet fatigue. "We all know they have to migrate to the internet but give us something new and radical," said one media analyst. "Competition is flooding into Reed's core markets and we're not convinced Davis really believes he can turn this thing around."

The group, which is dual-listed as Reed International in London and Elsevier in the Netherlands, saw its shares jump initially on announcement of the plan but then pull back sharply after outperforming the market by 84% in the past three months on hopes for a major internet push.

The Reed share price fell 60p to 545p and was further unsettled by a series of outstanding lawsuits against the company including one in the Virgin Islands alleging anti-competitive behaviour and claiming $6bn (£3.75bn) in damages. Mr Davis said the lawsuit was "irrelevant".

In common with other media groups hurrying to re-invent themselves as internet stocks, Reed said it was rebasing its dividend and reduced its 1999 payout by a third to 10p.

"Although we should not expect the turnaround to be quick, we feel positive and confident about Reed's future," said Mr Davis.

fields.headline: Jungle in talks about float
fields.standfirst: Online retailer worth a possible £700m seeks Warburg's adviceE-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Jungle.com, the online computer and home entertainment retailer, has appointed City advisers, raising speculation of a stock market flotation which could value the six-month-old company in excess of £700m.
fields.body:
Jungle.com, the online computer and home entertainment retailer, has appointed City advisers, raising speculation of a stock market flotation which could value the six-month-old company in excess of £700m.

Chief executive and major shareholder Steve Bennett is understood to have contracted investment bank Warburg Dillon Read to advise on future fundraising, building its brand and infrastructure expansion.

A flotation is one option under consideration. "Fast growing businesses obviously need finance to go forward and we have appointed advisers to examine all avenues," Mr Bennett said last night.

The 34-year-old has long stated his ambition to float Jungle.com at some stage. He predicts it will "easily" beat its first year revenue target of £33m. However, he is thought to be in no hurry to list the company, having recently completed second round fundraising from venture capital firm 3i, which holds a 25% stake.

It would likely be the second largest e-commerce flotation after QXL.com and slightly bigger than Lastminute.com, which recently announced its intention to float.

Jungle.com is halfway through a 10-week, £5m television, radio and press advertising campaign aimed at reaching the 11,000 internet novices who go online each day. Next month Jungle will re-release a version of the 1980s hit and its corporate theme tune "The Lion Sleeps Tonight" as a single.

Jungle.com's bold images and strong musical identity has made it Britain's third most visited e-commerce site, according to independent researchers Media Matrix. Separate rankings from Millward Brown make Jungle.com the third most recognised online retailer in Britain, after Amazon.com and Whsmith.com.

However, the fledgling company suffered a setback before Christmas when fulfilment problems forced Mr Bennett to defend the company's delivery record on BBC television's consumer show Watchdog.

Mr Bennett blamed higher than anticipated demand. Since the new year Jungle.com has been experimenting with new warehousing and courier delivery services.

A local home delivery trial is being undertaken in conjunction with a major retailer close to Jungle.com's west midlands base.

The company's main warehouse in Coleshill, Warwickshire which is shared with Mr Bennett's offline retailing business Software Warehouse, was also being extended, Mr Bennett said. Software Warehouse is 10 years old and has an annual turnover in excess of £100m.

Jungle.com has received more than 100m page impressions since going live in August. The company acts as a reseller for suppliers like Hewlett Packard, Microsoft, Compaq and Epsom and it guarantees consumers the lowest prices on products including PCs, games, CDs, videos and DVDs.

Experts say that the Jungle's rise was thanks in part to a £10m product giveaway at its launch and a high-profile advertising campaign.

 United News & Media is today expected to announce that its free internet service provider Lineone now has more than 750,000 registered users. It is likely to make Lineone Britain's second-largest ISP, ahead of AOL which has an estimated 700,000 users. Freeserve, the largest ISP, said last month that it had 1.675m registered users.

fields.headline: TechFare
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The US likes to corner the market in superlatives. One it can't claim rights to is the world's biggest internet fair. That honour goes to Germany where the CeBIT exhibition - lasting a week and expected to attract nearly 750,000 people - is being held. The Hanover show this week is Europe's attempt to prove that there's plenty the old world can do for the new economy.
fields.body:
The US likes to corner the market in superlatives. One it can't claim rights to is the world's biggest internet fair. That honour goes to Germany where the CeBIT exhibition - lasting a week and expected to attract nearly 750,000 people - is being held. The Hanover show this week is Europe's attempt to prove that there's plenty the old world can do for the new economy.

And to prove content is still king (or queen) telecoms group Motorola used CeBit to announce that it has tied up deals with 19 content providers - including Amazon.com and Reuters - to offer their services on its wireless application protocol mobile phones. The group aimed to increase the number of internet content providers for users of its mobile phones to 500.

Deutsche Telekom announced proposals to wire up Germany with a high-speed optical network - and selected cable expert Lucent as the company to deliver its plans. The deal, worth several hundred million German marks, means that by 2001, Deutsche Telekom will be able to offer its customers transmission rates up to 40 gigabits per second - the fastest for household use in Europe.

Those big boys and their small toys. Sony has signed up Microsoft so that its hi-tech CMD-Z5 GSM mobile phone will be powered by the Seattle-based company's Explorer browser. The Sony phone, which provides access to both Wap and Web services, weighs a mere 80 grams and is smaller than a credit card.

Tech-heads could not decide whether to cheer or jeer palm products maker Psion yesterday. The company that it was hoped would stymie the advance of Bill Gates Inc, is instead intent on getting into bed with the world's largest company.

A deal with Citrix Systems means the Cambridge-based company's customers will be able to use systems based on Microsoft's Windows operating system.

Question of the day was presented by mobile phone maker Ericsson. It launched a new water, dust and shock resistant GSM phone for outdoor adventure sports use called the R310.

The company said it can be used while climbing, hiking, river rafting or off-piste skiing. The question being asked in Germany is why anyone would answer while attempting any of the above.

webTitle: Health chiefs to shut Shipman's surgery

fields.headline: Health chiefs to shut Shipman's surgery
fields.standfirst: Shipman trial: special report
fields.trailText: The surgery where serial killer Harold Shipman is believed to have murdered at least five of his patients is to be closed, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
The surgery where serial killer Harold Shipman is believed to have murdered at least five of his patients is to be closed, it was announced yesterday.

Health authority officials have decided that it would be "inappropriate" for relatives to have to use or even pass by the surgery in the centre of Hyde, Greater Manchester.

Shipman operated a one-man practice from the surgery for six years during which he set out on a killing spree which led to him receiving 15 life sentences at Preston crown court last month.

The decision to move to new premises was endorsed last night by the Tameside and Glossop community health council. "We think it would be very unsettling for patients to be treated in premises where at least five women have died at the hands of their GP," said Pauline Davenport, chair of the council. "We need to restore some of the trust in the patient-doctor relationship that has been eroded by recent events.

The West Pennine area health authority does not expect any move for at least three months. "In the short term, the only realistic option is to keep the surgery open," said a spokesman. He said the medical practices committee would be asked to declare a vacancy.

The health authority and the community health council believe more than one doctor should take over Shipman's list of more than 3,000 patients.
