fields.headline: Softbank's Nippon buy-out
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Japan's voracious e-business sector looked ready to take a slice of the traditional economy yesterday when a consortium lead by internet company Softbank won approval for a bargain buy-out of one of the country's biggest financial institutions.
fields.body:
Japan's voracious e-business sector looked ready to take a slice of the traditional economy yesterday when a consortium lead by internet company Softbank won approval for a bargain buy-out of one of the country's biggest financial institutions.

The planned takeover of Nippon Credit Bank, which went belly-up during the financial crisis two years ago, was given a cautious welcome by analysts as a sign that Japan Inc is reinventing itself.

Concerns were expressed that the bank could become the tool of Softbank's president, Masayoshi Son, who is on course to overtake Bill Gates as the world's richest man. Mr Son's wealth is ticking up towards $70bn (£44bn), while Mr Gates can lay claim to $75bn.

The government, which nationalised NCB in 1998, said it was willing to sell the bank for about 1bn yen (£5.6m). It will use taxpayers' money to write off 3.2 trillion yen in bad debts held by the bank and strengthen its finances with a 240bn-yen capital infusion.

In return, Softbank and its partners - Orix Corp, Japan's largest leasing company, and insurer Tokio Marine & Fire - will pump an extra 1bn yen into the bank. This will be the second sale of its type in Japan, after the takeover last year of the defunct Long Term Credit Bank by Ripplewood, a New York-based investment group.

Softbank, an investment vehicle controlling more than 120 companies, said it would transform NCB into an internet bank funding technology start-ups. Japan's 14th largest lender when it collapsed, NCB has assets of some 5 trillion yen.

fields.headline: DoubleClick repels 'piracy of privacy' assault
fields.standfirst: His heroine championed individual rights. Now Kevin O'Connor's firm is accused of abusing themE-finance: special report
fields.trailText: A billboard near one of New York's most recognisable buildings welcomes visitors to Silicon Alley. High above the Flatiron building, the sign has been reprinted hundreds of times. Each time the sign is reprinted, the company that paid for the billboard is given another plug.
fields.body:
A billboard near one of New York's most recognisable buildings welcomes visitors to Silicon Alley. High above the Flatiron building, the sign has been reprinted hundreds of times. Each time the sign is reprinted, the company that paid for the billboard is given another plug.

"It was a brilliant marketing move," says Kevin O'Connor, chief executive of Doubleclick, the company emblazoned across the billboard. "And it had nothing to do with me." O'Connor, a serial entrepreneur who dreamt up DoubleClick after eight months working on business ideas in his basement, is the first to admit that he knows nothing about marketing.

Yet his company now reaches at least half of all internet users through agreements with more than 1,300 websites in 22 different countries. Click on almost any online advertisement today and it is likely to say "ad.doubleclick.net" at the bottom of your browser window.

Despite such dominance, the company remained virtually unknown to consumers - until now. In recent weeks, it as found itself at the centre of a core debate about the internet - the protection of privacy. Last week, the federal trade commission and two US states launched inquiries into the company's data collection.

Such inquiries are significant because the government has maintained a laissez-faire approach to internet regulation to date. The FTC report on the issue, expected in six to 12 month, could mark a turning point for the industry.

The investigations follow complaints by consumer advocacy groups such as the Centre for Democracy and Technology and a private lawsuit which accused DoubleClick of unlawfully obtaining and selling consumers' private information. The company, which provides the technology to put advertisements online as well as gathering consumer information, provoked the latest protests with its acquisition of Abacus, a direct marketing company, last year.

The purchase allowed the group, for the first time, to link information which identifies someone's name, address and offline purchasing habits with online information about their web-surfing habits.

DoubleClick updated its privacy policy earlier this month and offers an opt-out. But privacy advocates believe that few individuals know enough about what is going on to bother to do so.

The Silicon Alley company is staggering under the assault. It is soon to appoint a chief privacy officer to act as a sort of ombudsman for complaints and has appointed accountants to conduct regular privacy audits.

O'Connor, a softly spoken engineering graduate, has said little about the issue in recent weeks. But in an interview with the Guardian he explained how his company was founded on the idea of collecting information. "What makes the internet so attractive is that it's all about me," he says. "The internet takes its shape depending on what I want as a consumer."

In order to reach this peak of individualism, consumers have to give "something in return" and that something is personal information. "Consumers want free ac cess to the internet, they want relevant ads and cheaper products. If companies can market effectively then products should be cheaper," he says.

O'Connor becomes animated when talking about the privacy issue. "There are some people on the internet who want to go back to the old days when there was no advertising and it was government-controlled," he says. "We believe that this is a tremendous thing and that it should be free. That means it is going to be funded by advertising."

Few industry analysts have so far supported the calls for action against DoubleClick. Perry Boyle at Thomas Weisel and partners, the investment bank, says its detailed privacy policy and opt-out clause put DoubleClick on "the right side of God and man". They believe that the latest complaints reflect concerns about the little-understood power of the internet rather than the use of personal information by big business and cite lack of concern about use of information by credit card companies.

The company was formed by an amalgam of the software company created in O'Connor's basement and an ad sales group with the much better name of DoubleClick. O'Connor, who lives with his wife and two sons in New York, has a 16% stake in DoubleClick worth $1.6bn.

In the company's early days - it was founded in 1995 - former employees say that O'Connor rallied the troops by saying: "We want to be the Microsoft of internet advertising". He now looks a bit embarrassed when asked if he wants to emulate the company that has been accused of abusive monopolistic behaviour.

The standard response from friends and former colleagues when asked about the 38-year-old, however, is that he is a "good guy and intensely competitive".

He named his two sons after his heroes: Thomas Edison, the inventor, and Ayn Rand, the US novelist and writer, who was deeply concerned with the theme of extreme individualism. He has defended his passion for Rand by saying: "Basically she said individuals always do the best for the individual... If you can align the individuals' goals and desires with that of the company, you can build a very powerful company." Fighting words from a man whose company is at the centre of a conflict over the rights of the individual.

webTitle: Pakistan prosecutors try to stop Sharif testifying in public

fields.headline: Pakistan prosecutors try to stop Sharif testifying in public
fields.standfirst: Pakistan coup: special report
fields.trailText: A judge is to rule today on whether Pakistan's deposed prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, should be allowed to testify in open court.
fields.body:
A judge is to rule today on whether Pakistan's deposed prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, should be allowed to testify in open court.

Mr Sharif, who was overthrown by a military coup on October 12, is on trial along with his brother, Shahbaz, and five former senior government officials. They have pleaded not guilty to charges of hijacking, kidnapping, attempted murder and terrorism which could carry the death penalty.

Mr Sharif's lawyers were preparing to open their defence yesterday, but prosecutors intervened to argue that the former leader could undermine national security in Pakistan - currently ruled by a military-dominated administration - if his testimony was not kept private. His evidence will focus on the hours before the army seized control.

"I am not against the media. I just want to ensure that the national interest, security and integrity are not harmed," said the attorney general, Raja Qureshi.

On the day of the coup, Mr Sharif sacked the army chief, General Pervez Musharraf, who was flying back to Pakistan after a trip abroad.

The prosecution claims that Mr Sharif ordered that the Pakistan International Airlines jet carrying the general should be refused landing permission anywhere inside the country, even though it was running low on fuel, and so endangered the lives of the 198 people on board.

The plane landed after troops seized Karachi airport. Within hours Gen Musharraf had taken over, proclaimed himself "chief executive" and detained Mr Sharif.

Defence lawyers insist that Mr Sharif acted only after the army had launched its coup.

Since the trial began last month, prosecutors have called 27 witnesses to support their case, including the civil aviation authority chief, Aminullah Chaudhary, who was charged but pardoned after turning state's evidence.

Mr Chaudhary, a former colleague of the prime minister, testified that Mr Sharif gave the order to prevent the plane landing. Witnesses told how Karachi airport's lights were turned off and its runway blocked by fire engines.

Earlier in the hearing, Mr Qureshi refused to play instrument tapes from Gen Musharraf's plane, including the cockpit voice recorder which would have recorded conversations between the aircraft and Karachi air controllers. He said they were blank.

Lawyers for Mr Sharif insist that he should be given the right to speak in an open court. They also complained that notes taken by the defendants during the trial had been stolen from their cells and may have been passed to the prosecution.

webTitle: One year on and the crisis in the Balkans is unresolved

fields.headline: One year on and the crisis in the Balkans is unresolved
fields.standfirst: We must resist the temptation to ignore the troubled regionKosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Anniversaries can exercise a lunar pull on events. That was the effect, last year, of Nato's 50th anniversary, the imminence of which hardened western policy toward Serbia and helped bring on the Kosovo war.
fields.body:
Anniversaries can exercise a lunar pull on events. That was the effect, last year, of Nato's 50th anniversary, the imminence of which hardened western policy toward Serbia and helped bring on the Kosovo war. This year the March anniversary of the beginning of that war has set off efforts by the Milosevic regime to undo what there is of a settlement in Kosovo, with dramatic results in Mitrovice. The shock of Mitrovice, where international troops face the hostility, and perhaps the bullets, of both sides, could be salutary. As we approach the date when Nato's bombing campaign began last year, it is urgent that there should be a review of the failures of western policy not only in Kosovo, but also in Bosnia and in the wider region.

It is election year in America, and European states have their domestic preoccupations. But the temptation to let the Balkans slide ought to be resisted because of two important changes, one hopeful and one threatening. The first is the replacement of the Tudjman regime in Croatia last month by a genuinely democratic government, which does not want to continue running part of Bosnia as a covert dependency. This could mean a new start in Bosnia, the beginning of an end to "soft partition" between the three ethnic zones, and have wider beneficial effects. The second, threatening, development is that Slobodan Milosevic is going on the offensive, or preparing to do so, in northern Kosovo, Montenegro, and the Albanian populated parts of southern Serbia.

The standard approach in both Bosnia and Kosovo has been to avoid trouble, especially trouble which might lead to military casualties. The international authorities installed in both territories face entrenched ethnic attitudes, a one-party mentality in politics, distorted economic structures that reinforce patronage and communal separation, corruption and organised crime. But the "internationals", as they are called, have serious problems of cohesion, because so many organisations and nationalities are involved. They have been undermined, especially in Kosovo, by the refusal of governments to honour their pledges to provide personnel and funds. They seem to have available large means of coercion, in the shape of the many thousands of troops in the two territories. He described his efforts in a recent lecture in London. His biggest opportunity comes with the change in Croatia. Stipe Mesic, the new Croatian president, has told Bosnian Croats in future to look to Sarajevo, not Zagreb. The subventions, very costly to the Croat economy, with which the Tudjman government supported the Bosnian Croat community will be reduced and what continues may in future go through the central authorities in Sarajevo.

Change in Zagreb should also mean that more Serbian refugees go back to the Krajina, and more Croatian refugees to Bosnia. Bosnians who want an integrated state believe that this may be the last year in which the chance of it can be seized. But, even if it is seized, at some point in the future progress would halt unless the Dayton framework is fundamentally revised.

The equivalent of Dayton in Kosovo is the settlement which ended the war, a dilute version of the Rambouillet proposals. This leaves the territory stranded between in dependence, which is a forbidden topic, and re-attachment to Serbia, which is a nonsense. Without a clear political end in view, drift can take over. The administration and the international military force notoriously failed to prevent months of revenge attacks on Serbs, and also failed, more recently, to protect Albanians against Serbs in the few areas where such attacks are possible. It failed especially, in Mitrovice, to prevent Serbs seizing half a city, with the consequences we now see.

The ruling Serbian party, the Socialist Party of Serbia, has been holding meetings in Kosovo denouncing the UN and charging that its head, Bernard Kouchner, is allied to the "Albanian narco-mafia". Local leaders, directed from Serbia, have been re-establishing "governmental" bodies, setting up radio stations, and making plans for an assembly. Moderate Serbian leaders such as Bishop Artemje, who want to work within the Kosovo structures, are being marginalised and could soon be at risk of their lives. A partition strategy can easily be discerned. Down on the south-eastern border between Kosovo and Serbia, both the Serbs and the KLA may be preparing to start a fight. fields.headline: Caught in a global trap
fields.standfirst: Treasury tax options are narrowing
fields.trailText: The next budget - now less than a month away - will be a very unusual occasion: a Labour chancellor will be sitting on a budget surplus of £10bn or more in the midst of an eager clamour to improve public services like education, transport and health. But there are complications. First, surpluses at the peak of the economic cycle have to be balanced against deficits the the bottom end. Second, the economy is presumed by the authorities to be in danger of overheating - hence the recent increases in interest rates - so a public spending spree now could undermine the aim of stable growth so dear to the chancellor's heart. Third, there is no way that Gordon Brown will put at risk what he regards as a priceless asset - his reputation in the city as an iron chancellor.
fields.body:
The next budget - now less than a month away - will be a very unusual occasion: a Labour chancellor will be sitting on a budget surplus of £10bn or more in the midst of an eager clamour to improve public services like education, transport and health. But there are complications. First, surpluses at the peak of the economic cycle have to be balanced against deficits the the bottom end. Second, the economy is presumed by the authorities to be in danger of overheating - hence the recent increases in interest rates - so a public spending spree now could undermine the aim of stable growth so dear to the chancellor's heart. Third, there is no way that Gordon Brown will put at risk what he regards as a priceless asset - his reputation in the city as an iron chancellor.

There is another, less visible, reason for caution: a growing resistance to paying taxes among richer people. Globalisation and the spread of the internet will make that worse. Customers are already finding how easy it is to order products in one country through the world wide web for delivery in another to avoid local taxes. There is a strong movement in the US to make the internet a tax-free area to promote enterprise. And bookmakers and others are migrating to offshore islands where they can pursue their activities out of the taxman's shadow.

Britain's own explosion of internet start-up companies has unleashed a wealth of submerged entrepreneurial talent, promising a big boost to our GDP. But entrepreneurs are up in arms because the government levies national insurance contributions on unapproved share option schemes. This is a real problem because so many of the start-ups lure people to work for them with stock options rather than real money. The chancellor is eager to clear this up because the government is committed to encouraging enterprise. And there is the rub. In any one of these cases there may a good case to show leniency. But to look sympathetically at all of them would greatly erode the future tax base.

Take, for instance, the tax on sales of shares. It stands at a very modest 0.5% at present. Any reforming chancellor might regard an increase in duty as a painless way of extracting income from investors whose shares have soared in recent years by far more than they - or the City experts - ever envisaged. But this is not an option. It is much more likely that the level will be reduced. Why? Because stamp duty is lower in other key markets like the US. If London has a competitive disadvantage like this, much of the stock exchange could, electronically, migrate to New York. Thank you, globalisation.

Another example: the best way of defusing the booming housing market would be to impose capital gains tax on house sales. This is surely a better option than raising interest rates across the country just to clobber house prices in the south. But to do this would be like putting a financial dagger into the hearts of Daily Mail readers and is not even remotely on the agenda. Instead the chancellor may slightly increase the existing 1% stamp duty on houses worth more £60,000. This will not dampen demand much, but could still be seen by middle England as a "stealth tax".

Another source of income (as David Mills pointed out in the Guardian this week) would be a tax on the hundreds of thousands of foreigners who are resident in the UK but whose domicile (real home) is abroad and who pay little or no income taxes here. This is a neat wheeze - especially if the revenues were hypothecated to sort out London's traffic problems. But again the chancellor has to think global. Suppose that they all up sticks and move on to the next tax haven. He knows that they are only here in the first place because of the ease with which people and capital can move from one country to another in a globalised era.

The chancellor has enough money in his piggy bank this year not to worry about all this. He will be able to boost health spending by 5% or more and dare the opposition to decry it. But underneath the surface, the tectonic plates of the tax base are moving. There is a political embargo on raising the standard rate of income tax and the scope for increasing other taxes by stealth is becoming increasingly limited. When future recessions erode the budget surplus the government may have to find other subtler ways of raising taxes from assets that cannot move (like, say, land). The alternative is to educate the electorate into understanding why improvements in roads, education and health actually have to be paid for. Gordon Brown must be thankful that he will not have to do that this year. But ignoring the problem will not make it go away.

fields.headline: Death of a superstar
fields.standfirst:
We mourn both the man and his era
A human reminder to the monster
fields.trailText: For the death of a footballer to be greeted as the death of Sir Stanley Matthews has been, with tributes from Buckingham Palace and Downing Street downwards, suggests that something more is involved than saying goodbye to one of our greatest sporting stars. We are also saying goodbye to an era whose loss we regret and to values we fear may be lost.
fields.body:
For the death of a footballer to be greeted as the death of Sir Stanley Matthews has been, with tributes from Buckingham Palace and Downing Street downwards, suggests that something more is involved than saying goodbye to one of our greatest sporting stars. We are also saying goodbye to an era whose loss we regret and to values we fear may be lost.

The best of Sir Stanley's football was over by the end of the 1950s, which means that hardly anyone in this country under the age of 45 will have seen him at work. The television film told part of the story - the way he would draw a defender to him, show him, almost give him, the ball, only then to whip it away leaving him floundering, and cross it just to the point where his centre forward wanted it. But the baggy shorts and the stadiums full of men in hats were part of the story too. He never earned more than £20 a week. His transfer from Stoke to Blackpool cost his new club a mere £11,500. He played his whole career without troubling referees. There were no yellow cards in those days, and sending-offs, which now seem to furnish a sizeable list every week, were a rare and terrible punishment. Referees erred then as now, possibly more so, but were not chased in packs by dissatisfied players.

The crowds in those days went home to their teas on Saturday evening talking of Matthews's magic control, or Nat Lofthouse's supercharged headers, or Billy Wright's faultless defending, rather than rows between managers, players or agents, or complaints about the officials. What is at work is nostalgia, a practice much condemned but often hard to avoid. And why does it spread to those who never saw Stanley Matthews? Perhaps because, as the playwright Anouilh said, nostalgia for times you never experienced is sometimes the cruellest of all.

fields.headline: Going fishing
fields.standfirst:
Something odd has swum into Boris's net

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The Spectator has announced that the Guardian's line on Northern Ireland is covertly dictated by a republican cell, which has cleverly infiltrated its staff, taking its editor on pub crawls of the Bogside, impregnating its deputy editor and luring its columnists to secret fishing trips in Co Donegal.
fields.body:
The Spectator has announced that the Guardian's line on Northern Ireland is covertly dictated by a republican cell, which has cleverly infiltrated its staff, taking its editor on pub crawls of the Bogside, impregnating its deputy editor and luring its columnists to secret fishing trips in Co Donegal.

It is a disturbing claim by the magazine, which has lurched uncertainly under the new editorship of Boris Johnson, a tousled-haired Old Salopian who once stood for a Scottish constituency in the hope of acquiring the gravitas which some feel he lacks as a journalist. Mr Johnson has little understanding of Northern Ireland, but appreciates that his career prospects depend on increasing circulation. Making the claim that a national newspaper is in the secret grip of the IRA is a good enough wheeze. Mr Johnson's naivety on Ireland is a bonus for his columnist, Stephen Glover, a fanatical unionist. Mr Glover, who is the only son of the late character actor Brian, is regularly "used" by intelligence sources. In this role as an MI5/6 "asset", he is in a long line of obliging Spectator figures from Dominic Lawson to Alan Judd. Mr Johnson also enjoys the social cachet of dining with spooks. He will never admit error. As he often tells his sister, Ulrika: "If it's only half true it's only half wrong."

Some Guardian readers may find some of the above hard to believe. They are right. Some of it is true, some is half-baked gossip and some is garbage. But the fun of Doughty Street journalism is working out which is which. You decide.

webTitle: Iraqis stripped of hope, ambition and future

fields.headline: Iraqis stripped of hope, ambition and future
fields.standfirst:
Isolation due to embargo and war is deepened by the regime: doctors cannot use the internet, satellite TV is illegal

Iraq: special report
fields.trailText: Civil engineer Jalil Abadi, 55, is ending his career - for which he has been paid the equivalent of 30 cents (18p) a day - overseeing Baghdad museum's display of dusty mannequins in traditional costumes.
fields.body:
Civil engineer Jalil Abadi, 55, is ending his career - for which he has been paid the equivalent of 30 cents (18p) a day - overseeing Baghdad museum's display of dusty mannequins in traditional costumes.

His office has no computer, no journals, no filing cabinet and no heat. The electricity is on but could flick off at any moment under one of Baghdad's frequent rolling blackouts.

Mr Abadi's goals as local museum director are scrawled on a piece of ragged pink paper: add a few more mannequins; maybe get the heating fixed.

Normal life - the ability to plan schooling, a career or a family with some sense of what the future will be - ended in Iraq 20 years ago, when President Saddam Hussein launched a costly eight-year war with Iran. The uncertainty and upheaval were compounded in August 1990 when Iraq invaded Kuwait, leading to war with an American-led alliance and the punitive international sanctions that have gone on ever since.

After two decades in the suspended animation of war or economic sanctions, this is a country sapped of ambition, where everyone remembers someone killed or taken prisoner, but few have hopes for the future.

"Not married, no life, no continuous job," was how Mazan Jafar summed up his situation seven years after receiving an engineering degree. He sometimes gets work designing housing for a private firm, supplemented by work on a book stall.

Twenty years ago, Iraq was considered an emerging success story, with high literacy rates and social programmes that paid for the education abroad of thousands of Iraqis. Oil prices were high and the state's largesse helped boost living standards through electricity, road and other infrastructure projects, and direct loans for consumer goods such as automobiles.

But all that is gone, and the memory of it compounds the sense of loss.

"It's not normal, the situation now," said Jamal Daoud, dean of the business school at al-Mastansaria university. "My secretary takes home 3,000 dinars a month [less than £1.20]. That's not enough to buy two chickens... Iraq will need 20 years to start from the beginning."

From rising crime and an increase in fatherless households, to falling literacy rates and school enrolment, the evidence of decline is all around, United Nations workers say. The poor struggle under rationing, getting little more than a basic diet on the UN-monitored food programme.

Humanitarian groups have focused on the most dramatic effects of trade sanctions, including controversial estimates of "excess deaths" attributable to the restrictions.

UN officials have documented acute problems exacerbated by the sanctions, including a steep rise in infant mortality since the Gulf war and the recurrence of diseases attributable to poor sanitation and the initial collapse of immunisation programmes.

Some conditions are improving. But potentially more troubling is the collapse of the middle and technical class that Iraq's oil wealth had helped build in the 1970s. Such people have swapped professional aspirations for a cab driver's licence; they sell the family furniture to get by.

Links to the outside world are few. Dropout rates are rising. College students study from crumbling journals that were printed before the end of the cold war. Medical doctors are puzzled about a phenomenon called the internet.

"Iraq is quickly becoming a third world country again," said Hans von Sponeck shortly before announcing his resignation earlier this month as coordinator of the UN programme under which Iraq is allowed to sell a certain volume of oil to buy food, medicine and other relief supplies. "All of the energy goes into survival, coping."

A different sort of elite - what one UN official called "fixers, operators and black marketeers" - sustains a market for luxury cars and other expensive goods. But far more indicative of life in Baghdad are the thousands of vehicles belching exhaust and in need of repairs that their owners cannot afford in what has become a strapped together, baling-wire culture - this in a country with enough oil and other resources to sustain its people.

Discussion of how to improve matters is almost non-existent. There is a weak opposition movement outside the country, backed by the US, and an autonomous region run by Kurds in the north-east, also dependent on western air surveillance.

But in Baghdad, the heart of power, no one talks openly against, or even analytically about, a government known to punish dissent at the end of a rope and so sensitive about information that it jails citizens caught with satellite dishes.

When asked about the country's leadership, the more adventurous chuckle nervously. Others attribute their troubles to "bad luck". More likely they blame, as Mr Abadi does, "conspiracies" that forced Iraq to war with Iran and to invade Kuwait, or they devolve into complaints about US imperialism.

Principles have become an important part of the intellectual diet. Even the president has begun to counsel forbearance.

"Nothing is more capable of weakening resolution and blurring the ability to see things in the right perspective and evaluate them correctly than avarice and greed to acquire unnecessary food, clothing, drink and other things," he said recently in his annual speech.

But even critics of sanctions say Iraqis could manage better with the resources they are provided with: medical journals, for example, might be expensive and hard to get, but nothing is preventing the ministry of health from providing access to information around the globe through the internet.

"They say they are going to bring a computer, but it hasn't happened," said Abbas Owayed, 31, a doctor at Baghdad's main teaching hospital. "I hear it has gotten highly sophisticated." Washington Post

"Not married, no life, no continuous job," was how Mazan Jafar summed up his situation seven years after receiving an engineering degree. He sometimes gets work designing housing for a private firm, supplemented by work on a book stall. Twenty years ago, Iraq was considered an emerging success story, with high literacy rates and social programmes that paid for the education abroad of thousands of Iraqis. Oil prices were high and the state's largesse helped boost living standards through electricity, road and other infrastructure projects, and direct loans for consumer goods such as automobiles. But all that is gone, and the memory of it compounds the sense of loss. "It's not normal, the situation now," said Jamal Daoud, dean of the business school at al-Mastansaria university. "My secretary takes home 3,000 dinars a month [less than £1.20]. That's not enough to buy two chickens... Iraq will need 20 years to start from the beginning." From rising crime and an increase in fatherless households, to falling literacy rates and school enrolment, the evidence of decline is all around, United Nations workers say. The poor struggle under rationing, getting little more than a basic diet on the UN-monitored food programme. Humanitarian groups have focused on the most dramatic effects of trade sanctions, including controversial estimates of "excess deaths" attributable to the restrictions. UN officials have documented acute problems exacerbated by the sanctions, including a steep rise in infant mortality since the Gulf war and the recurrence of diseases attributable to poor sanitation and the initial collapse of immunisation programmes. Some conditions are improving. But potentially more troubling is the collapse of the middle and technical class that Iraq's oil wealth had helped build in the 1970s. Such people have swapped professional aspirations for a cab driver's licence; they sell the family furniture to get by. Links to the outside world are few. Dropout rates are rising. College students study from crumbling journals that were printed before the end of the cold war. Medical doctors are puzzled about a phenomenon called the internet. "Iraq is quickly becoming a third world country again," said Hans von Sponeck shortly before announcing his resignation earlier this month as coordinator of the UN programme under which Iraq is allowed to sell a certain volume of oil to buy food, medicine and other relief supplies. "All of the energy goes into survival, coping." A different sort of elite - what one UN official called "fixers, operators and black marketeers" - sustains a market for luxury cars and other expensive goods. But far more indicative of life in Baghdad are the thousands of vehicles belching exhaust and in need of repairs that their owners cannot afford in what has become a strapped together, baling-wire culture - this in a country with enough oil and other resources to sustain its people. Discussion of how to improve matters is almost non-existent. There is a weak opposition movement outside the country, backed by the US, and an autonomous region run by Kurds in the north-east, also dependent on western air surveillance. But in Baghdad, the heart of power, no one talks openly against, or even analytically about, a government known to punish dissent at the end of a rope and so sensitive about information that it jails citizens caught with satellite dishes. When asked about the country's leadership, the more adventurous chuckle nervously. Others attribute their troubles to "bad luck". More likely they blame, as Mr Abadi does, "conspiracies" that forced Iraq to war with Iran and to invade Kuwait, or they devolve into complaints about US imperialism. Principles have become an important part of the intellectual diet. Even the president has begun to counsel forbearance. "Nothing is more capable of weakening resolution and blurring the ability to see things in the right perspective and evaluate them correctly than avarice and greed to acquire unnecessary food, clothing, drink and other things," he said recently in his annual speech. But even critics of sanctions say Iraqis could manage better with the resources they are provided with: medical journals, for example, might be expensive and hard to get, but nothing is preventing the ministry of health from providing access to information around the globe through the internet. "They say they are going to bring a computer, but it hasn't happened," said Abbas Owayed, 31, a doctor at Baghdad's main teaching hospital. "I hear it has gotten highly sophisticated." webTitle: UN strives for unity in Mitrovice

fields.headline: UN strives for unity in Mitrovice
fields.standfirst:
K-For moves cautiously to return Albanian refugees to homes in Kosovo flashpoint

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: UN officials yesterday stepped up plans to escort ethnic Albanian refugees back to their homes in northern Mitrovice, the city that is currently the worst flashpoint in Kosovo.
fields.body:
UN officials yesterday stepped up plans to escort ethnic Albanian refugees back to their homes in northern Mitrovice, the city that is currently the worst flashpoint in Kosovo.

The first of 1,500 Albanians who fled Serb attacks on their homes during the past two weeks are to be screened today by a UN committee in the south of the divided city, where they have taken shelter. Officials say they will be asking people to prove they lived in the north.

Stung by the latest ethnic cleansing - and by accusations from US and Nato officials that the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, was behind the turmoil in the north of the city - the UN administrator for Kosovo, Bernard Kouchner, announced this week that Mitrovice would be transformed into a "united city", doing away with de facto partition that sees Serbs predominating on the north side of the river Ibar and ethnic Albanians on the south.

He also announced that he was increasing efforts to create a joint Serb and Albanian city administration. Oliver Ivanovic, the head of the local branch of the Serb National Council, was told by Mr Kouchner yesterday that he must cooperate with the new scheme.

The Serbs have been running a shadow government in northern Mitrovice. Such organisations, including those run by Albanians elsewhere in Kosovo, were outlawed last month.

The UN also plans to build a footbridge across the river Ibar within the next three weeks to connect the southern part of the city with an enclave of mainly Albanian houses, known as Little Bosnia, on the Serb-dominated northern side. Little Bosnia is surrounded by vehicles and troops of the Nato-led international peacekeeping force, K-For, but its inhabitants are virtually trapped.

Canadian troops yesterday stood guard by the barbed wire on the main bridge in Mitrovice, replacing British contingents which left yesterday. US troops who conducted weapons searches on Wednesday have also been withdrawn, to be replaced by Italians and Spanish. The Serb and Alban ian demonstrators who confronted each other across the bridge earlier this week have dispersed.

After violent incidents on Sunday, when Serbs stoned the American troops during weapons searches, Wednesday's searches were largely symbolic. The K-For commander, General Klaus Reinhardt, apparently did not want to give the impression that the Americans had retreated. They have since pulled out of the city.

A K-For spokesman said the massive search operations in the city were over for the time being, with the focus moving further north yesterday to the area beyond the city which adjoins the border with Serbia. There have been repeated allegations that Serb police and security forces in civilian clothes have been infiltrating.

Belgian troops mounted an operation in Leposavic yesterday and discovered eight AK47 assault rifles in Serb hands, according to Captain Olivier St Leger, a K-For spokesman in Mitrovice.

Mitrovice used to have an Albanian majority on both sides of the river Ibar. But after the UN moved into Kosovo in June, Serbs took over flats which had been home to Albanians before last year's ethnic cleansing.

The aim was partly to create a Serb fortress and to partition the city. When Serbs in southern Mitrovice found themselves forced out as Albanians returned from refugee camps abroad, the population of an gry Serbs in the north increased.

Mr Kouchner is trying to overcome the partition by assuring Serbs they will not be pushed out of the north if they let Albanian residents moves back in there. Up to now, the policy of the French military commander in charge of Mitrovice has been to block any large movement of Albanian men across the bridges.

"I understand that Serbs are scared and we have to work on building their confidence," Mr Kouchner said this week.

Mitrovice's new property committee will look at Serb claims to flats in the south as well as the plight of the Albanians who fled.

fields.headline: Hillary wins the Hollywood vote
fields.standfirst: Glitterati and literati line up behind Mrs Clinton in battle for New York senate seat but her rival Giuliani has the big money backersThe US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Glitterati and literati line up behind Mrs Clinton in battle for New York senate seat, but her rival Giuliani has the big money backers.
fields.body:
Hillary Clinton has already been accused of running a Mickey Mouse campaign in her run for a New York senate seat this November - her latest blunder was to fail to leave a tip after eating in a restaurant - but further evidence emerged yesterday when it was revealed that her biggest cash backers were the employees of Walt Disney.

Mrs Clinton raised at least $437,000 (£272,500) from the entertainment industry last year - $56,550 from Disneyland - second only to the number of contributions from those in the law field.

Lawyers, a traditional Democrat constituency, gave $667,000. They have particular reason to be grateful to the Clintons, who have so far paid $5.9m in fees for their various legal battles and who still owe $4.3m.

The first lady and her opponent, Rudolph Giuliani, the mayor of New York, aim to raise $25m each to finance their campaigns for the seat in the US senate, making it the most expensive electoral race of its kind.

Mrs Clinton may have the big names, but Mr Giuliani has the big money. By the end of last year Mrs Clinton had raised $8.07m but her rival easily topped that with $11.78m. Both spent most of their money on mailshots asking for more cash.

She says that he is taking money from extreme rightwingers around the country; he has not yet formally announced that he will run. Bruce Teitelbaum, Mr Giuliani's campaign spokesman, said: "Hillary's Hollywood pals are paying big bucks to elect someone from Illinois and Arkansas to represent the people of New York. Maybe she should run in California."

Howard Wolfson, spokesman for Mrs Clinton, said the volume of contributions from the entertainment industry came because she was "a champion of the arts". "She's running against a guy who tried to shut down a museum," he added.

This was a reference to Mr Giuliani's attempt to withdraw funds from the Brooklyn Museum of Art because it hosted the Sensation exhibition of works by young British artists. The mayor took particular exception to the work of Chris Ofili, the Turner Prize-winning artist whose painting the Holy Virgin Mary was created using elephant dung.

Styron's choice

Mrs Clinton's starrier list of contributors also included members of the literati, such as William Styron, author of Sophie's Choice, and his wife Rose who gave $3,000 between them. Jean Auel, who wrote Clan of the Cave Bear, gave $1,000 and even Gail Sheehy, whose biography of Mrs Clinton was none-too-friendly, came up with $500.

Tina Brown, the British editor of Talk magazine, came through with $1,000 - a month after publishing the interview with Mrs Clinton that helped to generate a buzz for the first issue.

Not all the offerings were so unequivocally fragrant: Sean "Puffy" Combs - also known as Puff Daddy - the rap music entrepreneur who gave $1,000, has just been charged with bribery. He already faces firearms charges.

Mr Wolfson said that the Clinton camp had no intention of returning Puffy's money. "We believe in the presumption of innocence," he said.

But Mr Giuliani's roll-call of the Republican establishment also accommodates supporters in keeping with his combative personality. Among them are Mike Ditka, one of the most widely disliked coaches in professional football, and Charlton Heston who, in addition to his responsibilities to the cinema audience, is president of the National Rifles Association. Paradoxically, the caustic Mr Giuliani is in favour of tighter gun control.

Like Mrs Clinton, Mr Giuliani has supporters in the gay community: she has Elizabeth Birch, executive director of the Human Rights Fund ($2,000) and Virginia Apuzzo of the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force ($1,000); he has members of the Log Cabin Republicans ($3,000).

The mayor has also received money from prominent restaurateurs in New York City, including Warner LeRoy who reopened the Russian Tea Room recently, and Sottha Khunn, the chef at Le Cirque 2000.

Each candidate has designer supporters but other kings and queens of the catwalk hedged their bets. Oscar de la Renta, for instance, gave $1,000 to the mayor and to Mrs Clinton. Nicole Miller found $2,000 for him and $1,000 for her.

However the contest is not being fought exclusively at the level of who can attract the most famous followers. Mrs Clinton's camp has accused Mr Giuliani of allying with the extreme right because his fund-raising letters were written with the assistance of Richard Viguerie, whose record includes helping Jerry Falwell to set up the rightwing group Moral Majority 21 years ago. "If these are Rudy Giuliani's allies, what kind of senator would he be?" Mr Wolfson asked.

But Mr Teitelbaum said: "It sounds an awful lot like sour grapes. They fell way short of their fund-rising goals and we broke records."

webTitle: The Grammy awards hit a religious note

fields.headline: The Grammy awards hit a religious note
fields.standfirst: Stars thank God while Christians protest outside
fields.trailText: Rock musician Carlos Santana picked up a record-equalling eight awards while British veterans Sting and Elton John walked away with prizes at the American music business's annual Grammy ceremony on Wednesday night. But the main question was how much credit God should take for the awards.
fields.body:
Rock musician Carlos Santana picked up a record-equalling eight awards while British veterans Sting and Elton John walked away with prizes at the American music business's annual Grammy ceremony on Wednesday night. But the main question was how much credit God should take for the awards.

Eight of the 100 prizes at the Los Angeles ceremony went, as widely predicted, to Carlos Santana who picked up best album, best record and best song of the year for his album, Supernatural and his song, Smooth.

Sting's Brand New Day beat the more widely tipped Ricky Martin and Backstreet Boys to the best pop album award and he also won best male vocal award.

Christina Aguilera was also a surprise winner in taking the best new artist award ahead of Macy Gray and Britney Spears. TLC's FanMail won the best R & B album, Eminem the best rap album and the Dixie Chicks the best country album on a damp and chilly evening at the new Staples centre.

Religion featured more than politics in the ceremony with many of the performers thanking God, just ahead of their producers and record companies, for their success.

An idea that this might happen prompted the show's presenter, chat show hostess Rosie O'Donnell, to tell the audience at the start of the night that she had "bumped into God backstage and he says 'you're welcome'." But after Whitney Houston had thanked the Almighty for her prize, O'Donnell wondered if God really had enough time "solving world hunger and finding a cure for Aids to make sure Whitney Houston gets that Grammy award."

The two had clashed earlier when O'Donnell mentioned Houston's run-in with the law over the discovery of a bag of marijuana at an airport in Hawaii and Houston had responded with a gesture from her seat. Sting thanked his parents who he said were with God.

Outside, fundamental Christians demonstrated against the music business in general for "promoting sin" and inside O'Donnell added the only mildly political note by telling the audience to vote

"No on 22", a proposition brought before the Californian electorate next month which would deny recognition to gay marriage and which gay activists see as a homophobic move.

With Carlos Santana equalling Michael Jackson's previous record and setting the theme that there may still be popular musical life beyond 50, there were lifetime achievement awards for Harry Belafonte, Woody Guthrie, John Lee Hooker, Mitch Miller and Willie Nelson.

Those who did not make the ceremony but were presumably able to make their thank-yous personally included classical award winners Stravinsky, Handel, Schubert and Britten.

Other veteran Brits to pick up awards included Phil Collins - for his soundtrack for Disney's Tarzan - and heavy rockers Black Sabbath for best metal performance for Iron Man, from the album Reunion.

"I didn't think that 31 years ago, I'd be standing up in a suit. I feel more like an accountant than the guy who plays drums in Black Sabbath," said Bill Ward as he collected the band's award. He called the recognition of older artists "totally cool".

Santana used his after-ceremony interviews to attack "gossip and sensationalism" in the media coverage of music and to say that "dignity and class" should be rewarded rather than "shallowness and crass".

Elton John was given his special award by Billy Joel and after the ceremony congratulated singers like Macy Gray who "get on the road and earn their corn" as opposed to relying on videos which he said he hated. Cher won best dance recording for Believe.

Other controversies on the night were provided by the country group, the Dixie Chicks who performed a graphically enacted song, Goodbye Earl, about murdering an abusive husband and disposing of his body.

Jennifer Lopez won the "least-dressed" award with a spectacular outfit and arrived with her boyfriend Sean 'Puffy' Combs, who earlier in the day had been charged with bribery in connection with a gun incident in a New York nightclub. He told reporters on his way to the event: "I'm innocent."

"I didn't think that 31 years ago, I'd be standing up in a suit. I feel more like an accountant than the guy who plays drums in Black Sabbath," said Bill Ward as he collected the band's award. He called the recognition of older artists "totally cool". Santana used his after-ceremony interviews to attack "gossip and sensationalism" in the media coverage of music and to say that "dignity and class" should be rewarded rather than "shallowness and crass". Elton John was given his special award by Billy Joel and after the ceremony congratulated singers like Macy Gray who "get on the road and earn their corn" as opposed to relying on videos which he said he hated. Cher won best dance recording for Believe. Other controversies on the night were provided by the country group, the Dixie Chicks who performed a graphically enacted song, Goodbye Earl, about murdering an abusive husband and disposing of his body. Jennifer Lopez won the "least-dressed" award with a spectacular outfit and arrived with her boyfriend Sean 'Puffy' Combs, who earlier in the day had been charged with bribery in connection with a gun incident in a New York nightclub. He told reporters on his way to the event: "I'm innocent."

webTitle: Spice Girls must pay up to £1m in damages

fields.headline: Spice Girls must pay up to £1m in damages
fields.trailText: The Spice Girls' attempt to sue the motorcycle manufacturer Aprilia backfired yesterday when a high court judge threw out their claim and instead landed them with a bill for damages of up to £1m.
fields.body:
The Spice Girls' attempt to sue the motorcycle manufacturer Aprilia backfired yesterday when a high court judge threw out their claim and instead landed them with a bill for damages of up to £1m.

The group had initially sued for £218,000 in unpaid royalties from the Italian firm, sponsors of their world tour in 1998, but Mrs Justice Arden dismissed that action and found in favour of a counter-claim by the company.

Aprilia claimed £434,000 for misrepresentation following Geri Halliwell's departure from the group shortly after they had signed a £500,000 sponsorship agreement. A further claim of £1.6m for breach of contract was dismissed.

Mrs Justice Arden upheld Aprilia's argument that the group had known Ms Halliwell was leaving the Spice Girls when they signed the sponsorship agreement in May, 1998.

Her departure undermined Aprilia's marketing campaign and promotional material, which had featured all five group members, the judge ruled.

Damages, costs and interest owed will be set at a future hearing, but yesterday it emerged that the group had rejected an offer to pay Aprilia a smaller sum in damages.

The total cost is expected to reach seven-figures.

Mrs Justice Arden accepted the band had entered into the agreement in good faith. "There is no suggestion whatever that the misrepresentation was intentional."

A spokesman for Aprilia said that before receiving a writ they had been willing to write off their losses, and been "astonished" when the group sued in October, 1998.

"Aprilia would not have sued if the Spice Girls had not brought their claim, and were deeply disappointed when they did."

When the Spice Girls began negotiations with Aprilia in the early part of 1998 the group consisted of Ms Halliwell, Victoria Adams, Emma Bunting, Melanie Brown and Melanie Chisolm.

But at a meeting backstage at Wembley arena on April 25, 1998, Ms Halliwell told the other group members she would be leaving at the end of the world tour the following September.

Just 10 days later they signed a one-year sponsorship agreement with Aprilia.

The agreement covered participating in commercials, photo shoots and providing a logo featuring all five band members for a special edition scooter, the Spice Sonic.

Roberto Brovazzo, head of Aprilia's marketing department, said that the group was "symbolic of the fashionable, fresh and a bit cheeky image that Aprilia wanted to convey for the Sonic scooter which it had recently launched".

Ms Halliwell's departure rendered the campaign "a complete marketing flop".

webTitle: Blood product promoted despite reports of patient deaths

fields.headline: Blood product promoted despite reports of patient deaths
fields.trailText: A £1.4m campaign has been launched by the plasma products industry to promote albumin, despite concerns that its use in critically ill patients may increase their chances of dying.
fields.body:
A £1.4m campaign has been launched by the plasma products industry to promote albumin, despite concerns that its use in critically ill patients may increase their chances of dying.

Albumin is a blood protein that has been used for more than 50 years to treat emergency shock and burns victims. But in the last two years it has been at the centre of a controversy following a review of 30 controlled trials on its use which was carried out by the Cochrane injuries group.

The Cochrane review, published in July 1998, found that treating critically ill patients with albumin did not save lives and, on the contrary, could account for six extra deaths in every 100 patients treated. While the scientists, in their paper published in the British Medical Journal, cautioned that the 30 studies were small, they concluded that "the use of human albumin solution in critically ill patients should be urgently reviewed."

One year later, the committee on the safety of medicines in the UK advised doctors that albumin use should be restricted to the treatment of hypovolaemia - an abnormal reduction of the volume of blood circulating around the body. The medicines control agency, the licensing body, is still considering with its European counterparts what guidance to issue on albumin.

The controversy has led to a marked drop in the use of the blood product.

But according to this week's BMJ, the plasma industry is fighting back. It has put together a dossier of studies favourable to albumin and is launching a campaign to collect favourable data and to market and promote albumin.

The campaign is being led by two trade associations, the International Plasma Products Industry Association and the European Association of the Plasma Products Industry. But the BMJ reveals that Richard Walker, chief executive of Bio Products Laboratory which makes albumin in Britain and is part of the national blood authority, has backed the campaign in his capacity as president of a third association of not-for-profit European plasma organisations.

Yesterday Mr Walker said there was no conflict of interest between his support for the pro-albumin campaign and his role as head of the manufacturing arm of the national blood authority, which is a NHS special health authority.

"Manufacturers of pharmaceuticals are duty bound to promote products in an appropriate manner to let people know they are available," he said.

"The albumin issue has deliberately been made a highly emotive issue by the review which the BMJ promoted very heavily, for which they were heavily criticised by some clinicians. If you read the review it says there might be a problem. It was publicised as 'albumin kills' which is not appropriate", he said.

"This is a competitive industry. Individual clinicians must make their own judgements on whether to treat with albumin."

He said that Bio Products would not be joining the £1.4m campaign but added: "We will promote albumin in accordance with the way we always have, in accordance with our product licence."

fields.headline: 'Huge fireball visible for miles'
fields.standfirst:
Butler tells of helpless horror

More about Michael Colvin MP
fields.trailText: Alvaro Pereira, 67, who has worked as the Colvins' butler for 31 years, was woken by another worker in the early hours. He described their battle to reach the couple.
fields.body:
Alvaro Pereira, 67, who has worked as the Colvins' butler for 31 years, was woken by another worker in the early hours. He described their battle to reach the couple.

"We raced round to the front and desperately tried to get in but were beaten back by the flames. I called their names and there was no response and we tried to open the front door but it was just too hot.

"In the end we had to give up and wait for the fire brigade to arrive. I can't even begin to describe what it was like knowing they were in there and we could do nothing. We are all really upset. They were a lovely couple to work for.

"Another man working here, Peter, smelled burning from his cottage could see smoke and flames so he ran to wake me. But there was nothing we could do."

Malcolm Eastwood, chief fire officer for Hampshire, said: "I could see this huge fireball on the horizon from five miles away. It was a massive fire. There was a white ball of fire engulfing the whole of the front of the house. The floors were collapsing and the roof was about to drop in. The noise was colossal.

"Around a dozen officers tried to get into the front of the building but were beaten back by the intense heat and flames.

"We had been told by the estate worker who called us that the Colvins were in an upstairs bedroom and could not get out. The officers went round the back and managed to enter the property from the rear... but were beaten back by the flames. There was no sound from the Colvins.

"It was difficult to get water as the local supply was sparse and we had to use other sources such as an ornamental pond.

"There was a very strong westerly wind blowing which whipped up the fire and sent it spreading across the front of the building.

"The property is simply a shell - there are no windows, no roof, and there is nothing left inside."

webTitle: Man gets life for axe murder of son's lover

fields.headline: Man gets life for axe murder of son's lover
fields.trailText: A devout Christian who hacked his son's former lover to death with an axe was jailed for life for murder yesterday.
fields.body:
A devout Christian who hacked his son's former lover to death with an axe was jailed for life for murder yesterday.

Anthony Phillips, a Methodist church steward from Wolverhampton, beheaded his next door neighbour, Lorraine Howell, after discovering his 16-year-old son had fathered her daughter.

He called at Mrs Howell's home last May and decapitated her in front of her nine-year-old son, James. Her six-month-old baby was asleep in another room.

Sentencing Phillips to life imprisonment, Mr Justice Latham said: "As a result of that obsession which you had over the relationship between Lorraine and your son, you not only committed a cold and calculated murder, as the jury have quite properly found, but you have destroyed the lives of your family, and in particular, the family of Lorraine Howell."

Birmingham crown court had heard that Jamie Phillips began an affair with Mrs Howell, 34, in August 1997. They only had sex on three occasions, but she became pregnant early in 1998 and their baby daughter was born in November.

His father felt overriding hatred towards Mrs Howell and was abusive to her in the street. After his arrest he told police it was God's way and he had been protecting society.

The jury took 50 minutes yesterday to reach a unanimous verdict of murder.

Earlier, Tony Nayani, a psychiatrist, told the jury that he believed Phillips was suffering from an abnormality of mind when he killed his neighbour.

Phillips, 43, said in police interviews: "It may be crude in the way I have reached retribution, but there was no other way."

He denied murder, but admitted manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility. He claimed that Mrs Howell was a paedophile rapist for sleeping with his son when the boy was only 15.

Dr Nayani said that Phillips had an intense concept of good and evil and could see nothing in between. Phillips believed Mrs Howell had enticed his son and should have been prosecuted for it.

Seven weeks before the murder, Phillips bought an axe from a local store. His wife Susan had told the court that she believed Mrs Howell had taken advantage of her innocent son. "My husband was quite shocked and distressed," she said. "He was a very highly moral man. He could not believe our son had let us down."

She said he returned from murdering Mrs Howell and calmly said: "She's dead."

Outside the court, Mrs Howell's mother, Isobel Weston, said: "We, her family, were devastated by her death and we are still in shock now. We can at least be satisfied that justice has been done."

She said the family had not been aware of the events leading up to her daughter's death.

fields.headline: 'Shampoo' man guilty of assault
fields.trailText: A man was found guilty yesterday of assaulting his former wife by placing shampoo on a door handle knowing she was allergic to it.
fields.body:
A man was found guilty yesterday of assaulting his former wife by placing shampoo on a door handle knowing she was allergic to it.

A jury at Dundee sheriff court found Colin Slane, 28, guilty by majority verdict.

They agreed to delete the part of the charge that said Slane had intended to endanger the life of his former wife, Heather Brown, 33.

Slane was found guilty by unanimous verdict of two further charges - assaulting Ms Brown by spitting in her face and damaging her car by stamping on the roof.

All the offences took place at Ms Brown's Dundee home.

Sheriff Richard Davidson said Slane deferred sentence until March 23 for social and community service reports.

The court was told Slane was a former Scots Guard with no previous convictions.

Sheriff Davidson granted Slane bail on condition he did not approach Ms Brown or her home, and warned him he would not necessarily escape a custodial sentence.

Slane is now engaged to be married again, to Dawn Adamson, 20.

fields.headline: Britons get 'stress and spend' blues
fields.trailText: Britain's "stress and spend" culture is creating a discontented nation in which people are growing disillusioned with material success yet craving more money, according to research published today.
fields.body:
Britain's "stress and spend" culture is creating a discontented nation in which people are growing disillusioned with material success yet craving more money, according to research published today.

Despite being wealthier than ever and enjoying impressive professional status, many Britons are unhappy with their lot and are now questioning the value of what they have achieved, the survey commissioned by the international development charity VSO claimed.

"Professional status and relative wealth have not left this group of people feeling fully satisfied," the Material World report concluded. "Fast-paced, consumer lifestyle Britain does not allow the time or space to reassess personal priorities. Media hype and 'lifestyle noise' can encourage a distorted sense of what is important."

In the survey carried out by NOP, more than 70% of respondents rejected the suggestion that most people were content with their lives, and almost 90% believed Britons increasingly expected to "have it all and have it now".

The report also revealed that while money may have failed to deliver happiness for sufferers of the "post-consumer blues", it still held a firm grip on the nation's psyche.

While more than 80% of respondents agreed that people were under too much pressure to spend unnecessarily, a similar number admitted that however much they earned it was never enough.

Only 11% said that money was the most important thing in their lives, but 15% said their lives could be improved by more material possessions, the same number who said that when they were feeling down they would cheer themselves up by going shopping.

In a finding which will reinforce a few gender stereotypes, women emerged as the most prone to indulge in retail therapy. Despite being most disillusioned by the materialistic pressures of modern life, they were three times as likely as men to shop when depressed.

"It seems that even though women are more aware and concerned about materialist influences than men, when they are feeling down they are more likely to succumb to them," the report said.

Others cited more positive ways of beating the blues. More than 40% said they would visit friends, and 6% said they would go to a place of worship. But 35% admitted that when life got tough, they would attempt to find solace by drinking.

VSO commissioned the research after being stunned by a 61% rise in applications for volunteer work overseas from business and management professionals in the second half of last year. Overall, applications increased by 35%.

"The Material World report clearly shows one thing - that we're fed up with the 'stress and spend' lifestyle many of us are leading in Britain," said Nick Barrett, the charity's recruitment director.

"VSO is the bemused but grateful beneficiary of this backlash. Many successful professionals are looking for something more - fulfilling jobs and some time and space to regain some perspective."

fields.headline: Hairy topers 'wasting Guinness'
fields.trailText: Guinness drinkers with moustaches are unknowingly wasting an estimated 162,719 pints every year by trapping it in their facial hair, scientists claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
Guinness drinkers with moustaches are unknowingly wasting an estimated 162,719 pints every year by trapping it in their facial hair, scientists claimed yesterday.

Research commissioned by the brewing company found that the average moustachioed tippler traps a pint and a half of the creamy liquid above their top lip annually, leaving them with an additional moustache tax of up to £4.58 a year.

With an estimated 92,370 drinkers with facial hair in the UK, who consume on average 180 pints each a year, the total cost of wasted Guinness works out at £423,070.

Robin Dover, a specialist in hair science and dermatological conditions, was called to explore the full extent of the loss. He spent two days analysing the Guinness soaked moustache hair of eight human guinea pigs, using a pre-weighed tissue and a set of super accurate scales. While the hair itself is capable of absorbing 20% of its own weight in liquid, Dr Dover observed that the majority of the wastage occurred between the fibres of the facial hair.

The scientist found the average drinker takes 10 sips to sink a pint, of which 0.56 millilitres of Guinness is trapped in the average moustache at every sip.

An estimated 162,719 pints are lost in total a year by drinkers with moustaches, meaning if every one of the 1.8 million men in the UK today with facial hair drank a pint of Guinness, the total loss in just one sitting would be 17,684 pints.

As the data was based on the average moustache surface area. Scientists were able to work out the amount of wastage depending on size, shape and density.

The WG Grace walrus moustache involved an annual wastage of £27.48 a year.

The Des Lynam-style loses around £12.59 a year because of its density, while the carefully manicured George Michael costs £9.16 per year in wasted Guinness.

But a more wasteful type of facial hair is the Noel Edmonds.

The moustache has the added complication of a full beard to collect residual overflow, which adds up to £22.90 in lost Guinness.

webTitle: Stomach ache turns into a baby

fields.headline: Stomach ache turns into a baby
fields.trailText: A 45-year-old woman who went to the bathroom thinking she had stomach ache came out with a baby daughter, it was revealed last night.
fields.body:
A 45-year-old woman who went to the bathroom thinking she had stomach ache came out with a baby daughter, it was revealed last night.

Sue Dacombe, who lives near Salisbury in Wiltshire, feared she had a serious illness and complained of pains to her GP three weeks ago.

Mrs Dacombe, who has two sons aged 18 and 22, went to the bathroom with severe pains on Sunday morning and feared for the worst. "It was excruciating," she said. "I thought I was dying. I put my hand down and suddenly something came out and I realised it was a head. Then the rest came out. We're still in shock. I hadn't had any morning sickness or cravings. I'd even had four glasses of red wine the night before."

Her husband, Rod, dashed into the bathroom, wrapped his daughter in a towel and cleared her airway before calling an ambulance.

Once at Salisbury district hospital, the baby - to be called Nerine after Mr Dacombe's favourite flower - weighed in at 5lb 9oz.

Mrs Dacombe, who works at a doctor's surgery as a pharmacy dispenser, added: "Rod phoned up my work to say I wouldn't be in. One of my colleagues thought it was a joke. My sons think it's great."

It is believed the pregnancy went unnoticed as the baby was in an unusual position.

fields.headline: Barrister admits blackmail and forgery
fields.trailText: A barrister who pleaded guilty at the Old Bailey yesterday to blackmailing an American investment banker by threatening to tell his employers he was gay faces a possible jail sentence next month.
fields.body:
A barrister who pleaded guilty at the Old Bailey yesterday to blackmailing an American investment banker by threatening to tell his employers he was gay faces a possible jail sentence next month.

Carol Winston-Churchill, 47, of Hampstead, north London, had earlier admitted forging a letter with the signature of her head of chambers to Harrods Trust bank applying for a £20,000 loan.

She was due to be tried on both charges in 1987 but failed to turn up for her trials at the Old Bailey and Southwark crown court and was assumed to have gone abroad. An arrest warrant was issued. She was eventually caught in 1998 when a detective constable looked her up in a bar directory and discovered she was practising under the name Carol Churchill. She had returned to Britain and practised law for five years.

She was caught by chance, according to Detective Constable Kenneth Cox of the Metropolitan police fraud squad. Her records were automatically destroyed after 10 years.

But in 1998, DC Cox was looking through names and details of people who had not been apprehended and had an idea. "I thought what if she had returned and was working as a barrister. I looked her up in a book containing barristers. I tried several versions of the name and eventually came up with Carol Churchill."

He said it took a year to establish it was her. "After she was arrested, she claimed it had all been a mistake and had all been sorted out years ago."

Winston-Churchill had been on her way to a bar council hearing against her following complaints from clients. She was disbarred last November after being found guilty of overcharging and misleading clients, and her disbarment was made final last week.

Her former head of chambers, Stuart Bates QC, whose signature she forged, and the banker she blackmailed, David Brown, both died last year.

She told police she returned to Jamaica, where she was born, instead of facing trial because her father was dying.

She met Mr Brown at a party on the island in 1983. Later he talked of buying a house and gave her $150,000 (£90,000). When the deal fell through his New York lawyers asked for the money back. He was given a cheque but it was mislaid and he could not get a replacement, said DC Cox.

His lawyers told her legal proceedings had been started to recover the money. "When she wrote back, she said she would falsely tell his employers, Bear, Stern & Co, that he was gay if he went ahead."

Winston-Churchill obtained £20,000 from Harrods Trust bank by producing the forged letter which said she would be able to pay it back because of work she had pending.

She was remanded in custody when she was arrested last year but later allowed bail.

Judge David Paget said the fact he was allowing her bail again did not mean he had ruled out jailing her. She will be sentenced on March 30, when the judge will also deal with her failure to answer to bail in 1987.

fields.headline: Vaccine hope for epilepsy
fields.trailText: A vaccine which protects against the effects of epilepsy and stroke has been successfully tested on animals. It dramatically reduced the de velopment of seizures in epileptic rats, and cut brain damage caused by strokes in another group of laboratory rats by 70%.
fields.body:
A vaccine which protects against the effects of epilepsy and stroke has been successfully tested on animals. It dramatically reduced the de velopment of seizures in epileptic rats, and cut brain damage caused by strokes in another group of laboratory rats by 70%.

Scientists hope this or similar vaccines could extend to a wide range of other brain diseases and conditions, including motor-neurone disease Parkinson's, dementia, and even depression.

The drug, developed at Thomas Jefferson university in Philadelphia, USA, and the University of Auckland, New Zealand, causes the body to make antibodies that bind to a specific receptor protein in the brain.

The receptors are involved in the cascade of events that lead to brain death due to stress or injury.

The researchers reported their results yesterday in the journal Science.

In one study, they immunised 100 rats. A month later a number of the animals were given a neurotoxin which triggers epileptic-like seizures.

Matthew During, from Jefferson medical college, who led the work, said: "About 70% of the rats should have gone into seizures, whereas only 20% of the rats immunised did so."

The scientists then induced strokes in a separate group of rats five months after vaccination by injecting a chemical which constricts the arteries. It provided "dramatic protection" against the effects.

fields.headline: Man cleared of Bahamas murder
fields.trailText: A man accused of killing a British tourist, Joanne Clarke, from Banbury, Oxfordshire, on a Bahamas beach has been cleared by a jury.
fields.body:
A man accused of killing a British tourist, Joanne Clarke, from Banbury, Oxfordshire, on a Bahamas beach has been cleared by a jury.

The court was told that 20-year-old Tennell McIntosh was framed by police trying to protect the Bahamas tourist industry.

Ms Clarke, 24, disappeared from a Paradise Island beach on August 21 1998. Her body was found in bushes near the beach a day later. A postmortem revealed that she had been sexually assaulted before being killed.

McIntosh, who is partially blind, deaf and has a mental age of 10, collapsed to his knees in the dock and prayed as the jury foreman returned not guilty verdicts to charges of rape and murder.

His lawyer, Godfrey Pinder, had argued that the police had tried to frame McIntosh in order to convince foreign tourists, on whom the Bahamas depends, that the islands were safe.

He claimed the police used coercion to extract a confession and suggested that they had tampered with DNA evidence. Police denied the claims.

fields.headline: Germans seek damages from BNFL
fields.trailText: The government's hopes of selling part of British Nuclear Fuels took a fresh battering yesterday when a German reactor to which the firm sold fuel with falsified documents suspended operations and asked for compensation.
fields.body:
The government's hopes of selling part of British Nuclear Fuels took a fresh battering yesterday when a German reactor to which the firm sold fuel with falsified documents suspended operations and asked for compensation.

The decision threatened the future of BNFL's contracts for the sale of reprocessed fuel to German power stations. The company has already lost its only firm order from Japan because of a continuing row over its falsification of quality control guarantees.

PreussenElektra, the utility which runs the Unterweser reactor near the Dutch border, said the shutdown was ordered so that it could replace fuel elements delivered with falsified papers four years ago.

The German firm said it was satisfied that the fuel rods had not compromised safety at the plant. "Nevertheless, the fact that documents had been falsified by a supplier is, in the opinion of PreussenElektra, so serious that the firm opted for the replacement of the relevant fuel elements."

The suspension represented a victory for political consid erations over technical advice. PreussenElektra officials had previously made it clear that they did not consider it necessary to suspend operations on safety grounds .

This is bad news for BNFL. Germany's Green environment minister, Jürgen Trittin, is a determined opponent of nuclear reprocessing. The move will strengthen his drive to persuade the utilities to break off dealings with BNFL.

The Unterweser plant, a boiling water reactor with a capacity similar to that of the Sizewell B plant, has been in operation since 1979.
