fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Pensioner jailed for sex abuse
fields.body:
Pensioner jailed for sex abuse

A disabled pensioner was jailed yesterday at Manchester crown court after taking a boy to a prison for a convicted paedophile to abuse.

Gerald Frank, 79, was sentenced to five years for indecent assault after offering the 10-year-old as a "present" to his stepson Stephen Carruthers, 40, who was serving seven years at Manchester prison for child sex offences.

Carruthers sat the boy on his knee and began kissing him. The police inquiry which followed uncovered earlier abuse of the boy and his nine-year-old brother.

Social services chief goes sick

A social services chief criticised by the Waterhouse report into abuse at North Wales children's homes has taken sick leave. Ceredigion county council yesterday announced an independent assessment of its social services department led by Gethin Evans. He was head of children's services at Gwynedd county council from June 1982 and August 1995.

French keep murder suspect

A Frenchman wanted for questioning over the murder in Britain of his mother-in-law and the stabbing of his estranged wife may avoid extradition to Britain after French police reopened a murder investigation.

British police wanted to question Cherif Doua, 37, over the murder of Valarie Brocklesby, 62, and the stabbing of her 27-year-old daughter, Jayne, in West Bromwich in January. Since his arrest in Paris on February 20, French Police have restarted an investigation into the murder of the mother of Doua's first wife in 1988.

Arrest after body found

A murder inquiry was launched last night after a woman's body was found in a ward at the Royal Hospital, Haslar in Gosport. The 57-year-old woman from Locks Heath, Hampshire A 59-year-old man was arrested and was last night helping police with their inquiries.

Farm to help wild birds

Wildlife campaigners are buying a 180 hectare farm near Cambridge to help reverse declines of as much as 60% in bird numbers.

The Royal Society for the Protection of Birds wants to develop environmentally-friendly farming methods to benefit once common farm bird species such as skylark, corn bunting and yellowhammer.

webTitle: Three children die in house fire

fields.headline: Three children die in house fire
fields.trailText: Three children died and their mother was last night fighting for her life after a fire swept through their home yesterday.
fields.body:
Three children died and their mother was last night fighting for her life after a fire swept through their home yesterday.

Daniel Joynes, six, and his brothers Martyn, five, and Kenneth, three, died in the fire at their home in Walsall, west Midlands. Their mother, Jeanette Joynes, 24, was in a critical condition after being rescued by firefighters.

The boys' father was rescued by a neighbour who used a lad der to reach him at an upstairs window.

Debbie Read, 29, who knew the family, said: "I am devastated by the news. The family kept themselves to themselves and the children were lovely. It will be a big shock to the community. No one had a bad word to say about them."

The house was gutted and the street was closed while police and the fire service investigated the cause.

The family's neighbour, Henry Smith, 63, said he dialled 999 after hearing breaking glass and seeing flames.

"I tried to break in the back door but couldn't," he said. "The father seemed to be trapped in the bedroom upstairs. We got a ladder to the top window and got him out but we couldn't get the children out. It's such a shame. They had only been here for a couple of months."

fields.headline: Bomber admits Soho killings
fields.trailText: A man who planted three nail bombs around London last year yesterday admitted killing three people who were caught in the final blast at the Admiral Duncan pub in Soho.
fields.body:
A man who planted three nail bombs around London last year yesterday admitted killing three people who were caught in the final blast at the Admiral Duncan pub in Soho.

David Copeland, 23, denied murder but pleaded guilty to manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility in a 25 minute hearing at the Old Bailey. He might still face trial in June if the prosecution decides not to accept the pleas.

Copeland, a London Underground engineer from Cove, near Farnborough, Hampshire, stood with his hands behind his back as the court clerk read out the charges.

The first three charges related to blasts last year: in Brixton, south London on April 17; in Brick Lane, east London on April 24; and at the Admiral Duncan in Old Compton Street, central London, on April 30.

Asked to plead whether he had unlawfully and maliciously caused the explosions, he replied: "Guilty." He was also accused of murdering Andrea Dykes, 27, John Light, 32, and Nick Moore, 31. After the details of each charge were read out, Copeland said: "Not guilty to murder, guilty to manslaughter."

John Sweeney, prosecuting, said the crown's preliminary view was that the pleas to manslaughter on the grounds of diminished responsibility were unacceptable.

A decision on whether to proceed to trial is likely to be made at a hearing on March 29.

webTitle: Speedy drivers face tough new penalties

fields.headline: Speedy drivers face tough new penalties
fields.trailText: Motorists who break speed limits will face toughened penalties, including more penalty points and earlier disqualification, under a new offence of excessive speeding to be unveiled by minsters next week.
fields.body:
Motorists who break speed limits will face toughened penalties, including more penalty points and earlier disqualification, under a new offence of excessive speeding to be unveiled by minsters next week.

Measures stemming from the long-awaited road safety review, to be unveiled next Wednesday, will target unsafe and careless drivers as part of government efforts to make speeding as socially unacceptable as drink driving.

However, though the high penalties for those who break limits by a wide margin will please safety campaigners, there will be disappointment if speed limits are left at current levels, as expected.

Despite receiving advice, according to a BBC Panorama programme, that 2,500 children a year could be saved from serious injury if a nationwide 20mph speed limit were introduced on all roads frequented by children, the review will leave the decision about whether to cut speed limits in built-up areas to local authorities, possibly with an extended remit to introduce low-speed zones.

Ministers are also understood to have shied away from imposing a national speed limit of 50mph on rural roads - down from 60mph.

Maintaining current speed limits will leave the government open to accusations that a fear of angering motorists, particularly in rural areas, has overtaken safety concerns.

The review, announced in a white paper in 1998, is expected to include measures to clamp down on drink drivers, including tougher punishments and steeper fines.

Strict new US-style retraining schemes for offenders, including those guilty of violence, are expected to form part of the package.

So are proposals for fast new digital breathalysers.

The government decided not to cut the drink-drive limit from 80mg to 50mg of alcohol per 100mls of blood.

This is despite the fact that its own consultation paper suggested that a cut to 50mg would save 50 lives and nearly 1,500 serious injuries a year.

John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, originally spoke out strongly in favour. But the concerns of Downing Street advisers that such a measure would damage country pubs and be widely resented have won out.

As well as looking at tougher penalties, in conjunction with the home office, the review will cover all aspects of road safety, including the training of drivers and vehicle standards.

Consultation is expected on a mandatory six-month L-plate period for all learner drivers, together with a proposal that drivers should be required to carry special continental-style provisional plates for the first year after they qualify.

Fixed penalty fines for traffic offences - such as jumping a red light - are also expected to rise from the current £40.

The speed limits issue has proved the trickiest element of the review for the government. Last autumn, there were reports that Downing Street had intervened to veto plans to cut speed limits on single-carriageway rural roads.

The environment minister, Lord Whitty, announced new legislation last summer allowing local authorities to create reduced speed zones in residential areas without prior government approval.

More than 600 20mph schemes have been introduced and have proved successful, reducing overall pedestrian casualties by 60% and child pedestrian and child cyclist casualties by 67%.

However, local authorities are concerned that imposing new local speed limits without adequate enforcement powers will merely anger motorists and traders to no useful effect.

webTitle: Magnetic chips end era of heavy batteries

fields.headline: Magnetic chips end era of heavy batteries
fields.trailText: Just when it seemed mobile phones and laptop computers could not get smaller or lighter, British scientists have invented a microchip that promises to revolutionise the world of portable electronics by virtually doing away with the need for heavy batteries.
fields.body:
Just when it seemed mobile phones and laptop computers could not get smaller or lighter, British scientists have invented a microchip that promises to revolutionise the world of portable electronics by virtually doing away with the need for heavy batteries.

In a breakthrough which could give ultra-light mobiles computing power far in excess of today's most souped-up desktop PC, British scientists have made a chip which uses magnetism instead of electricity to process data.

As well as packing a greater data processing punch, magnetic chips require a fraction of the power used by silicon chips.

The bulky batteries used by today's laptop computers could be replaced by watch batteries. "It's a completely new type of microchip," said Russsell Cowburn, who developed the technology with Mark Welland at Cambridge university. "We're the first to demonstrate anything like this working at room temperature.

"Computers developed using magnetic microchips will need much less power to work. The days of carrying around heavy batteries for laptop computers and mobile phones will be numbered."

Other labs around the world, looking ahead to the day about a 10 years away when it will be impossible to crowd more transistors onto silicon chips, have tried to fashion magnetic ones. But they have only been able to make them work at a fraction of a degree above absolute zero.

Shirt pocket computers and mobiles small enough to fit into the palm of the hand are already commonplace, but their processing power and battery life is limited.

"Mobile phones will soon need to have a lot more computing power on board," said Dr Cowburn.

"It's a question of packing more computer power into the same space so you can use the internet."

What the Cambridge team has done is to create a magnetic transistor one ten millionth of a metre across, consisting of a nickel-iron dot.

This basic building block of the new chip could one day be 40,000 times smaller than its silicon equivalent, making it possible to squeeze 250 bn transistors into a square centimetre.

webTitle: MP and wife die in 1,000C inferno

fields.headline: MP and wife die in 1,000C inferno
fields.standfirst:
Destroyed: Firefighters to begin search for clues after blaze rages through £3m country manor house

More about Michael Colvin MP
fields.trailText: Michael Colvin, the Tory MP for Romsey, and his wife Nichola died yesterday in a devastating fire which ripped through their country manor house with the ferocity of a blowtorch.
fields.body:
Michael Colvin, the Tory MP for Romsey, and his wife Nichola died yesterday in a devastating fire which ripped through their country manor house with the ferocity of a blowtorch.

Heat reaching 1,000C made it impossible for fire crews in the village of Tangley, near Andover, Hampshire, to enter the £3m home, 95% of which was wrecked by the blaze.

The bodies of the couple could not be located as fire officers were last night still unable to enter the property because it was structurally unsafe. They may not be able to do so until later today or even tomorrow after contractors have demolished part of the remains.

But after consulting family and friends, police said yesterday they believed Mr Colvin, 67, and his wife, 62, had died in their home of nearly 40 years, Tangley Hall. They are believed to have been trapped in their first-floor bedroom.

The alarm was raised shortly before 4am by Peter Woolnough, a maintenance worker on the 855-acre estate who was woken by the smell of burning at his home Fairground Cottage, a few yards from the estate walls.

Initially he feared his thatched roof was on fire. Having checked it he returned to bed, but the smell was so pervasive that he left his house and discovered that Tangley Hall was ablaze.

He called Hampshire fire brigade and ran to the tied cottage which the Colvins' butler, Alvaro Pereira, shares with his wife, Angelina, their cook.

Mr Pereira rushed to the house where he saw smoke coming from the Colvins' bedroom in the west wing of the 10-bedroom home, which was not fitted with smoke detectors."There was smoke coming out of the window but no fire," said Mr Pereira, 67, who had worked for the couple for 31 years.

"The main part of the fire was on the ground floor. We shouted for the Colvins but we didn't hear anything.

"I tried to do something but it was impossible. I tried to open the door but it was too hot. Then I just waited for the fire brigade to come as I could do nothing."

Within 14 minutes of being called, the first of 17 fire appliances - 12 pumping engines and five specialist appliances - and 85 fire crew from Hampshire and neighbouring Wiltshire swept down the house's 100m drive.

Malcolm Eastwood, chief fire officer for Hampshire, said: "I could see this huge fireball on the horizon from five miles away. There was a white ball of fire engulfing the whole of the front of the house. The floors were collapsing and the roof was about to drop in. The noise was quite colossal."

Advised that there were people inside, the first crew to arrive on the scene, from Andover, attempted to enter the building but were beaten back by the heat and white-hot flames.

They then tried to enter through the west wing, but the strong wind was whipping the fire through the house with the intensity of a blowtorch, Mr Eastwood said, forcing them to abandon their attempt.

Efforts to fight the fire were also hampered by the remote location, high on a hill, which made it difficult for crews to find enough water.

A pond and well on the estate were pumped, as were two hydrants in the village. Two tankers containing 12,000 litres of water each were brought to the scene but they were empty within nine minutes. It took more than four hours to bring the blaze under control.

The cause of the blaze, which appears to have begun under the couple's bedroom on the ground floor, remains unknown.

Only the north-east corner of the house, near the front entrance, remained anything like intact last night, with some windows and part of the roof still standing.

Mr Eastwood said: "The search will be difficult. It's a good quality construction that has all come down layer by layer. That has been sandwiched together by the intensity of the fire."

Mr Colvin was an outspoken supporter of hunting, a member of the Countryside Alliance and a former chairman of the British Field Sports Society. Police are not ruling out foul play until they discover the cause of the blaze, but it is not thought that the MP was a target of animal rights activists.

About an hour after the alarm was raised, the Colvins' son Jamie, who grew up in the house and lives nearby in Wiltshire, arrived at the scene, knowing almost certainly that his parents were dead inside the house. The couple also had two daughters.

Checks were made with other relatives and party colleagues about Mr Colvin's movements the night before. He drove his grandson Nicholas back to nearby Marlborough College at about 7pm on Wednesday. It soon became clear that the couple had returned home afterwards, and just before midday yesterday police announced that they were believed to have died in the blaze.

The tragedy has stunned Mr Colvin's neighbours and political colleagues. Tory leader William Hague said: "I am shocked and deeply saddened at Michael's tragic death.

"I knew Michael as a true Tory, in the best sense of the word. He cared about his country and he cared about the countryside."

Further tributes came from the prime minister Tony Blair and Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy.

webTitle: Patrician who stumbled into apartheid row

fields.headline: Patrician who stumbled into apartheid row
fields.standfirst:
Old Etonian and former Grenadier guardsman was one of the last members of the Tory squire brigade

More about Michael Colvin MP
fields.trailText: In an age in which the Conservative party seems to have been taken over by estate agents, Michael Colvin was an elegant reminder of an earlier era when estate owners held sway.
fields.body:
In an age in which the Conservative party seems to have been taken over by estate agents, Michael Colvin was an elegant reminder of an earlier era when estate owners held sway.

With his silver hair and impeccable manners, the former Etonian and Grenadier guardsman was held in affection on the Tory benches.

"Michael was one of the last members of the gentle Tory squire brigade," his old friend, the former Tory MP Peter Temple-Morris, said yesterday.

William Hague led the tributes to Mr Colvin and his wife, Nichola, 62. "The tragic death of Michael and Nichola has left all of us who knew them both shocked and deeply saddened. I knew Michael as a true Tory, in the best sense of the word. He cared about his country and he cared about the countryside."

Tony Blair said: "My feelings went out to the family of Michael Colvin and his wife as soon as I heard of the terrible fire at their home. I am truly saddened."

His remarks were echoed by Liz Perry, chairman of the Romsey Conservative Association and a friend of the MP since childhood, who described the death of Mr Colvin and his wife as a devastating blow.

"They were a devoted couple and contributed so much to the life of the local community."

Mr Colvin, 67, first entered the Commons when Margaret Thatcher swept to power in 1979. As a smooth Etonian, Mr Colvin never prospered under Lady Thatcher, which left him to concentrate his energies on his twin loves of defence and foreign affairs.

"Michael was not a doer or a shaker, but he was very knowledgeable on defence and foreign affairs," Mr Temple-Morris said. "He was widely travelled and used to make lovely sketches with coloured crayons during the trips."

Just as Mr Colvin's patrician manner looked out of place in today's Conservative party, some of his views on foreign affairs looked painfully out of date in today's world.

During the 1980s he was a regular traveller to apartheid South Africa.

Some of his rhetoric came back to haunt Mr Colvin when Nelson Mandela was swept to power on a wave of worldwide popularity.

In 1990 Mr Colvin deplored "the continued condemnation of South Africa on the basis of largely obsolete disinformation sedulously propagated by the anti-apartheid movement".

Mr Colvin's interest in South Africa landed him in difficulty with Commons authorities when, along with the disgraced former MP Neil Hamilton, he failed to declare an interest with a lobbying firm linked to the apartheid regime.

Mr Colvin said in 1994 that he was guilty of no more than an "oversight" when he failed to register a paid consultancy with Strategy Network International, which lobbied against the imposition of economic sanctions on apartheid South Africa.

Mr Temple-Morris, who never shared his friend's views on South Africa, believes that Mr Colvin's stance before the fall of apartheid should not detract from his record as an MP.

"Michael had a Conservative colonial attitude which was not in the same league as some rightwing Tories.

"He believed in gentle change and would not have believed in agitating against the regime."

As a wealty landowner - he farmed 855 acres in Hampshire - and a passionate defender of country sports, Mr Colvin was one of a handful of Tory MPs who became close to the Prince of Wales.

His admiration for the prince prompted him to speak in 1992 of his "profound disquiet at the thought that the Princess of Wales might one day become Queen".

Despite his wealth, Mr Colvin complained earlier this week that he too was suffering in the present farming crisis. In Tuesday's Commons debate on defence he said that he had postponed buying a combine harvester because he had run short of funds.

"I can stomach that," he told MPs. "But when the defence of the realm is involved, it is no use [delaying purchases] because the treasury says the money is not available."

It was his final Commons speech and Mr Colvin combined the two passions of his life with characteristic eloquence.

fields.headline: Wood and wind intensified fire
fields.standfirst:
Blaze may have spread unseen

More about Michael Colvin MP
fields.trailText: The ferocity of the blaze which engulfed the Colvins' home is likely to have been caused by a combination of factors, fire experts said last night.
fields.body:
The ferocity of the blaze which engulfed the Colvins' home is likely to have been caused by a combination of factors, fire experts said last night.

By the time firefighters arrived at Tangley House, the blaze had already taken hold with temperatures reaching 1000C. It had also spread with alarming speed throughout the building.

John Ibbetson, a programme manager at the fire services college in Moreton-in-the- Marsh, Gloucestershire, said the intensity of the inferno suggested that there were ample supplies of the two main ingredients in every fire: combustible material and oxygen.

The fuel would have been provided by the 90-year-old mansion's wood-panelled walls, as well as the paintings which hung on them, curtains and furniture.

The age of the furniture could also have been significant. Suites and mattresses manufactured before the 1980s were likely to have used materials which generated great amounts of heat, allowing fires to reach temperatures where anything combustible would burst into flames. Plastic materials, such as television casings and video cas settes, could become highly combustible in intense heat.

Materials which had been smouldering for some time would ignite into huge blazes if they were given a sudden dose of oxygen - a situation known to firefighters as a "flashover". That is why fire crews at Tangley House had cited strong winds as a cause of the blaze's intensity.

The age and design of the building would have made it easier for the fire to spread. Wood used in building naturally contains some moisture but over time that would dry out, making it extremely combustible. Fire could get into the voids behind panelled walls and spread undetected to all corners of the building, Mr Ibbetson said.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Timbuktu | Dirk Bogarde On 4
fields.body:
Graeme Fife set off to cycle to Timbuktu (11.0am, Radio 4), the ancient city in the West African desert which some still think is an invented synonym for "the back of beyond". As ever, it serves as the regional centre for the salt trade, a mineral so scarce that in the past it fetched its weight in gold. No longer, as Fife reports. When the ferocious heat eventually forced him off his bike, he discovered the locals' new source of wealth - fleecing Europeans.

The afternoon play is Dirk Bogarde On 4 (2.15pm, Radio 4), a tribute to the actor who died last year. James Fox introduces two radio performances Bogarde gave after he returned to Britain from years of living abroad. The most moving is his monologue A Short Walk From Harrods, which painfully dissects his sense of loneliness when the terminal illness of his close friend and manager made him flee the south of France for London.

webTitle: Sheriff calls for disciplinary action over boy's death at dentist's

fields.headline: Sheriff calls for disciplinary action over boy's death at dentist's
fields.trailText: A sheriff has called for big changes in dental and medical practice, and disciplinary action against two dentists and a doctor over the death of a 10-year-old boy during a routine tooth extraction.
fields.body:
A sheriff has called for big changes in dental and medical practice, and disciplinary action against two dentists and a doctor over the death of a 10-year-old boy during a routine tooth extraction.

Darren Denholm died under anaesthetic at a dental clinic in Edinburgh in October 1998. Yesterday, his mother called on the General Medical Council and the General Dental Council to act on the recommendations made by Sheriff Nigel Morrison, who investigated Darren's death in a fatal accident inquiry.

"It seems to me that our son's life was worth £14 - the price paid when a general anaesthetic is carried out," said Isla Denholm.

In a damning report, Sheriff Morrison said a catalogue of errors had led to Darren's death. He suggested the GMC should consider disciplinary action against Dr John Evans-Appiah, who administered the anaesthetic but had no specialist qualification in anaesthesia; and that the GDC should consider similar action against Maurice Beckett, proprietor of Peffermill dental clinic where Darren was treated, and Paul Shields, of Armadale dental clinic, who referred Darren for treatment.

Sheriff Morrison also called on the Scottish executive to end the use of general anaesthetics in dental surgeries and harshly criticised the GMC and GDC for their registration and monitoring procedures.

The fatal accident inquiry had heard of a catalogue of incompetence on the day Darren had died.

Dr Evans-Appiah, 57, failed to sedate Darren adequately, neglected to monitor his blood pressure or heart, advised a local anaesthetic be administered on top of the gas, and later tried to cover his tracks, writing out records on Darren's readings after his death.

Darren, who had been playing with a yo-yo in the waiting room at around 4pm, was dead by 5.30pm.

Sheriff Morrison criticised the GMC for letting practitioners like Dr Evans-Appiah stumble from temporary job to temporary job as a locum. In 25 years, he had held 40 appointments.

Mrs Denholm said she was pleased the sheriff had ruled that general anaesthetics should stop in dental clinics. "It's too late for Darren but we hope all the publicity his case has been given will save some other child."

A spokesman for the GMC said it was considering the sheriff's report and recommendations. Later, it was confirmed that Dr Evans-Appiah was working as a GP in Walthamstow, east London. The GMC's chief executive, Finlay Scott, told BBC Scotland there were no restrictions on Dr Evans-Appiah being in general practice, as long as he did not give anaesthetics.

Dr Evans-Appiah said in a statement that he was devastated by Darren's death but duty and patient confidential ity prevented him from commenting further.

 A doctor who showed lack of urgency and repeated failure in referring for specialist treatment a patient who later died of cancer was yesterday cleared of serious professional misconduct.

Sudhir Kumar, of Grimsby, Lincolnshire, failed to recognise the symptoms of a tumour and instead treated Edmund Sterriker, 62, as having a urinary tract infection, a GMC hearing was told.

fields.headline: Crowded House
fields.standfirst:
The Tories have latched on to the unprecedented number of peers created by the Blair government. But do the numbers really matter?

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: In this post-socialist age, after the collapse of Tito's dream of a Balkans confederation in the ruins of Sarajevo and Pristina, the name of Milovan Djilas has been lost. The communist system, he argued, had become deformed. His 1957 book, The New Class, said communist apparatchiks and their cronies had become literally that: a cadre of privileged beneficiaries, who protected their interests much like the oppressors they had ostensibly replaced.
fields.body:
In this post-socialist age, after the collapse of Tito's dream of a Balkans confederation in the ruins of Sarajevo and Pristina, the name of Milovan Djilas has been lost. The communist system, he argued, had become deformed. His 1957 book, The New Class, said communist apparatchiks and their cronies had become literally that: a cadre of privileged beneficiaries, who protected their interests much like the oppressors they had ostensibly replaced.

Perhaps it is a sign of Tory desperation, perhaps a tribute to their flexibility of mind that today Djilas should be given a new lease of life on the right. His metaphor has inspired the author of a Centre for Policy Studies pamphlet to bring together all those appointed to pelf and position by the Blair government and declare its new class the enemy of democracy and accountability. Tony's cronies (so says the CPS) form a class with a creed: David Puttnam, Helena Kennedy, Greg Dyke et al believe in social engineering, state regulation and (unspecified) norms of political correctness.

Unfortunately the pamphlet turns out to have a tautology at its heart. If you define "the new class" as people who look like Gerry Robinson and Ed Balls then finding them in the House of Lords or Gordon Brown's office is hardly surprising. The CPS makes no effort to distinguish those Labour functionaries who are old-style "great and good" (Tessa Blackstone for example) from such as Lord Alli (television producer) who are interestingly new. Howard Davies of the Financial Services Authority makes an odd candidate: he got most of his preferment under the Tories. Meanwhile no government with any sense would reject an offer of public service from David Sainsbury.

Because the Tories still cannot bring themselves to review the Thatcher years with honesty and rigour, no serious effort is made to compare and contrast Blair with his immediate predecessors. Their best shot is to list Blair's new peers.

Since May 1997 he created 176 life peers compared with Thatcher's 216 in 11 years, as the chart shows. But that figure does not not mean a great deal in the context of Lords' reform. Besides, as the government's failure over the Greater London election mailshot shows Labour still lacks control.

The CPS notes that while 41% of new peers created between 1958 and 1997 had backgrounds in politics, only 32% of Blair's new peers are former politicians. Some people might think this progress. Hitherto unrepresented sectors are getting their turn - some 7% of Blairite creations come from the voluntary sector, against 1.6% during 1958-97.

The Tories' lack of ambition in this pamphlet is a pity because it leaves a good question without an answer. Does "inclusive" government, into which large numbers of new people are recruited, run any better? Peter Hennessy of Queen Mary Westfield College praised the transfusion model.

He concluded that the large influx of "outsiders" into government during the second world war was wholly beneficial. It shook up prejudices and deepened the pool of experience and talent in Whitehall; some irregular public servants stayed, others left; the net result was national benefit. Mrs Thatcher liked new blood, too, prizing the contributions of David Young and his brother, Derek Rayner, Peter Levene and many others. The right was not heard in the 80s bemoaning the arrival of business people in Whitehall as an undemocratic new class.

Trevor Smith (Lord Smith of Clifton) of the Joseph Rowntree Reform Trust says Tony Blair's 2,500 recruits to his raft of task forces, inquiries and review teams is "elite par ticipation" that injures the democratic principle and accountability.

The best account of what some have called Blair's "task force revolution" was compiled by Tony Barker of Essex University with the backing of the interest group Democratic Audit (Ruling by Task Force, Politico's Publishing, www. politicos.co.uk). He counts 502 task forces and internal policy reviews launched between the election and the end of 1998. The number might need to be doubled to take in the reviews launched since.

The treasury's 2000 spending review embraces a dozen or more "internal" reviews, many of which will reach outside for contributions. Some subjects have lately been the subject of multiple, simultaneous examination. Each review will have a network of external contributors. But does being invited to a seminar convened by the cabinet office's performance and innovation unit constitute "absorption"?

Conspiracy theories say Blair's new model army of peers, consultees, task forcers and review teams is a means of neutralising opposition. Ministers - so the argument runs - may be free with invitations to sit on official committees but they limit their range and surreptitiously manage their agenda; this ends up making policy-making less open.

But Tony Barker argues the opposite: the task forces have opened government up and brought a greater diversity of experience to bear on problems. His misgivings have to do with procedure. Whitehall does things ad hoc. Although it has sought this year to "review reviews", little effort is put into collating and publicising the results of task forces and reviews. So they are often not transparent - it would help if all the task forces had websites. Some do. The CPS pamphlet makes a silly reference to the various policy action teams convened by the Social Exclusion Unit having long names. What matters is that their work has been exhibited quickly on the web and can be accessed by the public who will feel its impact.

The Great and Good? The Rise of the New Class by Martin McElwee can be found on the Centre for Policy Studies website: www.cps.org.uk

webTitle: Blair fourth in best leader poll

fields.headline: Blair fourth in best leader poll
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Labour MPs have voted Tony Blair the fourth best party leader of the last 100 years, and the chancellor, Gordon Brown, the "best leader that never was" in a poll to mark the party's centenary.
fields.body:
Labour MPs have voted Tony Blair the fourth best party leader of the last 100 years, and the chancellor, Gordon Brown, the "best leader that never was" in a poll to mark the party's centenary.

Clement Attlee, whose post-war premiership saw the creation of the national health service and the modern welfare state, was selected as Labour's greatest leader.

Also finishing higher than the prime minister in the poll, carried out by the New Statesman magazine, were Harold Wilson - who won four elections for Labour in the 1960s and 70s - and John Smith, who died in 1994 after just two years as leader.

Not all votes cast for Mr Blair by 80 of Labour's 418 MPs who responded were favourable, with one naming him as the party's worst leader.

However, that dubious honour went to Ramsay MacDonald, Labour's first prime minister, who was expelled from the party for his "betrayal" of 1931 when he formed a national coalition government with Liberals and Conservatives.

When the government split and fell over financial problems caused by high unemployment, MacDonald did not tender his resignation to the king, but instead offered to form a national government, turning his back on the party he helped create.

Mr Brown won the "best leader who never was" vote by a whisker from Denis Healey, followed by Aneurin Bevan, Ernest Bevin, Tony Benn and Robin Cook.

The creation of the NHS was selected as the party's proudest achievement by 63 of the participants, with mentions also for the minimum wage, the welfare state and the abolition of the death penalty.

Labour's most shameful action was deemed to be the national government of 1931 and the party's support for the US in the Vietnam war.

The Millennium Dome, New Labour's benefit cuts and the introduction of tuition fees were each nominated by two MPs as the actions by the party of which they were most ashamed.

Labour's best

1. Clement Attlee

2. Harold Wilson

3. John Smith

4. Tony Blair

5. Keir Hardie

6. Neil Kinnock

7. James Callaghan

8. Hugh Gaitskell

9. George Lansbury

10. Michael Foot

11. Arthur Henderson

12. Ramsay MacDonald

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Jackal | El Topo | Blue Steel | I Love You To Death
fields.body:
The Jackal

(Michael Caton-Jones, 1997)

10.15pm, Sky Premier

Big-bucks updating of Zinnemann's 1973 film, the original's study in low-key tension giving way to a brash face-off between major league players: Bruce Willis v Richard Gere. Willis operates with cold efficiency as the Jackal, an international assassin-cum-master of disguise hired by the Russian mafia; Gere almost sinks the movie as Declan, an IRA man and former associate of the killer: he just stops short of dancing a merry Oirish jig in his risible impersonation. Still, Caton-Jones is a dab hand with the action scenes, including a breathless subway showdown.

El Topo

(Alexandro Jodorowsky, 1971)

11.30pm, FilmFour

An extraordinary desert fantasy stuck somewhere between Leone and Pasolini: Jodorowsky called it his zen western. He wrote the script and also stars, as an implacable black leather-clad wanderer avenging a family massacre, before skewing off into biblical meanderings in the wasteland, confronting the four gun masters - they're gurus, but they're armed and dangerous - for the love of a woman. Crazy.

Blue Steel

(Kathryn Bigelow, 1990)

11.50pm, Sky Cinema

Rookie New York cop Megan Turner (Jamie Lee Curtis) is not only being framed by a psychopathic killer, but gets seduced by him too; dodgy start for a woman wanting to make it in the men's league. But Megan is made of stern stuff and heads for a violent showdown with her persecutor. Bigelow's film revels in the police hardware and gunplay, but there's a subtle performance by Curtis in there too.

I Love You To Death

(Lawrence Kasdan, 1990)

10pm, Paramount

Proof that the transition from true story to movie is sometimes so badly done that it's not worth it, this hamfisted account tells of Joey Boca (Kevin Kline), an Italian family man who is sleeping with everyone except his wife.

fields.headline: Bar room blues
fields.standfirst: TV's obsession with 'how to' programming continues tonight with Dick's Bar, a guide to the world of cocktails. But, asks  Matt Lucas, do we really want to spend our Friday nights making Zombies in front of the telly?
fields.trailText: TV's obsession with 'how to' programming continues tonight with Dick's Bar, a guide to the world of cocktails. But do we really want to spend our Friday nights making Zombies in front of the telly?
fields.body:
If the turn of the century is to be remembered for anything, it may as well be the spate of lifestyle "make-and-do" infotainment shows that the broadcasters are currently filling up the schedules with. Of course, the most famous examples are the diet of cookery shows hosted by pre-pubescent lispy mockneys, and the wallpaper of "If You're Really Going To Let Someone Else Decide What Your House Is Going To Look Like Then You Deserve Everything You Get". I'm not against the genre itself. Your Delias, your Titchmarshs and (I can't believe I'm saying this) even your Clarksons all have their place. It's the sheer volume that deluges our screens nowadays that gets me. You see, for every Raj Persaud there's got to be a Denise Robertson. MUST WE CONSTANTLY BE TOLD WHAT TO DO ALL THE TIME? And yet we don't do what we're told, do we? And that's my point.

We may have abolished corporal punishment but a generation of children were nevertheless traumatised when they tried and failed to make Tracey Island on Blue Peter a few years back. The glue didn't stick and the colours were all wrong (anyway someone trod on it - need I go on?) It was rubbish, but the parents were ever so proud, so there it sat on display, a beacon of inaccuracy and mediocrity for all to see.

"No point trying this at home, I'll never be able to make it like he does" was a truth learnt early then, a bit like "it's not as good as it looks in the adverts" and "there's no such thing as Father Christmas". With such invaluable knowledge I reconciled myself quite contendly to the ensuing years of half-term inactivity, to lying on the sofa in my ET pyjamas and watching things being made by people who could actually make them.

Do you know anyone who even bothers trying to make the things they see being made on television? Of course not. It's a myth. Talk is cheap and filming in someone's kitchen or garden is even cheaper, which is why this type of television continues to pervade our screens.

The latest addition to the make-and-do canon is Dick's Bar (tonight, 1.15am, Channel 4). In fairness, it's hardly a primetime show. You can't hate Dick Bradsell the way you can, say, Handy Andy. Firstly, he doesn't try to be your mate and, secondly, Dick hasn't probably pushed a half-decent sitcom or documentary off our screens. At barely five minutes long, the only programming Dick's going to edge out of the schedules is most likely one of those deplorably indulgent short films that make no sense and end up with a fat man at the bottom of the stairs laughing (you know the sort - they look like they were made in 1988 but, bafflingly, were actually made as recently as 1997).

Which brings me back to Dick's Bar. Shot cheaply on video, at the counter, with its soft focus blacks and silvers and pinks, its mixers and shakers, its cocktails, and its sharply besuited, underwhelmingly cool presenter, it also looks strangely like it was made in 1988. This is also partly down to the show's simple yet high concept which harks back to the delightfully ill-conceived but hugely likeable halcyon days of late-night television, with programmes like Rivron - in which Roland Rivron interviewed his guests as they all floated in the freezing Thames - or Naked Yoga, or After Dark where anything could happen but usually didn't (Ollie Reed, sadly, the exception that proved the rule).

In Dick's Bar, the camera sways a little, dutching and panning, as if to suggest that you the viewer - the customer, the barfly - has already had a few. This might explain his self-conciously detached, professsional manner (he calls you "sir" and doesn't smile). There's no inane laughter or mugging from Dick - well, not until he's made his cocktails, at least. In the first episode, accompanied by scary music, Dick expertly makes a Zombie - a colourful, potent concoction, sir - and wisely only pretends to be a zombie once the drink is made. Even then, he only does it for a mercifully short time, as if to remind you of the sort of presenter he's thankfully not. Yet. Give him time.

For the moment at least, Dick's Bar is filler, with perhaps an "I'm surely the only person actually watching this" feel to it. In fact, Channel Four is going to be showing it immediately before the late night poker, which itself has a slightly less desirable "I really ought to get myself a girlfriend" feel to it.

Maybe I'm being unfair. Maybe you'll all watch Dick's Bar. Maybe you'll video it and talk about it at work or in the pub and sit there enthralled as Dick tells you how to make the perfect punch. Maybe you'll write the recipe down. Maybe you'll buy the ingredients. Heck, maybe you'll even try to make the bloody thing.

One things for sure though - you'll never be able to make it like he does.

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the Metz ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the Metz ad says about you
fields.body:
The ad: A decidedly weird drinks ad this, complete with haunting folk music and fairytale voiceover. It opens on a peculiar East European-style puppet theatre, shifting to a lone traveller wandering through a snowy, moonlit wood. We see a spiky-haired man creepily pursuing him then jumping out in his path, armed with an icy bottle of Metz. He lures the traveller to a bar in the heart of the forest, where he takes a sip of the drink and instantly shudders, frost tracing through his body. We pull back to reveal the traveller is now a puppet too, being operated by the creepy Metz man from above.

The jargon: This commercial is for Bacardi Martini's Schnapps-based PPS (Premium Packaged Spirit). It is attempting to create a modern-day fairy story around the youth brand, giving it an Eastern European storybook feel reminiscent of Hansel and Gretel - a novel departure from the more usual, blokey alcohol ads.

Personality: The spot is targeting you if you are a cool, 20-year old male or female who enjoys the unexpected and an adventurous night out. You probably have "above average intelligence" and are bored with the patronising, Ibitha-in-a-bottle way spirits are usually sold to you, says agency HHCL.

Financial status: A bottle of Metz costs around £2.50, like a PPL (Premium Packaged Lager), so it's generally affordable.

Telling lifestyle detail: You are a peer group leader, rather than a follower, and you are not hung up on macho, laddish images or the Cannon and Ball-styled humour more usually associated with alcohol ads.

Other relevant data: The commercial was shot in Budapest, using hand-cranked cameras and early turn-of-the-century film techniques to give it a genuinely spooky, fairytale feel.

fields.headline: War stories
fields.trailText: Great Military Blunders | Dispatches: Tax Wars | Fred Dibnah's Magnificent Monuments
fields.body:
Extolling the virtues of management consultants is not an activity to be indulged in lightly. But watching the first episode of Great Military Blunders (C4) left one with the impression that nothing would have helped save the British and US armies from their greatest battlefield balls-ups so much as a few months of the McKinsey treatment. It was the programme's intent to demonstrate that these tragic disasters all stemmed from the destructive vanity of impossibly ignorant military leaders - but what was even more glaringly obvious was how the army hierarchies simply weren't designed to allow for the existence of anyone to question them.

"We lost about 200 men before the fighting started. And that was when we realised things were starting to go wrong", one former soldier noted with comical understatement of Operation Market Garden, the doomed attack at Arnhem in 1944 that sacrificed numerous British lives to Montgomery's towering arrogance. Meanwhile, General MacArthur's terrifying nuclear brinkmanship with Mao (as we learned by means of the kind of hurried juxtapositions that pass for psychoanalysis when you've only got 15 minutes per war leader) was all down to his mother, who hired a hotel room overlooking her son's room at the West Point military academy for four years, to check that the future atom bomb enthusiast was doing his homework properly.

But the film did find time for some less well-thumbed pages of military history. Charles Townshend's doomed quest to conquer Baghdad, culminating in the humiliating siege of Kut, was revealed, true to the pro gramme's somewhat monomaniacal argument, to be nothing more than an attempt to kick-start a stagnating career. His strategy failed, but the Turks gave Townshend a first-class ticket to Constantinople, luxury accommodation and a free yacht, while tens of thousands of his men were killed or languished in prison. He never asked after them.

It's tempting to draw parallels between such mindless self-certainty and the similarly destructive arrogance on display in Dispatches: Tax Wars (C4), which took a trawl through some of the more incomprehensible and infuriating VAT decisions of HM Customs and Excise, who are prone to slap ruinous tax liabilities on formerly zero-rated businesses for no discernible reason. The same cavalier disregard for the possibility of alternative viewpoints was certainly on display at one biscuit factory, forced to spend thousands in legal bills defending the notion that marshmallows in wafer cones are biscuits not cakes - before Customs grudgingly admitted that it had probably misread its own rulebook. But the truly interesting revelation of this otherwise unremarkable documentary was that the motive isn't arrogance at all, but a craven fear of internally imposed revenue targets - where failure can mean a reduced pay packet or even disciplinary proceedings.

There's absolutely no reason why Fred Dibnah's Magnificent Monuments (BBC2, 8pm) should work. It's hard to imagine a metropolitan BBC commissioning editor responding positively to the idea of sending any other bumbling gent in a flat cap and collarless shirt with a heavy Lancastrian accent motoring around Britain to poke around old buildings aimlessly, regularly emitting a gurgling chuckle that would sound frankly lecherous if its objects weren't wattle and daub and well crafted roof tiles. But there has been no real explanation for Dib nah ever since his early work as a pioneer of televised steeplejacking, and nobody seems to mind. The series has the feel of having slipped, fully formed, through a gap in time from an era when pointing a camera at something interesting - the intricate oak panelling of Hampton Court Palace, in this case, and the windows of Lacock Abbey in Wiltshire, where Fox Talbot invented photography - counted as good television. Oddly, it still does.

There's evidence, too, that Dibnah's is not a persona honed for the small screen: he seems to have been like this as a teenager, as he revealed in last night's episode. Eschewing conventional adolescent pursuits, he built a spindly replacement chimney on his parents' house. He didn't design it first. "I just kept altering it in shape and size as it went up... The new owners want to dismantle it, but the council's put a preservation order on it", said Dibnah. And chuckled.

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.body:
Remember the hairy cornflake, DLT? Simon Bates and Our Tune? Steve Wright and his wacky studio crew? (way before Chris Evans, that one). They were just a few of the Smashie and Nicey DJs fronting Radio 1 until the early 1990s and the arrival of one Matthew Bannister (pictured below). Now think of Blood On The Carpet - the BBC series produced by dirt-digging film-maker Robert Thirkell, which has leered indulgently over the business troubles of the likes of Forte when it succumbed to the might of a Granada takeover. Put them together and what have you got? A bunch of DJs lining up to get their revenge on Bannister for axing so many of their crumbling number in a cruel and calculated clear-out which repositioned the Beeb's toptastic radio station as a yoof-ful listen.

Or at least, that's how a forthcoming episode of Blood On The Carpet is being billed, as it seeks to bring "at least one DJ" from the dark Bannister days together with Bannister himself in a no-holds-barred postmortem of what happened when Nicey turned nasty. In making the show, Thirkell is effectively turning the camera on his own boss. Bannister is now chief executive of BBC Production - the in-house BBC department which makes Blood On The Carpet along with a number of Thirkell specials such as Trouble and The Big Top. The highlight of that floorshow, featuring the painful gestation of the Dome, was erstwhile Dome minister Peter Mandelson getting all confused about his dates. "Here we are in 2000 AD. Or is it BC? No, it's AD, isn't it? Oh God...." So what will the pool of Bannister's blood look like when it hits the carpet in this new show? Perhaps we'll be treated to a recollection of just how sad the departure of "Ooo" Gary Davies was, when he quit R1 in 1993 saying it had become a minority station. The same station that just increased its share from 10.6% to 10.9% of all listening. In this show, it seems, the last laugh is with Bannister.

 Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast

webTitle: New breed of Labour elite riles think tank

fields.headline: New breed of Labour elite riles think tank
fields.trailText: A new establishment of left-leaning lawyers, showbusiness figures, academics and business people has been surreptitously levered into key positions of power in Britain under New Labour, according to a study published today.
fields.body:
A new establishment of left-leaning lawyers, showbusiness figures, academics and business people has been surreptitously levered into key positions of power in Britain under New Labour, according to a study published today.

A report by the centre for policy studies highlights the rise of a "new class" of Labour-supporting great and good who, through peerages, taskforce jobs and quango posts, have taken over the reins of power in Tony Blair's Britain.

Members of the new establishment are linked by an intricate web of connections ranging from the governing body of the London School of Economics to the Demon Eyes football team featuring a clutch of Downing Street policy advisers. Many are major donors to the party.

The swift rise of figures such as Lords Puttnam, Haskins and Bragg and Baroness Kennedy is evidence of how support for new Labour is repaid with political advancement and patronage, the study claims.

The Labour party last night dismissed The Great and Good? The Rise of the New Class, by CPS deputy editor Martin McElwee, as "hot air from Mrs T's favourite think tank".

However, while not the first observation of the rise of the New Labour establishment, the report is one of the most comprehensive analyses of the phenomenon. Coming from the CPS, the rightwing think tank set up by Margaret Thatcher and Sir Keith Joseph which helped initiate policies including privatisation, trade union reform and council house sales, it can be viewed as sour grapes on the part of those displaced from power.

But the study also highlights the realities of the mechanisms used by the government to create its own establishment.

As part of continuing reform of the House of Lords, Mr Blair has created new life peers at an annual rate unprecedented in 50 years. Since May 1997, 176 life peers have been appointed; with around 50 more to come, Mr Blair is on course to become the most prolific creator of life peers of any British prime minister.

The report claims: "Not since the days of Harold Wilson has Britain witnessed such a conscious attempt to create a new class." The manifestion of the Blairite class is "the assault on the old establishment", the promotion of "cool Britannia" and everything new, the wide-eyed enthusiasm for the information superhighway and the dome".

The phenomenon is more than "merely another example of a government giving its natural supporters positions of authority", since it is both on a grander scale and is designed to spread New Labour views while stifling all political debate, the report claims.

Condemning "the silence of the sheep", the study accuses the government of binding in potential critics such as pressure groups, trade unions and members of other political parties by giving them places on quangos, task forces and in the Lords.

The study points to Tory big hitters such as Chris Patten, Michael Heseltine and Kenneth Clarke who have been brought into New Labour's big tent.

A Labour spokeswoman said: "Clearly the centre for policy studies objects to diverse new faces coming forward on the basis of merit and experience. Would they prefer the old Tory ways, preferring the few on the basis of background and privilege?"

Key figures in the new class

Lord Bragg
Ennobled by Blair in 1998, the South Bank Show presenter is a prime example of the showbusiness, culture and the arts wing of the new establishment. A high profile New Labour supporter from the Kinnock years, and a substantial donor to the party, he has formidable connections at the BBC and LWT (where he is controller of arts). He is president of the National Campaign for the Arts and, like a string of other new Labour figures, is a governor of the London School of Economics.

Baroness Kennedy of the Shaws
Ennobled by Blair in 1997. A QC and crusading barrister, she is one of the most prominent of a growing band of successful London lawyers directly involved in government or influential in political life. Described by the centre for policy studies as a key member of the "new class", she is a long-time Labour supporter and is prominent on many legal bodies. However, her stock may have fallen slightly after she outspokenly opposed government moves to restrict the right to jury trial.

Lord Haskins
A major Labour donor and staunch supporter, ennobled in 1998. As chairman of Northern Foods he has been a strong voice for new Labour in the business community. The CPS ranks him highly among the swathe of key business figures swept into the bosom of New Labour. A prominent quango member, the prime minister appointed him chairman of the better regulation taskforce and the interchange steering council. Lord Haskins is also a trustee of the left-leaning think tank, Demos.

Lord Puttnam
Enobled in 1997, he was, like Lord Bragg, a longtime Labour donor and supporter, and is a governor of the LSE. Holding one of the largest clutches of top task force posts under New Labour, the Oscar-winning film producer has been appointed to the board of the Science Museum, the arts council lottery panel, the creative industries task force and the general teaching council.

Anthony Giddens
The prime figure in the academic category of the new class. The director of the LSE is guru of the Third Way, and is close to Tony Blair. Governors of the LSE include new establishment stalwarts such as Cherie Blair, Lord Puttnam, Lord Stevenson, Heather Rabbatts, Lord Grabiner and Lord Gavron.

fields.headline: Scots strive for section 28 deal
fields.standfirst:
Devolution in Scotland: special report
More about section 28
fields.trailText: The Scottish executive yesterday tried to end the escalating row over the repeal of section 28 by announcing it will be replaced with a new clause stressing the value of stable family life.
fields.body:
The Scottish executive yesterday tried to end the escalating row over the repeal of section 28 by announcing it will be replaced with a new clause stressing the value of stable family life.

The vaguely worded clause, drawn up after days of tortuous debate, is seen as a desperate effort to try and reassure parents, satisfy supporters of repeal, and keep the coalition with the Liberal Democrats in place.

But last night, Brian Souter, the Stagecoach tycoon who has bankrolled a public campaign against repeal of section 28, which bans the promotion of the acceptability of homosexuality in schools, said the new clause was an insult to Scottish parents.

"It offers no protection against the promotion of homosexuality and it places homosexual relationships on the same moral basis as marriage," he said. "We have to ask ourselves; who have the government been listening to? The gay pressure groups or Scottish parents?"

The Scottish executive's move is likely to be seen as a precursor to a compromise over section 28 in England and Wales.

The education secretary, David Blunkett, is searching for a way to placate church leaders and ensure that the bill to repeal the clause makes it through the rebellious House of Lords.

Yesterday Scottish first minister Donald Dewar said his executive was committed to the repeal of section 28. He said the new section, which will be put in the forthcoming ethical standards in public life bill, was not a u-turn and offered a child-centered response to concerns.

The clause says: "It is the duty of a council in the performance of those of its functions which relate principally to children to have regard to the value of stable family life in a child's development."

Mr Dewar declined to define "stable family life" but said the clause was designed to be inclusive.

"I have no doubt that some will cry surrender and others bitterly complain that the proposals do not go far enough." But he insisted: "Our new provision is a sensible buttressing of local government's duty of care and a practical support for the decent sensitive regime that has been the rule in our schools and in the delivery of local government services to children over many years."

The Liberal Democrats backed the compromise. Many had wanted outright repeal with no replacement.

But SNP leader Alex Salmond said the new wording was woolly and might cause problems in future.

fields.headline: Livingstone eclipses mayoral contenders
fields.standfirst:
Beaten rival stays silent as candidates debate policies

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone, in his trademark wrinkled khaki suit, sat alone, with his arms folded looking like a modern day Banquo's ghost. But to the waiting crowd at last night's Guardian London mayoral debate, he was the king in waiting.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone, in his trademark wrinkled khaki suit, sat alone, with his arms folded looking like a modern day Banquo's ghost. But to the waiting crowd at last night's Guardian London mayoral debate, he was the king in waiting.

The debate, in Westminster's Church House, had been billed as the first chance to see the three main party's official candidates put their policies to Londoners.

Mr Livingstone, who is enjoying a self-imposed week-long purdah while he waits for Mr Dobson's "honourable resignation", was not among the panel.

The arrival of the Brent East MP was greeted like the return of the prodigal son by the 500-strong audience, who applauded, cheered and whistled as he made his way down the long narrow aisle to his seat, not on the podium alongside Labour's Frank Dobson, the Tories' Steven Norris and Liberal Democrat Susan Kramer, but four rows back, alongside the voters of London.

The standing ovation from many in the audience, if embarrassing for the Brent East MP, delighted his entourage of supporters, one of whom remarked: "That's the middle class people with nothing to do on a wet Thursday night vote sewn up."

Unfortunately for Tony Blair and the apparatchiks at Millbank, the applause for the three official candidates was lukewarm in contrast.

Mr Dobson and Mr Norris - both dressed in the obligatory uniform of sober politicians - dark suit, white shirt and burgundy tie - joined Ms Kramer and Guardian columnist Jonathan Freedland on the podium, while Mr Livingstone smiled and blushed his way through the debate.

After a show of hands revealed that the support among the audience was in favour of Mr Livingtone standing as either the official Labour or an independent candidate for the May 4 elections, it was time to get down to business.

Mr Dobson said: "I'm sick of what's wrong with London. There's a job to be done and I believe I can get that job done."

He promised to tackle the problems on the tube, crime levels, lack of jobs and racism.

Mr Dobson offered an olive brach to Mr Livingstone's supporters opposed to his policy of partial privatisation of the tube. He promised to set up an independent panel to review the best financing option for the tube and vowed to publish their findings.

In a small climb-down from his previously stated policy, he said: "Some people are dogmatically in favour of bonds and against PPP [public private partnership]. Others are dogmatically in favour of PPP and against bonds. I'm neither."

Next it was Susan Kramer. "This is a very difficult job," she said. "It's a matter of getting hold of the problems and dealing with them. I have the advantage over my two friends here. I was selected last August, by one member one vote."

Mr Livingstone, his arms still folded, chuckled at this.

Ms Kramer continued: "Our communities are becoming ghettos of the very rich who can afford London prices and ghettos of people on housing benefit. We will change this society because I'm not in the race for any other reason."

Steven Norris, clearly not a favourite among the audience last night, has never been a man to be bowed by public opinion. "I think it's a marvellous city to celebrate, extraordinary in its diversity. It's a great city and yet, and yet - it's not doing itself, in my view, the justice it deserves," he said.

But it was Susan Kramer who had the hardest hitting message for Mr Livingstone. "Londoners have real problems, that's what we should be talking about. Anyone who wants to get in to the race - and this is a free country - get into it and let's get on with dealing with those problems."

And with 10 weeks to go before the election proper takes place, she added: "London deserves at least 10 weeks of serious debate."

He promised to tackle the problems on the tube, crime levels, lack of jobs and racism. Mr Dobson offered an olive brach to Mr Livingstone's supporters opposed to his policy of partial privatisation of the tube. He promised to set up an independent panel to review the best financing option for the tube and vowed to publish their findings. In a small climb-down from his previously stated policy, he said: "Some people are dogmatically in favour of bonds and against PPP [public private partnership]. Others are dogmatically in favour of PPP and against bonds. I'm neither." Next it was Susan Kramer. "This is a very difficult job," she said. "It's a matter of getting hold of the problems and dealing with them. I have the advantage over my two friends here. I was selected last August, by one member one vote." Mr Livingstone, his arms still folded, chuckled at this. Ms Kramer continued: "Our communities are becoming ghettos of the very rich who can afford London prices and ghettos of people on housing benefit. We will change this society because I'm not in the race for any other reason." Steven Norris, clearly not a favourite among the audience last night, has never been a man to be bowed by public opinion. "I think it's a marvellous city to celebrate, extraordinary in its diversity. It's a great city and yet, and yet - it's not doing itself, in my view, the justice it deserves," he said. But it was Susan Kramer who had the hardest hitting message for Mr Livingstone. "Londoners have real problems, that's what we should be talking about. Anyone who wants to get in to the race - and this is a free country - get into it and let's get on with dealing with those problems." And with 10 weeks to go before the election proper takes place, she added: "London deserves at least 10 weeks of serious debate."

fields.headline: Ofra Haza
fields.standfirst: Israeli singer who became a worldwide ambassador for her people
fields.trailText: Ofra Haza, who has died suddenly aged 42, was Israel's most successful international pop star. While her driving Middle East-flavoured dance tracks were known in techno clubs from New York to Tokyo, her ethereal ballads also mesmerised world music enthusiasts. But her lasting legacy was her cultural impact in Israel. Almost single-handedly, she popularised the culture of the country's Oriental Jews, the Mizrachim. By doing so, she raised their status as the custodians of exquisite traditions which had long been neglected by the artistic establishment.
fields.body:
Ofra Haza, who has died suddenly aged 42, was Israel's most successful international pop star. While her driving Middle East-flavoured dance tracks were known in techno clubs from New York to Tokyo, her ethereal ballads also mesmerised world music enthusiasts. But her lasting legacy was her cultural impact in Israel. Almost single-handedly, she popularised the culture of the country's Oriental Jews, the Mizrachim. By doing so, she raised their status as the custodians of exquisite traditions which had long been neglected by the artistic establishment.

Ofra's origins were humble. One of eight children born to Yemeni-Jewish parents who had moved to Israel to escape persecution, she grew up in a Tel Aviv slum. She loved singing traditional Yemenite Jewish folk tunes with her mother and at 12 joined a local theatre group where her talent was recognised and she was recruited as a singer/actress. After two years' army service she returned to the troupe, and then launched her solo career at 19.

Her 1979 hit, The Tart's Song, was notable for its slangy lyrics and in 1983 she came second in the Eurovision Song Contest with an equally vivacious number called Stay Alive.

More audacious in a wider sense was her 1985 album, Yemenite Songs. Earlier Israeli rock artists had updated folk songs from the country's pioneer generation or borrowed from the western idiom. But Ofra showed that one could return to a far older diaspora tradition by turning a devotional poem from the 17th century Yemenite rabbi Shalom Shabazi into a nightclub sensation in the mid-1980s. The album became an instant success in Israel.

She cleverly re-released Yemenite Songs as Fifty Gates of Wisdom, and followed it with Shaday (a mystical name for God). By then her international success was assured, and her survival in a plane crash intensified her adulation.

For all her loyalty to tradition, she never shied away from experimentation. Her innovation was to pluck the old melodies out of the folk-club ghetto. Her music acquired a harder rock sound with Desert Wind in 1990, and two years later she recorded a single with the avant-garde Sisters of Mercy.

That same year she sang with the Pakistani ghazal virtuoso, Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan, on Sony's Millennium tribute Prayer Cycle, while Iggy Pop intoned the chorus to Ofra's feminist ballad Daw da Hiya. This appeared on her 1992 Grammy-nominated CD Kirya, which one rock magazine hailed as "the beginning of the next era in the world fusion of music."

By now Ofra was singing in both Hebrew and English, and addressing issues other than forbidden love. The Trains of No Return warns against accepting another Holocaust, while other numbers attacked slavery and the plight of refugees. Never overtly political, Ofra Haza was none the less devoted to peace. In 1991 she appeared on the international Give Peace a Chance line-up and in 1994 Yitzhak Rabin, winner of the Nobel peace prize with Shimon Peres and Yasser Arafat, requested that she should sing at the award ceremony.

More than just an ambassador for Israel's Yemenite community, Ofra presented an authentically Levantine face of Israel to the wider world. Despite her glamour, she was never a prima donna; she co-operated generously with musicians the world over and was a private, almost shy, person. The memory of her vocal clarity and unaffected piety will endure.

She is survived by her husband, Doron Ashkenazi, whom she married in 1998.

fields.headline: Pat McLoughlin
fields.standfirst: Producer who lured a galaxy of talent to the Woman's Hour serial
fields.trailText: The name of Pat McLoughlin, who has died aged 66, is almost synonymous with the daily serial she produced for 23 years on BBC Radio 4's Woman's Hour. She joined the BBC as a studio manager straight out of the Wrens and a shortlived marriage to a dashing, naval doctor. It was at a time when each episode of the serial would be read live by an actor and the only way to stop it overrunning was to rush into the studio and remove the final pages.
fields.body:
The name of Pat McLoughlin, who has died aged 66, is almost synonymous with the daily serial she produced for 23 years on BBC Radio 4's Woman's Hour. She joined the BBC as a studio manager straight out of the Wrens and a shortlived marriage to a dashing, naval doctor. It was at a time when each episode of the serial would be read live by an actor and the only way to stop it overrunning was to rush into the studio and remove the final pages.

With her hugely eclectic taste and uncanny knowledge of what would touch the hearts of listeners, McLoughlin was responsible for establishing the serial as radio's most respected literary slot. When Clare Selerie and I became editors of the programme in 1987, she adapted spiritedly to our championing of women writers, but could never resist taunting us with the reminder of the most popular serial ever - the gigantic, distinctly unfeminist two-volume tome Ebenezar le Page.

Pat was an actor's producer, gaining the respect of generations of our most distinguished performers: Diana Rigg, Janet Suzman, Maggie Steed, Anna Massey, Ronald Pickup, Edward Petherbridge, Harriet Walter, Juliet Stevenson, Maria Aitken, Patricia Hodge, Judi Dench, Martin Jarvis.

It was Pat who persuaded Alan Bennett to read his memoirs for us and Dame Edna Everage to perform hers. And it was Pat who steadily championed and promoted unknown talents - such as Deric Longden, whose Diana's Story, a tribute to the courage of his wife when struck down by a debilitating illness, became a best-seller after it was aired as a serial.

Pat introduced audiences to the works of half-forgotten writers such as Rosamund Lehmann and Elizabeth Bowen, to countless new discoveries such as Jane Smiley and Anne Tyler, and indulged her particular relish for crime fiction with regular doses of PD James, Ruth Rendell, Dorothy L Sayers and Margaret Yorke.

She braved the wrath of sensitive listeners with the occasional sexy love scene or necessary blasphemy. When these occurred during the school holidays, as they often seemed to do, she would cheerfully appear on Radio 4's listener access programme Feedback with her characteristic dismissive snort.

Once she substituted "dog poo" for the original "shit", and was frustrated that angry listeners were just as incensed either way. Deborah Moggach wrote to thank her for her sensitive adaptation of The Ex-Wives, and especially for leaving in all the best jokes. Unfortunately, one of these involved yet another airing of the "s" word and yet another barrage of complaints.

Through her production and brilliant choices, Pat achieved an astonishing 21 commercial recordings of readings for the BBC Radio Collection, including the whole run of Jane Austen novels read by leading actresses. She prided herself on tackling the weightier classics, though I'll never forget her awaiting in trepidation an audience onslaught for what she feared had been a mutilation of Jane Eyre. It never came, they hadn't spotted the joins.

Pat was also editor of two books of Woman's Hour short stories, and the WH Book Of Poetry, accompanied by audio cassettes. Faintly surprised at her own achievements, she would blame me for encouraging her into print, referring grimly to my manipulation of her as "the bolt in the neck".

For years the oldest of the Woman's Hour team, she gained the admiration and love of generations of staff. It was Pat who urged us to wild Thursday evenings of drink and companionship and offered her support during crises.

At her 1993 retirement party she confessed that during the time when we were resisting attempts to remove Woman's Hour in 1991, the badges that had appeared in the BBC council chamber, attached to each portrait of past director-generals proclaiming "I'm a Woman's Hour Man", had been placed by her. They had delighted the press, gathered there to celebrate Shula's wedding in The Archers.

Having left the BBC at the official retirement age of 60 - and with an MBE for services to broadcasting - Pat took a law degree at Thames Valley University. She then studied for the bar, achieving a distinction.

She leaves her devoted friend and partner, Susan Loppert, with whom she shared her final years, as well as droves of friends and colleagues who will cherish her great-heartedness, her sense of fun, and her refusal never to compromise her sense, intelligence, and integrity.

 Patricia McLoughlin, broadcaster, born August 17 1933; died February 23 2000
