fields.headline: Michael Colvin
fields.standfirst: After marrying an heiress he became a gentleman farmer, Tory MP and champion of whites in South Africa
fields.trailText: Michael Colvin, the 67-year-old Conservative MP who has died with his heiress wife in a fire at his Tangley House mansion, near Andover, would have made a presentable US-type presidential candidate. With handsome aquiline features and wavy white hair, the son of a naval captain who married into the Cayzer shipping fortune had the background to pursue his political ambitions. And the cushion of a 1,000-acre farming estate to fall back on.
fields.body:
Michael Colvin, the 67-year-old Conservative MP who has died with his heiress wife in a fire at his Tangley House mansion, near Andover, would have made a presentable US-type presidential candidate. With handsome aquiline features and wavy white hair, the son of a naval captain who married into the Cayzer shipping fortune had the background to pursue his political ambitions. And the cushion of a 1,000-acre farming estate to fall back on.

He was a friend of the Prince of Wales, but a sharp critic of Princess Diana. He was a leader of the post-Hungerford and post-Dunblane "gun lobby" and a supporter of field sports. He was also a somewhat secretive former propagandist for apartheid South Africa and a friend of other lobbyists such as Ian Greer, Neil Hamilton and Derek Laud. But he was not monochromatic. He was liberal on abortion, favoured free eye and dental treatment, and would have preferred the whites he backed in southern Africa to be more reformist

Above all, he was a defence and aviation specialist, serving actively until last month on the defence select committee, which he chaired from 1995 to 1997. On Tuesday, two days before he died, he made a 25-minute speech, the longest in the Commons defence debate. His swansong deplored the forces' manpower shortage, which he attributed to the ministry of defence losing battles with the treasury.

Colvin came by such interests naturally. He was born the son of Captain Ivan Beale Colvin RN and Joy Arbuthnot. His family had a political background: a great-great uncle had successfully introduced a bill to ban bear-baiting.

His education was suited to the military wing of the Tory squirearchy. He attended West Downs prep school at Winchester; Eton; and the Royal Military Academy at Sandhurst. At 18 he went into the Grenadier Guards, serving in Berlin, Suez and Cyprus, emerging as a captain.

His economic future was assured when, at the age of 24, he married Nichola Cayzer, the daughter of Lord Cayzer, top man in the British and Commonwealth shipping company. Initially, he worked for four years in advertising with the agency J Walter Thompson, then for 14 years as a director of Accrep Ltd, a property investment firm.

A decade or so ago the family funds had swollen adequately for him and his wife to become Lloyd's names and to buy the Tangley estate. He also became briefly the owner of the Cricketers' Arms, to save it for the village. To qualify himself as a major farmer, he studied at the Royal Agricultural College at Cirencester.

Initially, his political ambitions were satisfied in local government. He was elected to Tangley parish council for 12 years from 1964, to Andover rural district council for seven years from 1965, and to Hampshire county council for five years from 1970.

His first parliamentary seat was Bristol North West, which he captured from Labour in 1979, when Margaret Thatcher achieved power. He showed political ambivalence, urging a new centre party on the one hand, but also calling for privatisation of NHS services. He showed his commitment to the doomed rightwing, white forces in Africa by endorsing the South-African-backed anti-Swapo regime in Namibia in 1981.

In 1983 he switched to the new, much safer seat of Romsey and Waterside, stretching out from the Southampton suburbs. As a Cayzer son-in-law, he opposed the phasing out of tax allowances on new shipbuilding and urged a larger, more modern merchant marine fleet. He opposed the slicing off of BA's routes just when it was becoming successful. He favoured easier conditions for pub licencees

But above all, he spoke up for the whites of southern Africa, particularly after twice visiting apartheid South Africa and Bophuthatswana as a guest of their governments, first in 1986. He was liberal enough to support reformist Dennis Worral's 1987 election campaign. But in 1988 he criticised the BBC for broadcasting its Mandela concert tribute. In 1989 he visited Bophuthatswana again and Angola as a guest of Unita, backed by the CIA and South Africa. He also welcomed the visit of FW de Klerk to Britain and condemned a telecast by Peter Hain and anything emanating from Anti-Apartheid.

Such views led him to become in 1991 a consultant, at £10,000 a year - replacing Neil Hamilton - to Strategic Network International, a lobbyist front organised, possibly unbeknown to him, by pre-Mandela South African intelligence organisations. Later, he became a director, with the black Tory, Derek Laud, of the Laud Ludgate lobbying organisation.

As chairman of the Council for Country Sports from 1988, Colvin stepped up his opposition to gun-control and bans on foxhunting. As captain of the Commons shooting club, he opposed the conversion of its shooting range into a creche.

In all things, Michael Colvin was an ardent advocate of those he chose to speak for. Among his last words on Tuesday, in the midst of his defence speech, was to complain for farmers: "As a farmer, I am experiencing a crisis at present. I have postponed the purchase of a new combine because I cannot afford it this year."

That problem has been left in the hands of his son and two daughters.

 Michael Keith Beale Colvin, politician, born September 27 1932; died February 24 2000

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: UN bolsters Congo monitors
fields.body:
UN bolsters Congo monitors

The security council yesterday authorised a 5,500-member UN force to monitor a shaky ceasefire in the many-sided conflict that has plagued the Democratic Republic of the Congo.

The long-awaited vote on the US resolution from the 15-country council was unanimously in favour of vastly increasing the mission's manpower from its meagre allocation of 90 liaison officers. Reuters, New York

Gunman kills 7 in South Africa

After an apparent dispute over cattle-grazing, a 60-year-old man went on a shooting rampage in a South African village yesterday, killing seven people, including five family members, before shooting himself dead.

The gunman killed his two wives, his six-year-old daughter, and his son and daughter-in-law, before breaking into a nearby house to wound a woman and kill her young daughter. He later shot dead a man who owed him £3 and then killed himself. AP, Kabokweni, South Africa

Activists stage basilica protest

Three Basque environmental campaigners scaled the cupola of St Peter's basilica yesterday to unfurl banners protesting against a controversial dam in Spain's Itoiz valley, in the Basque region.

The activists have recently staged similar protests on London's millennium wheel and Berlin's Brandenberg gate. One of the banners said "No to the dams" in Italian. Reuters, Vatican City

Two Siberian tigers shot

Wildlife officials in Russia's far east killed two rare Siberian snow tigers this week after the large, carnivorous animals began marauding villages, according to a news report. Only about 300 of the tigers remain in the wild. AP, Moscow

webTitle: Ex-Coke boss aims to take fizz out of Mexico's ruling elite

fields.headline: Ex-Coke boss aims to take fizz out of Mexico's ruling elite
fields.standfirst: Candidates limber up for presidential election
fields.trailText: Between the advertisements for Sol beer and Wonderbras at the side of the crowded ring roads in Mexico City, are posters of an enormous hand signalling V for victory. Beside the hand is the smiling face of a man who claims he is about to end the 70-year monopoly of the Institutional Revolutionary party (PRI).
fields.body:
Between the advertisements for Sol beer and Wonderbras at the side of the crowded ring roads in Mexico City, are posters of an enormous hand signalling V for victory. Beside the hand is the smiling face of a man who claims he is about to end the 70-year monopoly of the Institutional Revolutionary party (PRI).

Since its inception in 1929, the PRI, which has been in power longer than any other party in the world, has permeated all areas of society in Mexico and become a political freemasonry bestowing protection and favours to its supporters while subtly excluding or co-opting its opponents.

The Peruvian writer Mario Vargas Llosa has called it "the perfect dictatorship". The Mexican writer Gabriel Zaid in his book The Sham Republic, preferred to see the system as a "lie" in which the government's continued rule was assured by a web of dishonesty.

But, with the six-yearly presidential election due on July 2, is there any real belief that the monopoly is about to end?

"The difference with this election is that for once we don't know who is going to win," said Luis Hernandez, opinion editor of the daily newspaper La Jornada. Mr Hernandez believes the national desire for change could finally see in a new government.

At present, the only candidate apparently capable of effecting this change is Vicente Fox, the former head of Coca-Cola in Mexico. He is a tall, self-confident northerner, proud of his roots and his cowboy boots, and of his plain talking and casual style, unsullied by the corruption of national office.

The candidate for the right-wing National Action party (PAN), Mr Fox is a former governor of his home state of Guanajuato who believes he can succeed if he can broker the necessary deals with smaller parties. He has already started negotiations and hopes to announce alliances next month.

The PRI candidate - still a favourite with most commentators - is the patrician Francisco "Pancho" Labastida, who emerged as a surprise winner of the party's primaries.

A career politician and former ambassador to Portugal who won the party's nomination last November, Mr Labastida is trying to distance himself as politely as possible from the PRI establishment, and claims that he is the man to tackle corruption within the party. Embarrassingly, last Friday he was fined £25 for defacing public property after spray-painting a PRI slogan on a wall as a publicity stunt.

The third candidate, lagging far behind the two front-runners is Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, of the left-of-centre Democratic Revolution party (PRD), which he founded.

Many Mexicans believe that Mr Cardenas had presidential victory stolen from him by a PRI fraud in the 1988 election. A former PRI member and son of a former president, he comes to the campaign after a term as mayor of Mexico City.

An opinion poll published this week in the daily newspaper El Universal gives Mr Labastida 42% of the vote, a drop of 5% points since December. Mr Fox is on 39%, with Mr Cardenas on 16%. Mr Labastida and Mr Fox are neck and neck in urban areas, according to the poll.

"Fox knows how to present himself, although it is not clear exactly what he stands for," said Mr Hernandez. "He appears as a non-politician." Mr Hernandez said of Mr Cardenas: "He has suffered a big campaign against him. He is an honest politician and we don't have many of them. He has been portrayed as 'old left', wanting more state intervention and social policies that are not regarded as successful any more."

Alma Guillermoprieto, a writer and commentator, said of Mr Labastida: "This is the party apparatus, this steamroller who is presented every six years. One of the more sinister effects [of the PRI's monopoly of power] is that it is very hard for the opposition to generate any leaders."

She said that he was misguided in presenting himself in casual outfits. "Mexicans probably want someone in a nice suit who can stand among other presidents and make Mexico look good."

Jorge Castaneda, author, academic and political analyst, also believed that Mr Labastida was the odds-on favourite, but said that if the PAN and the PRD were to bury their differences and make the election a referendum on the PRI, there was a "small chance" they could win.

But one political analyst said that he already knew the result: "The winner of the next election will be the United States. They prefer a corrupt and known system. Fox is not corrupt, so they have nothing to pressure him with."

But Mr Fox has his wealthy backers and many of them believe that there has never been a greater chance for voters to flash his V for victory sign.

webTitle: Riots risk return to darkness, Nigerian leader warns

fields.headline: Riots risk return to darkness, Nigerian leader warns
fields.trailText: The deaths of more than 300 people this week in religious violence prompted by plans for the introduction of Islamic sharia law in the northern Nigerian state of Kaduna has brought fresh warnings that Africa's most populous country is fracturing.
fields.body:
The deaths of more than 300 people this week in religious violence prompted by plans for the introduction of Islamic sharia law in the northern Nigerian state of Kaduna has brought fresh warnings that Africa's most populous country is fracturing.

Nigeria's principal Islamic leader, the Sultan of Sokoto, warned that the bloody clashes between Muslim and Christian elements in the city of Kaduna posed a "dangerous and very serious threat to the peace and unity of this great nation".

In a televised address to the nation, President Olusegun Obasanjo said that ethnic and religious violence - which has claimed more than 1,000 lives since democracy was restored in May - threatens Nigeria's revival after years of military rule which plundered the nation's wealth.

"To be engaged in activities that so unsettle public peace is not only criminal but highly unpatriotic, particularly now that the international community is beginning to regain its confidence in our nation," he said.

But General Obasanjo's critics, who include some of the parliamentary leaders of his own People's Democratic party, say he is also to blame for the crisis. They accuse him of running an "imperial presidency", and say he remains aloof from ethnic and religious tensions while concentrating on solving Nigeria's enormous economic problems and staving off the threat of another army coup.

In particular, they say his failure to take a stand on critical issues such as the introduction of sharia in some Muslim-dominated states has exacerbated the crisis by giving the impression that the government is uninterested in the concerns of ordinary people.

On Wednesday, the national assembly called on President Obasanjo to make a "categorical statement" on the adoption of Islamic laws which, among other things, segregates the sexes in transport and schooling.

Many Nigerians fear that if the violence intensifies, or if the country seems to be breaking up, there are military men waiting for an excuse to seize power.

In an interview before the latest bloodshed, President Obasanjo acknowledged that ethnic and religious tensions were increasing, but insisted they would die down as the government turned the economy around: "A lot of this violence happens because when you push people to that crescendo over an issue you have trouble pulling them back. But what leads to division and conflict is inequality. We have to tackle that first," he said.

"We have stabilised the currency. We have raised foreign exchange reserves. Inflation has gone from 14% to 8%. We know there is a lot of poverty. There are problems with education and water supply. But things are moving."

Even Gen Obasanjo's critics acknowledge that in the past nine months he has achieved some notable successes. He took advantage of the near total disgrace of the army, and his own position as a former general and military ruler, to dismiss almost an entire layer of corrupt senior officers with barely a murmur of protest.

Gen Obasanjo's anti-corruption programme has also been praised for sending the right message, even if it has a long way to go before significantly curbing graft. But the president is virtually at war with parliament, which has passed just one bill in nine months, and accuses its members of wanting to be bribed to do their work, particularly after they were granted huge "furniture allowances".

"The national assembly has a problem," the president said. "The average age of the members is probably 29 or 30. They have power without knowl edge or experience, which is dangerous. They seem to get carried away by emotion or personal interest."

The president's advisers say he is so sick of the national assembly that he will use his powers to bypass it if it fails to cooperate. Some parliamentarians, who say he has already carried out his threat, have threatened to impeach him for allegedly "riding roughshod" over every other arm of government and the courts after his administration ignored an order to release from prison a former senior army officer arrested for corruption.

There is also considerable bitterness among representatives from the Niger Delta over the heavy-handed use of the army to deal with unrest in the oil-rich region, particularly in the village of Odi where soldiers massacred several hundred people and destroyed every house in November.

Gen Obasanjo denies that he is out of touch: "All the things I have done for the last eight months have been nothing but populist. The returning of looted goods, the ending of the queues at petrol stations, the going into human rights issues of the past are all popular."

"Democracy is a means to an end not an end in itself. If I go to my village and say, I will bring you democracy, they will say I am mad. But if I say I will bring you piped water and tarred roads because of democracy they will want to hear about it. That is what the people want and that is what I am doing."

webTitle: Colombian troops accused of deep links with militias

fields.headline: Colombian troops accused of deep links with militias
fields.trailText: As the United States congress debates a massive increase in military aid to Colombia, a human rights report released yesterday alleges that the Colombian army maintains an intimate relationship with far-right paramilitaries and drug traffickers.
fields.body:
As the United States congress debates a massive increase in military aid to Colombia, a human rights report released yesterday alleges that the Colombian army maintains an intimate relationship with far-right paramilitaries and drug traffickers.

According to Human Rights Watch, in recent years the army has worked hand in hand with militias funded by drug cartels, sharing intelligence, coordinating joint operations and providing arms, medical attention and ammunition. Soldiers have also committed armed robbery, abduction and murder, it claims.

"Military support for paramilitary activity remains national in scope and includes areas where units receiving or scheduled to receive US military aid operate," the study by the Washington-based group concludes.

The report coincides with a visit to Colombia by the White House's anti-drugs chief, Barry McCaffrey, a big supporter of a $1.6bn (£1bn) aid package designed to help Colombia combat the drugs trade and end a 36-year civil war.

Direct US aid to the Colombian army was suspended in 1994 in response to military involvement in torture and other human rights abuses, but 80% of the new proposed package is military aid.

Although US law forbids military aid to units involved in human rights abuses, observers say that the screening process is far from perfect.

"All international security assistance should be conditioned on explicit actions by the Colombian government to sever links at all levels between the Colombian military and paramilitary groups,"the report says.

President Andres Pastrana has stated his determination to stamp out corruption in the military, dismissing several high-ranking army officers. But a Human Rights Watch researcher, Robin Kirk, said: "It's clear that this activity continues. While it's true that direct military involvement in human rights abuses has decreased, the military continues to contract out abuses to paramilitary groups."

Wednesday's report, which is based on interviews with witnesses and government investigators, focuses on three of the Colombian army's most prestigious brigades, operating in the capital Bogota, and the cities of Medellin and Cali.

One witness, a former army intelligence officer who moonlighted as a cartel gunman, said that army officers set up a paramilitary group in Cali, south-west of Bogota, after leftwing rebels seized 140 worshippers from a Catholic church in May 1999. Between May and September the group is believed to have killed 40 people, and forced more than 2,000 from their homes.

The witness described the difference between drug traffickers, paramilitaries and the Colombian army as "virtually non-existent".

Few of those detailed in the report have come to trial in civil court and dozens of prosecutors have fled the country after receiving death threats.

Colombia's paramilitary militias were founded by drug dealers and landowners in the 1980s to combat extortion and kidnapping by leftwing guerrillas. Rebels and paramilitaries rarely fight each other directly, instead targeting civilians they accuse of sympathising with their enemies.

Last week 45 people were shot and hacked to death in a five-day killing spree by paramilitaries in the northern town of Ovejas.

webTitle: Fiery warning:  Evacuation for 30,000 after Philippine volcano erupts

fields.headline: Fiery warning:  Evacuation for 30,000 after Philippine volcano erupts
fields.trailText: Apprehensive Philippine villagers look on as the Mayon volcano erupts in a series of explosions, spewing lava and super-heated ash over a wide area around its base.
fields.body:
Apprehensive Philippine villagers look on as the Mayon volcano erupts in a series of explosions, spewing lava and super-heated ash over a wide area around its base.

Lava began gushing out of Mayon's crater before dawn yesterday, accompanied by loud rumblings. A brightly glowing lava river snaked 3.5 miles down the mountain's slopes, about about 200 miles south-east of Manila on the island of Luzon. Ash rained as far as seven miles away and burning rocks were thrown six miles into the sky.

While there were no reports of injuries, it was estimated that more than 18 villages around the volcano had been evacuated of some 30,000 residents.

"We became so scared we decided to leave," said Judel Mirandilla, 14, of Bonga village. She was awoken at 1am by a series of explosions from the eruption. "Other people were waking up our neighbours" to move out.

Fourteen explosions were recorded by late afternoon, according to the Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology, indicating that magma is still rising to the dome and that the volcanic activity could continue for some time, said Juan Cordon, a research specialist at the institute.

Ash rained down on large areas west of the volcano and the authorities closed the airport in Legazpi, the closest city to the volcano.

The 2,460-metre (8,118ft) mountain has been emitting ash plumes and occasional lava flows for about a week.

webTitle: Dental probe proves mightier than gun

fields.headline: Dental probe proves mightier than gun
fields.trailText: Hunting a robber who only held up dentists, police have arrested a suspect in Rio de Janeiro after two victims identified the man by his rotting teeth.
fields.byline: Alex Bellos in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
Hunting a robber who only held up dentists, police have arrested a suspect in Rio de Janeiro after two victims identified the man by his rotting teeth.

For months the Brazilian city's dentists had been frightened at the prospect of encountering the bandit whose modus operandi was to ask for an appointment and, while his teeth were being looked at, pull out a revolver.

Last week a dentist was killed during a failed robbery and the suspect was arrested soon afterwards. At the police station, in the suburb of Tijuca, investigators called in two dentists who alleged that they had been assaulted by the same man.

The dentists were fairly sure that he was their assailant when they saw him in the police lineup. But when he opened his mouth wide, they were convinced.

"The guy has an unmistakable dental arch. It is full of holes," a police inspector said.

The man, Osvaldo Rui Ferreira, 32, is suspected of having robbed at least four other dentists in recent months.

"It was very easy for him to get an appointment because he has such terrible teeth. But they are so distinctive that any dentist can recognise them," the police officer said.

webTitle: Fire fuels nuclear row in Japan

fields.headline: Fire fuels nuclear row in Japan
fields.trailText: Japan's beleaguered nuclear industry suffered a new blow yesterday when a fire broke out at one of the country's power plants.
fields.body:
Japan's beleaguered nuclear industry suffered a new blow yesterday when a fire broke out at one of the country's power plants.

Although no radiation was leaked, it is the latest of many accidents in recent years that has undermined public confidence in atomic energy, which Japan relies on for more than a third of its electricity.

The fire broke out at the Onagawara nuclear power plant in Miyagi prefecture, about 200 miles north-east of Tokyo. Employees called the fire department after noticing smoke curling up from the power supply room, which is located below the control centre of the number-one reactor.

According to the operator, Tohoku Electric Power, the fire burnt itself out before firemen arrived - half an hour after the accident was reported.

The company said there were no injuries and no release of radiation because the 524-megawatt reactor had been shut down since last month for regular maintenance.

Questions are likely to be raised, however, about the cause of the fire and the slow response of the emergency services.

The accident comes five months after Japan's worst nuclear disaster, the uncontrolled chain reaction at a uranium-processing facility in Tokaimura, which killed one worker and exposed more than 400 people to radiation.

A string of fires and leaks has exposed the industry's lax safety standards and crisis management. In 1997, an explosion at a reprocessing plant in Tokaimura exposed 37 workers to low-level radiation. Two years earlier, radioactive sodium had been released from the Monju fast-breeder reactor. In these and other cases, plant officials were criticised for slow responses that appeared to focus more on covering-up mishaps than dealing with them.

In December, the government enacted new laws to tighten supervision of nuclear plants and speed up the process for dealing with accidents.

But these measures have failed to quell growing public hostility to atomic energy. In a devastating setback to the industry earlier this week, the governor of Mie prefecture became the first regional head to reject plans for a new nuclear power plant.

Because Japan has almost no natural energy resources, government officials insist that the country will push ahead with plans to build 20 new reactors by 2010, but privately some admit that this may no longer be possible.

In December, the government enacted new laws to tighten supervision of nuclear plants and speed up the process for dealing with accidents. But these measures have failed to quell growing public hostility to atomic energy. In a devastating setback to the industry earlier this week, the governor of Mie prefecture became the first regional head to reject plans for a new nuclear power plant. Because Japan has almost no natural energy resources, government officials insist that the country will push ahead with plans to build 20 new reactors by 2010, but privately some admit that this may no longer be possible.

webTitle: Secret service race trial sought by black agents

fields.headline: Secret service race trial sought by black agents
fields.trailText: Like their white colleagues, black secret service agents in the United States are expected to use their bodies to shield the president from an assassin's bullet, if necessary. But, when it comes to handing out promotions, they argue that the secret service is not quite so colour-blind.
fields.body:
Like their white colleagues, black secret service agents in the United States are expected to use their bodies to shield the president from an assassin's bullet, if necessary. But, when it comes to handing out promotions, they argue that the secret service is not quite so colour-blind.

For the first time in the service's history, a group of black agents has broken the code of silence: yesterday the agents launched an attempt to take their employers to court for racial discrimination, in a case likely to cast a rare spotlight on the organisation's inner workings.

One of the agents, Ray Moore, said his professionalism raised him to the service's top field position, the lead man in the president's protective detail. He became a familiar face around Bill Clinton, scanning the crowd and occasionally issuing orders into his sleeve microphone. But then, he says, he hit a glass ceiling blocking promotion into management.

Instead of winning the powerful White House desk job he believed was his due, he was ordered to train a white agent who was promoted in his place. Then he was transferred to an anti-counterfeiting squad in Dallas, Texas. He said that his sense of grievance finally overcame his deep loyalty to the service.

"I did it the way I was supposed to do it," Mr Moore told the New York Times. "I got a very, very wrong deal."

Mr Moore is the lead plaintiff in the group's attempt to sue the secret service, alleging a pattern of racial discrimination. The equal employment opportunity commission began an evaluation of the case yesterday. If it gives the go-ahead, the lawsuit will go to court.

"The secret service takes very seriously any complaint of racial discrimination," a service spokesman, Jim Mackin, said. "This organisation has actively engaged in ensuring a diverse work environment and affording equal opportunity to each of our employees."

Two of the service's seven assistant directors are black, as are four of the heads of its 11 largest field offices. However David Shaffer, the black agents' lawyer, said two of those positions were awarded in the past week "because they knew this case was coming".

Mr Shaffer, who has also taken the FBI and the bureau of alcohol, tobacco and firearms to court for racial discrimination, described the secret service culture as an "old-boy network where who you know is more important than what you know".

webTitle: Holocaust past added to French curriculum

fields.headline: Holocaust past added to French curriculum
fields.standfirst: Schools confront guilty past with lessons on deportation of Jews
fields.trailText: Sixty years after France introduced anti-semitic laws that resulted in the wartime deportation of more than 75,000 Jews, the Holocaust is to become a subject of study in French secondary schools from this autumn.
fields.body:
Sixty years after France introduced anti-semitic laws that resulted in the wartime deportation of more than 75,000 Jews, the Holocaust is to become a subject of study in French secondary schools from this autumn.

The latest step in the country's slow recognition of its wartime past was revealed to coincide with a visit to Israel by the French prime minister, Lionel Jospin.

He was education minister in 1983 when reference to France's complicity in the deportations was introduced into textbooks after being censored by successive governments since the second world war. But the subject currently only takes up a total of two hours of classes at lycée level as part of teaching on the war.

The new learning programme will use a special textbook based on a Swedish teaching manual called Tell Ye Your Children, written by a Frenchman, Stéphane Bruchfield, and an American, Paul Levine. A section on the French round-ups will be written by the Nazi hunter Serge Klarsfeld, who tracked down the Lyon gestapo chief Klaus Barbie, and pursued the former Vichy official and Nazi collaborator Maurice Papon for crimes against humanity.

Teachers had complained that, despite the general issue of history books that include photographs of French police rounding up Jews, it was left to individual schools to decide the importance of the lessons. Many have their own pro grammes which include special exhibitions, or films on the Holocaust, while others treat the matter summarily.

Laurence Brisset, speaking for the national teachers' union, Se-Fen, said that the subject was usually rushed through in the year before the baccalaureate. Thirteen-year-olds were also supposed to be taught about the consequences of the Holocaust, but there had been a lack of encouragement from the top, Mr Brisset said.

In the new textbook there will be references to specific French cases, including deportations from the Drancy concentration camp in the Paris suburbs, and the detention of thousands of Jews in the city's former bicycle stadium in 1942, before being sent to Auschwitz.

According to the textbook's publisher, Jean-Claude Gawsewitch, the book could eventually be distributed to primary school pupils. Several other countries, including Britain and Germany, are expected to use the book for class studies.

webTitle: Party of scandal faces first poll test in Germany

fields.headline: Party of scandal faces first poll test in Germany
fields.standfirst: Regional vote could decide who leads tainted CDU
fields.trailText: Battered by scandal, Germany's opposition Christian Democrat Union faces the verdict of the people this weekend in regional elections that could influence the party's choice of a new leader.
fields.body:
Battered by scandal, Germany's opposition Christian Democrat Union faces the verdict of the people this weekend in regional elections that could influence the party's choice of a new leader.

Two markedly different politicians are vying to succeed Wolfgang Schäuble. One is Volker Rühe, a former defence minister who represents the hopes of the party establishment. His rival, Angela Merkel, is the party's general secretary and the choice of many members who want a decisive break with the CDU's tainted past.

The forceful, combative Mr Rühe will be the party's candidate to run the government of Schleswig-Holstein when voters in Germany's northernmost region go to the polls on Sunday. But unless he can put up a creditable showing, his chances of seizing the leadership will evaporate, clearing the way for Ms Merkel.

The challenge facing Mr Rühe is formidable. Support has been haemorrhaging from the Christian Democrats since it emerged in recent months that for years the party had been illegally funded through a network of slush funds.

What is more, the scandal shows no signs of abating. The focus has shifted to evidence that the office of the chancellor was cleared of potentially compromising documents when Helmut Kohl lost power as chancellor in 1998.

Last week, his successor as party leader, Mr Schäuble, announced that he would not be standing when the party elects a new chief in April.

Mr Schäuble, who had repeatedly changed his account of his own involvement in covert funding, said he was stepping down to give the Christian Democrats the opportunity of a "new beginning".

But a poll published yesterday showed them still trailing the governing Social Democrats by 17 percentage points. Barely a quarter of voters said they would opt for the conservatives who, until last autumn, had been comfortably ahead in the polls.

The slush funds scandal has also taken a toll in Schleswig-Holstein, though to a lesser extent than nationally. Recent soundings in the mainly rural region have given the Christian Democrats 33%.

Mr Rühe is thus most unlikely to win on Sunday. But he has told fellow party officials that he would consider it a victory if he were to equal the score of four years ago when the Christian Democrats took 37%. Any improvement on the latest poll results would probably keep him in the race.

"The results of the vote will decide my future," Mr Rühe, 57, told a press conference earlier this week.

At first glance, he is an unlikely candidate to take over the CDU. He was the party's general secretary from 1989 to 1992 - throughout the period in which millions of pounds in undisclosed donations were flowing through secret party accounts.

But he has denied all knowledge of the slush funds, and no evidence has come to light to suggest otherwise. Just as importantly, though, his campaign has gathered momentum from concerns that Ms Merkel could represent an altogether too radical departure.

Those fears are particularly widespread in the CDU's sister party in predominantly Roman Catholic Bavaria, the Christian Social union (CSU). As far as the more right-leaning party and its leader, Edmund Stoiber, are concerned, everything about Ms Merkel is wrong.

She is a woman, an easterner and a social progressive. Not only is she a Protestant, but the daughter of a Protestant pastor.

Behind the scenes Mr Stoiber and his aides have been working hard to block her route to the leadership. Seen from Bavaria, the prospect of a CDU led by Ms Merkel is not just unappetising, but dangerous.

Mr Stoiber's reactionary, populist rhetoric, tinged with scepticism about the euro and the European union's planned expansion to the east, serves to bind some of the more extreme rightwing elements in Bavaria into the mainstream of conservative politics.

With the entry into government of Jörg Haider's far right Freedom party in neighbouring Austria, those elements will need a lot more persuading that their best prospects of influence lie with the mainstream.

If Germany's main conservative party were to be taken over by a woman known for her progressive record on abortion and the legal status of gay partnerships, they would need even more convincing.

The problem for the right of the Christian Democrat movement is that, for now, all hopes rest with a candidate whose prospects could be undone in a single, local vote on Sunday.

webTitle: Turkey jails Kurds and charges mayors

fields.headline: Turkey jails Kurds and charges mayors
fields.trailText: Turkey's judiciary launched a fresh offensive against Kurdish political activism yesterday, sending 18 people to prison for supporting the rebel Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK), and charging three prominent Kurdish mayors with similar offences.
fields.body:
Turkey's judiciary launched a fresh offensive against Kurdish political activism yesterday, sending 18 people to prison for supporting the rebel Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK), and charging three prominent Kurdish mayors with similar offences.

The leader of Turkey's main pro-Kurdish party, Ahmet Turan Demir, and his predecessor, Murat Bozlak, were among the group of Kurds who received sentences of at least three years each.

They were found guilty of organising demonstrations and hunger strikes early last year in support of the imprisoned Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan. Their party, the People's Democracy party (Hadep), was already facing a legal challenge that could close it down.

The new campaign against Hadep has dashed hopes that the Turkish establishment may relax restrictions on peaceful forms of Kurdish politics following the capture and sentencing of Ocalan.

European institutions have been quick to express concern about the detention of the three Kurdish mayors from the towns of Siirt, Bingol and Diyarbakir, who were also members of Hadep.

Under emergency regulations, they were detained at the weekend and questioned for four days without legal representation before being formally arrested yesterday.

Diplomats in Ankara were particularly concerned about the way in which the three men were detained; the mayor of Diyarbakir, Feridun Celik, was taken from his car in the middle of the street shortly after he attended several days of meetings with western officials to discuss Kurdish political issues.

The Council of Europe has already criticised Turkey for "imprisoning elected leaders", whom it believes were campaigning for peaceful reform.

Meanwhile, a delegation from the European Union visited the Turkish foreign ministry yesterday to request further details of the charges against Hadep's members. Turkish prosecutors, however, say that they have evidence that the mayors were taking their instructions from the PKK, and supplying the rebel group with money.

Ankara has criticised European politicians for siding with Hadep, and for meeting human rights groups during official visits to Turkey. "[EU countries] have a plan to put us under greater pressure than before," the prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, said this week. "But we will not play that game."

The fear now is that the crackdown on Hadep could mark the end - at least temporarily - of the most peaceful period the south-east has experienced for a long time. After 15 years of conflict between the security forces and the PKK, a rebel ceasefire has been holding.

"It's very tense at the moment," said one Diyarbakir resident yesterday. "People are worried about what might happen next."

Hadep won significant popular support in the south-east in the last elections, but officials in Ankara have consistently refused to treat its party leaders as representatives of wider Kurdish political issues. The government believes that Hadep is a front for the PKK, and that time will prove its caution justified.

"Do we want to treat the PKK like the IRA, and Hadep like Sinn Fein in Northern Ireland?" wrote a columnist, Mehmet Ali Kislali, in the Radikal newspaper. "If that's what anyone expects, they are living in a fantasy world."

Turkey's relations with the EU are bound to be negatively affected by the events of the last few days.

Before Ankara can enter into formal negotiations with the EU, it has to satisfy what are known as the "Copenhagen criteria", which, among other things require the candidates to "achieve stability of institutions guaranteeing democracy, the rule of law, human rights and respect for and protection of minorities".

No one ever believed that Turkey's progress towards membership would be easy, but the first big bump in the road seems to have come much sooner than expected.

fields.headline: Vote-rigging scandal mars Iranian poll
fields.standfirst: More about Iran
fields.trailText: Vote-rigging in 100 Tehran polling stations is suspected to have occurred in last week's parliamentary election to ensure a seat for former president Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, election officials from the interior ministry confirmed yesterday.
fields.body:
Vote-rigging in 100 Tehran polling stations is suspected to have occurred in last week's parliamentary election to ensure a seat for former president Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, election officials from the interior ministry confirmed yesterday.

Final results were scheduled to be released yesterday at 12pm local time but were delayed because of fears that votes had been faked in Mr Rafsanjani's favour, officials said. Preliminary results had shown the former president squeaking by in 29th place out of 30 seats from Tehran. But if vote-rigging indeed occurred, Mr Rafsanjani could be forced into a run-off election in April, a race he would probably lose.

At one polling station at the Teleqani mosque, sources said, 1,500 out of 1,800 votes were tallied for Mr Rafsanjani. In fact he received only 150 votes.

"Some ballot boxes are being recounted. Protests have been made against alleged vote-rigging, especially in the south of Tehran," one interior ministry official said. "The interior ministry is following up the case. God willing, final results will be released by tomorrow [Friday] night."

Ballots at another 100 polling stations out of a total of 3,111 have yet to be counted.

The parliamentary polls held on February 18 were celebrated as Iran's fairest to date. Yesterday's news will cast a pall on a contest that the outside world heralded as a great exercise in democracy.

Nearly all sides in Iran's political battle have an interest in Mr Rafsanjani winning a seat. Reformers aligned with the moderate President Mohammad Khatami admitted privately that they wished he had stayed out of the contest. But once he entered the race, he became a necessary evil, they said.

His defeat would cause extensive hostility from his conservative backers whom the reformers need to accommodate if they plan to push their policies through the new parliament. Although reformers won a solid victory, they still need the support of a variety of more conservative factions to pass legislation for social and political change.

Thus, in the convoluted world of Iranian politics, both conservatives and reformers have a keen interest in Mr Rafsanjani winning a spot in the 290-seat parliament.

In the weeks running up to the election, Mr Rafsanjani suffered merciless attacks from reformers who accused him of numerous crimes, including turning a blind eye to rogue intelligence agents who killed intellectuals while he was president. Seminars were scheduled solely for the purpose of condemning his legacy in post-revolutionary Iran.

His daughter, Faezeh, who also ran in the election, suffered a more serious blow for her public defence of her father. Preliminary results showed her placing in the low 50s. Four years ago, she came second.

Election officials have vowed to get to the bottom of the allegations. "The officials in the interior ministry in coordination with Mr Khatami's policies will not allow even one vote to be manipulated," said Mohammad Qadimi-Zaker, the ministry's director general of elections.

fields.headline: Your CD's in the fridge
fields.trailText: The titles of the tracks are not exactly in the David Bowie class. One is called A Shirt Ironed Hastily; another, Finally, the Freezer is Full Again.
fields.body:
The titles of the tracks are not exactly in the David Bowie class. One is called A Shirt Ironed Hastily; another, Finally, the Freezer is Full Again.

Neverthless, the producers of Nie Mehr Allein (Alone No More) are hoping that their new CD can win a place in the hearts and collections of a lucrative section of the record-buying public. It is the ultimate in singleton listening: more than an hour of background noise simulating the presence of a non-existent partner.

"It has the advantage over a real partner that, if you are bothered, you can switch it off. This is difficult to do with real partners," said Bernd Klosterfelde, whose inspiration it was.

The album is due to reach the shelves of record stores in Germany next week. Mr Klosterfelde, who works for a Hamburg publishing house, said negotiations were in progress with distributors in other countries, including Britain.

The German version, promising "62 minutes of togetherness", comes in a case bearing the vacuously smiling face of a shop window mannequin.

"You feel cared for. But you don't feel disturbed at all," says one advert. "Alone No More sweetens the solitude and lightens the loneliness."

Mr Klosterfelde, a 56-year-old divorcee, got the idea three years ago shortly after he began to live by himself. "I was speaking on the telephone to a friend on a Sunday morning which is when you tend to think most about being alone."

It was not until last December, however, that he got around to turning his idea into a CD. The recording was simplicity itself.

"A young colleague of mine followed his girlfriend through the flat with a microphone," Mr Klosterfelde said.

An initial run of 3,000 copies was produced for marketing exclusively on the internet. A spokesman for the distributors said returns showed that the highest sales so far had been in Switzerland.

"Maybe it's because of the mountains," Mr Klosterfelde ventured.

The webpage advertising Alone No More could serve as a manifesto for Singleton Pride.

"Only the single tree in an open field is a desirable subject for a photograph," it enthuses. "If the same tree were to stand in the middle of a forest no one would notice it."

The distributor's spokesman said the response had been promising, with 300 copies sold since the CD went on sale in January. "We are pretty confident we will sell out," he added.

Mr Klosterfelde said a deal had been signed to make Alone No More available through conventional outlets in much bigger numbers. "Hopefully, tens of thousands."

fields.bodyText: The titles of the tracks are not exactly in the David Bowie class. One is called A Shirt Ironed Hastily; another, Finally, the Freezer is Full Again. Neverthless, the producers of Nie Mehr Allein (Alone No More) are hoping that their new CD can win a place in the hearts and collections of a lucrative section of the record-buying public. It is the ultimate in singleton listening: more than an hour of background noise simulating the presence of a non-existent partner. "It has the advantage over a real partner that, if you are bothered, you can switch it off. This is difficult to do with real partners," said Bernd Klosterfelde, whose inspiration it was. The album is due to reach the shelves of record stores in Germany next week. Mr Klosterfelde, who works for a Hamburg publishing house, said negotiations were in progress with distributors in other countries, including Britain. The German version, promising "62 minutes of togetherness", comes in a case bearing the vacuously smiling face of a shop window mannequin. "You feel cared for. But you don't feel disturbed at all," says one advert. "Alone No More sweetens the solitude and lightens the loneliness." Mr Klosterfelde, a 56-year-old divorcee, got the idea three years ago shortly after he began to live by himself. "I was speaking on the telephone to a friend on a Sunday morning which is when you tend to think most about being alone." It was not until last December, however, that he got around to turning his idea into a CD. The recording was simplicity itself. "A young colleague of mine followed his girlfriend through the flat with a microphone," Mr Klosterfelde said. An initial run of 3,000 copies was produced for marketing exclusively on the internet. A spokesman for the distributors said returns showed that the highest sales so far had been in Switzerland. "Maybe it's because of the mountains," Mr Klosterfelde ventured. The webpage advertising Alone No More could serve as a manifesto for Singleton Pride. "Only the single tree in an open field is a desirable subject for a photograph," it enthuses. "If the same tree were to stand in the middle of a forest no one would notice it." The distributor's spokesman said the response had been promising, with 300 copies sold since the CD went on sale in January. "We are pretty confident we will sell out," he added. Mr Klosterfelde said a deal had been signed to make Alone No More available through conventional outlets in much bigger numbers. "Hopefully, tens of thousands." He is confident it can be marketed internationally. "After all, there is very little to translate."

fields.headline: Star quality
fields.standfirst: The Michelin restaurant and hotel guide is 100 this year. Does it still deserve its reputation?
fields.trailText: The Michelin restaurant and hotel guide is 100 this year. Does it still deserve its reputation?
fields.body:
The Guide Michelin France is 100. Some of us think its age has been showing for some time. The hotel and restaurant guide, whose symbol is "Bibendum", the smiling fat man made of tyres, is slow to spot trends.

It can even be argued that its star system - three for "exceptional cuisine, worth a journey", two for "excellent cooking, worth a detour", and one for "a very good restaurant in its category" - has done a lot of harm to restaurants in France. But we would be lost without it (sometimes literally, as the superb city centre maps have helped many a driver to find a hotel bed or dinner).

When the new guide is published on Tuesday, the word is that Bibendum will be playing it safe. It is said to be restoring the three stars lost by the Paris restaurant Le Grand Véfour in 1983. For the past nine years the chef of the historic restaurant at the Palais Royal has been 43-year-old Guy Martin, who was promoted to top rank by the less cautious guides, such as Le Guide Pudlowski, as long ago as 1995.

Anyone who has used Michelin regularly can't help but be sentimental about the thick red book. I remember my first meal in a three-star establishment. It was the early 70s and I was driving to the south of France with my mother. That night we were stopping in Tours, at a small hotel chosen from the guide because it had two towers ("comfortable").

We walked to our dinner at Charles Barrier (now demoted to one star and under new ownership, following M Barrier's six months in prison in 1984, for destroying discarded bills paid in cash and failing to note their amounts in his accounts). Dressed to kill, we were shocked to see that our fellow diners were tie-less and shirt-sleeved. There was worse to come before the warm oysters with endives and the baby pigeon cooked with an infusion of thyme flowers, garlic and preserved cabbage. We didn't know whether to giggle or weep when the terrine de canard was served in its ceramic Donald Duck pot.

Since then I have been led by Michelin to a two-star eatery in Digoin decorated with stalactites and stalagmites; a one-time three-star in Bordeaux that was a huge papier-mché grotto; and a hotel room in Paris with a lurid 60s orange carpet. It's only in the Michelin-rated upper echelons of hotels and restaurants that you are treated to this display of specifically French Bad Taste.

The first restaurant guide was published in 1803; the next year Grimod de la Reynière's Almanach des Gourmands listed 500 restaurants in Paris. (Pretty rapid expansion, considering that the first use of the word "restaurant" was by Boulanger in 1765, and the first real one, Beauvillier's La Grande Taverne de Londres, only opened in 1782.)

In 1900 the Michelin tyre company published its first motorist's guide to hotels and restaurants in France. The company also sponsored a gastronomic column in several newspapers, and for a time this was written, as "Bibendum", by Maurice Edmond Sailland (1872-1956), better known by his nom de fourchette , "Curnonsky". Michelin introduced its star ratings with a single star in 1926, then one to three in the 1931 edition.

"Because of difficulties of provisioning," says Jean-François Mesplède's Trois Étoiles au Michelin, a history of three-star restaurants, "the classification of three stars" vanished with the 1939 edition, only to reappear after the war. The first three-star ratings were given in 1951, with three Paris restaurants (Café de Paris, La Tour d'Argent and Lapérouse) and four provincial ones (La Mère Brazier near Lyons, La Cte d'Or of Alexandre Dumaine at Saulieu, L'Auberge du Père Bise at Talloire and La Pyramide of Fernand Point at Vienne).

Last year there were 21 three-star eateries, as there were in 1981 and 1982 - the heyday of nouvelle cuisine. The new culinary phenomenon had been noticed as early as 1972, by Raymond Sokolov, who reported in the New York Times that a chef called Paul Bocuse was serving a new style of food in his restaurant near Lyons.

The next year, two Paris journalists, Henri Gault and Christian Millau, christened the movement la nouvelle cuisine, and the guide that bore their names (founded in 1969) began to challenge Michelin for supremacy. Poor Fat Mich just didn't get it.

Many of their three-stars, the Troisgros brothers, Barrier, Roger Vergé, Michel Guérard, and another eight chefs, were all practising a lighter sort of cooking with a new emphasis on the visual appearance of the food. Gault-Millau printed their names in red, to distinguish them from the traditional chefs printed in black. Michelin never did find a way to identify the nouvelle cuisine chefs. This wasn't so serious at the three-star level, as the chefs had become celebrities in their own right by the 80s, and punters knew what to expect from them.

But if you took a chance on an unfamiliar two-star-or-less listing in Michelin you could not predict whether you would get what the American food writer Calvin Trillin called heavy-heavy stuff-stuff, or a food picture painted on your plate. As for those shabby places with great food we all treasure, the wordless Michelin symbols just don't have the means to convey such secrets.

Then there was the issue of stars for the amenities of the restaurant. Having three stars had been a licence to print money; suddenly, in the late 90s, for the first time in the history of the guide, two three-stars went bust.

Pierre Gagnaire at St Etienne and Marc Veyrat on Lake Annecy had borrowed and invested too much in their premises and furnishings. The third Michelin star seems always to have been awarded for surroundings and service as well as food, but in the 80s it seemed to many two-star restaurateurs that you could, in effect, buy your third star by investing in marble loos and expensive china. Every cook aspired to be a chef-patron and own an elaborately furnished dining room, plus some (high-profit) bedrooms and, if possible, like Georges Blanc at Vonnas, a heli-pad.

For Blanc, whose mother before him had owned the premises, this was possible but heaven help the chef-patron paying rent - plus rates, and the social wage to the army of chefs and waiters needed to get and keep the third star. The chief reason there are so many good little places to eat in France and so relatively few here is that restaurants there are still usually a family business, the freehold owned and the family living off the business rather than paying themselves wages. It works differently at the top of the foodie chain.

So who cares that the British Michelin is a joke by comparison, more useful for its (scrupulously checked) telephone numbers than its recommendations? There is only one (French) restaurant left in Britain with three stars, Michel Roux's Waterside Inn at Bray.

Those terrors of the dining room, Marco Pierre White and Nico Ladenis, have handed back their three stars. They now have none; while Gordon Ramsay and Raymond Blanc have not achieved their ambitions to gain a third. Never mind that Blanc has been serving three-star nosh for years, and that the best high-end meal I ate last year was at Ramsay's.

Of course, we British eat Indian or Chinese or Thai, given the choice, and Michelin's French-biased inspectors don't know which end of a samosa or a chopstick to hold. We shouldn't take it personally: the Michelin volumes for Germany, Italy and Spain are even worse. But the maps are great. And now that nouvelle cuisine is dead, the Guide Michelin France is again at least reliable. Many happy returns of the day, old man.

fields.headline: Private Lives
fields.standfirst: My mother is in residential care. Should I give away her belongings?
fields.trailText: My mother lived with us until six months ago when she went into a residential home because of dementia. Her rooms are still filled with her belongings. She spent Christmas with us and, although she still recognises my husband and myself, she did not recognise any of her things. I am torn between keeping everything as it is and distributing her things among the family, then using the rooms.
fields.body:
My mother lived with us until six months ago when she went into a residential home because of dementia. Her rooms are still filled with her belongings. She spent Christmas with us and, although she still recognises my husband and myself, she did not recognise any of her things. I am torn between keeping everything as it is and distributing her things among the family, then using the rooms.

I feel guilty even thinking of this while she is alive and I'm not sure what the family's reaction will be if I broach the subject with them. Yet if my mother had retained her faculties, I'm certain she would have said, "Let them have what they want. It's of no use to me."

Have any other readers had to deal with this difficult situation?

Time to move on

We have recently experienced a similar situation. As three sisters, we divided our mother's possessions and her house is now for sale. One keeps hoping the past life might still be possible and it is difficult to admit that this phase in our mother's life is over.

You need to plan for the future. Speak to your family and when all are on board, go ahead and divide up your mother's things. For us, it was a time to remember our mother and our childhoods.

Don't be burdened with guilt. You must make the decisions your mother would have made were she able. When we make decisions for our mother, my sisters and I ask "What would she have done?"

While she still recognises you, visit her often and make things as happy as possible. When she no longer recognises you, still visit often to ensure she is being treated with gentle care and respect. I wish you luck.

Name and address withheld

Follow your heart

You know how your mother felt about things before she became ill. Follow your heart and do what you think she would have said given the chance today.

It's obvious you love your mother very much. You've made sure she's been given the care and attention she needs. It's time for you to start to let go and sorting through her possessions will be your first big step in saying goodbye.

My own mother died last year, quickly and peacefully. I kept a lot of what could be described by others as inconsequential things. Throwing out those half-used tubes of Germolene and the hairbrush that still holds the threads of long, grey hair broke my heart - but slowly I'm managing to do what needs to be done. The most lasting thing my mother left me is her wish that I live a happy life. Given the chance I'm sure your mother would say the same to you.

Fulfil her dream.

Name and address withheld

Overcome the emotion

Unless your mother can give permission for you to dispose of her possessions while being able to understand what she has done, I suggest you have no right to give her things away unless you have power of attorney over her affairs.

Assuming you have either of these, I see no reason why you should not dispose of her possessions in consultation with the rest of the family. Your room is a different matter. If all the advice is that she will never return to your home, you may do what you wish with your own property. You can always box up your mother's possessions if she or the family are against giving them away.

The problem is emotion. You imply you are the person with care. I find that relatives and friends less directly involved with care of the old are more likely to act emotionally rather than practically. It is you who has to solve the matter, not them. If you believe it is right to take back the use of your mother's old room and, subject to the above, dispose of her possessions among the family, do it.

I wish you everything you wish yourself in carrying out this duty of seeing your mother leave this world into which she brought you.

David Bond, Oxon

Don't feel guilty

I, too, faced this difficult situation last year. I had looked after my mother until her Alzheimer's disease made it impossible to continue. Like you, I kept her home intact for several months after she had gone into care until I realised that this could not go on indefinitely. The house has now been sold and, yes, it was a traumatic period.

The first and most important thing is not to feel guilty. You have obviously done everything possible to make your mother comfortable and, most importantly, feel loved. Second, approach other family members; you will be surprised how supportive they will be. Invite them to visit you and your mother, so that they can see that she is well cared for, and to take anything of hers that has sentimental value for them. As you rightly say, your mother would want them to have it. Any household items that are not wanted could be given to charities.

Third, do redecorate and use the rooms and enjoy them: that is what your mother would want for you.

Carol Cosham, Manchester

Next week

My 24-year-old son has been a worry since school. Due to an injury sustained while drunk, plus a period of mental instability and depression, it took him an extra year to complete his university studies but he eventually gained a social sciences degree.

He returned home for a year, living off benefits. He did little around the house and had meals cooked and washing done for him.

Then my son joined a Christian community and, with their support, seemed to become more independent. He found casual work and somewhere to live.

All seemed well until he rang a few weeks ago to say he had flu and wanted to come home. He has not said whether he is coming back permanently, but I do wonder.

I feel that at the first hint of illness he is giving up. We hoped his move away would make him more self-reliant. Now I'm afraid he will go back to square one.

We were enjoying having our home to ourselves again and feel this is now threatened. What do people suggest?

Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. Write to Private Lives, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, fax 0171 239 9935, email privatelives@theguardian.com (please do not send attachments).

fields.headline: The $2.7bn college flop
fields.trailText: 1943 David Lawrence Geffen, born February 21 in Brooklyn, to Abe and Batya Geffen, bra manufacturers.
fields.body:
1943 David Lawrence Geffen, born February 21 in Brooklyn, to Abe and Batya Geffen, bra manufacturers.

1961 Enrols at the University of Texas, Austin, where his brother Mitchell is a student. Discovers his girlfriend's sister is dating Phil Spector, and makes his first showbusiness contact.

1963 Fails to graduate but lands a job at CBS television in Los Angeles. When John F Kennedy's assassination is announced during a show, an audience member applauds; Geffen punches him and is fired. Takes job in the William Morris Agency mailroom, claiming to be Spector's cousin.

1968 Rising to become William Morris's hottest young agent, Geffen takes a job with the Ashley Famous Agency at $1,000 per week.

1970 Founds Asylum Records, signing Joni Mitchell and The Eagles.

1972 Sells Asylum to Warner, to the outrage of many of his artists. Promises to stay on at Asylum, but soon moves into movies at Warner.

1973 Meets Cher at the opening of his Roxy nightclub on Sunset Boulevard. After a whirlwind romance, the two plan to marry, but Cher changes her mind in early 1974.

1975 Hired by Warner Pictures as vice-chairman and "crown prince" to the company's chairman, Ted Ashley.

1976 Fired 11 months later, after a personality clash with Ashley.

1977 Diagnosed with cancer of the bladder.

1980 Founds Geffen Records with Warner, signing Elton John, John Lennon and Guns N' Roses.

1981 Founds Geffen Pictures with Warner. Backs the musical Dreamgirls and, subsequently, Andrew Lloyd Webber's Cats, on Broadway.

1986 Geffen Records has its first big hit album with Peter Gabriel's So.

1990 Sells Geffen Records to MCA for the company's stock, and makes $710m when MCA is sold soon after.

1992 Makes public the fact that he is homosexual; provides financial backing for Bill Clinton's presidential campaign.

1994 Joins with Steven Spielberg and Jeffrey Katzenberg to form Dreamworks. Hits include Saving Private Ryan and American Beauty.

1999 Forbes magazine values Geffen's fortune at $2.7bn.

Geffen and 'friends': the quotes

The teenage Geffen to his brother at their father's funeral:

"You know, Mitch, nobody knows that we're not rich. We could be rich riding in this limousine."

Clint Eastwood when Geffen, then Warner Bros vice chairman, suggested his film, The Outlaw Josey Wales, should be cut by 20 minutes:

Eastwood: "Why don't you study the picture some more and see if you have any more thoughts. When you do, give me a call over at Paramount."

Geffen: "Why over at Paramount?"

Eastwood: "Because that's where I'll be making my next movie."

Advice to Warners executive Paul Weinstein from her analyst :

"No . . . more . . . David . . . Geffen!"

Calvin Klein explaining why Geffen should name his new record label Geffen records:

"You'll get laid more."

Geffen to Jaws, Close Encounters and ET director Steven Spielberg:

"Gee, you've made a few hit movies. How much money do you have?"

Discovers his girlfriend's sister is dating Phil Spector, and makes his first showbusiness contact. 1963 Fails to graduate but lands a job at CBS television in Los Angeles. When John F Kennedy's assassination is announced during a show, an audience member applauds; Geffen punches him and is fired. Takes job in the William Morris Agency mailroom, claiming to be Spector's cousin. 1968 Rising to become William Morris's hottest young agent, Geffen takes a job with the Ashley Famous Agency at $1,000 per week. 1970 Founds Asylum Records, signing Joni Mitchell and The Eagles. 1972 Sells Asylum to Warner, to the outrage of many of his artists. Promises to stay on at Asylum, but soon moves into movies at Warner. 1973 Meets Cher at the opening of his Roxy nightclub on Sunset Boulevard. After a whirlwind romance, the two plan to marry, but Cher changes her mind in early 1974. 1975 Hired by Warner Pictures as vice-chairman and "crown prince" to the company's chairman, Ted Ashley. 1976 Fired 11 months later, after a personality clash with Ashley. 1977 Diagnosed with cancer of the bladder. 1980 Founds Geffen Records with Warner, signing Elton John, John Lennon and Guns N' Roses. 1981 Founds Geffen Pictures with Warner. Backs the musical Dreamgirls and, subsequently, Andrew Lloyd Webber's Cats, on Broadway. 1986 Geffen Records has its first big hit album with Peter Gabriel's So. 1990 Sells Geffen Records to MCA for the company's stock, and makes $710m when MCA is sold soon after. 1992 Makes public the fact that he is homosexual; provides financial backing for Bill Clinton's presidential campaign. 1994 Joins with Steven Spielberg and Jeffrey Katzenberg to form Dreamworks. Hits include Saving Private Ryan and American Beauty. 1999 Forbes magazine values Geffen's fortune at $2.7bn. fields.headline: Barrier methods
fields.standfirst: A woman prisoner is pregnant after having sex with her boyfriend while she was in detention. How could it happen?  Erwin James,   who is serving a life sentence, says you can take away someone's freedom but you can't contain their sexual desire
fields.trailText: A woman prisoner is pregnant after having sex with her boyfriend while she was in detention. How could it happen?  Erwin James,   who is serving a life sentence, says you can take away someone's freedom but you can't contain their sexual desire.
fields.body:
Conjugal visits are unavailable for prisoners in British jails, officially that is. But the revelation last week that, despite separation by a barred gate, a couple locked in the cell area below Swansea Crown Court had managed to enjoy a sexual encounter while the guards were looking elsewhere, showed that you can lock people up, but you can't stop them doing what comes naturally if the opportunity arises.

For most prisoners, however, a monk-like existence is the best that they can hope for as far as sex is concerned. Of course, it takes a strong will and a disciplined mind to understand the demands of the primal urge for any significant length of time. Long hours confined without the succour of human warmth serve only to intensify a sense of carnal deprivation.

The landings of long-term prisons are littered with wan individuals, hollow-eyed through years of unrestrained masturbation. Pathetic maybe - but for those unable to master their instincts there are few options available from which to gain relief from the torment of Priapus. Some are reduced to desperate measures. One man I knew of some years ago found himself in an extremely embarrassing situation, as well as a painful one, after apparently attempting to achieve some pleasure from performing an act upon himself involving four RS20 batteries, taped together in a clump.

The man ended up being rushed to an outside hospital when the tape came apart and two of the batteries were left lodged deep inside his colon. When news of his "accident" reached the wings ruthless jail wags christened him Torchy - and the name stuck for the remainder of his sentence. Likewise "HP" was utilising a sauce bottle in a similar manner when it broke. Heaven knows what the local hospital thought about what was going on in that prison.

The "married quarters" (or, more crudely, Vaseline Alley) is the section of a wing or landing where men who prefer to adopt a gay lifestyle in private tend to congregate. The need for physical intimacy is so great that inhibitions may be sacrificed for the palliative effect of warm skin upon warm skin.

Because not all who locate themselves within this community are necessarily full-time homosexuals. Some are "jail gays" only and often have wives or girlfriends who visit regularly, unaware of their imprisoned partner's complex coping strategy. Visiting-room sex also used to cause major headaches for the authorities. While most couples managed to confide their intimacies to discreet fumblings under tables, others were not so inhibited. I remember once in the visiting room of a maximum security prison a female visitor sat blatantly astride the man she was visiting, chatting and laughing while gently moving her hips backwards and forwards.

Though nothing could be seen beneath the camouflage of her long dress, it did not take a great deal of imagination to work out what was going on. At the end of visiting time prisoners would form an orderly queue at one end of the room and visitors would form another at the other end by the exit. Both groups would remain in the room until everyone had been counted. On this particular occasion the visits ended and the two groups duly waited at either end of the room in silence - all except the amorous couple, who by then had become vigorously animated in their endeavour to achieve satisfaction.

It was a surreal scene, made even more absurd when the action was over and the woman simply climbed off her partner, straightened her dress and walked briskly across the room to join the other visitors. The man stood up, adjusted his denims and then sauntered over to tag on to the end of the prisoners' queue.

"All complete!" shouted the prison officer monitoring the prisoners, to his colleague standing by the visitors. "Thank you, sir!" came the reply.

Once the control room had been informed by walkie-talkie that everyone in the visitoring room had been accounted for, the two groups vacated the premises in the usual way, as if nothing untoward had ever taken place.

That was the old nature of prison visiting rooms, however. Such exhibitions are rare nowadays, what with CCTV and robust floor patrols. But the tensions generated by forced celibacy continue.

Sadly, and perhaps surprisingly in view of the current social climate, the issue of how prisoners are meant to manage their sexual needs while incarcerated and later upon release remains unacknowledged by the authorities.

An associate of mine, recently released after 18 years, was so concerned about the prospect of renewed sexual relations that shortly before his day of liberation he decided to broach the subject with the prison psychologist, a woman.

"What should I expect with regard to my first sexual experience?" he asked sheepishly.

"What do you mean?" replied the psychologist.

"Is there anything I should be aware of that might or, er, . . . might not happen," he said, even more sheepishly. The lady was dismissive in her response, and not a little embarrassed. She quickly ushered my confused acquaintance out of the office. As he told me later: "If I'd wanted to speak about sexual deviancy, we'd probably have been talking all week."

Sexual interaction between human beings is a precious and potent gift. It is God given and as the couple in Swansea demonstrated, steel bars may take away our liberty, but desire cannot be so easily contained.

fields.trailText: The commissioner of the Metropolitan police, Sir John Stevens, has asked us to say that the suggestion on page 7, yesterday, that his working relationship with deputy assistant commissioner John Grieve was "not good" could not be farther from the truth. He says that he and Mr Grieve have been good personal friends for over 20 years and work closely together. We accept that and apologise unreservedly to both of them for suggesting otherwise.
fields.body:
The commissioner of the Metropolitan police, Sir John Stevens, has asked us to say that the suggestion on page 7, yesterday, that his working relationship with deputy assistant commissioner John Grieve was "not good" could not be farther from the truth. He says that he and Mr Grieve have been good personal friends for over 20 years and work closely together. We accept that and apologise unreservedly to both of them for suggesting otherwise.

In a report headed Iran's MPs promise individual privacy, page 16, February 23, we incorrectly attributed remarks about Iran's relations with the US to President Khatami. They were, in fact, made by the president's brother, Mohammad Reza Khatami. The error was introduced in editing the report.

Contrary to what we said in a report on page 13, February 22 - Chancellor unveils plan to speed euro switch - euro notes and coins will not be introduced next January in the eurozone. The date for their introduction is January 2002. The Financial Times has asked us to point out that contrary to the impression given in Notebook, page 27, yesterday, the company has in fact contracted out all technological development work associated with its internet site, FT.com.

In a report, Straw's concession on jury trial change, page 6, February 23, we described Mark Fisher as MP for Stoke-on-Trent. Specifically he is MP for Stoke-on-Trent Central. Joan Walley is the MP for Stoke-on-Trent North and George Stevenson represents Stoke-on-Trent South.
