fields.headline: On message
fields.trailText:
Build up
Dutch bank ABN Amro is planning to spend more than £1bn on building up its e-commerce business. Initiatives will include internet banking for all its Dutch customers, online brokerage in several European countries and a virtual car dealer in Brazil where the bank is a big lender to car buyers. ABN yesterday reported pre-tax profits higher by 46.7% to 4.25bn euros (£2.58bn).
fields.body:
Build up
Dutch bank ABN Amro is planning to spend more than £1bn on building up its e-commerce business. Initiatives will include internet banking for all its Dutch customers, online brokerage in several European countries and a virtual car dealer in Brazil where the bank is a big lender to car buyers. ABN yesterday reported pre-tax profits higher by 46.7% to 4.25bn euros (£2.58bn).

Opinion
A breakup of Microsoft, if the company is found guilty of competition law violation, would be "illogical" the Washington Post quoted a Harvard University law professor as saying while advising the trial judge. Professor Lawrence Lessig, who has twice been asked by US District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson to advise on competition issues in Microsoft cases, said imposing restrictions on the company's business practice would be a sufficient penalty. "I'm sceptical about breakup," Mr Lessig said. "It doesn't seem logical to me, but it does to the government."

webTitle: Boys will always be joys to me

fields.headline: Boys will always be joys to me
fields.standfirst:
They may not do as well as girls at school, but they are charming
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: One of the great questions of the age is: what is the point of men? We are told that boys do worse than girl's at school, have poorer communication skills so are less well equipped for today's employment market and play an increasingly insignificant role in the process of reproduction.
fields.body:
One of the great questions of the age is: what is the point of men? We are told that boys do worse than girl's at school, have poorer communication skills so are less well equipped for today's employment market and play an increasingly insignificant role in the process of reproduction. The suggestion is that they are almost redundant. But this is nonsense. It is obvious that men are the superior sex. They are more clever, more charming, more affectionate and more attractive.

As a child I wasn't prepared to accept what was, in those days, the commonly held view that men were more intelligent than women. But then, as a teenager, I learnt that boys think about sex once every three seconds. I thought about sex myself - particularly in libraries, for some reason. But I had to wait for my reveries to pass before I could attempt to absorb Chadwick's Sanitation Report.

Anyone who could think about sex every three seconds and pass exams must, I realised, be very clever indeed - a fact that was driven home when I arrived at university. For there I discovered something else that clearly indicated that men are brainier than women.

Only female undergraduates took lecture notes. This, it soon became obvious, was something to be despised. It apparently demonstrated that women were plodders who attempted to compensate for their lack of male genius by sucking up to teacher - something which the current generation of secondary school pupils has done nothing to dispel.

If I read once more that school girls read more than boys, study harder and have a better relationship with their teachers, I will begin to despair at us ever achieving sexual equality. Today's girls should do their bit, as I did mine. Determined to demonstrate that not all university girls were sickening goody goodies, I rarely went to lectures at all.

However, sadly, when it came to my final exams I was overcome by what was doubtless a hormone-fuelled terror of getting a third class degree. Only men were considered exciting and sparkling enough to do either extremely well, or extremely badly.

I asked groups of friends if I could photocopy their notes and a boy agreed. It turned out that he had, for the past three years, simply pretended not to be doing much work. This, was, of course, part and parcel of his charm. An art at which men excel. The recent scientific survey that purported to prove that women are more charming than men, in fact proved the opposite. For the charm that can be illustrated in graphs and pie charts after a few interviews isn't charming at all.

Real charm is both a tool of ambition and a mask to disguise its face. Once spotted it is perceived as a threat and becomes useless.

My charming friend was as generous with his notes as he was silent on the subject of his exam results. He may have got a starred first or a pass degree. One didn't like to ask, but I note that he seems to have done extremely well since.

These days I have the academic careers of three sons to think about. I read their school reports with pride and, I admit, intermittent panic, as is to be expected from a mere mother.

But they are a reminder, too, that affection is a very male attribute. Little girls are quite self-contained when compared to little boys, who demand a lot of hugs, particularly after fisticuffs. When they grow up, it is much the same story. Happily sons stay with their mothers for longer than daughters do, so mine may remain with me for some time. But one day they will doubtless move in with a partner.

I am aware of the well worn phrase: "All men are bastards". But it simply isn't true. They only leave a woman if another woman is taking them in. Women, on the other hand, just go off to find a new life, as often as not, taking their children with them far away. What kind of bastard does that? Not a very attractive one, that is for sure.

But then, I don't think women are very attractive. At best they are horribly smooth-faced, at worst they have breasts.

It is amazes that lipstick lesbianism has become as fashionable as it has. Besides a woman's -one can only say "feminine" - appearance, women can do absolutely nothing to you that a man can't do. What is the point? Male homosexuality - now that I can understand. A woman would be almost useless to a gay man.

Gay or straight, chaps come first.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: After a bright start, shares in London were quickly thrown into reverse as traders began to mutter about a big correction on Wall Street.
fields.body:
After a bright start, shares in London were quickly thrown into reverse as traders began to mutter about a big correction on Wall Street.

Nerves were stretched throughout the afternoon, although it was not until after the London market had closed that the Dow Jones industrial average moved decisively below 10,000, before bouncing once again.

The FTSE 100 index ended the session 57.4 points lower at 6,086.7 as just over 2bn shares changed hands.

A slew of results from big corporations failed to please. AstraZeneca was typical, with a fall from £21.41 to £19.26, while Reed International fell from 605p to 548p after an initial move higher.

Apple Computers sold another small slice of ARM Holdings, reducing its holding by a little under 1% to 4.95%. But that did not bother the market, which marked ARM's shares up from £41.33 to £43.14.

A reversal in the fortunes of BT, which has made strong progress over recent trading sessions, wiped almost 20 points off the main index. The shares closed 66p lower at £10.99.

United News & Media climbed 29p to 888p ahead of this morning's results announcement. The company is expected to give positive news about its internet divisions and update shareholders on plans to merge with Carlton Communications.

Shares in dairy group Unigate closed the session 33p higher at 290p after moving above 300p at one stage, following reports that venture capital group Candover Investments was preparing a bid and using Schroders to advance it. The company put out a statement denying it was in takeover talks, but dealers still seemed to believe that something was going on.

A sell-off on the American Nasdaq market did not really effect technology-related issues over here.

After well-received figures on Wednesday, for example, Logica jumped a further 369p to £27.86 as American investment bank JP Morgan issued a favourable recommendation on the stock.

Lower down the corporate ladder, Zotefoams jumped 46p to 135p after the foam maker said it was negotiating a major "strategic alliance" with an unnamed third party. Further details are expected with its full-year figures due out next week.

Mediakey, which was trading below 5p last autumn before it was transformed into an internet stock, jumped 3p to 14p. The company said that it had signed a contract supply deal with Icollector, the internet-based auction company backed by Bernard Arnauld.

Shares in dairy group Unigate closed the session 33p higher at 290p after moving above 300p at one stage, following reports that venture capital group Candover Investments was preparing a bid and using Schroders to advance it. The company put out a statement denying it was in takeover talks, but dealers still seemed to believe that something was going on. A sell-off on the American Nasdaq market did not really effect technology-related issues over here. After well-received figures on Wednesday, for example, Logica jumped a further 369p to £27.86 as American investment bank JP Morgan issued a favourable recommendation on the stock. Lower down the corporate ladder, Zotefoams jumped 46p to 135p after the foam maker said it was negotiating a major "strategic alliance" with an unnamed third party. Further details are expected with its full-year figures due out next week. Mediakey, which was trading below 5p last autumn before it was transformed into an internet stock, jumped 3p to 14p. The company said that it had signed a contract supply deal with Icollector, the internet-based auction company backed by Bernard Arnauld.

fields.headline: Techmark 100
fields.trailText: In early November the launch of the FTSE Techmark 100 index was given full flippant treatment in these pages. This was nothing but a public relations exercise by the stock exchange - stung by suggestions that it had somehow failed to match the go-go growth markets of mainland Europe such as Le Nouveau Marché in France and the Neuer Markt.
fields.body:
In early November the launch of the FTSE Techmark 100 index was given full flippant treatment in these pages. This was nothing but a public relations exercise by the stock exchange - stung by suggestions that it had somehow failed to match the go-go growth markets of mainland Europe such as Le Nouveau Marché in France and the Neuer Markt.

The exchange was simply creating a new sector - went the argument at the time - without addressing the deeper problems associated with funding young companies.

Well, a short four months on, the Techmark is proving a successful piece of marketing. Every company with the vaguest "new economy" credentials wants to be a member, and yesterday for the first time the Techmark index ran above the 5,000 level - closing 92.49 points higher at 5090.13, to be exact. Since the launch of the index the Techmark has jumped 110%, and if the figures were run back to January 1998 on a pro forma basis, the gain would be a staggering fivefold.

Certainly the index is packed with star performers. There is Anite, the software firm - up from 69p to 290p since November 4.

There is Atlantic Telecom, the radio telephony group, which has jumped from 400p at the beginning of November to £11.32p. Drugs hopeful Axis-Shield has risen from 415p to 995p.

Ireland's wonder stock, Baltimore Technology, has risen from £22.50 at Techmark's launch to £113.50 yesterday. Among the resurgent biotechnology companies, Cambridge Antibody has surged from 220p to £16.65... in fact, the list simply goes on and on.

fields.headline: Diageo struggles to win admirers
fields.trailText: Murmurs of discontent about Diageo became significantly louder yesterday, following disappointing results from the world's largest drinks company.
fields.body:
Murmurs of discontent about Diageo became significantly louder yesterday, following disappointing results from the world's largest drinks company.

Excluding exceptional items, the group's operating profits rose only 4.7% to £1.15bn. In response, its shares fell 10% in the morning before recovering slightly to close down 28p at 500p.

Since its creation two years ago through a merger of Guinness and Grand Metropolitan, the company has struggled to win admirers in the City.

When the deal was announced, its stock rose to more than 750p. Since then, the company's market value has fallen by £7bn.

In the past, concerns surrounded its long tail of minor drinks brands. The group was devoting too much time to bourbon whiskies, Italian wines and obscure spirits.

However, a clear-out over the past 12 months has seen the sale of most of these, to concentrate on nine "global priority brands", including Johnnie Walker, Smirnoff and Baileys. These are performing well, with volume growth of 9% in the first half, including a 32% surge in sales of Baileys in Britain.

Attention has now turned to problems at Pillsbury - Diageo's US-based packaged food operation.

Pillsbury contributed flat profits of £271m, with sales up just 4% despite a 15% increase in marketing spending. Among the poorer performers were Green Giant frozen meals, El Paso sauces and bakery goods.

Analyst Philip Hawkins of Merrill Lynch said: "There's an element of disappointment about the performance of Pillsbury. There is concern about the long-term future of the business."

Burger King is also under the spotlight - the launch of its widely hyped new fries last year produced only modest benefit. Global like-for-like sales rose 0.4%, and profits edged up 5% to £104m.

Diageo's chief executive John McGrath played down suggestions that the food operations should be demerged. He pointed out that a sale of either Burger King or Pillsbury would mean a capital gains tax bill of up to $1bn. His preferred option is to pool resources with other food companies through joint ventures - such as a deal last year between Diageo's Haagen-Dazs ice cream and Nestlé.

However, analysts suggest that a separation of the foods business could be the only way to inject momentum into Diageo's shares.

Leaving aside the food operations, there is still a perception in Britain that spirits are a mature market - most popular among the older generation. There are concerns that once the group finishes making the £290m of cost cuts promised in its merger, it will struggle to push profits forward.

webTitle: OFT chief fails to win a second term

fields.headline: OFT chief fails to win a second term
fields.trailText: The government is not renewing its contract with John Bridgeman, the director general of the office of fair trading, when his initial five-year term heading the consumer body comes to an end in October.
fields.body:
The government is not renewing its contract with John Bridgeman, the director general of the office of fair trading, when his initial five-year term heading the consumer body comes to an end in October.

Mr Bridgeman admitted yesterday that he would move on - and indicated that his approach had not always been appreciated by a government determined to demonstrate its credentials as a tub-thumping consumer champion.

Next week the OFT is to be given sweeping new powers under the competition act, which will allow it to mount dawn raids and fine firms found to be operating cartels at up to 10% of their turnover.

"The government has created a powerful new role for the director general of fair trading, and I have known for some time that it would want to make its own appointment to the post when my term ends," said Mr Bridgeman.

Separately - and in what is sure to be interpreted as a biting aside at the Labour party's priorities - he said: "Perhaps if there is a criticism [of my tenure at the OFT] it is that I have spent most of this office's resources on the issues of the less well-off." The OFT has a budget of £24m and employs about 430 staff.

The frontrunners to take over the £150,000 a year job are City lawyer and Labour party veteran Denise Kingsmill and Don Cruickshank, a treasury favourite who headed the telecoms watchdog Oftel before leading the government's millennium bug taskforce.

Mr Cruickshank is at present investigating the levels of competition among the banks - a job he was handpicked for by the chancellor, Gordon Brown.

There is speculation that moves are under way to replace Mr Bridgeman before his contract ends in October, but yesterday the OFT insisted that was "totally wrong", and Mr Bridgeman made it clear that he wants to see out his term. "I have a lot to do in the next few months", he said, "including major reviews of e-commerce and the brewing industry and a consumer report on the car servicing sector".

Mr Bridgeman has undoubtedly clashed with some ministers. When the chancellor requested an inquiry into petrol prices, the OFT pointed out that most of the pricing issue on British forecourts was due to the levels of tax imposed.

The chancellor's decision to call in Mr Cruickshank to look at banking was interpreted as a deliberate snub. Similarly, Mr Bridgeman had made a pitch for the OFT to regulate the mortgage business, but that job was handed to the City watchdog, the financial services authority.

He mounted a long and ultimately fruitless investigation into computer prices and lost an expensive legal action against the premier league in the restrictive practices court.

But the OFT stresses its credentials in its investigations into car prices and supermarkets. It sent both to the competition commission for further inquiries.

Mr Bridgeman, 55, said he was "looking forward to new challenges". Prior to joining the OFT he spent six years at the monopolies and mergers commission, before which he worked for British Alcan.

webTitle: LSE sets up market for Barclays iShare

fields.headline: LSE sets up market for Barclays iShare
fields.trailText: The London stock exchange is to create a new market to allow Barclays Global Investors to sell iShares, its new investment products.
fields.body:
The London stock exchange is to create a new market to allow Barclays Global Investors to sell iShares, its new investment products.

BGI, the fund management arm of Barclays which yesterday confirmed the creation of the new fund-cum-share, will be the first company to list products on the exchange's new Extramark once it has gained regulatory approval.

Aimed at professional and private investors, iShares will be BGI's version of exchange-traded funds, which are a cross between shares and unit and investment trusts and already active in the United States and Canada, where more than $35bn is invested in similar investment products.

"iShares essentially try to combine the benefit of shares with the benefits of funds.

"They are simple from the perspective of the user," said John Demaine, director of iShares at BGI.

BGI, one of the world's biggest index-tracking fund managers, will offer a number of iShares to track a range of stock market indices.

As their name suggests, the iShares will trade like ordinary shares during normal exchange hours but give investors' exposure to more than one company.

Private investors should be able to trade them through their internet broker, although Mr Demaine admitted iShares are more likely to interest pro fessional investors at first. The stock exchange aims to attract other companies to Extramark, which it describes as an "attribute" market designed to provide innovative new products. It is its second such market after the introduction of Techmark last year for technology stocks.

"Tracking an index helps to spread risk and exposes investors to a wider variety of companies, but can be difficult and expensive for most private investors to do on their own."

webTitle: A trade war likely to end in jaw-jaw

fields.headline: A trade war likely to end in jaw-jaw
fields.standfirst: Revenge is sweet but short-lived
fields.trailText: Revenge, according to the proverb, is a dish best served cold - and following its defeat at the hands of the Americans in the trade war over bananas, the European Union has waited a long time to get its own back. Now it has.
fields.body:
Revenge, according to the proverb, is a dish best served cold - and following its defeat at the hands of the Americans in the trade war over bananas, the European Union has waited a long time to get its own back. Now it has.

What has happened is that the former EU trade commissioner, Leon Brittan, complained to the World Trade Organisation about the whopping export subsidies amounting to $2.2bn a year handed out by Washington to enormous American corporations including Boeing, Exxon, Ford, Microsoft and Monsanto.

The money encouraged American companies to set up offshore tax havens to qualify for exemptions on foreign earnings, but Brussels said they amounted to a prohibited export subsidy because they were based on export performance.

A WTO disputes panel agreed with the EU in a preliminary ruling in October and has now rejected an appeal from the United States.

Corporate America is not happy with the decision, but the Clinton administration has been given until October to comply. With a presidential election less than nine months away and protectionist sentiment ever more evident on Capitol Hill, all the ingredients seem to be in place for a full-scale trade war.

On balance, however, the chances are that this will not happen. Following the failure to launch a new round of trade talks in Seattle last December, both Washington and Brussels are keen to lower the temperature in the hope that serious talks on trade liberalisation can resume sooner rather than later.

As one trade diplomat remarked yesterday: "This is not the time to be at each other's throats."

The EU has no real desire to impose retaliatory sanctions on the US - partly because the new trade commissoner, Pascal Lamy, favours a less confrontational approach and partly because it has no great desire to have to its own regime of tax breaks closely scrutinised by hotshot Washington trade lawyers. Instead, it will probably be happy to see the Americans make minor adjustments to their tax system which would make it compliant with WTO rules.

That, of course, does not detract from the importance of the ruling. Indeed, the much maligned WTO deserves credit for striking a blow against corporate welfare by coming down against the shell companies set up by American big business in Barbados, Guam and the Virgin Islands.

But American protests against the decision have been muted and Roderick Abbott, the EU's trade representative to the WTO, wants to sit down with the Americans to discuss ways in which the US can be brought into compliance with the ruling. That does not sound like the start of hostilities, and this dispute will end in jaw-jaw rather than war-war.

Calling the shots

The negotiations are still some way from completion but EADS - the French, German and Spanish combine of Aerospatiale, DaimlerChrysler Aerospace and Casa -is sounding increasingly confident that the deal to turn Airbus into a conventional company rather than a partnership will be done on its terms.

BAE Systems - the old British Aerospace plus the Marconi defence business - is still sticking out for a bigger stake than the 20% on offer from the other side. But EADS is digging in its heels on the issue, offering cash not shares if a valuation of the assets BAE is injecting into the new corporate Airbus entitles it to a higher figure.

More to the point EADS executives are beginning to refer to Airbus as an EADS division rather than the standalone company BAE envisages, providing a clear signal about who it expects to call the shots in future.

In the short run, once negotiations are completed, EADS will not want to do anything which could damage the chances of Airbus being given British government launch aid for the company's planned A3XX super-jumbo.

But BAE needs to look very hard at its Airbus stake. A 20% shareholder would usually be someone with a very powerful voice in a company's affairs. But not when the only other shareholder has 80%.

There must be a real risk that BAE could end up as a bit-part player in a very important business. Airbus is, after all, around 40% of EADS turnover and slightly more than 20% of BAE's.

Certainly the 80-20 split in a company in which the two shareholders have differing views about Airbus' status appears potentially unstable in a fast changing industry.

BAE could consider folding itself into EADS, which is probably what mainland Europe would like. Or it could put more weight on its transatlantic links - something EADS chiefs would presumably find less palatable.

fields.headline: UB bidders moot joining forces
fields.trailText: US and French-backed groups battling to take over United Biscuits were yesterday in talks about joining forces.
fields.body:
US and French-backed groups battling to take over United Biscuits were yesterday in talks about joining forces.

The two bidders - Finalrealm, comprising Danone, Cinven and offshoots of Paribas and Deutsche Bank and Burlington - Texas-based financiers Hicks Muse Tate and Furst in combination with US food company Nabisco - have been waging rival battles for control of the group. But they now have until next Tuesday - the takeover panel's deadline for final bids - to come up with a plan to share out the UB spoils.

Burlington offered 254p a share for Edinburgh-based UB, valuing it at £1.2bn and announced it has won acceptance from more than 35% of UB's shareholders. Finalrealm offered 265p a share, but only managed to pick up a tiny percentage of shares.

There has been mounting speculation in the past couple of weeks whether Burlington would raise its offer to secure a victory or walk away from the contest allowing Hicks Muse to bank a big profit from selling its stake to Finalrealm.

Yesterday a spokeswoman for Burlington refused to comment on the negotiations but a source close to the talks between the two bidders said "they could still go either way".

They are also believed to be considering the possibility of a higher offer if a deal cannot be agreed. It is understood that Finalrealm approached Burlington about a joint bid as it grew concerned that the US group was ready to trump its 265p offer, which has been accepted by the UB board.

They are thought to be looking at a joint offer of 265p, which would disappoint investors. If Burlington are unable to negotiate a deal it is thought they will raise their offer to 270p. Nabisco is understood to be ready to finance the bulk of any offer as buying the UB portfolio would put the US group ahead of Danone in European market share.

fields.headline: AstraZeneca punished for vulnerability
fields.trailText: AstraZeneca's shares plunged to a 15-month low yesterday as the drugs company failed to convince the City that it had enough in its pipeline to replace blockbuster ulcer treatment Losec.
fields.body:
AstraZeneca's shares plunged to a 15-month low yesterday as the drugs company failed to convince the City that it had enough in its pipeline to replace blockbuster ulcer treatment Losec.

Announcing a 12% rise in annual profits to £3.9bn, chief executive Tom McKillop said: "I'm confident our position is strong. We believe we have a future rich in opportunity."

However, analysts said the group's new products were performing poorly, leaving it vulnerable when Losec loses patent protection in 2001. The shares slumped 215p to £19.26.

Losec - the world's top selling prescription drug - contributes more than a third of AstraZeneca's total revenue. Its sales rose 24% to £5.9bn.

One analyst said: "Losec is driving growth very nicely at the moment. But the bigger it gets the further the company will fall in a year or two."

Mr McKillop sounded a bullish note on Nexium, the group's improved version of Losec, which will be launched later this year.

"This is going to be a mega-brand," the chief executive said. "We've got no doubt Nexium will do very well. Any company would be delighted to have a product with significant improvements over the world's number one selling medicine."

However, there was disappointment that AstraZeneca announced no new clinical data on the drug yesterday.

Mr McKillop said: "Are we feeling a bit bruised by the stock market? No. The market is the market - we just get on with it."

He insisted he was unconcerned by the proposed mergers between rival drugs groups Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham, and Pfizer and Warner Lambert.

"We believe we are large enough," he said. "I'm not out there seeking mergers."

Announcing a 12% rise in annual profits to £3.9bn, chief executive Tom McKillop said: "I'm confident our position is strong. We believe we have a future rich in opportunity." However, analysts said the group's new products were performing poorly, leaving it vulnerable when Losec loses patent protection in 2001. The shares slumped 215p to £19.26. Losec - the world's top selling prescription drug - contributes more than a third of AstraZeneca's total revenue. Its sales rose 24% to £5.9bn. One analyst said: "Losec is driving growth very nicely at the moment. But the bigger it gets the further the company will fall in a year or two." Mr McKillop sounded a bullish note on Nexium, the group's improved version of Losec, which will be launched later this year. "This is going to be a mega-brand," the chief executive said. "We've got no doubt Nexium will do very well. Any company would be delighted to have a product with significant improvements over the world's number one selling medicine." However, there was disappointment that AstraZeneca announced no new clinical data on the drug yesterday. Mr McKillop said: "Are we feeling a bit bruised by the stock market? No. The market is the market - we just get on with it." He insisted he was unconcerned by the proposed mergers between rival drugs groups Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham, and Pfizer and Warner Lambert. "We believe we are large enough," he said. "I'm not out there seeking mergers."

fields.headline: Centrica drives into telecoms
fields.standfirst: £417m profit to back challenge for a million BT customers
fields.trailText: Centrica, more commonly known as British Gas, yesterday announced ambitious plans to pitch its tent firmly in the new economy by capturing 1m telecoms customers by the end of next year.
fields.body:
Centrica, more commonly known as British Gas, yesterday announced ambitious plans to pitch its tent firmly in the new economy by capturing 1m telecoms customers by the end of next year.

The group, reporting a thumping rise in pre-tax profits from £252m to £417m last year, also rebooted its Goldfish credit card business as a provider of online financial services.

Last year Centrica paid £780m net of cash for the AA and is now negotiating with multimedia operators and content providers to relaunch the motoring organisation's directory of guides and maps as an in-car online service.

But the drive into telecoms, offering fixed, mobile and internet services to the group's 18m domestic customers in a direct challenge to BT, initially sparked market enthusiasm, with the shares up 3% before ending just 1p up at 182p.

"E-commerce is not something we're talking about but actually getting on with and doing," said Roy Gardner, chief executive, who is to spend £150m in the next two years on launching the service - under the British Gas name.

The new business, to be headed by ex-Marconi executive Saul Lanyado, will link up with several operators and will by the end of this year employ 450 staff at a call centre - "somewhere in the UK".

Mr Gardner said he expects the business to be profitable by 2003. "It will be extremely competitive with some extra, unique functions and benefits," he said. But, unlike its fel low demerger partner, BG, Centrica has no plans to lay its own cables.

He said the group was well-advanced towards achieving its vision of being the leading supplier of products and services in and around the home and is even talking of providing a domestic boiler "that rings the service centre when it is feeling unwell".

The Goldfish operation, to be augmented by a dot.com business, has 1m customers and, according to Mark Clare, finance director, is worth £400m on a conventional valuation.

Mr Gardner said the idea of offering - like Egg, the Prudential's online bank to be partially floated this year - a current account was "pretty interesting". It is clear an eventual float has been pencilled in.

AA membership, Mr Gard ner said, rose to an all-time high of 9.7m and the motoring body's financial operations have been folded into Centrica's, making an operating profit of £11m.

More than 1,000 jobs in the AA have gone since Centrica bought it, with more likely to be shed. It now claims to be the UK's largest home and motor insurance intermediary with 1.6m policies.

Mr Clare said the aim was to push non-energy sales to 40% of turnover within 10 years but British Gas lays claim to 14.8m gas customers and 2.8m electricity customers - netting 35,000 new contracts a week.

The group, which aims to be the biggest electricity supplier, with 4m contracts by the end of the year, said lower prices and increased output from its own gas fields helped boost profits to £461m from £248m in 1998.

The only blot on the horizon is global warming which knocked an estimated £24m off last year's bottom line.

webTitle: Colt reveals extent of European ambitions

fields.headline: Colt reveals extent of European ambitions
fields.trailText: Colt Telecom, the stellar stock market performer, yesterday set out plans to become the pan-European operator for state-of-the-art business communications.
fields.body:
Colt Telecom, the stellar stock market performer, yesterday set out plans to become the pan-European operator for state-of-the-art business communications.

It disclosed an 87% rise in annual turnover last year to £401.6m and said it would be operating in 27 European cities by the end of the year and in 30 to 32 by the end of 2001.

Colt, which has 20 city networks, including more than 2,000km of cable in Germany, said it would have more than 8,000km providing end-to-end connections for businesses.

Chairman Jim Curvey said 1999 had been "a year of extraordinary success" which saw Colt bring to 3,781 the number of connected buildings - a rise of 73% on the year. Shares rose another 6.3% or 207p to close at 3480p as the company revealed pre-tax losses last year of £10.3m.

 Redstone Telecom, the small business communications provider, wants to raise £121m in a rights issue to fund expansion only four months after floating for £20m.

Graham Cove, chief executive, said the Borehamwood-based group would pay £16.5m in cash for Telefficiency, a switchless reseller of telecoms services to 5,500 small and medium-sized enterprises. About £75m will be used to extend Redstone's network in selected metropolitan areas.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Pearl and NPI to axe 1,250
fields.body:
Pearl and NPI to axe 1,250

Up to 1,250 administrative and support jobs will be axed at Pearl and NPI by the end of the year, the life and pensions groups' parent, AMP of Australia, confirmed yesterday. AMP, an Australian former mutual insurer, plans to cut costs in Britain by £80m over the next two years. AMP said the cuts were not related to the A$424m loss for 1999 it reported yesterday. NPI, the former mutual, is the group's latest acquisition. It bought Pearl in 1989, and owns Henderson INvestors, London Life, and a 50% stake in Virgin Direct.

Lex drives RAC on to the net

Lex plans to turn the RAC into a leading motoring services net portal, Andy Harrison, chief executive, said yesterday. The group, which is paying £5m for 30% of online car finder Autohit, wants to turn the RAC into "a comprehensive cradle to grave motoring services brand," says Mr Harrison. Reporting a £9.2m drop in pre-tax profits last year to £64.1m, the RAC raised membership to 6.3m and contributed £10.2m in earnings in six months, compared with the £8.7m for the whole of 1998.

Regulator finds against Link

Don Cruickshank, the treasury's banking investigator, is to criticise the banks for "very high and discriminatory prices for withdrawing cash", according to documents cited by BBC TV's Watchdog. The documents calculate that the real charge of running cash machines is 29p, within the 20p to 40p range uncovered by the Guardian last year. Some banks charge as much as £1.50 to withdraw cash. The allegations come days before the members of Link, which runs the cash machine network, meet to hammer out the best way to charge.

Britannic pulls out of United bid

Insurer Britannic yesterday pulled out of bidding for its rival, United Assurance Group, which has agreed to a takeover by mutual insurer Royal London, for £1.5bn. Britannic and United had been cited as potential partners but yesterday Britannic issued an official statement to the stock exchange that effectively ruled out the possibility of a bid.

S&N creates 300 jobs

Brewery and leisure group Scottish & Newcastle plans to create 300 jobs as it expands its chain of themed restaurant and leisure sites. S&N has already opened up one City Limits operation in Romford, Essex, and is planning to start constructing new sites in Croydon and Milton Keynes, each employing 150 staff.

webTitle: CBI doubts boom and bust is beaten

fields.headline: CBI doubts boom and bust is beaten
fields.trailText: The Confederation of British Industry yesterday urged Gordon Brown to boost investment in next month's Budget as it cast doubts on the chancellor's claims to have eradicated the boom-bust cycle in the British economy.
fields.body:
The Confederation of British Industry yesterday urged Gordon Brown to boost investment in next month's Budget as it cast doubts on the chancellor's claims to have eradicated the boom-bust cycle in the British economy.

Despite reporting a slight strengthening in order books, the CBI warned the chancellor that the strong pound was taking its toll on exporters and would contribute to a signficant widening of the trade gap.

Kate Barker, the chief economist at the employers' organisation, said: "The favourable picture for consumers - with real incomes continuing to rise briskly - is in sharp contrast to the difficulties in the corpo rate sector, where many exporters are still trading on slender margins."

Ms Barker added that the chancellor's boasts about achieving a stable economy would not ring true with parts of industry. "Many manufacturing firms wouldn't see this as stability at all, and frequently say so. It is disturbing to see in our forecasts the imbalances in the economy continuing and this leads to some concern about the long-term prospects for the economy.

The CBI said that consumer spending growth of 3.5% would be the main driving force behind growth of 3.1% this year, but manufacturing investment would follow a 15% fall last year with a further 6% decline in 2000.

webTitle: Blair sets up Co-op review board

fields.headline: Blair sets up Co-op review board
fields.standfirst: Rivalry hurts beleaguered movement
fields.trailText: The threat to the survival of Britain's £8.4bn Co-operative movement posed by the fierce rivalry among supermarket chains has led Tony Blair to back the establishment of a commission to review the movement's future.
fields.body:
The threat to the survival of Britain's £8.4bn Co-operative movement posed by the fierce rivalry among supermarket chains has led Tony Blair to back the establishment of a commission to review the movement's future.

The commission's 12 members, drawn from various co-operatives, unions and the Labour party, have been asked to consider and make recommendations on the movement's ownership structure, control and management.

The diminishing success of Britain's co-operatives - they once commanded a quarter of the country's grocery market - has been blamed on the lack of unification in the movement, with some co-operatives run as local fiefdoms rather than commercial entities.

The prime minister immediately ruled out a private or public sale of the movement which would have been considered under the commission's ownership review.

"The Co-operative movement represents a vital part of UK business," Mr Blair said.

"Not publicly, not privately, but co-operatively owned and controlled by its members to ensure that its commercial and community interests go hand in hand."

The option of the demutualisation of the 47 co-operatives has been ruled out, according to Co-operative insiders.

The commission will be chaired by John Monks, the general secretary of the TUC, at Mr Blair's request. The six-month review, the second in the co-operative's history, will also consider the profitability of the group.

The financial struggles of some co-operatives have become increasingly evident with the proposed merger of the movement's two biggest societies, the Co-operative Wholesale Society and Co-operative Retail Services.

The CRS reported a loss of almost £60m last year and it is expected that the commission could highlight the need for more mergers if the group is to capitalise on its huge asset base - which includes prop erty, retail shops, travel agencies, the Co-op bank and CIS insurance operation, and funeral parlours.

Asked about the need for the review, Mr Monk said: "I think the time is ripe for giving the plcs a run for their money. We want to help the Co-operative in any we can to deal with its existing problems."

He denied that trying to make the Co-operative more competitive with the big supermarkets would be difficult, given its strong association with the union. "I don't think the co-operative is a patsy employer," he said.

The commission's other members include Alan Donnelly, former leader of the European parliamentary Labour party, Mervyn Pedelty, chief executive of the Co-operative Bank and former trade minister Lord Simon of Highbury.

However, the lack of retailing expertise among the commission members surprised industry experts.

Richard Hyman, chairman of retail research firm Verdict, said: "Is this a quasi-government inquiry? Why are there no retailers involved? Why are there only politicians looking to identify commercial opportunities? Because they are not good at that."

Graham Melmoth, chief executive of the CWS, said: "It's about the future and not the past. I think the process of mergers does continue and it's possible the commission will encourage more of this."

He said the commission would look at the areas where the movement could improve its productivity and the possible cross-selling of products to members. Mr Melmoth said he put the idea of a commission to senior Labour party members last summer and in the past few months has held talks with Mr Blair.

Mr Melmoth said the response from briefings to CRS members indicated the vote on Saturday week would be in favour of a merger. "The fact that those members are, as far as we can tell, very persuaded, is very encouraging."

fields.headline: Rochdale roots to predators' target
fields.trailText: The co-operative movement began in the 1800s as the industrial revolution created an impoverished working class concentrated in the north of England and Scotland.
fields.body:
The co-operative movement began in the 1800s as the industrial revolution created an impoverished working class concentrated in the north of England and Scotland. Robert Owen, a mill owner, attempted to establish wholesale trading companies to buy in bulk, sell cheap and split the profits with his workers. Although it failed, his idea found favour in 1844 with the founding of the Rochdale Equitable Pioneers Society.

By the outbreak of the second world war the movement had become Britain's biggest retailing chain. Yet the emergence of supermarket chains has seen the decline of the Co-operative. The survival of the movement was thrown into doubt in 1997 when entrepreneur Andrew Regan nearly launched a bid for CWS, the largest of the co-operatives.

Despite his failure, amid accusations of stolen information, a harsh light was thrown on the antiquated organisation and its laborious decision-making processes.

Mr Regan now lives in Monaco and is fending off attempts by the serious fraud office to extradite him in connection with another of his business deals.

webTitle: Day-trading industry to come under fire

fields.headline: Day-trading industry to come under fire
fields.trailText: The average American day trader needs to make a daily profit of $464 (£290) to break even, according to a damaging report on the fast-growing industry to be published today.
fields.body:
The average American day trader needs to make a daily profit of $464 (£290) to break even, according to a damaging report on the fast-growing industry to be published today.

Other findings in the report, which follow an eight-month inquiry, suggest that day-trading firms are also flouting government rules in order to encourage individuals to spend more than they can afford.

The findings are likely to prompt more calls for tighter regulation in the industry. Some of the problems outlined in the report, such as failing to disclose the risks of day trading, are not illegal.

The report could set off alarm bells in Britain where day trading has taken off and questions remain over how many unsuspecting investors are lured into high-risk share dealing.

Coming at the end of a week in which two day-trading firms were accused of exceeding government margin lending rules, the report is also expected to lead to further investigations of individual companies.

Senator Susan Collins, head of the Senate sub-committee which has been investigating day trading and produced the report, told the Wall Street Journal that regulators had been too slow in responding to obvious abuses in the industry.

"Many day-trading firms entice unsophisticated investors to speculate with money they can ill afford to lose," she said.

The paper reveals that 15 day trading firms earned $66.5m on sales of $541m last year, while few individual traders made any money at all.

Examples of day traders being encouraged to trade, using funds drawn from credit cards or with a family's savings, are cited in the Senate report.

The report adds to pressure on an industry which was rocked last summer when former day trader Mark Barton opened fire in two firms, killing 16 before turning on his family and then himself.

Nose Colds and flu: supplements of zinc and vitamin C plus the herb echinacea; boost the immune system with positive experiences such as laughter and sex.

Despite the successes of the CM irregulars, a counter-revolution is still possible, and it is most likely to come from Europe. Britain is a wild frontier of alternative medicines, and allows higher-dose vitamins and supplements than any other Europeans. The EC has pushed for standardised vitamin levels for years, which would mean a big drop in levels available here. The current arrangement is such a bureaucratic tangle that if you treat patients with herbs in Denmark, you might be labelled a waiter: regulations say you can supply only two classes of edible things - medicine or food - to people: as herbs are not classed a medicine, they must be a food.

This legal fiction, concocted in the 60s, was actually intended to help herbalists. Stringent drug testing, at huge cost, was introduced, so a deal was done. Practitioners were told: if you say you are treating a specific disease with a particular herb, it's a medicine and you'll have to pay; but if you make no specific claims and talk vaguely about 'well-being' and 'health-boosting', we'll pretend you're giving people food and you won't have to get a medical licence.

That was fine 30 years ago, when everyone believed that herbal use would dwindle away and the idea of using nutrition to treat disease was way off the medical dial. Now, it is an obvious anomaly. But there are regular scares that the logic of this division will be rigorously enforced, driving most herbal products underground. Again, the spectres of the big drug firms can be glimpsed in the shadows, muscling in on a growing market.

It is true that herbs can be harmful - some Chinese and Indian herbs have been found to be adulterated, certain Chinese herbs have been linked with liver damage and some herbs can produce allergies - but the scale of the problem, compared with that in pharmaceutical drugs, is tiny: of the 1.8 billion adverse drug reactions listed in a WHO database, 9,000 concern herbal remedies. And while some herbal medicines can interact badly with OM drugs - there are some current concerns about St John's Wort - that is as nothing compared with interactions between different OM drugs

'Herbs have been used for a long time,' declares Dr Peter Houghton, lecturer in pharmacognosy at King's College, London. 'There has been a long process of weeding out the ones that are dangerous. More significantly, herbs produce their effects in humans by using processes also used in the plant. The reason we can get anti-oxidants from plants, for example, is that they also need protection against free radicals.'

Many types of CM treatments can trace their roots back to the Ancient Greeks and beyond. Massage, at the base of more than 30 touch-and-movement therapies, was a favourite in ancient Egypt, while Hippocrates famously said, 'The physician must be experienced in many things but assuredly in rubbing.' The basic holistic principle that crops up in so many CM therapies - strengthening body and mind so you can heal yourself - was also commonplace at the time of Hippocrates, who recommended rest, exercise and plain food in moderation.

In fact, the earliest Indian and Chinese medical systems, originating more than 5,000 years ago, were essentially holistic, and treated different patients differently with massage, diet and herbs, as well as giving advice about relaxation and general behaviour. Just as they do today.

At the end of the 19th century, many of these approaches were rediscovered and adapted by practitioners for a western clientele. The Society of Masseurs was founded in Britain in 1894 after a Swedish gymnast, Per Henrik Ling, made therapeutic massage respectable. Around the same time, Benedict Lust founded the American School of Naturopathy in New York, a system based on diet, exercise and sunlight that had come from the spa towns of Austria and Hungary. Among those it influenced was John Kellogg, of breakfast cereal fame, who ran a clinic at Battle Creek in Michigan. The original aim of his concoction was to reduce sexual desire.

Many of these therapies were variations on massage. In 1895, a Canadian doctor, Daniel Palmer, cured a janitor of the deafness he had suffered for 18 years by manipulating his spine. The treatment he went on to develop became known as chiropractic. Twenty years later, the idea that different zones in the feet corresponded to organs in the body was pioneered by US ear-nose-and-throat specialist Dr William Fitzgerald, and reflexology was born.

About a century earlier, the German doctor Samuel Hahnemann developed homoeopathy, a complementary system that mixed ancient principles with some very idiosyncratic ones. Combining the medieval idea of like curing like (snow was a folk remedy for chilblains, for example) with the notion that the more you dilute a tincture, the more potent it is, it has been under attack from the start. It was one of the first targets of the American Medical Association when it was formed in 1847.

One of the few CM approaches born in this century is clinical ecology, or environmental medicine. Based on the idea that many disorders are caused by environmental factors, such as the relationship between food allergies and exposure to synthetic chemicals, it has no single founder. The term 'allergy' was coined by a Viennese paediatrician in 1906, and in the 20s several US doctors studied delayed or hidden reactions to food.

Most of these systems almost vanished in the golden age of drugs after the last war, but began gradually to re-emerge in the 70s.

fields.headline: Thatcher 'spied on ministers'
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Lady Thatcher used a global surveillance system to spy on two of her cabinet ministers in 1983, a former Canadian intelligence agent was reported as saying last night.
fields.body:
Lady Thatcher used a global surveillance system to spy on two of her cabinet ministers in 1983, a former Canadian intelligence agent was reported as saying last night.

The two unnamed ministers were not suspected of any security breaches but the former prime minister is believed to have thought they disagreed with her on policy matters, according to Mike Frost, a former Candadian agent.

Mr Frost made the allegations to the American news programme 60 Minutes, according to released comments from the programe.

Last night, no comment was available from Lady Thatcher but a spokeswoman for Number 10 said the government would draw the allegations to her attention.

"We will make sure Baroness Thatcher is aware of these allegations so she can judge whether they merit a response."

Mr Frost, who said he worked for Canadian intelligence from 1972-1992, told the programme the five countries involved in the Echelon global surveillance system could get around domestic laws preventing spying by asking another member nation to do it for them.

"The British parliament now have total deniability," he said, referring to the alleged spying on the two ministers, whom he did not identify. "They didn't do anything... We did it for them.

"[Thatcher] had two ministers that she said "weren't 'on side'... so my boss went to London and did intercept traffic from those two ministers," Mr Frost told 60 Minutes, which is due to be broadcast in America on Sunday.

The Echelon system, which is run by the US, Canada, Britain, Australia and New Zealand, is capable of intercepting phone conversations, faxes and e-mail messages around the world for any of the five countries involved in the network.

Mr Frost's allegations come in the same week that a European parliament report said the Echelon surveillance network, a series of listening posts around the world, was used for industrial espionage.

On Wednesday the government denied it used Echelon for industrial spying in Europe. Echelon was designed to eavesdrop on suspected terrorists, drug lords and governments hostile to the five members.Each member state has a "dictionary" of codewords which when they appear a certain number of times or in connection with other words, are monitored. However, this can sometimes lead to ordinary people having their communications monitored, Mr Frost said.

He cited a woman whose name and telephone number went into the network's database as a possible terrorist because she had told a friend on the phone that her son had "bombed" in a school play.

fields.headline: Hoddle's England better, says Simeone
fields.standfirst: Heskey can bring out the Caesar in Shearer
fields.trailText: Diego Simeone could not resist another dig: "This England side is not as good as the one we beat in the 1998 World Cup."
fields.body:
Diego Simeone could not resist another dig: "This England side is not as good as the one we beat in the 1998 World Cup."

Simeone, the co-villain in David Beckham's infamous sending-off in St Etienne, was not alone in the Argentine camp in claiming that Kevin Keegan's England are talking a much better game than they actually played in Wednesday's goalless draw at Wembley.

Even the widely acclaimed power and pace of Emile Heskey did not impress his vastly more experienced Argentinian counterpart. "Nothing special," said Gabriel Batistuta of the 22-year-old heavyweight newcomer.

Keegan might be hailing a new beginning but Simeone believes that not only were Glenn Hoddle's class of France 98 superior but that England are reverting to traditional failings. "We have the greatest respect for the English because of the way they play the game," said the Lazio midfielder. "But technically they are inferior to that [World Cup] side, who really caused us problems and stretched us.

"This side gives the ball away too easily and you can't do that at this level of international football and expect to do well."

Batistuta, Argentina's record scorer, was so inactive as to be virtually a spectator until substituted early in the second half. So he had plenty of opportunity to study Heskey. "He did not do much," he said. "He only got through once on goal for a chance."

Then Batigol offered Keegan some advice. "England might help Heskey out more if they could get the ball to him a lot quicker. Then I think he would do better."

At least Mauricio Pochettino, the defender brought on hastily to subdue the Heskey menace, congratulated his English opponent. "He was so dangerous and it was an impressive full debut for him.

"He is very strong and very quick and he was always a threat. I thought he did well."

webTitle: Heskey can bring out the Caesar in Shearer

fields.headline: Heskey can bring out the Caesar in Shearer
fields.standfirst: Hoddle's England better, says Simeone
fields.trailText: If Emile Heskey has a role to play for England in Euro 2000 it will principally involve extending the international career of Alan Shearer.
fields.body:
Before Emile Heskey roused Wembley by disturbing the equilibrium of Argentina's defenders in Wednesday's scoreless friendly, the last Leicester striker to make an impact for England had announced himself with a goal against the Republic of Ireland in the same stadium on a March evening in 1985.

Gary Lineker started as he meant to go on. Until then his only appearance had been as a substitute against Scotland the previous May, and he was to win three more caps coming off the bench before Bobby Robson gave him a regular place.

Should Heskey play for his country 80 times while scoring 48 goals, Wednesday's performance will really turn out to have been the start of something big. For the moment, however, Kevin Keegan would settle for a reprise in one of his three remaining warm-up matches before Euro 2000, accompanied by an improved end product.

Lineker played alongside Mark Hateley or Kerry Dixon at first and it was not until he linked up with Peter Beardsley that the prolific possibilities of playing two medium-size strikers began to emerge. For now any similarity between the 6ft 2in Heskey and the 5ft 9in Lineker is not so much coincidental as invisible.

Lineker was a born finisher, a natural taker of goals; Heskey is more of a hunter, beating about the bushes and disturbing prey but not yet a gifted marksman. If he has a role to play for England in Euro 2000 it will principally involve extending the international career of Alan Shearer who, like Caesar, has expressed a desire to be surrounded by large men.

Shearer's revived scoring form at Newcastle in regular partnership with Duncan Ferguson has encouraged the hope that he will have a better tournament in Euro 2000 than in the 1998 World Cup. Just so long as he does not meet a defender of Roberto Ayala's quality too often.

Then again, Heskey's speed and aggression did see off the experienced Nestor Sensini 10 minutes before half-time, Marcelo Bielsa, the Argentine coach, deciding that Mauricio Pochettino's extra pace was needed. From an English point of view this alone made Wednesday's exercise worthwhile. By playing so well Heskey has established himself as a firm option for Keegan should Michael Owen or Robbie Fowler not be fit.

In the meantime it would be useful to see how Heskey and Kevin Phillips play together. No sooner did Phillips come on as a substitute than Heskey went off.

Keegan's problem is that realistically he only has the match against Brazil on May 27 to have a look at alternatives before naming his squad of 22 for Euro 2000 straight after the Ukraine friendly four days later. But since the coach reckons he will need five strikers, Heskey and Phillips will probably be selected.

The consistent quality of Dennis Wise's passes has also raised the interesting possibility of Chelsea's ageing enfant terrible becoming the fulcrum of England's midfield, although defensively Wise was only occasionally tested.

Overall England's passing and movement showed distinct improvement, but playing David Beckham in central midfield meant his immaculate service from the flanks was restricted to set pieces, and a system designed to assist him inhibited the forward runs of Paul Scholes. So in one respect England lost more than they gained.

fields.headline: Norman Spinrad's top 10 novels
fields.trailText: A peer of writers such as Harlan Ellison, Michael Moorcock and Samuel R Delany, Spinrad's best known and most controversial novels, 1969's Bug Jack Barron and 1972's The Iron Dream - the latter featuring Adolf Hitler as a pulp SF author - were republished in the UK last year by Toxic Press. The French edition of The Iron Dream earned the author the Prix Apollo in 1974. A new novel, Greenhouse Summer, was published last year, but as a protest at what he sees as publishers' cynical promotion of business over literary value, Spinrad is offering the US rights to his next novel, He Walked Among Us, for $1 to anyone who will "publish it properly".
fields.body:
A peer of writers such as Harlan Ellison, Michael Moorcock and Samuel R Delany, Spinrad's best known and most controversial novels, 1969's Bug Jack Barron and 1972's The Iron Dream - the latter featuring Adolf Hitler as a pulp SF author - were republished in the UK last year by Toxic Press. The French edition of The Iron Dream earned the author the Prix Apollo in 1974. A new novel, Greenhouse Summer, was published last year, but as a protest at what he sees as publishers' cynical promotion of business over literary value, Spinrad is offering the US rights to his next novel, He Walked Among Us, for $1 to anyone who will "publish it properly".
Buy The Iron Dream at Amazon.co.uk

"A top 10 books of all time is a daunting and somehow quixotic list. Here are 10 favourites in different categories for different reasons."

1. Moby Dick by Herman Melville
I first read it at the age of 11, when I greatly enjoyed it, but found it a bit slow. Reading it again as an adult it had the same effect, but I had more patience for the slow discursive bits. Any novel that can be appreciated by such an age range is very impressive.

2. Alice in Wonderland and Alice Through the Looking Glass by Lewis Carroll
It's a toss-up between them for the best all time children's book. I love them - I'll even watch the Disney Looking Glass film any chance I get. Ordered it up in a hotel during an acid trip.

3. Tropic of Cancer by Henry Miller
My dad handed me this one when it was freshly unbanned in the US; I was about 16. "You've got to read this!" he said excitedly. Not for the dirty bits, though. "What prose! What use of language!" He was dead right.

4. The Three Stigmata of Palmer Eldritch by Philip K Dick
My favourite by both the best SF writer of all time and the best metaphysical novelist of all time.

5. The Stars My Destination by Alfred Bester
A stupendous novel that breaks entirely out of both the form and straight prose at the end and into something indescribable. His Golem 100 is even more radical, combining prose,poetry, collage, musical score, illustration, but it's not as successful on a narrative level.

6. Le Grand Dictionnaire de Cuisine by Alexandre Dumas
The ultimate cook book. 566 pages on how to cook anything, and I do mean ANYTHING, by the great French novelist and obsessive gourmet. Cook book as literature.

7. Looking for the Mahdi by N Lee Wood
It admittedly takes chutzpah to choose a novel written by my own wife, but not as much chutzpah as it took a non-Arabic non-Muslim American woman to write an SF novel with a Palestinian-American heroine in the political atmosphere of the late 1980s.

8. The Once and Future King by TH White
The best all time fantasy novel, for both literary form and inventiveness. I'm no big fan of Arthurian fantasy, but this one is written as if no one had done it before, and no one need bother since.

9. Thirty Six Views of Mt Fuji by Hokusai
My all time favourite art book.

10. A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court by Mark Twain
My favourite novel by one of my favourite writers. When I reread it recently, I was staggered by how contemporary it was a century after it was written. Here Twain not only invented the time-travel novel and the alternate history novel, but worked out all the paradoxes and techniques. And in a serious-minded comic novel whose humour remains sharp as a scalpel and still crazy after all these years.

fields.headline: Grand Prix of murder
fields.standfirst:
Breath, Boom
Royal Court, London
***
fields.trailText: They love girl gangs at the Royal Court. Rebecca Prichard's Yard Gal dealt with the leaders of a Hackney posse; now we have Kia Corthron's American equivalent, which takes us into the world of black Bronx teenagers. It's a much better play than the same writer's Splash Hatch on the E Going Down, which surfaced last year at the Donmar, and it's vigorously acted and directed, but Corthron still has a tendency to fall in love with her own dialogue.
fields.body:
They love girl gangs at the Royal Court. Rebecca Prichard's Yard Gal dealt with the leaders of a Hackney posse; now we have Kia Corthron's American equivalent, which takes us into the world of black Bronx teenagers. It's a much better play than the same writer's Splash Hatch on the E Going Down, which surfaced last year at the Donmar, and it's vigorously acted and directed, but Corthron still has a tendency to fall in love with her own dialogue.

The play's main plus is its extraordinary heroine: the cool, tough Prix, who at 16 is a female Capone effortlessly dominating her gang, and whose rise and fall we watch till she reaches 30. Prix is fixated by fireworks and power: she dispatches orders for killings, always received from an unseen Mr Big, with peremptory authority, yet she has a pyrotechnic obsession that leads her to sculpt fireworks out of multi-coloured pipecleaners.

Corthron remains intriguingly ambivalent about Prix. She shows her violence to stem, in part, from her domestic background: her common-law father beats her mother who, in turn, is driven to retaliatory killing. Prix is also the product of a culture in which male, middle-aged violence is either exculpated or seen as the social norm. But, just when you think Corthron is going soft on her heroine, she reminds you that she is an extremely cold fish: while in jail she rehearses a deeply sincere speech for the benefit of her captors - "my home was violent, my teachers suspicious, potential employers uninterested" - that she herself greets with derisive laughter.

Corthron pins down the mixed motives that drive teenage gangsters; she also shows how they are supplanted by even more ruthless successors. But, while Corthron brings Prix to vivid life, she too often lets her gift for language run away with her: a counselling session, for instance, spools on, adding sociological rather than dramatic information. She also provides a number of false endings so that the play constantly seems to be reaching a climax.

Indeed, my one criticism of Gemma Bodinetz's excellent production, which I saw at a last preview in the handsomely restored Jerwood Theatre Upstairs, is that it treats Prix's park-square Fourth of July firework display too much as a climactic spectacle. Otherwise everything reeks of authenticity and Diane Parish's Prix is eye-opening: I've rarely seen such gimlet-eyed authority in a young actress. Marsha Thomason as a suicide-prone cellmate, Rakie Ayola as a terrified gang member and Adjoa Andoh as Prix's mother lend striking support in a play that takes you behind the headlines to examine a disturbing social phenomenon with unblinking honesty.

Until March 11. Box office: 0171-565 5000.

fields.headline: A bit of a drag
fields.standfirst:
Sarah Lucas: The Fag Show
Sadie Coles HQ, London
**
fields.trailText: When the history of late 20th century British art is written there will have to be a chapter called Fags or The Sublime. "When I finish a cigarette I think about death," said Damien Hirst, coming right to the point, which is what you wish Sarah Lucas would do in her ciggy-themed solo show.
fields.body:
When the history of late 20th century British art is written there will have to be a chapter called Fags or The Sublime. "When I finish a cigarette I think about death," said Damien Hirst, coming right to the point, which is what you wish Sarah Lucas would do in her ciggy-themed solo show.

Lucas once made a cast of her mouth with a fag hanging out. Stark, ugly and erotic, the cigarette spoke of sex and death. Now, however, she has reportedly given up smoking and uses the white tubes solely for art, proposing some alternative uses for the suicide stick. Why not use them to decorate a garden gnome? Lucas has even done self-portraits in cigarettes, and in case you forget she is the author of this show, she includes two big photos of herself.

Lucas once displayed a cigarette-wrapped motorbike helmet on a burnt-out armchair, an image that made you think of kids killed on motorbikes and their granddads going up in smoke - a desolate pulp fiction about sex, death and class. But this exhibition seems to be more concerned with high-art questions of authorship, originality and the nature of beauty.

There's a disconcerting prettiness to it all, as she takes the banal form of the cigarette and repeats it ad nauseam. The installation is funny, but without the fag ash, the cancer smoke, where is the poetry? A cigarette is perfect when taken out of the pack but it ends up a stinking stump. That image of mortality is missing from The Fag Show. Without it, the meanings that can be found in this work feel contrived and sterile.

The exhibition contains so many quotations from pop artists that it reads as a history of pop art. Iconic works, from Andy Warhol's cow wallpaper to the erotic 50s Hoover in Richard Hamilton's collage "Just What is it That Makes Today's Homes...", are directly borrowed - so obviously that it must mean something. All those male pop artists appropriated objects associated with women's work. I suppose Lucas has now taken revenge by appropriating them in turn.

I don't know where the garden gnomes fit in. I don't know where the viewer fits in either. "Selfish in bed", says the t-shirt Lucas is wearing in her portraits. And a drag in the gallery.

Until March 18. 0171-434 2227.

webTitle: Hot spot homes sell in days

fields.headline: Hot spot homes sell in days
fields.trailText: Houses are selling in record time, and the average number of buyers competing for each property has reached a new high, according to figures published yesterday.
fields.body:
Houses are selling in record time, and the average number of buyers competing for each property has reached a new high, according to figures published yesterday.

The typical time between a home being put on the market and a sale being agreed is now nine weeks - the shortest time recorded since Home Report started in 1995. In June last year the UK average figure was 12 weeks, according to Bradford & Bingley estate agents, who published the report.

The findings come days after official data showed that the average house price in England and Wales has risen 15.2% in a year, and suggest that four interest rate rises over the past six months have done little to take the heat out of the property boom.

In some "hot spots", homes are selling in days. In Ipswich, Suffolk, and Horsham, West Sussex, homes are finding buy ers within a week. Other fast-selling areas include the fashionable Manchester suburb of Didsbury, Ivybridge in Devon, and the Kingston Park area of Newcastle-upon-Tyne (each two weeks), and the west end of Glasgow (three weeks).

The shortage of high quality properties for sale continues to be a problem, frustrating would-be buyers, the report says. Nationally, there are six buyers registered for every property that comes on to the market, but in the south-east the ratio has risen to 13 to one. Eight months ago the figure for the south-east was 11 to 1. In the north and west of England there are three buyers for each property for sale.

The survey found that the national average price paid by first-time buyers is £74,466, though the figures vary hugely by region. At £103,580, the typical price achieved in the south-east is almost exactly double the £52,330 paid by a first-time buyer in the north of England.

fields.headline: Twists and shouts
fields.standfirst:
Visiting Mr Green
West Yorkshire Playhouse, Leeds
**
fields.trailText: Jeff Baron's New York two-hander about a young American Express executive who, for the crime of reckless driving, is given community service visiting the elderly Jewish man he almost knocked over, is a variation on the old odd-couple routine. The two appear to have nothing in common, but turn out to be brothers under the skin linked by religion, sexuality and the ties of family.
fields.body:
Jeff Baron's New York two-hander about a young American Express executive who, for the crime of reckless driving, is given community service visiting the elderly Jewish man he almost knocked over, is a variation on the old odd-couple routine. The two appear to have nothing in common, but turn out to be brothers under the skin linked by religion, sexuality and the ties of family.

Warren Mitchell as the bigoted 86-year-old Mr Green, and Reece Dinsdale as Ross Gardiner, a man whose smooth exterior belies a more anxious psyche and a troubled family background, play the sharp New York wit with relish. But they are limited by characters who, despite the play's six-month time span, never develop beyond stereotypes.

Green ignores anything he doesn't like and that doesn't fit in with his orthodoxy. That includes his family. So as the men's prickly relationship begins to develop into an uneasy friendship and Gardiner spills the beans about his sexual orientation and his difficult relationship with his father, it looks as if Green will turn his back on the young man. But Baron's play is set in fairytale-land: the cantankerous Green is soon transformed into a charming substitute father and Gardiner into a wise substitute son, as the oppressions of Jews and gays are neatly tied together.

If you can believe all this, and the other predictable twists in the plot, then you probably also believe that pigs can fly. But Baron delivers it in that distinctively American mixture of earnestness and wisecrack, so you find yourself being unexpectedly charmed and moved by this hokum.

Less appealing is the construction of the play, which is as old-fashioned as its sentiments and consists of a number of brief scenes to mark passing weeks. It gives the short evening a stop/start jerkiness and never allows the actors to develop a rhythm or the action any momentum. With its small cast, star names and its ability to tug at the heart strings, I wouldn't be surprised if this production eventually popped up in the West End, where this kind of drama, geriatric in more ways than one, still gets an audience.

Until March 25. Box office: 0113-213 7700.
